dictionary.p: 4. Nearly; approximately; with close correspondence, in quality, manner, degree, etc.; as, about as cold; about as high; -- also of quantity, number, time. "There fell . . . about three thousand men." Exod. xxii. 28.

p.def: To a reserved position; half round; in the opposite direction; on the opposite tack; as, to face about; to turn one's self about.

dictionary.p: To bring about, to cause to take place; to accomplish. -- To come about, to occur; to take place. See under Come. -- To go about, To set about, to undertake; to arrange; to prepare. "Shall we set about some revels?" Shak. -- Round about, in every direction around.
A*bout"-sledge" (AMP?;), n. The largest hammer used by smiths. Weale.

A*bove" (AMP?;), prep. [OE. above, aboven, abuffe, AS. abufon; an (or on) on + be by + ufan upward; cf. Goth. uf under. AMPradic;199. See Over.] 1. In or to a higher place; higher than; on or over the upper surface; over; -- opposed to below or beneath.

p.blockquote:
Fowl that may fly above the earth.
Gen. i. 20.

dictionary.p: 2. Figuratively, higher than; superior to in any respect; surpassing; beyond; higher in measure or degree than; as, things above comprehension; above mean actions; conduct above reproach. "Thy worth . . . is actions above my gifts." Marlowe.

p.blockquote:
I saw in the way a light from heaven above the brightness of the sun.
Acts xxxvi. 13.

p.def: Surpassing in number or quantity; more than; as, above a hundred. (Passing into the adverbial sense. See Above, adv., 4.)

dictionary.p: above all, before every other consideration; chiefly; in preference to other things.
Over and above, prep. or adv., besides; in addition to.
A*bove" (AMP?;), adv. 1. In a higher place; overhead; into or from heaven; as, the clouds above.

p.def: Higher in rank or power; as, he appealed to the court above.
More than; as, above five hundred were present.

dictionary.p: Above is often used elliptically as an adjective by omitting the word mentioned, quoted, or the like; as, the above observations, the above reference, the above articles. -- Above is also used substantively. "The waters that come down from above." Josh. iii. 13.

It is also used as the first part of a compound in the sense of before, previously; as, above-cited, above- described, above-mentioned, above-named, abovesaid, abovespecified, above-written, above-given.
A*bove"board` (AMP?;), adv. Above the board or table. Hence: in open sight; without trick, concealment, or deception. "Fair and aboveboard." Burke.
AMPfist; This expression is said by Johnson to have been borrowed from gamesters, who, when they change their cards, put their hands under the table.
A*bove"-cit`ed (AMP?;), a. Cited before, in the preceding part of a book or writing.
A*bove"deck` (AMP?;), a. On deck; and hence, like aboveboard, without artifice. Smart.
A*bove"-men`tioned (AMP?;), A*bove"-named`(AMP?;), a. Mentioned or named before; aforesaid.
A*bove"said` (AMP?;), a. Mentioned or recited before.
A*box" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. (Naut.) Braced aback.

Ab`ra*ca*dab"ra (AMP?;), n. [L. Of unknown origin.] A mystical word or collocation of letters written as in the figure. Worn on an amulet it was supposed to ward off fever. At present the word is used chiefly in jest to denote something without meaning; jargon.
Ab*ra"dant (AMP?;), n. A material used for grinding, as emery, sand, powdered glass, etc.

Ab*rade" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Abraded; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Abrading.] [L. abradere, abrasum, to scrape off; ab + radere to scrape. See Rase, Raze.] To rub or wear off; to waste or wear away by friction; as, to abrade rocks. Lyell.
A*brade" (AMP?;), v. t. Same as Abraid. [Obs.]
A`bra*ham"ic (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to Abraham, the patriarch; as, the Abrachamic covenant.
A`bra*ham*it"ic, *ic*al(AMP?;), a. Relating to the patriarch Abraham.

A"bra*ham-man` (AMP?;) or A"bram-man`(AMP?;), n. [Possibly in allusion to the parable of the beggar Lazarus in Luke xvi. Murray (New Eng. Dict. ).] One of a set of vagabonds who formerly roamed through England, feigning lunacy for the sake of obtaining alms. Nares.
To sham Abraham, to feign sickness. Goldsmith.

A*braid" (AMP?;), v. t. AMP i. [OE. abraiden, to awake, draw (a sword), AS. AMPamacr;bredgan to shake, draw; pref. AMPamacr;- (cf. Goth. us-, Ger. er-, orig. meaning out) + bregdan to shake, throw. See Braid.] To awake; to arouse; to stir or start up; also, to shout out. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A*bran"chi*al (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Abranchiate.

||A*bran`chi*a"ta (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., from Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?;, pl., the gills of fishes.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A group of annelids, so called because the species composing it have no special organs of respiration.
A*bran"chi*ate (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Without gills.
Ab*rase" (AMP?;), a. [L. abrasus, p. p. of abradere. See Abrade.] Rubbed smooth. [Obs.] "An abrase table." B. Jonson.
Ab*ra"sion (AMP?;), n. [L. abrasio, fr. abradere. See Abrade.] 1. The act of abrading, wearing, or rubbing off; the wearing away by friction; as, the abrasion of coins.

p.def: The substance rubbed off.
A superficial excoriation, with loss of substance under the form of small shreds.

dictionary.p: Ab*ra"sive (AMP?;), a. Producing abrasion. Ure.
A*braum" or A*braum" salts (AMP?;), n. [Ger., fr. abrAMPauml;umen to remove.] A red ocher used to darken mahogany and for making chloride of potassium.

||A*brax"as (AMP?;), n. [A name adopted by the Egyptian Gnostic Basilides, containing the Greek letters AMPalpha;, AMPbeta;, AMPrho;, AMPalpha;, AMPxi;, AMPalpha;, AMPsigma;, which, as numerals, amounted to 365. It was used to signify the supreme deity as ruler of the 365 heavens of his system.] A mystical word used as a charm and engraved on gems among the ancients; also, a gem stone thus engraved.
A*bray" (AMP?;), v. [A false form from the preterit abraid, abrayde.] See Abraid. [Obs.] Spenser.
A*breast" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + breast.] 1. Side by side, with breasts in a line; as, "Two men could hardly walk abreast." Macaulay.
4. At the same time; simultaneously. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Abreast therewith began a convocation.
Fuller.

dictionary.p: A*breg"ge (AMP?;), v. t. See Abridge. [Obs.]
Ab`re*nounce" (AMP?;), v. t. [L. abrenuntiare; ab + renuntiare. See Renounce.] To renounce. [Obs.] "They abrenounce and cast them off." Latimer.
Ab`re*nun`ci*a"tion (AMP?;), n. [LL. abrenuntiatio. See Abrenounce.] Absolute renunciation or repudiation. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
An abrenunciation of that truth which he so long had professed, and still believed.
Fuller.

dictionary.p: Ab*rep"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. abreptus, p. p. of abripere to snatch away; ab + rapere to snatch.] A snatching away. [Obs.]
||A`breu`voir" (AMP?;), n. [F., a watering place.] (Masonry) The joint or interstice between stones, to be filled with mortar. Gwilt.
A"bri*cock (AMP?;), n. See Apricot. [Obs.]

A*bridge" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Abridged (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Abridging.] [OE. abregen, OF. abregier, F. abrAMPeacute;ger, fr. L. abbreviare; ad + brevis short. See Brief and cf. Abbreviate.] 1. To make shorter; to shorten in duration; to lessen; to diminish; to curtail; as, to abridge labor; to abridge power or rights. "The bridegroom . . . abridged his visit." Smollett.

p.blockquote:
She retired herself to Sebaste, and abridged her train from state to necessity.
Fuller.

p.def: To shorten or contract by using fewer words, yet retaining the sense; to epitomize; to condense; as, to abridge a history or dictionary.
To deprive; to cut off; -- followed by of, and formerly by from; as, to abridge one of his rights.

dictionary.p: A*bridg"er (AMP?;), n. One who abridges.

A*bridg"ment (-brAMPibreve;j"ment), n. [OE. abregement. See Abridge.] 1. The act of abridging, or the state of being abridged; diminution; lessening; reduction or deprivation; as, an abridgment of pleasures or of expenses.

p.def: An epitome or compend, as of a book; a shortened or abridged form; an abbreviation.

p.blockquote:
Ancient coins as abridgments of history.
Addison.

dictionary.p: 3. That which abridges or cuts short; hence, an entertainment that makes the time pass quickly. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
What abridgment have you for this evening? What mask? What music?
Shak.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Abridgment, Compendium, Epitome, Abstract, Synopsis. An abridgment is made by omitting the less important parts of some larger work; as, an abridgment of a dictionary. A compendium is a brief exhibition of a subject, or science, for common use; as, a compendium of American literature. An epitome corresponds to a compendium, and gives briefly the most material points of a subject; as, an epitome of history. An abstract is a brief statement of a thing in its main points. A synopsis is a bird's-eye view of a subject, or work, in its several parts.
A*broach" (AMP?;), v. t. [OE. abrochen, OF. abrochier. See Broach.] To set abroach; to let out, as liquor; to broach; to tap. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A*broach", adv. [Pref. a- + broach.] 1. Broached; in a condition for letting out or yielding liquor, as a cask which is tapped.

p.blockquote:
Hogsheads of ale were set abroach.
Sir W. Scott.

dictionary.p: A*broad" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + broad.] 1. At large; widely; broadly; over a wide space; as, a tree spreads its branches abroad.

p.blockquote:
The fox roams far abroad.
Prior.

p.def: Without a certain confine; outside the house; away from one's abode; as, to walk abroad.

p.blockquote:
I went to St. James', where another was preaching in the court abroad.
Evelyn.

dictionary.p: 3. Beyond the bounds of a country; in foreign countries; as, we have broils at home and enemies abroad. "Another prince . . . was living abroad." Macaulay.

p.def: Before the public at large; throughout society or the world; here and there; widely.

p.blockquote:
He went out, and began to publish it much, and to blaze abroad the matter.
Mark i. 45.

dictionary.p: To be abroad. (a) To be wide of the mark; to be at fault; as, you are all abroad in your guess. (b) To be at a loss or nonplused.
Ab"ro*ga*ble (AMP?;), a. Capable of being abrogated.
Ab"ro*gate (AMP?;), a. [L. abrogatus, p. p.] Abrogated; abolished. [Obs.] Latimer.

Ab"ro*gate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Abrogated; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Abrogating.] [L. abrogatus, p. p. of abrogare; ab + rogare to ask, require, propose. See Rogation.] 1. To annul by an authoritative act; to abolish by the authority of the maker or his successor; to repeal; -- applied to the repeal of laws, decrees, ordinances, the abolition of customs, etc.

p.blockquote:
Let us see whether the New Testament abrogates what we so frequently see in the Old.
South.

Whose laws, like those of the Medes and Persian, they can not alter or abrogate.
Burke.

p.def: To put an end to; to do away with.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To abolish; annul; do away; set aside; revoke; repeal; cancel; annihilate. See Abolish.
Ab`ro*ga"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. abrogatio, fr. abrogare: cf. F. abrogation.] The act of abrogating; repeal by authority. Hume.
Ab"ro*ga*tive (AMP?;), a. Tending or designed to abrogate; as, an abrogative law.
Ab"ro*ga`tor (AMP?;), n. One who repeals by authority.
A*brood" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + brood.] In the act of brooding. [Obs.] Abp. Sancroft.
A*brook" (AMP?;), v. t. [Pref. a- + brook, v.] To brook; to endure. [Obs.] Shak.

Ab*rupt" (AMP?;), a. [L. abruptus, p. p. of abrumpere to break off; ab + rumpere to break. See Rupture.] 1. Broken off; very steep, or craggy, as rocks, precipices, banks; precipitous; steep; as, abrupt places. "Tumbling through ricks abrupt," Thomson.
2. Without notice to prepare the mind for the event; sudden; hasty; unceremonious. "The cause of your abrupt departure." Shak.

p.def: Having sudden transitions from one subject to another; unconnected.

p.blockquote:
The abrupt style, which hath many breaches.
B. Jonson.

p.def: Suddenly terminating, as if cut off.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Sudden; unexpected; hasty; rough; curt; unceremonious; rugged; blunt; disconnected; broken.

Ab*rupt" (AMP?;), n. [L. abruptum.] An abrupt place. [Poetic] "Over the vast abrupt."
Milton.
Ab*rupt", v. t. To tear off or asunder. [Obs.] "Till death abrupts them." Sir T. Browne.

p.def: Precipitously.

dictionary.p: Abruptly pinnate (Bot.), pinnate without an odd leaflet, or other appendage, at the end. Gray.

p.def: Suddenness; unceremonious haste or vehemence; as, abruptness of style or manner.

dictionary.p: Ab"scess (AMP?;), n.; pl. Abscesses (AMP?;). [L. abscessus a going away, gathering of humors, abscess, fr. abscessus, p. p. of absedere to go away; ab, abs + cedere to go off, retire. See Cede.] (Med.) A collection of pus or purulent matter in any tissue or organ of the body, the result of a morbid process.

Cold abscess, an abscess of slow formation, unattended with the pain and heat characteristic of ordinary abscesses, and lasting for years without exhibiting any tendency towards healing; a chronic abscess.
Ab*scind" (AMP?;), v. t. [L. absindere; ab + scindere to rend, cut. See Schism.] To cut off. [R.] "Two syllables . . . abscinded from the rest." Johnson.
Ab*sci"sion (AMP?;), n. [L. abscisio.] See Abscission.
Ab"sciss (AMP?;), n.; pl. Abscisses (AMP?;). See Abscissa.

Ab*scis"sa (AMP?;), n.; E. pl. Abscissas, L. pl. AbscissAMPaelig;. [L., fem. of abscissus, p. p. of absindere to cut of. See Abscind.] (Geom.) One of the elements of reference by which a point, as of a curve, is referred to a system of fixed rectilineal coAMPouml;rdinate axes. When referred to two intersecting axes, one of them called the axis of abscissas, or of X, and the other the axis of ordinates, or of Y, the abscissa of the point is the distance cut off from the axis of X by a line drawn through it and parallel to the axis of Y. When a point in space is referred to three axes having a common intersection, the abscissa may be the distance measured parallel to either of them, from the point to the plane of the other two axes. Abscissas and ordinates taken together are called coAMPouml;rdinates. -- OX or PY is the abscissa of the point P of the curve, OY or PX its ordinate, the intersecting lines OX and OY being the axes of abscissas and ordinates respectively, and the point O their origin.
Ab*scis"sion (AMP?;), n. [L. abscissio. See Abscind.] 1. The act or process of cutting off. "Not to be cured without the abscission of a member." Jer. Taylor.

p.def: The state of being cut off.
A figure of speech employed when a speaker having begun to say a thing stops abruptly: thus, "He is a man of so much honor and candor, and of such generosity -- but I need say no more."

dictionary.p: Ab*scond" (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Absconded; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Absconding.] [L. abscondere to hide; ab, abs + condere to lay up; con + dAMPabreve;re (only in comp.) to put. Cf. Do.] 1. To hide, withdraw, or be concealed.

p.blockquote:
The marmot absconds all winter.
Ray.

p.def: To depart clandestinely; to steal off and secrete one's self; -- used especially of persons who withdraw to avoid a legal process; as, an absconding debtor.

p.blockquote:
That very homesickness which, in regular armies, drives so many recruits to abscond.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: Ab*scond", v. t. To hide; to conceal. [Obs.] Bentley.
Ab*scond"ence (AMP?;), n. Fugitive concealment; secret retirement; hiding. [R.] Phillips.
Ab*scond"er (AMP?;), n. One who absconds.
Ab"sence (AMP?;), n. [F., fr. L. absentia. See Absent.] 1. A state of being absent or withdrawn from a place or from companionship; -- opposed to presence.

p.blockquote:
Not as in my presence only, but now much more in my absence.
Phil. ii. 12.

dictionary.p: 2. Want; destitution; withdrawal. "In the absence of conventional law." Kent.
3. Inattention to things present; abstraction (of mind); as, absence of mind. "Reflecting on the little absences and distractions of mankind." Addison.

p.blockquote:
To conquer that abstraction which is called absence.
Landor.

dictionary.p: Ab"sent (AMP?;), a. [F., fr. absens, absentis, p. pr. of abesse to be away from; ab + esse to be. Cf. Sooth.] 1. Being away from a place; withdrawn from a place; not present. "Expecting absent friends." Shak.

p.def: Not existing; lacking; as, the part was rudimental or absent.
Inattentive to what is passing; absent-minded; preoccupied; as, an absent air.

p.blockquote:
What is commonly called an absent man is commonly either a very weak or a very affected man.
Chesterfield.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Absent, Abstracted. These words both imply a want of attention to surrounding objects. We speak of a man as absent when his thoughts wander unconsciously from present scenes or topics of discourse; we speak of him as abstracted when his mind (usually for a brief period) is drawn off from present things by some weighty matter for reflection. Absence of mind is usually the result of loose habits of thought; abstraction commonly arises either from engrossing interests and cares, or from unfortunate habits of association.

Ab*sent" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Absented; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Absenting.] [Cf. F. absenter.] 1. To take or withdraw (one's self) to such a distance as to prevent intercourse; -- used with the reflexive pronoun.

p.blockquote:
If after due summons any member absents himself, he is to be fined.
Addison.

dictionary.p: 2. To withhold from being present. [Obs.] "Go; for thy stay, not free, absents thee more." Milton.
Ab`sen*ta"ne*ous (AMP?;), a. [LL. absentaneus. See absent] Pertaining to absence. [Obs.]
Ab`sen*ta"tion (AMP?;), n. The act of absenting one's self. Sir W. Hamilton.

Ab`sen*tee" (AMP?;), n. One who absents himself from his country, office, post, or duty; especially, a landholder who lives in another country or district than that where his estate is situated; as, an Irish absentee. Macaulay.
Ab`sen*tee"ism (AMP?;), n. The state or practice of an absentee; esp. the practice of absenting one's self from the country or district where one's estate is situated.
Ab*sent"er (AMP?;), n. One who absents one's self.
Ab"sent*ly (AMP?;), adv. In an absent or abstracted manner.
Ab*sent"ment (AMPabreve;b*sAMPebreve;nt"ment), n. The state of being absent; withdrawal. [R.] Barrow.
Ab`sent-mind"ed(AMP?;), a. Absent in mind; abstracted; preoccupied. -- Ab`sent-mind"ed*ness, n. -- Ab`sent-mind"ed*ly, adv.
Ab"sent*ness (AMP?;), n. The quality of being absent-minded. H. Miller.
Ab"sey-book`(AMP?;), n. An A-B-C book; a primer. [Obs.] Shak.
{ Ab"sinth`, Ab"sinthe` } (AMP?;), n. [F. absinthe. See Absinthium.] 1. The plant absinthium or common wormwood.

p.def: A strong spirituous liqueur made from wormwood and brandy or alcohol.

dictionary.p: Ab"sin"thate (AMP?;), n. (Chem.) A combination of absinthic acid with a base or positive radical.
Ab*sin"thi*al (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to wormwood; absinthian.
Ab*sin"thi*an (AMP?;), n. Of the nature of wormwood. "Absinthian bitterness." T. Randolph.
Ab"sin"thi*ate (AMP?;), v. t. [From L. absinthium: cf. L. absinthiatus, a.] To impregnate with wormwood.
Ab*sin"thi*a`ted (AMP?;), a. Impregnated with wormwood; as, absinthiated wine.
Ab*sin"thic (AMP?;), a. (Chem.) Relating to the common wormwood or to an acid obtained from it.
Ab*sin"thin (AMP?;), n. (Chem.) The bitter principle of wormwood (Artemisia absinthium). Watts.
Ab"sin*thism (AMP?;), n. The condition of being poisoned by the excessive use of absinth.
Ab*sin"thi*um (AMP?;), n. [L., from Gr. AMP?;.] (Bot.) The common wormwood (Artemisia absinthium), an intensely bitter plant, used as a tonic and for making the oil of wormwood.
Ab"sis (AMP?;), n. See Apsis.
Ab*sist" (AMP?;), v. i. [L. absistere, p. pr. absistens; ab + sistere to stand, causal of stare.] To stand apart from; top leave off; to desist. [Obs.] Raleigh.
Ab*sist"ence (AMP?;), n. A standing aloof. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
So absolute she seems,
And in herself complete.
Milton.

p.def: Viewed apart from modifying influences or without comparison with other objects; actual; real; -- opposed to relative and comparative; as, absolute motion; absolute time or space.

dictionary.p: Absolute rights and duties are such as pertain to man in a state of nature as contradistinguished from relative rights and duties, or such as pertain to him in his social relations.

p.def: Loosed from, or unconnected by, dependence on any other being; self-existent; self-sufficing.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; In this sense God is called the Absolute by the Theist. The term is also applied by the Pantheist to the universe, or the total of all existence, as only capable of relations in its parts to each other and to the whole, and as dependent for its existence and its phenomena on its mutually depending forces and their laws.

p.def: Capable of being thought or conceived by itself alone; unconditioned; non-relative.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; It is in dispute among philosopher whether the term, in this sense, is not applied to a mere logical fiction or abstraction, or whether the absolute, as thus defined, can be known, as a reality, by the human intellect.

p.blockquote:
To Cusa we can indeed articulately trace, word and thing, the recent philosophy of the absolute.
Sir W. Hamilton.

dictionary.p: 6. Positive; clear; certain; not doubtful. [R.]

p.blockquote:
I am absolute 't was very Cloten.
Shak.

dictionary.p: 7. Authoritative; peremptory. [R.]

p.blockquote:
The peddler stopped, and tapped her on the head,
With absolute forefinger, brown and ringed.
Mrs. Browning.

p.def: Pure; unmixed; as, absolute alcohol.
Not immediately dependent on the other parts of the sentence in government; as, the case absolute. See Ablative absolute, under Ablative.

dictionary.p: Absolute curvature (Geom.), that curvature of a curve of double curvature, which is measured in the osculating plane of the curve. -- Absolute equation (Astron.), the sum of the optic and eccentric equations. -- Absolute space (Physics), space considered without relation to material limits or objects. -- Absolute terms. (Alg.), such as are known, or which do not contain the unknown quantity. Davies AMP Peck. -- Absolute temperature (Physics), the temperature as measured on a scale determined by certain general thermo-dynamic principles, and reckoned from the absolute zero. -- Absolute zero (Physics), the be ginning, or zero point, in the scale of absolute temperature. It is equivalent to -273AMPdeg; centigrade or - 459.4AMPdeg; Fahrenheit.
Syn. -- Positive; peremptory; certain; unconditional; unlimited; unrestricted; unqualified; arbitrary; despotic; autocratic.
Ab"so*lute (AMP?;), n. (Geom.) In a plane, the two imaginary circular points at infinity; in space of three dimensions, the imaginary circle at infinity.
Ab"so*lute*ly, adv. In an absolute, independent, or unconditional manner; wholly; positively.
Ab"so*lute*ness, n. The quality of being absolute; independence of everything extraneous; unlimitedness; absolute power; independent reality; positiveness.

Ab`so*lu"tion (AMP?;), n. [F. absolution, L. absolutio, fr. absolvere to absolve. See Absolve.] 1. An absolving, or setting free from guilt, sin, or penalty; forgiveness of an offense. "Government . . . granting absolution to the nation." Froude.
2. (Civil Law) An acquittal, or sentence of a judge declaring and accused person innocent. [Obs.]

p.def: The exercise of priestly jurisdiction in the sacrament of penance, by which Catholics believe the sins of the truly penitent are forgiven.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; In the English and other Protestant churches, this act regarded as simply declaratory, not as imparting forgiveness.

p.def: An absolving from ecclesiastical penalties, -- for example, excommunication.
The form of words by which a penitent is absolved.

dictionary.p: 6. Delivery, in speech. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Absolution day (R. C. Ch.), Tuesday before Easter.

p.blockquote:
The element of absolutism and prelacy was controlling.
Palfrey.

p.def: Doctrine of absolute decrees.

dictionary.p: Ab"so*lu`tist (AMP?;), n. 1. One who is in favor of an absolute or autocratic government.

p.def: One who believes that it is possible to realize a cognition or concept of the absolute.

dictionary.p: Ab"so*lu`tist, a. Of or pertaining to absolutism; arbitrary; despotic; as, absolutist principles.
Ab`so*lu*tis"tic (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to absolutism; absolutist.
Ab*sol"u*to*ry (AMP?;), a. [L. absolutorius, fr. absolvere to absolve.] Serving to absolve; absolving. "An absolutory sentence." Ayliffe.
Ab*solv"a*ble (AMP?;), a. That may be absolved.
Ab*solv"a*to*ry (AMP?;), a. Conferring absolution; absolutory.

Ab*solve" (#; 277), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Absolved (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Absolving.] [L. absolvere to set free, to absolve; ab + solvere to loose. See Assoil, Solve.] 1. To set free, or release, as from some obligation, debt, or responsibility, or from the consequences of guilt or such ties as it would be sin or guilt to violate; to pronounce free; as, to absolve a subject from his allegiance; to absolve an offender, which amounts to an acquittal and remission of his punishment.

p.blockquote:
Halifax was absolved by a majority of fourteen.
Macaulay.

p.def: To free from a penalty; to pardon; to remit (a sin); -- said of the sin or guilt.

p.blockquote:
In his name I absolve your perjury.
Gibbon.

dictionary.p: 3. To finish; to accomplish. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The work begun, how soon absolved.
Milton.

dictionary.p: 4. To resolve or explain. [Obs.] "We shall not absolve the doubt." Sir T. Browne.

Syn. -- To Absolve, Exonerate, Acquit. We speak of a man as absolved from something that binds his conscience, or involves the charge of wrongdoing; as, to absolve from allegiance or from the obligation of an oath, or a promise. We speak of a person as exonerated, when he is released from some burden which had rested upon him; as, to exonerate from suspicion, to exonerate from blame or odium. It implies a purely moral acquittal. We speak of a person as acquitted, when a decision has been made in his favor with reference to a specific charge, either by a jury or by disinterested persons; as, he was acquitted of all participation in the crime.
Ab*solv"ent (AMP?;), a. [L. absolvens, p. pr. of absolvere.] Absolving. [R.] Carlyle.
Ab*solv"ent, n. An absolver. [R.] Hobbes.
Ab*solv"er (AMP?;), n. One who absolves. Macaulay.
Ab"so*nant (AMP?;), a. [L. ab + sonans, p. pr. of sonare to sound.] Discordant; contrary; -- opposed to consonant. "Absonant to nature." Quarles.

Ab*sorb" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Absorbed (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Absorbing.] [L. absorbere; ab + sorbere to suck in, akin to Gr. AMP?;: cf. F. absorber.] 1. To swallow up; to engulf; to overwhelm; to cause to disappear as if by swallowing up; to use up; to include. "Dark oblivion soon absorbs them all." Cowper.

p.blockquote:
The large cities absorb the wealth and fashion.
W. Irving.

p.def: To suck up; to drink in; to imbibe; as a sponge or as the lacteals of the body.
To engross or engage wholly; to occupy fully; as, absorbed in study or the pursuit of wealth.
To take up by cohesive, chemical, or any molecular action, as when charcoal absorbs gases. So heat, light, and electricity are absorbed or taken up in the substances into which they pass.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To Absorb, Engross, Swallow up, Engulf. These words agree in one general idea, that of completely taking up. They are chiefly used in a figurative sense and may be distinguished by a reference to their etymology. We speak of a person as absorbed (lit., drawn in, swallowed up) in study or some other employment of the highest interest. We speak of a person as ebgrossed (lit., seized upon in the gross, or wholly) by something which occupies his whole time and thoughts, as the acquisition of wealth, or the attainment of honor. We speak of a person (under a stronger image) as swallowed up and lost in that which completely occupies his thoughts and feelings, as in grief at the death of a friend, or in the multiplied cares of life. We speak of a person as engulfed in that which (like a gulf) takes in all his hopes and interests; as, engulfed in misery, ruin, etc.

p.blockquote:
That grave question which had begun to absorb the Christian mind -- the marriage of the clergy.
Milman.

Too long hath love engrossed Britannia's stage,
And sunk to softness all our tragic rage.
Tickell.

Should not the sad occasion swallow up
My other cares?
Addison.

And in destruction's river
Engulf and swallow those.
Sir P. Sidney.

dictionary.p: Ab*sorb`a*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. The state or quality of being absorbable. Graham (Chemistry).
Ab*sorb"a*ble, a. [Cf. F. absorbable.] Capable of being absorbed or swallowed up. Kerr.
Ab*sorb"ed*ly, adv. In a manner as if wholly engrossed or engaged.
Ab*sorb"en*cy (AMP?;), n. Absorptiveness.
Absorbent ground (Paint.), a ground prepared for a picture, chiefly with distemper, or water colors, by which the oil is absorbed, and a brilliancy is imparted to the colors.
Ab*sorb"ent, n. 1. Anything which absorbs.

p.blockquote:
The ocean, itself a bad absorbent of heat.
Darwin.

p.def: Any substance which absorbs and neutralizes acid fluid in the stomach and bowels, as magnesia, chalk, etc.; also a substance e. g., iodine) which acts on the absorbent vessels so as to reduce enlarged and indurated parts.
The vessels by which the processes of absorption are carried on, as the lymphatics in animals, the extremities of the roots in plants.

dictionary.p: Ab*sorb"er (AMP?;), n. One who, or that which, absorbs.
Ab`sor*bi"tion (AMP?;), n. Absorption. [Obs.]
Ab*sorpt` (AMP?;), a. [L. absorptus, p. p.] Absorbed. [Arcahic.] "Absorpt in care." Pope.

Ab*sorp"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. absorptio, fr. absorbere. See Absorb.] 1. The act or process of absorbing or sucking in anything, or of being absorbed and made to disappear; as, the absorption of bodies in a whirlpool, the absorption of a smaller tribe into a larger.

p.def: An imbibing or reception by molecular or chemical action; as, the absorption of light, heat, electricity, etc.
In living organisms, the process by which the materials of growth and nutrition are absorbed and conveyed to the tissues and organs.
Entire engrossment or occupation of the mind; as, absorption in some employment.

dictionary.p: Ab*sorp"tive (AMP?;), a. Having power, capacity, or tendency to absorb or imbibe. E. Darwin.
Ab*sorp"tive*ness, n. The quality of being absorptive; absorptive power.
Ab`sorp*tiv"i*ty (AMP?;), n. Absorptiveness.
Ab*squat"u*late (AMP?;), v. i. To take one's self off; to decamp. [A jocular word. U. S.]
||Abs"que hoc (AMP?;). [L., without this.] (Law) The technical words of denial used in traversing what has been alleged, and is repeated.

Ab*stain" (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Abstained (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Abstaining.] [OE. absteynen, abstenen, OF. astenir, abstenir, F. abstenir, fr. L. abstinere, abstentum, v. t. AMP v. i., to keep from; ab, abs + tenere to hold. See Tenable.] To hold one's self aloof; to forbear or refrain voluntarily, and especially from an indulgence of the passions or appetites; -- with from.

p.blockquote:
Not a few abstained from voting.
Macaulay.

Who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?
Shak.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To refrain; forbear; withhold; deny one's self; give up; relinquish.
Ab*stain", v. t. To hinder; to withhold.

p.blockquote:
Whether he abstain men from marrying.
Milton.

dictionary.p: Ab*stain"er (AMP?;), n. One who abstains; esp., one who abstains from the use of intoxicating liquors.
Ab*ste"mi*ous (AMP?;), a. [L. abstemius; ab, abs + root of temetum intoxicating drink.] 1. Abstaining from wine. [Orig. Latin sense.]

p.blockquote:
Under his special eye
Abstemious I grew up and thrived amain.
Milton.

p.def: Sparing in diet; refraining from a free use of food and strong drinks; temperate; abstinent; sparing in the indulgence of the appetite or passions.

p.blockquote:
Instances of longevity are chiefly among the abstemious.
Arbuthnot.

p.def: Sparingly used; used with temperance or moderation; as, an abstemious diet.

dictionary.p: 4. Marked by, or spent in, abstinence; as, an abstemious life. "One abstemious day." Pope.
5. Promotive of abstemiousness. [R.]

p.blockquote:
Such is the virtue of the abstemious well.
Dryden.

dictionary.p: Ab*ste"mi*ous*ness, n. The quality of being abstemious, temperate, or sparing in the use of food and strong drinks. It expresses a greater degree of abstinence than temperance.
Ab*sten"tion (AMP?;), a. [F. See Abstain.] The act of abstaining; a holding aloof. Jer. Taylor.
Ab*sten"tious (AMP?;), a. Characterized by abstinence; self-restraining. Farrar.
Ab*sterge (AMP?;), v. t. [L. abstergere, abstersum; ab, abs + tergere to wipe. Cf. F absterger.] To make clean by wiping; to wipe away; to cleanse; hence, to purge. [R.] Quincy.
Ab*ster"gent (AMP?;), a. [L. abstergens, p. pr. of abstergere.] Serving to cleanse, detergent.
Ab*ster"gent, n. A substance used in cleansing; a detergent; as, soap is an abstergent.
Ab*sterse" (AMP?;), v. t. To absterge; to cleanse; to purge away. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Ab*ster"sion (AMP?;), n. [F. abstersion. See Absterge.] Act of wiping clean; a cleansing; a purging.

p.blockquote:
The task of ablution and abstersion being performed.
Sir W. Scott.

dictionary.p: Ab*ster"sive (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. abstersif. See Absterge.] Cleansing; purging. Bacon.
Ab*ster"sive, n. Something cleansing.

p.blockquote:
The strong abstersive of some heroic magistrate.
Milton.

dictionary.p: Ab*ster"sive*ness, n. The quality of being abstersive. Fuller.

Ab"sti*nence (AMP?;), n. [F. abstinence, L. abstinentia, fr. abstinere. See Abstain.] 1. The act or practice of abstaining; voluntary forbearance of any action, especially the refraining from an indulgence of appetite, or from customary gratifications of animal or sensual propensities. Specifically, the practice of abstaining from intoxicating beverages, -- called also total abstinence.

p.blockquote:
The abstinence from a present pleasure that offers itself is a pain, nay, oftentimes, a very great one.
Locke.

p.def: The practice of self-denial by depriving one's self of certain kinds of food or drink, especially of meat.

p.blockquote:
Penance, fasts, and abstinence,
To punish bodies for the soul's offense.
Dryden.

dictionary.p: Ab"sti*nen*cy (AMP?;), n. Abstinence. [R.]

Ab"sti*nent (AMP?;), a. [F. abstinent, L. abstinens, p. pr. of abstinere. See Abstain.] Refraining from indulgence, especially from the indulgence of appetite; abstemious; continent; temperate. Beau. AMP Fl.
Ab"sti*nent, n. 1. One who abstains.

p.def: One of a sect who appeared in France and Spain in the 3d century.

dictionary.p: Ab"sti*nent*ly, adv. With abstinence.
Ab*stort"ed (AMP?;), a. [As if fr. abstort, fr. L. ab, abs + tortus, p. p. of torquere to twist.] Wrested away. [Obs.] Bailey.
Ab"stract` (#; 277), a. [L. abstractus, p. p. of abstrahere to draw from, separate; ab, abs + trahere to draw. See Trace.] 1. Withdraw; separate. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The more abstract . . . we are from the body.
Norris.

p.def: Considered apart from any application to a particular object; separated from matter; existing in the mind only; as, abstract truth, abstract numbers. Hence: ideal; abstruse; difficult.
Expressing a particular property of an object viewed apart from the other properties which constitute it; -- opposed to concrete; as, honesty is an abstract word.
Resulting from the mental faculty of abstraction; general as opposed to particular; as, "reptile" is an abstract or general name.

p.blockquote:
A concrete name is a name which stands for a thing; an abstract name which stands for an attribute of a thing. A practice has grown up in more modern times, which, if not introduced by Locke, has gained currency from his example, of applying the expression "abstract name" to all names which are the result of abstraction and generalization, and consequently to all general names, instead of confining it to the names of attributes.
J. S. Mill.

dictionary.p: 4. Abstracted; absent in mind. "Abstract, as in a trance." Milton.

An abstract idea (Metaph.), an idea separated from a complex object, or from other ideas which naturally accompany it; as the solidity of marble when contemplated apart from its color or figure. -- Abstract terms, those which express abstract ideas, as beauty, whiteness, roundness, without regarding any object in which they exist; or abstract terms are the names of orders, genera or species of things, in which there is a combination of similar qualities. -- Abstract numbers (Math.), numbers used without application to things, as 6, 8, 10; but when applied to any thing, as 6 feet, 10 men, they become concrete. -- Abstract or Pure mathematics. See Mathematics.
Ab*stract" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Abstracted; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Abstracting.] [See Abstract, a.]

p.def: To withdraw; to separate; to take away.

p.blockquote:
He was incapable of forming any opinion or resolution abstracted from his own prejudices.
Sir W. Scott.

p.def: To draw off in respect to interest or attention; as, his was wholly abstracted by other objects.

p.blockquote:
The young stranger had been abstracted and silent.
Blackw. Mag.

p.def: To separate, as ideas, by the operation of the mind; to consider by itself; to contemplate separately, as a quality or attribute.
To epitomize; to abridge.
To take secretly or dishonestly; to purloin; as, to abstract goods from a parcel, or money from a till.

p.blockquote:
Von Rosen had quietly abstracted the bearing-reins from the harness.
W. Black.

p.def: To separate, as the more volatile or soluble parts of a substance, by distillation or other chemical processes. In this sense extract is now more generally used.

dictionary.p: Ab*stract", v. t. To perform the process of abstraction. [R.]

p.blockquote:
I own myself able to abstract in one sense.
Berkeley.

dictionary.p: Ab"stract` (AMP?;), n. [See Abstract, a.] 1. That which comprises or concentrates in itself the essential qualities of a larger thing or of several things. Specifically: A summary or an epitome, as of a treatise or book, or of a statement; a brief.

p.blockquote:
An abstract of every treatise he had read.
Watts.

Man, the abstract
Of all perfection, which the workmanship
Of Heaven hath modeled.
Ford.

p.def: A state of separation from other things; as, to consider a subject in the abstract, or apart from other associated things.
An abstract term.

p.blockquote:
The concretes "father" and "son" have, or might have, the abstracts "paternity" and "filiety."
J. S. Mill.

p.def: A powdered solid extract of a vegetable substance mixed with sugar of milk in such proportion that one part of the abstract represents two parts of the original substance.

dictionary.p: Abstract of title (Law), an epitome of the evidences of ownership.
Syn. -- Abridgment; compendium; epitome; synopsis. See Abridgment.
Ab*stract"ed (AMP?;), a. 1. Separated or disconnected; withdrawn; removed; apart.

p.blockquote:
The evil abstracted stood from his own evil.
Milton.

dictionary.p: 2. Separated from matter; abstract; ideal. [Obs.]
3. Abstract; abstruse; difficult. [Obs.] Johnson.
4. Inattentive to surrounding objects; absent in mind. "An abstracted scholar." Johnson.
Ab*stract"ed*ly, adv. In an abstracted manner; separately; with absence of mind.
Ab*stract"ed*ness, n. The state of being abstracted; abstract character.
Ab*stract"er (AMP?;), n. One who abstracts, or makes an abstract.
Ab*strac"tion (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. abstraction. See Abstract, a.] 1. The act of abstracting, separating, or withdrawing, or the state of being withdrawn; withdrawal.

p.blockquote:
A wrongful abstraction of wealth from certain members of the community.
J. S. Mill.

p.def: The act process of leaving out of consideration one or more properties of a complex object so as to attend to others; analysis. Thus, when the mind considers the form of a tree by itself, or the color of the leaves as separate from their size or figure, the act is called abstraction. So, also, when it considers whiteness, softness, virtue, existence, as separate from any particular objects.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; Abstraction is necessary to classification, by which things are arranged in genera and species. We separate in idea the qualities of certain objects, which are of the same kind, from others which are different, in each, and arrange the objects having the same properties in a class, or collected body.

p.blockquote:
Abstraction is no positive act: it is simply the negative of attention.
Sir W. Hamilton.

p.def: An idea or notion of an abstract, or theoretical nature; as, to fight for mere abstractions.
A separation from worldly objects; a recluse life; as, a hermit's abstraction.
Absence or absorption of mind; inattention to present objects.

dictionary.p: 6. The taking surreptitiously for one's own use part of the property of another; purloining. [Modern]

p.def: A separation of volatile parts by the act of distillation.

dictionary.p: Ab*strac"tion*al (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to abstraction.
Ab*strac"tion*ist, n. An idealist. Emerson.
Ab`strac*ti"tious (AMP?;), a. Obtained from plants by distillation. [Obs.] Crabb.
Ab*strac"tive (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. abstractif.] Having the power of abstracting; of an abstracting nature. "The abstractive faculty." I. Taylor.
Ab*strac"tive*ly, adv. In a abstract manner; separately; in or by itself. Feltham.
Ab*strac"tive*ness, n. The quality of being abstractive; abstractive property.
Ab"stract`ly (#; 277), adv. In an abstract state or manner; separately; absolutely; by itself; as, matter abstractly considered.
Ab"stract`ness, n. The quality of being abstract. "The abstractness of the ideas." Locke.
Ab*stringe" (AMP?;), v. t. [L ab + stringere, strictum, to press together.] To unbind. [Obs.] Bailey.
Ab*strude" (AMP?;), v. t. [L. abstrudere. See Abstruse.] To thrust away. [Obs.] Johnson.
Ab*struse" (AMP?;), a. [L. abstrusus, p. p. of abstrudere to thrust away, conceal; ab, abs + trudere to thrust; cf. F. abstrus. See Threat.] 1. Concealed or hidden out of the way. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The eternal eye whose sight discerns
Abstrusest thoughts.
Milton.

p.def: Remote from apprehension; difficult to be comprehended or understood; recondite; as, abstruse learning.

p.blockquote:
Profound and abstruse topics.
Milman.

dictionary.p: Ab*struse"ly, adv. In an abstruse manner.
Ab*struse"ness, n. The quality of being abstruse; difficulty of apprehension. Boyle.
Ab*stru"sion (AMP?;), n. [L. abstrusio. See Abstruse.] The act of thrusting away. [R.] Ogilvie.
Ab*stru"si*ty (AMPabreve;b*strAMPudd;"sAMPibreve;*tAMPybreve;), n. Abstruseness; that which is abstruse. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Ab*sume" (AMPabreve;b*sAMPumacr;m"), v. t. [L. absumere, absumptum; ab + sumere to take.] To consume gradually; to waste away. [Obs.] Boyle.
Ab*sump"tion (AMPabreve;b*sAMPubreve;mp"shAMPubreve;n; 215), n. [L. absumptio. See Absume.] Act of wasting away; a consuming; extinction. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.

Ab*surd" (AMPabreve;b*sAMPucirc;rd"), a. [L. absurdus harsh-sounding; ab + (prob) a derivative fr. a root svar to sound; not connected with surd: cf. F. absurde. See Syringe.] Contrary to reason or propriety; obviously and flatly opposed to manifest truth; inconsistent with the plain dictates of common sense; logically contradictory; nonsensical; ridiculous; as, an absurd person, an absurd opinion; an absurd dream.

p.blockquote:
This proffer is absurd and reasonless.
Shak.

'This phrase absurd to call a villain great.
Pope. p. 9

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Foolish; irrational; ridiculous; preposterous; inconsistent; incongruous. -- Absurd, Irrational, Foolish, Preposterous. Of these terms, irrational is the weakest, denoting that which is plainly inconsistent with the dictates of sound reason; as, an irrational course of life. Foolish rises higher, and implies either a perversion of that faculty, or an absolute weakness or fatuity of mind; as, foolish enterprises. Absurd rises still higher, denoting that which is plainly opposed to received notions of propriety and truth; as, an absurd man, project, opinion, story, argument, etc. Preposterous rises still higher, and supposes an absolute inversion in the order of things; or, in plain terms, a "putting of the cart before the horse;" as, a preposterous suggestion, preposterous conduct, a preposterous regulation or law.
Ab*surd" (AMPabreve;b*sAMPucirc;rd"), n. An absurdity. [Obs.] Pope.

Ab*surd"i*ty (-AMPibreve;*tAMPybreve;), n.; pl. Absurdities (-tAMPibreve;z). [L. absurditas: cf. F. absurdite.] 1. The quality of being absurd or inconsistent with obvious truth, reason, or sound judgment. "The absurdity of the actual idea of an infinite number." Locke.

p.def: That which is absurd; an absurd action; a logical contradiction.

p.blockquote:
His travels were full of absurdities.
Johnson.

dictionary.p: Ab*surd"ly, adv. In an absurd manner.
Ab*surd"ness, n. Absurdity. [R.]
||A*bu"na (AMPadot;*bAMPoomac;"nAMPadot;), n. [Eth. and Ar., our father.] The Patriarch, or head of the Abyssinian Church.

A*bun"dance (AMPadot;*bAMPubreve;n"dans), n. [OE. (h)abundaunce, abundance, F. abondance, L. abundantia, fr. abundare. See Abound.] An overflowing fullness; ample sufficiency; great plenty; profusion; copious supply; superfluity; wealth: -- strictly applicable to quantity only, but sometimes used of number.

p.blockquote:
It is lamentable to remember what abundance of noble blood hath been shed with small benefit to the Christian state.
Raleigh.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Exuberance; plenteousness; plenty; copiousness; overflow; riches; affluence; wealth. -- Abundance, Plenty, Exuberance. These words rise upon each other in expressing the idea of fullness. Plenty denotes a sufficiency to supply every want; as, plenty of food, plenty of money, etc. Abundance express more, and gives the idea of superfluity or excess; as, abundance of riches, an abundance of wit and humor; often, however, it only denotes plenty in a high degree. Exuberance rises still higher, and implies a bursting forth on every side, producing great superfluity or redundance; as, an exuberance of mirth, an exuberance of animal spirits, etc.

A*bun"dant (AMP?;), a. [OE. (h)abundant, aboundant, F. abondant, fr. L. abudans, p. pr. of abundare. See Abound.] Fully sufficient; plentiful; in copious supply; -- followed by in, rarely by with. "Abundant in goodness and truth." Exod. xxxiv. 6.

Abundant number (Math.), a number, the sum of whose aliquot parts exceeds the number itself. Thus, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, the aliquot parts of 12, make the number 16. This is opposed to a deficient number, as 14, whose aliquot parts are 1, 2, 7, the sum of which is 10; and to a perfect number, which is equal to the sum of its aliquot parts, as 6, whose aliquot parts are 1, 2., 3.
A*bun"dant*ly, adv. In a sufficient degree; fully; amply; plentifully; in large measure.
A*burst" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + burst.] In a bursting condition.
A*bus"a*ble (AMP?;), a. That may be abused.
A*bus"age (AMP?;), n. Abuse. [Obs.] Whately (1634).

A*buse" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Abused (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Abusing.] [F. abuser; L. abusus, p. p. of abuti to abuse, misuse; ab + uti to use. See Use.] 1. To put to a wrong use; to misapply; to misuse; to put to a bad use; to use for a wrong purpose or end; to pervert; as, to abuse inherited gold; to make an excessive use of; as, to abuse one's authority.

p.blockquote:
This principle (if one may so abuse the word) shoots rapidly into popularity.
Froude.

p.def: To revile; to reproach coarsely; to disparage.

p.blockquote:
The . . . tellers of news abused the general.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: 4. To dishonor. "Shall flight abuse your name?" Shak.

p.def: To violate; to ravish.

dictionary.p: 6. To deceive; to impose on. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Their eyes red and staring, cozened with a moist cloud, and abused by a double object.
Jer. Taylor.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To maltreat; injure; revile; reproach; vilify; vituperate; asperse; traduce; malign.

A*buse" (AMP?;), n. [F. abus, L. abusus, fr. abuti. See Abuse, v. t.] 1. Improper treatment or use; application to a wrong or bad purpose; misuse; as, an abuse of our natural powers; an abuse of civil rights, or of privileges or advantages; an abuse of language.

p.blockquote:
Liberty may be endangered by the abuses of liberty, as well as by the abuses of power.
Madison.

dictionary.p: 2. Physical ill treatment; injury. "Rejoice . . . at the abuse of Falstaff." Shak.

p.def: A corrupt practice or custom; offense; crime; fault; as, the abuses in the civil service.

p.blockquote:
Abuse after disappeared without a struggle..
Macaulay.

p.def: Vituperative words; coarse, insulting speech; abusive language; virulent condemnation; reviling.

p.blockquote:
The two parties, after exchanging a good deal of abuse, came to blows.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: 5. Violation; rape; as, abuse of a female child. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Or is it some abuse, and no such thing?
Shak.

dictionary.p: Abuse of distress (Law), a wrongful using of an animal or chattel distrained, by the distrainer.

Syn. -- Invective; contumely; reproach; scurrility; insult; opprobrium. -- Abuse, Invective. Abuse is generally prompted by anger, and vented in harsh and unseemly words. It is more personal and coarse than invective. Abuse generally takes place in private quarrels; invective in writing or public discussions. Invective may be conveyed in refined language and dictated by indignation against what is blameworthy. C. J. Smith.
A*buse"ful (AMP?;), a. Full of abuse; abusive. [R.] "Abuseful names." Bp. Barlow.
A*bus"er (AMP?;), n. One who abuses [in the various senses of the verb].
A*bu"sion (AMP?;), n. [OE. abusion, abusioun, OF. abusion, fr. L. abusio misuse of words, f. abuti. See Abuse, v. t.] Evil or corrupt usage; abuse; wrong; reproach; deception; cheat. Chaucer.

p.blockquote:
I am . . . necessitated to use the word Parliament improperly, according to the abusive acceptation thereof.
Fuller.

dictionary.p: 2. Given to misusing; also, full of abuses. [Archaic] "The abusive prerogatives of his see." Hallam.

p.def: Practicing abuse; prone to ill treat by coarse, insulting words or by other ill usage; as, an abusive author; an abusive fellow.

dictionary.p: 4. Containing abuse, or serving as the instrument of abuse; vituperative; reproachful; scurrilous. "An abusive lampoon." Johnson.
5. Tending to deceive; fraudulent; cheating. [Obs.] "An abusive treaty." Bacon.
Syn. -- Reproachful; scurrilous; opprobrious; insolent; insulting; injurious; offensive; reviling.
A*bu"sive*ly, adv. In an abusive manner; rudely; with abusive language.
A*bu"sive*ness, n. The quality of being abusive; rudeness of language, or violence to the person.

p.blockquote:
Pick out mirth, like stones out of thy ground,
Profaneness, filthiness, abusiveness.
Herbert.

dictionary.p: A*but" (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Abutted; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Abutting.] [OF. abouter, aboter; cf. F. aboutir, and also abuter; a (L. ad) + OF. boter, buter, to push: cf. F. bout end, and but end, purpose.] To project; to terminate or border; to be contiguous; to meet; -- with on, upon, or against; as, his land abuts on the road.

A*bu"ti*lon (AMP?;), n. [Ar. aubAMPumacr;tAMPimacr;lAMPumacr;n.] (Bot.) A genus of malvaceous plants of many species, found in the torrid and temperate zones of both continents; -- called also Indian mallow.
A*but"ment (AMPadot;*bAMPubreve;t"ment), n. 1. State of abutting.

2. That on or against which a body abuts or presses; as (a) (Arch.) The solid part of a pier or wall, etc., which receives the thrust or lateral pressure of an arch, vault, or strut. Gwilt. (b) (Mech.) A fixed point or surface from which resistance or reaction is obtained, as the cylinder head of a steam engine, the fulcrum of a lever, etc. (c) In breech-loading firearms, the block behind the barrel which receives the pressure due to recoil.
A*but"tal (AMP?;), n. The butting or boundary of land, particularly at the end; a headland. Spelman.
A*but"ter (AMP?;), n. One who, or that which, abuts. Specifically, the owner of a contiguous estate; as, the abutters on a street or a river.
A*buzz" (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- + buzz.] In a buzz; buzzing. [Colloq.] Dickens.

{ A*by", A*bye" } (AMP?;), v. t. AMP i. [imp. AMP p. p. Abought (AMP?;).] [AS. AMPamacr;bycgan to pay for; pref. AMPamacr;- (cf. Goth. us- , Ger. er-, orig. meaning out) + bycgan to buy. See Buy, and cf. Abide.] 1. To pay for; to suffer for; to atone for; to make amends for; to give satisfaction. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Lest to thy peril thou aby it dear.
Shak.

dictionary.p: 2. To endure; to abide. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
But nought that wanteth rest can long aby.
Spenser.

dictionary.p: A*bysm" (AMP?;), n. [OF. abisme; F. abime, LL. abyssimus, a superl. of L. abyssus; Gr. AMP?;. See Abyss.] An abyss; a gulf. "The abysm of hell." Shak.
A*bys"mal (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to, or resembling, an abyss; bottomless; unending; profound.

p.blockquote:
Geology gives one the same abysmal extent of time that astronomy does of space.
Carlyle.

dictionary.p: A*bys"mal*ly, adv. To a fathomless depth; profoundly. "Abysmally ignorant." G. Eliot.

A*byss" (AMP?;), n. [L. abyssus a bottomless gulf, fr. Gr. AMP?; bottomless; 'a priv. + AMP?; depth, bottom.] 1. A bottomless or unfathomed depth, gulf, or chasm; hence, any deep, immeasurable, and, specifically, hell, or the bottomless pit.

p.blockquote:
Ye powers and spirits of this nethermost abyss.
Milton.

The throne is darkness, in the abyss of light.
Dryden.

p.def: Infinite time; a vast intellectual or moral depth.

p.blockquote:
The abysses of metaphysical theology.
Macaulay.

In unfathomable abysses of disgrace.
Burke.

p.def: The center of an escutcheon.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; This word, in its leading uses, is associated with the cosmological notions of the Hebrews, having reference to a supposed illimitable mass of waters from which our earth sprung, and beneath whose profound depths the wicked were punished. Encyc. Brit.
A*byss"al (AMP?;), a. [Cf. Abysmal.] Belonging to, or resembling, an abyss; unfathomable.

Abyssal zone (Phys. Geog.), one of the belts or zones into which Sir E. Forbes divides the bottom of the sea in describing its plants, animals, etc. It is the one furthest from the shore, embracing all beyond one hundred fathoms deep. Hence, abyssal animals, plants, etc.
Ab`ys*sin"i*an (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to Abyssinia.
Abyssinian gold, an alloy of 90.74 parts of copper and 8.33 parts of zink. Ure.
Ab`ys*sin"i*an, n. 1. A native of Abyssinia.

p.def: A member of the Abyssinian Church.

dictionary.p: A*ca"ci*a (AMP?;), n. (Antiq.) A roll or bag, filled with dust, borne by Byzantine emperors, as a memento of mortality. It is represented on medals.

A*ca"cia (AMP?;), n.; pl. E. Acacias (AMP?;), L. AcaciAMPaelig; (AMP?;). [L. from Gr. AMP?;; orig. the name of a thorny tree found in Egypt; prob. fr. the root ak to be sharp. See Acute.] 1. A genus of leguminous trees and shrubs. Nearly 300 species are Australian or Polynesian, and have terete or vertically compressed leaf stalks, instead of the bipinnate leaves of the much fewer species of America, Africa, etc. Very few are found in temperate climates.

p.def: The inspissated juice of several species of acacia; -- called also gum acacia, and gum arabic.

dictionary.p: Ac"a*cin, Ac"a*cine (AMP?;), n. Gum arabic.
Ac`a*deme" (AMP?;), n. [L. academia. See Academy.] An academy. [Poetic] Shak.
Ac`a*de"mi*al (AMP?;), a. Academic. [R.]
Ac`a*de"mi*an (AMP?;), n. A member of an academy, university, or college.
{ Ac`a*dem"ic (AMP?;), Ac`a*dem"ic*al (AMP?;), } a. [L. academicus: cf. F. acadAMPeacute;migue. See Academy.] 1. Belonging to the school or philosophy of Plato; as, the Academic sect or philosophy.
2. Belonging to an academy or other higher institution of learning; scholarly; literary or classical, in distinction from scientific. "Academic courses." Warburton. "Academical study." Berkeley.
Ac`a*dem"ic, n. 1. One holding the philosophy of Socrates and Plato; a Platonist. Hume.

p.def: A member of an academy, college, or university; an academician.

dictionary.p: Ac`a*dem`ic*al*ly, adv. In an academical manner.
Ac`a*dem"ic*als (AMP?;), n. pl. The articles of dress prescribed and worn at some colleges and universities.

Ac`a*de*mi"cian (#; 277), n. [F. acadAMPeacute;micien. See Academy.] 1. A member of an academy, or society for promoting science, art, or literature, as of the French Academy, or the Royal Academy of arts.
2. A collegian. [R.] Chesterfield.
Ac`a*dem"i*cism (AMP?;), n. 1. A tenet of the Academic philosophy.

p.def: A mannerism or mode peculiar to an academy.

dictionary.p: A*cad"e*mism (AMP?;), n. The doctrines of the Academic philosophy. [Obs.] Baxter.
A*cad"e*mist (AMP?;), n. [F. academiste.] 1. An Academic philosopher.
2. An academician. [Obs.] Ray.

A*cad"e*my (AMP?;), n.; pl. Academies (AMP?;). [F. acadAMPeacute;mie, L. academia. Cf. Academe.] 1. A garden or grove near Athens (so named from the hero Academus), where Plato and his followers held their philosophical conferences; hence, the school of philosophy of which Plato was head.
3. A place of training; a school. "Academies of fanaticism." Hume.

p.def: A society of learned men united for the advancement of the arts and sciences, and literature, or some particular art or science; as, the French Academy; the American Academy of Arts and Sciences; academies of literature and philology.
A school or place of training in which some special art is taught; as, the military academy at West Point; a riding academy; the Academy of Music.

dictionary.p: Academy figure (Paint.), a drawing usually half life-size, in crayon or pencil, after a nude model.
A*ca"di*an (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to Acadie, or Nova Scotia. "Acadian farmers." Longfellow. -- n. A native of Acadie.

Acadian epoch (Geol.), an epoch at the beginning of the American paleozoic time, and including the oldest American rocks known to be fossiliferous. See Geology. -- Acadian owl (ZoAMPouml;l.), a small North American owl (Nyctule Acadica); the saw-whet.
||Ac"a*jou (AMP?;), n. [F. See Cashew.] (Bot.) (a) The cashew tree; also, its fruit. See Cashew. (b) The mahogany tree; also, its timber.
{ Ac"a*leph (AMP?;), Ac`a*le"phan (AMP?;) } n.; pl. Acalephs (AMP?;), Acalephans (AMP?;). [See AcalephAMPaelig;.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of the AcalephAMPaelig;.

||Ac`a*le"phAMPaelig; (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., from Gr. AMP?;, a nettle.] A group of CAMPoelig;lenterata, including the MedusAMPaelig; or jellyfishes, and hydroids; -- so called from the stinging power they possess. Sometimes called sea nettles.
Ac`ale"phoid (AMP?;), a. [Acaleph + - oid.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Belonging to or resembling the AcalephAMPaelig; or jellyfishes.
A*cal"y*cine (AMP?;), Ac`a*lys`i*nous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; calyx.] (Bot.) Without a calyx, or outer floral envelope.
A*canth" (AMP?;), n. Same as Acanthus.

p.def: A spine or prickly fin.
The vertebral column; the spinous process of a vertebra.

dictionary.p: Ac"an*tha"ceous (AMP?;), a. 1. Armed with prickles, as a plant.

p.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of which the acanthus is the type.

dictionary.p: A*can"thine (AMP?;), a. [L. acanthinus, Gr. AMP?;, thorny, fr. AMP?;. See Acanthus.] Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the plant acanthus.
A*can`tho*car"pous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; thorn + AMP?; fruit.] (Bot.) Having the fruit covered with spines.
||A*can`tho*ceph"a*la (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., from Gr. AMP?; a spine, thorn + AMP?; head.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A group of intestinal worms, having the proboscis armed with recurved spines.
A*can`tho*ceph"a*lous (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Having a spiny head, as one of the Acanthocephala.
Ac`an*thoph"o*rous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; spine + AMP?; to bear.] Spine-bearing. Gray.
A*can`tho*po"di*ous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; thorn + AMP?;, AMP?;, foot.] (Bot.) Having spinous petioles.
||Ac`an*thop"ter*i (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., from Gr. AMP?; thorn + AMP?; wing, fin.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A group of teleostean fishes having spiny fins. See Acanthopterygii.
Ac`an*thop"ter*ous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; spine + AMP?; wing.] 1. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Spiny- winged.

p.def: Acanthopterygious.

dictionary.p: Ac`an*thop`ter*yg"i*an (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Belonging to the order of fishes having spinose fins, as the perch. -- n. A spiny-finned fish.

||Ac`an*thop`ter*yg"i*i (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., from Gr. AMP?; thorn + AMP?; fin, dim. fr. AMP?; wing.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) An order of fishes having some of the rays of the dorsal, ventral, and anal fins unarticulated and spinelike, as the perch.
Ac`an*thop`ter*yg"i*ous (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Having fins in which the rays are hard and spinelike; spiny-finned.
A*can"thus (AMP?;), n.; pl. E. Acanthuses (AMP?;), L. Acanthi (AMP?;). [L., from Gr. AMP?;. Cf. Acantha.]

p.def: A genus of herbaceous prickly plants, found in the south of Europe, Asia Minor, and India; bear's- breech.
An ornament resembling the foliage or leaves of the acanthus (Acanthus spinosus); -- used in the capitals of the Corinthian and Composite orders.

dictionary.p: ||A cap*pel"la (AMP?;). [It. See Chapel.] (Mus.) (a) In church or chapel style; -- said of compositions sung in the old church style, without instrumental accompaniment; as, a mass a capella, i. e., a mass purely vocal. (b) A time indication, equivalent to alla breve.
A*cap"su*lar (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- not + capsular.] (Bot.) Having no capsule.
A*car"di*ac (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;; 'a priv. + AMP?; heart.] Without a heart; as, an acardiac fetus.
A*car"i*dan (AMP?;), n. [See Acarus.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of a group of arachnids, including the mites and ticks.

||Ac`a*ri"na (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., from Gr. AMP?; a mite.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) The group of Arachnida which includes the mites and ticks. Many species are parasitic, and cause diseases like the itch and mange.
Ac"a*rine (AMP?;), a. (Med.) Of or caused by acari or mites; as, acarine diseases.
Ac"a*roid (AMP?;), a. [NL., acarus a mite + -oid.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Shaped like or resembling a mite.
Ac`ar*pel"lous (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- not + carpel.] (Bot.) Having no carpels.
||Ac"a*rus (AMP?;), n.; pl. Acari (AMP?;). [NL., from Gr. AMP?; the cheese mite, tick.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A genus including many species of small mites.

A*cat`a*lec"tic (AMP?;), a. [L. acatalecticus, Gr. AMP?;, not defective at the end; 'a priv. + AMP?; to cease.] (Pros.) Not defective; complete; as, an acatalectic verse. -- n. A verse which has the complete number of feet and syllables.

A*cat"a*lep`sy (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?;; 'a priv. + AMP?; to seize, comprehend.] Incomprehensibility of things; the doctrine held by the ancient Skeptic philosophers, that human knowledge never amounts to certainty, but only to probability.
A*cat`a*lep"tic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;.] Incapable of being comprehended; incomprehensible.
A*ca"ter (AMP?;), n. See Caterer. [Obs.]
A*cates" (AMP?;), n. pl. See Cates. [Obs.]
A*cau"date (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- not + caudate.] Tailless.
Ac`au*les"cent (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- not + caulescent.] (Bot.) Having no stem or caulis, or only a very short one concealed in the ground. Gray.
A*cau"line (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- not + cauline.] (Bot.) Same as Acaulescent.
{ A*cau"lose (AMP?;), A*cau"lous (AMP?;), } a. [Gr. AMP?;; 'a priv. + AMP?; stalk or L. caulis stalk. See Cole.] (Bot.) Same as Acaulescent.
Ac*ca"di*an (AMP?;), a. [From the city Accad. See Gen. x. 10.] Pertaining to a race supposed to have lived in Babylonia before the Assyrian conquest.
-- Ac*ca"di*an, n., Ac"cad (AMP?;), n. Sayce.
Ac*cede" (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Acceded; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Acceding.] [L. accedere to approach, accede; ad + cedere to move, yield: cf. F. accAMPeacute;dere. See Cede.]
1. To approach; to come forward; -- opposed to recede. [Obs.] T. Gale.

p.def: To enter upon an office or dignity; to attain.

p.blockquote:
Edward IV., who had acceded to the throne in the year 1461.
T. Warton.

If Frederick had acceded to the supreme power.
Morley.

p.def: To become a party by associating one's self with others; to give one's adhesion. Hence, to agree or assent to a proposal or a view; as, he acceded to my request.

p.blockquote:
The treaty of Hanover in 1725 . . . to which the Dutch afterwards acceded.
Chesterfield.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To agree; assent; consent; comply; acquiesce; concur.
Ac*ced"ence (AMP?;), n. The act of acceding.
Ac*ced"er (AMP?;), n. One who accedes.
||Ac*cel`er*an"do (AMP?;), a. [It.] (Mus.) Gradually accelerating the movement.

Ac*cel"er*ate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Accelerated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Accelerating.] [L. acceleratus, p. p. of accelerare; ad + celerare to hasten; celer quick. See Celerity.] 1. To cause to move faster; to quicken the motion of; to add to the speed of; -- opposed to retard.

p.def: To quicken the natural or ordinary progression or process of; as, to accelerate the growth of a plant, the increase of wealth, etc.
To hasten, as the occurence of an event; as, to accelerate our departure.

dictionary.p: Accelerated motion (Mech.), motion with a continually increasing velocity. -- Accelerating force, the force which causes accelerated motion. Nichol.
Syn. -- To hasten; expedite; quicken; dispatch; forward; advance; further.

Ac*cel`er*a"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. acceleratio: cf. F. accAMPeacute;lAMPeacute;ration.] The act of accelerating, or the state of being accelerated; increase of motion or action; as, a falling body moves toward the earth with an acceleration of velocity; -- opposed to retardation.

p.blockquote:
A period of social improvement, or of intellectual advancement, contains within itself a principle of acceleration.
I. Taylor.

dictionary.p: (Astr. AMP Physics.) Acceleration of the moon, the increase of the moon's mean motion in its orbit, in consequence of which its period of revolution is now shorter than in ancient times. - - Acceleration and retardation of the tides. See Priming of the tides, under Priming. -- Diurnal acceleration of the fixed stars, the amount by which their apparent diurnal motion exceeds that of the sun, in consequence of which they daily come to the meridian of any place about three minutes fifty-six seconds of solar time earlier than on the day preceding. -- Acceleration of the planets, the increasing velocity of their motion, in proceeding from the apogee to the perigee of their orbits.
Ac*cel"er*a*tive (AMP?;), a. Relating to acceleration; adding to velocity; quickening. Reid.
Ac*cel"er*a`tor (AMP?;), n. One who, or that which, accelerates. Also as an adj.; as, accelerator nerves.
Ac*cel"er*a*to*ry (AMP?;), a. Accelerative.
Ac*cel"er*o*graph (AMP?;), n. [Accelerate + -graph.] (Mil.) An apparatus for studying the combustion of powder in guns, etc.
Ac*cel`er*om"e*ter (AMP?;), n. [Accelerate + -meter.] An apparatus for measuring the velocity imparted by gunpowder.

Ac*cend" (AMP?;), v. t. [L. accendere, accensum, to kindle; ad + candAMPebreve;re to kindle (only in compounds); rel. to candAMPemacr;re to be white, to gleam. See Candle.] To set on fire; to kindle. [Obs.] Fotherby.
Ac*cend`i*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. Capacity of being kindled, or of becoming inflamed; inflammability.
Ac*cend"i*ble (AMP?;), a. Capable of being inflamed or kindled; combustible; inflammable. Ure.
Ac*cen"sion (AMP?;), n. The act of kindling or the state of being kindled; ignition. Locke.
Ac*cen"sor (AMP?;), n. [LL., from p. p. accensus. See Accend.] (R. C. Ch.) One of the functionaries who light and trim the tapers.

Ac"cent` (AMP?;), n. [F. accent, L. accentus; ad + cantus a singing, canere to sing. See Cant.] 1. A superior force of voice or of articulative effort upon some particular syllable of a word or a phrase, distinguishing it from the others.

AMPfist; Many English words have two accents, the primary and the secondary; the primary being uttered with a greater stress of voice than the secondary; as in asAMPprime;pira\'b6tion, where the chief stress is on the third syllable, and a slighter stress on the first. Some words, as anAMPprime;tiapAMPprime;o-plec\'b6tic, in- comAMPprime;pre-henAMPprime;si-bil\'b6i-ty, have two secondary accents. See Guide to Pron., t=t= 30-46.

p.def: A mark or character used in writing, and serving to regulate the pronunciation; esp.: (a) a mark to indicate the nature and place of the spoken accent; (b) a mark to indicate the quality of sound of the vowel marked; as, the French accents.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; In the ancient Greek the acute accent (AMPprime;) meant a raised tone or pitch, the grave (`), the level tone or simply the negation of accent, the circumflex ( ~ or ^) a tone raised and then depressed. In works on elocution, the first is often used to denote the rising inflection of the voice; the second, the falling inflection; and the third (^), the compound or waving inflection. In dictionaries, spelling books, and the like, the acute accent is used to designate the syllable which receives the chief stress of voice.

3. Modulation of the voice in speaking; manner of speaking or pronouncing; peculiar or characteristic modification of the voice; tone; as, a foreign accent; a French or a German accent. "Beguiled you in a plain accent." Shak. "A perfect accent." Thackeray.

p.blockquote:
The tender accent of a woman's cry.
Prior.

dictionary.p: 4. A word; a significant tone; (pl.) expressions in general; speech.

p.blockquote:
Winds! on your wings to Heaven her accents bear,
Such words as Heaven alone is fit to hear.
Dryden.

p.def: Stress laid on certain syllables of a verse.
A regularly recurring stress upon the tone to mark the beginning, and, more feebly, the third part of the measure.
A special emphasis of a tone, even in the weaker part of the measure.
The rhythmical accent, which marks phrases and sections of a period.
The expressive emphasis and shading of a passage.
A mark placed at the right hand of a letter, and a little above it, to distinguish magnitudes of a similar kind expressed by the same letter, but differing in value, as yAMPprime;, yAMPPrime;.
A mark at the right hand of a number, indicating minutes of a degree, seconds, etc.; as, 12AMPprime;27AMPPrime;, i. e., twelve minutes twenty seven seconds.
A mark used to denote feet and inches; as, 6AMPprime; 10AMPPrime; is six feet ten inches.

dictionary.p: Ac*cent" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Accented; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Accenting.] [OF. accenter, F. accentuer.]

p.def: To express the accent of (either by the voice or by a mark); to utter or to mark with accent.
To mark emphatically; to emphasize.

dictionary.p: Ac"cent`less (AMP?;), a. Without accent.
Ac*cen"tor (AMP?;), n. [L. ad. + cantor singer, canere to sing.] 1. (Mus.) One who sings the leading part; the director or leader. [Obs.]

p.def: A genus of European birds (so named from their sweet notes), including the hedge warbler. In America sometimes applied to the water thrushes.

dictionary.p: Ac*cen"tu*a*ble (AMP?;), a. Capable of being accented.
Ac*cen"tu*al (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to accent; characterized or formed by accent.
Ac*cen`tu*al"i*ty (AMP?;), n. The quality of being accentual.
Ac*cen"tu*al*ly (AMP?;), adv. In an accentual manner; in accordance with accent.

Ac*cen"tu*ate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Accentuated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Accentuating.] [LL. accentuatus, p. p. of accentuare, fr. L. accentus: cf. F. accentuer.] 1. To pronounce with an accent or with accents.

p.def: To bring out distinctly; to make prominent; to emphasize.

p.blockquote:
In Bosnia, the struggle between East and West was even more accentuated.
London Times.

p.def: To mark with the written accent.

dictionary.p: Ac*cen`tu*a"tion (AMP?;), n. [LL. accentuatio: cf. F. accentuation.] Act of accentuating; applications of accent. Specifically (Eccles. Mus.), pitch or modulation of the voice in reciting portions of the liturgy.
Ac*cept" (AMPabreve;k*sAMPebreve;pt"), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Accepted; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Accepting.] [F. accepter, L. acceptare, freq. of accipere; ad + capere to take; akin to E. heave.]

p.def: To receive with a consenting mind (something offered); as, to accept a gift; -- often followed by of.

p.blockquote:
If you accept them, then their worth is great.
Shak.

To accept of ransom for my son.
Milton.

She accepted of a treat.
Addison.

p.def: To receive with favor; to approve.

p.blockquote:
The Lord accept thy burnt sacrifice.
Ps. xx. 3.

Peradventure he will accept of me.
Gen. xxxii. 20.

p.def: To receive or admit and agree to; to assent to; as, I accept your proposal, amendment, or excuse.
To take by the mind; to understand; as, How are these words to be accepted?
To receive as obligatory and promise to pay; as, to accept a bill of exchange.
In a deliberate body, to receive in acquittance of a duty imposed; as, to accept the report of a committee. [This makes it the property of the body, and the question is then on its adoption.]

dictionary.p: To accept a bill (Law), to agree (on the part of the drawee) to pay it when due. -- To accept service (Law), to agree that a writ or process shall be considered as regularly served, when it has not been. -- To accept the person (Eccl.), to show favoritism. "God accepteth no man's person." Gal. ii. 6.
Syn. -- To receive; take; admit. See Receive.
Ac*cept", a. Accepted. [Obs.] Shak.
Ac*cept`a*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. [LL. acceptabilitas.] The quality of being acceptable; acceptableness. "Acceptability of repentance." Jer. Taylor.

Ac*cept"a*ble (-sAMPebreve;pt"AMPadot;*b'l; 277), a. [F. acceptable, L. acceptabilis, fr. acceptare.] Capable, worthy, or sure of being accepted or received with pleasure; pleasing to a receiver; gratifying; agreeable; welcome; as, an acceptable present, one acceptable to us.
Ac*cept"a*ble*ness (AMPabreve;k*sAMPebreve;pt"AMPadot;*b'l*nAMPebreve;s), n. The quality of being acceptable, or suitable to be favorably received; acceptability.
Ac*cept"a*bly, adv. In an acceptable manner; in a manner to please or give satisfaction.

Ac*cept"ance (AMP?;), n. 1. The act of accepting; a receiving what is offered, with approbation, satisfaction, or acquiescence; esp., favorable reception; approval; as, the acceptance of a gift, office, doctrine, etc.

p.blockquote:
They shall come up with acceptance on mine altar.
Isa. lx. 7.

dictionary.p: 2. State of being accepted; acceptableness. "Makes it assured of acceptance." Shak.

p.def: An assent and engagement by the person on whom a bill of exchange is drawn, to pay it when due according to the terms of the acceptance.
The bill itself when accepted.

An agreeing to terms or proposals by which a bargain is concluded and the parties are bound; the reception or taking of a thing bought as that for which it was bought, or as that agreed to be delivered, or the taking possession as owner.
An agreeing to the action of another, by some act which binds the person in law.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; What acts shall amount to such an acceptance is often a question of great nicety and difficulty. Mozley AMP W.
AMPfist; In modern law, proposal and acceptance are the constituent elements into which all contracts are resolved.

Acceptance of a bill of exchange, check, draft, or order, is an engagement to pay it according to the terms. This engagement is usually made by writing the word "accepted" across the face of the bill. Acceptance of goods, under the statute of frauds, is an intelligent acceptance by a party knowing the nature of the transaction.
6. Meaning; acceptation. [Obs.]
Acceptance of persons, partiality, favoritism. See under Accept.
Ac*cept"an*cy (AMP?;), n. Acceptance. [R.]

p.blockquote:
Here's a proof of gift,
But here's no proof, sir, of acceptancy.
Mrs. Browning.

dictionary.p: Ac*cept"ant (AMP?;), a. Accepting; receiving.
Ac*cept"ant, n. An accepter. Chapman.
Ac`cep*ta"tion (AMP?;), n. 1. Acceptance; reception; favorable reception or regard; state of being acceptable. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
This is saying worthy of all acceptation.
1 Tim. i. 15.

Some things . . . are notwithstanding of so great dignity and acceptation with God.
Hooker.

p.def: The meaning in which a word or expression is understood, or generally received; as, term is to be used according to its usual acceptation.

p.blockquote:
My words, in common acceptation,
Could never give this provocation.
Gay.

dictionary.p: Ac*cept"ed*ly (AMP?;), adv. In a accepted manner; admittedly.
Ac*cept"er (AMP?;), n. 1. A person who accepts; a taker.
2. A respecter; a viewer with partiality. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
God is no accepter of persons.
Chillingworth.

p.def: An acceptor.

dictionary.p: Ac*cep`ti*la"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. acceptilatio entry of a debt collected, acquittance, fr. p. p. of accipere (cf. Accept) + latio a carrying, fr. latus, p. p. of ferre to carry: cf. F. acceptilation.] (Civil Law) Gratuitous discharge; a release from debt or obligation without payment; free remission.
Ac*cep"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. acceptio a receiving, accepting: cf. F. acception.] Acceptation; the received meaning. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Here the word "baron" is not to be taken in that restrictive sense to which the modern acception hath confined it.
Fuller.

dictionary.p: Acception of persons or faces (Eccl.), favoritism; partiality. [Obs.] Wyclif.
Ac*cept"ive (AMP?;), a. 1. Fit for acceptance.
2. Ready to accept. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Ac*cept"or (#; 277), n. [L.] One who accepts; specifically (Law AMP Com.), one who accepts an order or a bill of exchange; a drawee after he has accepted.
Ac*cess" (#; 277), n. [F. accAMPegrave;s, L. accessus, fr. accedere. See Accede.] 1. A coming to, or near approach; admittance; admission; accessibility; as, to gain access to a prince.

p.blockquote:
I did repel his letters, and denied
His access to me.
Shak.

dictionary.p: 2. The means, place, or way by which a thing may be approached; passage way; as, the access is by a neck of land. "All access was thronged." Milton.

p.def: Admission to sexual intercourse.

p.blockquote:
During coverture, access of the husband shall be presumed, unless the contrary be shown.
Blackstone.

p.def: Increase by something added; addition; as, an access of territory. [In this sense accession is more generally used.]

p.blockquote:
I, from the influence of thy looks, receive
Access in every virtue.
Milton.

p.def: An onset, attack, or fit of disease.

p.blockquote:
The first access looked like an apoplexy.
Burnet.

dictionary.p: 6. A paroxysm; a fit of passion; an outburst; as, an access of fury. [A Gallicism]
Ac*ces"sa*ri*ly (AMP?;), adv. In the manner of an accessary.
Ac*ces"sa*ri*ness, n. The state of being accessary.
Ac*ces"sa*ry (#; 277), a. Accompanying, as a subordinate; additional; accessory; esp., uniting in, or contributing to, a crime, but not as chief actor. See Accessory.

p.blockquote:
To both their deaths thou shalt be accessary.
Shak.

Amongst many secondary and accessary causes that support monarchy, these are not of least reckoning.
Milton.

dictionary.p: Ac*ces"sa*ry (277), n.; pl. Accessaries (AMP?;). [Cf. Accessory and LL. accessarius.] (Law) One who, not being present, contributes as an assistant or instigator to the commission of an offense.

Accessary before the fact (Law), one who commands or counsels an offense, not being present at its commission. -- Accessary after the fact, one who, after an offense, assists or shelters the offender, not being present at the commission of the offense.

AMPfist; This word, as used in law, is spelt accessory by Blackstone and many others; but in this sense is spelt accessary by Bouvier, Burrill, Burns, Whishaw, Dane, and the Penny Cyclopedia; while in other senses it is spelt accessory. In recent text-books on criminal law the distinction is not preserved, the spelling being either accessary or accessory.
