dictionary.p: Ad"vo*ca*cy (AMP?;), n. [OF. advocatie, LL. advocatia. See Advocate.] The act of pleading for or supporting; work of advocating; intercession.

Ad"vo*cate (AMP?;), n. [OE. avocat, avocet, OF. avocat, fr. L. advocatus, one summoned or called to another; properly the p. p. of advocare to call to, call to one's aid; ad + vocare to call. See Advowee, Avowee, Vocal.] 1. One who pleads the cause of another. Specifically: One who pleads the cause of another before a tribunal or judicial court; a counselor.

AMPfist; In the English and American Law, advocate is the same as "counsel," "counselor," or "barrister." In the civil and ecclesiastical courts, the term signifies the same as "counsel" at the common law.

p.def: One who defends, vindicates, or espouses any cause by argument; a pleader; as, an advocate of free trade, an advocate of truth.
Christ, considered as an intercessor.

p.blockquote:
We have an Advocate with the Father.
1 John ii. 1.

dictionary.p: Faculty of advocates (Scot.), the Scottish bar in Edinburgh. -- Lord advocate (Scot.), the public prosecutor of crimes, and principal crown lawyer. -- Judge advocate. See under Judge.

Ad"vo*cate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Advocated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Advocating (AMP?;).] [See Advocate, n., Advoke, Avow.] To plead in favor of; to defend by argument, before a tribunal or the public; to support, vindicate, or recommend publicly.

p.blockquote:
To advocate the cause of thy client.
Bp. Sanderson (1624).

This is the only thing distinct and sensible, that has been advocated.
Burke.

Eminent orators were engaged to advocate his cause.
Mitford.

dictionary.p: Ad"vo*cate, v. i. To act as advocate. [Obs.] Fuller.
Ad"vo*cate*ship, n. Office or duty of an advocate.
Ad`vo*ca"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. advocatio: cf. OF. avocation. See Advowson.] 1. The act of advocating or pleading; plea; advocacy. [Archaic]

p.blockquote:
The holy Jesus . . . sits in heaven in a perpetual advocation for us.
Jer. Taylor.

dictionary.p: 2. Advowson. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The donations or advocations of church livings.
Sanderson.

p.def: The process of removing a cause from an inferior court to the supreme court.

dictionary.p: Ad"vo*ca*to*ry (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to an advocate. [R.]
Ad*voke" (AMP?;), v. t. [L. advocare. See Advocate.] To summon; to call. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Queen Katharine had privately prevailed with the pope to advoke the cause to Rome.
Fuller.

dictionary.p: Ad`vo*lu"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. advolvere, advolutum, to roll to.] A rolling toward something. [R.]
Ad*vou"trer (AMP?;), n. [OF. avoutre, avoltre, fr. L. adulter. Cf. Adulterer.] An adulterer. [Obs.]
Ad*vou"tress (AMP?;), n. An adulteress. [Obs.] Bacon.
{ Ad*vou"try, Ad*vow"try } (AMP?;), n. [OE. avoutrie, avouterie, advoutrie, OF. avoutrie, avulterie, fr. L. adulterium. Cf. Adultery.] Adultery. [Obs.] Bacon.
Ad*vow*ee" (AMP?;), n. [OE. avowe, F. avouAMPeacute;, fr. L. advocatus. See Advocate, Avowee, Avoyer.] One who has an advowson. Cowell.

Ad*vow"son (?; 277), n. [OE. avoweisoun, OF. avoAMPeuml;son, fr. L. advocatio. Cf. Advocation.] (Eng. Law) The right of presenting to a vacant benefice or living in the church. [Originally, the relation of a patron (advocatus) or protector of a benefice, and thus privileged to nominate or present to it.]

AMPfist; The benefices of the Church of England are in every case subjects of presentation. They are nearly 12,000 in number; the advowson of more than half of them belongs to private persons, and of the remainder to the crown, bishops, deans and chapters, universities, and colleges. Amer. Cyc.
Ad*voy"er (AMP?;), n. See Avoyer. [Obs.]
Ad*ward" (AMP?;), n. Award. [Obs.] Spenser.
||Ad`y*na"mi*a (AMP?;), n. [NL. adynamia, fr. Gr. AMP?; want of strength; AMP?; priv + AMP?; power, strength.] (Med.) Considerable debility of the vital powers, as in typhoid fever. Dunglison.
Ad`y*nam"ic (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. adynamique. See Adynamy.] 1. (Med.) Pertaining to, or characterized by, debility of the vital powers; weak.

p.def: Characterized by the absence of power or force.

dictionary.p: Adynamic fevers, malignant or putrid fevers attended with great muscular debility.
A*dyn"a*my (AMP?;), n. Adynamia. [R.] Morin.

||Ad"y*tum (AMP?;), n. Adyta (#). [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;, n., fr. AMP?;, a., not to be entered; 'a priv. + AMP?; to enter.] The innermost sanctuary or shrine in ancient temples, whence oracles were given. Hence: A private chamber; a sanctum.

{ Adz, Adze } (AMP?;), n. [OE. adese, adis, adse, AS. adesa, adese, ax, hatchet.] A carpenter's or cooper's tool, formed with a thin arching blade set at right angles to the handle. It is used for chipping or slicing away the surface of wood.
Adz, v. t. To cut with an adz. [R.] Carlyle.

AMPAElig; or Ae. A diphthong in the Latin language; used also by the Saxon writers. It answers to the Gr. ai. The Anglo-Saxon short AMPaelig; was generally replaced by a, the long AMPaemacr; by e or ee. In derivatives from Latin words with ae, it is mostly superseded by e. For most words found with this initial combination, the reader will therefore search under the letter E.

||AMPAElig;*cid"i*um (AMP?;), n.; pl. AMPAElig;cidia (AMP?;). [NL., dim. of Gr. AMP?; injury.] (Bot.) A form of fruit in the cycle of development of the Rusts or Brands, an order of fungi, formerly considered independent plants.

AMPAElig;"dile (AMP?;), n. [L. aedilis, fr. aedes temple, public building. Cf. Edify.] A magistrate in ancient Rome, who had the superintendence of public buildings, highways, shows, etc.; hence, a municipal officer.
AMPAElig;"dile*ship, n. The office of an AMPaelig;dile. T. Arnold.
||AMPAElig;`gi*cra"ni*a (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?;, AMP?;, goat + AMP?;, n. pl., heads.] (Arch.) Sculptured ornaments, used in classical architecture, representing rams' heads or skulls.
AMPAElig;g"i*lops (AMP?;), n. [L. aegilopis, Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?;, gen. AMP?;, goat + AMP?; eye.] 1. (Med.) An ulcer or fistula in the inner corner of the eye.

p.def: The great wild-oat grass or other cornfield weed.
A genus of plants, called also hardgrass.

dictionary.p: ||AMPAElig;"gis (AMP?;), n. [L. aegis, fr. Gr. AMP?; a goat skin, a shield, AMP?; goat, or fr. AMP?; to rush.] A shield or protective armor; -- applied in mythology to the shield of Jupiter which he gave to Minerva. Also fig.: A shield; a protection.
AMPAElig;*goph"o*ny (AMP?;), n. Same as Egophony.
||AMPAElig;*gro"tat (AMP?;), n. [L., he is sick.] (Camb. Univ.) A medical certificate that a student is ill.
AMPAElig;*ne"id (AMP?;), n. [L. Aeneis, Aeneidis, or -dos: cf. F. AMPEacute;nAMPeacute;de.] The great epic poem of Virgil, of which the hero is AMPAElig;neas.
A*AMPeuml;"ne*ous (AMP?;), a. [L. aAMPeuml;neus.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Colored like bronze.

AMPAElig;*o"li*an (AMP?;), a. [L. Aeolius, Gr. AMP?;.] 1. Of or pertaining to AMPAElig;olia or AMPAElig;olis, in Asia Minor, colonized by the Greeks, or to its inhabitants; AMPaelig;olic; as, the AMPAElig;olian dialect.

p.def: Pertaining to AMPAElig;olus, the mythic god of the winds; pertaining to, or produced by, the wind; aAMPeuml;rial.

p.blockquote:
Viewless forms the AMPaelig;olian organ play.
Campbell.

dictionary.p: AMPAElig;olian attachment, a contrivance often attached to a pianoforte, which prolongs the vibrations, increases the volume of sound, etc., by forcing a stream of air upon the strings. Moore. -- AMPAElig;olian harp, AMPAElig;olian lyre, a musical instrument consisting of a box, on or in which are stretched strings, on which the wind acts to produce the notes; - - usually placed at an open window. Moore. -- AMPAElig;olian mode (Mus.), one of the ancient Greek and early ecclesiastical modes.
AMPAElig;*ol"ic (AMPesl;*AMPobreve;l"AMPibreve;k), a. [L. Aeolicus; Gr. A'ioliko`s.] AMPAElig;olian, 1; as, the AMPAElig;olic dialect; the AMPAElig;olic mode.

{ AMPAElig;*ol"i*pile, AMPAElig;*ol"i*pyle } (AMP?;), n. [L. aeolipilae; Aeolus god of the winds + pila a ball, or Gr. AMP?; gate (i. e., doorway of AMPAElig;olus); cf. F. AMPeacute;olipyle.] An apparatus consisting chiefly of a closed vessel (as a globe or cylinder) with one or more projecting bent tubes, through which steam is made to pass from the vessel, causing it to revolve. [Written also eolipile.]
AMPfist; Such an apparatus was first described by Hero of Alexandria about 200 years b. c. It has often been called the first steam engine.

AMPAElig;`o*lo*trop"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; changeful + AMP?; a turning, AMP?; to turn.] (Physics) Exhibiting differences of quality or property in different directions; not isotropic. Sir W. Thomson.
AMPAElig;`o*lot"ro*py (AMP?;), n. (Physics) Difference of quality or property in different directions.
||AMPAElig;"o*lus (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;.] (Gr. AMP Rom. Myth.) The god of the winds.
AMPAElig;"on (AMP?;), n. A period of immeasurable duration; also, an emanation of the Deity. See Eon.
AMPAElig;*o"ni*an (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;.] Eternal; everlasting. "AMPAElig;onian hills." Tennyson.
||AMPAElig;`py*or"nis (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; high + AMP?; bird.] A gigantic bird found fossil in Madagascar.

A"AMPeuml;r*ate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. AAMPeuml;rated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. AAMPeuml;rating (AMP?;).] [Cf. F. aAMPeacute;rer. See Air, v. t.] 1. To combine or charge with gas; usually with carbonic acid gas, formerly called fixed air.

p.blockquote:
His sparkling sallies bubbled up as from aAMPeuml;rated natural fountains.
Carlyle.

p.def: To supply or impregnate with common air; as, to aAMPeuml;rate soil; to aAMPeuml;rate water.
To expose to the chemical action of air; to oxygenate (the blood) by respiration; to arterialize.

dictionary.p: AAMPeuml;rated bread, bread raised by charging dough with carbonic acid gas, instead of generating the gas in the dough by fermentation.
A`AMPeuml;r*a"tion (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. aAMPeacute;ration.] 1. Exposure to the free action of the air; airing; as, aAMPeuml;ration of soil, of spawn, etc.

p.def: A change produced in the blood by exposure to the air in respiration; oxygenation of the blood in respiration; arterialization.
The act or preparation of charging with carbonic acid gas or with oxygen.

dictionary.p: A"AMPeuml;r*a`tor (AMP?;), n. That which supplies with air; esp. an apparatus used for charging mineral waters with gas and in making soda water.

A*AMPeuml;"ri*al (AMP?;), a. [L. aAMPeuml;rius. See Air.] 1. Of or pertaining to the air, or atmosphere; inhabiting or frequenting the air; produced by or found in the air; performed in the air; as, aAMPeuml;rial regions or currents. "AAMPeuml;rial spirits." Milton. "AAMPeuml;rial voyages." Darwin.

p.def: Consisting of air; resembling, or partaking of the nature of air. Hence: Unsubstantial; unreal.
Rising aloft in air; high; lofty; as, aAMPeuml;rial spires.
Growing, forming, or existing in the air, as opposed to growing or existing in earth or water, or underground; as, aAMPeuml;rial rootlets, aAMPeuml;rial plants.
Light as air; ethereal.

dictionary.p: AAMPeuml;rial acid, carbonic acid. [Obs.] Ure. -- AAMPeuml;rial perspective. See Perspective.
A*AMPeuml;`ri*al"i*ty (AMP?;), n. The state of being aAMPeuml;rial; unsubstantiality. [R.] De Quincey.
A*AMPeuml;"ri*al*ly (AMP?;), adv. Like, or from, the air; in an aAMPeuml;rial manner. "A murmur heard aAMPeuml;rially." Tennyson.

Ae"rie (?; 277), n. [OE. aire, eire, air, nest, also origin, descent, OF. aire, LL. area, aera, nest of a bird of prey, perh. fr. L. area an open space (for birds of prey like to build their nests on flat and open spaces on the top of high rocks). Cf. Area.] The nest of a bird of prey, as of an eagle or hawk; also a brood of such birds; eyrie. Shak. Also fig.: A human residence or resting place perched like an eagle's nest.
A`AMPeuml;r*if"er*ous (AMP?;), a. [L. aAMPeuml;r air + -ferous: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rifAMPegrave;re.] Conveying or containing air; air- bearing; as, the windpipe is an aAMPeuml;riferous tube.
A`AMPeuml;r*i*fi*ca"tion (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. aAMPeacute;rification. See AAMP?;rify.] 1. The act of combining air with another substance, or the state of being filled with air.

p.def: The act of becoming aAMPeuml;rified, or of changing from a solid or liquid form into an aAMPeuml;riform state; the state of being aAMPeuml;riform.

dictionary.p: A"AMPeuml;r*i*form (?; 277), a. [L. aAMPeuml;r air + -form: cf. F. aAMPeacute;riforme.] Having the form or nature of air, or of an elastic fluid; gaseous. Hence fig.: Unreal.
A"AMPeuml;r*i*fy (AMP?;), v. t. [L. aAMPeuml;r air + -fly.] 1. To infuse air into; to combine air with.

p.def: To change into an aAMPeuml;riform state.

dictionary.p: A"AMPeuml;r*o-. [Gr. AMP?;, AMP?;, air.] The combining form of the Greek word meaning air.

A"AMPeuml;r*o*bies (AMP?;), n. pl. [AAMPeuml;ro- + Gr. AMP?; life.] (Biol.) MicroAMPouml;rganisms which live in contact with the air and need oxygen for their growth; as the microbacteria which form on the surface of putrefactive fluids.
A`AMPeuml;r*o*bi*ot"ic (?; 101), a. (Biol.) Related to, or of the nature of, aAMPeuml;robies; as, aAMPeuml;robiotic plants, which live only when supplied with free oxygen.
A"AMPeuml;r*o*cyst (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + cyst.] (Bot.) One of the air cells of algals.
A"AMPeuml;r*o*dy*nam"ic (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to the force of air in motion.

A`AMPeuml;r*o*dy*nam"ics (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + dynamics: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rodynamique.] The science which treats of the air and other gaseous bodies under the action of force, and of their mechanical effects.

A`AMPeuml;r*og"no*sy (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + Gr. AMP?; knowing, knowledge: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rognosie.] The science which treats of the properties of the air, and of the part it plays in nature. Craig.
A`AMPeuml;r*og"ra*pher (AMP?;), n. One versed in aAMPeuml;ography: an aAMPeuml;rologist.
A`AMPeuml;r*og"ra*phy (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + -graphy: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rographie.] A description of the air or atmosphere; aAMPeuml;rology.
A`AMPeuml;r*o*hy`dro*dy*nam"ic (AMP?;), a. [AAMPeuml;ro- + hydrodynamic.] Acting by the force of air and water; as, an aAMPeuml;rohydrodynamic wheel.
A"AMPeuml;r*o*lite (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + -lite: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rolithe.] (Meteor.) A stone, or metallic mass, which has fallen to the earth from distant space; a meteorite; a meteoric stone.
AMPfist; Some writers limit the word to stony meteorites.
A"AMPeuml;r*o*lith (AMP?;), n. Same as AAMP?;rolite.
A`AMPeuml;r*o*li*thol"o*gy (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + lithology.] The science of aAMPeuml;rolites.
A`AMPeuml;r*o*lit"ic (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to aAMPeuml;rolites; meteoric; as, aAMPeuml;rolitic iron. Booth.
{ A`AMPeuml;r*o*log"ic (AMP?;), A`AMPeuml;r*o*log"ic*al (AMP?;), } a. Of or pertaining to aAMPeuml;rology.
A`AMPeuml;r*ol"o*gist (AMP?;), n. One versed in aAMPeuml;rology.
A`AMPeuml;r*ol"o*gy (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + -logy: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rologie.] That department of physics which treats of the atmosphere.
A"AMPeuml;r*o*man`cy (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + -mancy: cf. F. aAMPeacute;romancie.] Divination from the state of the air or from atmospheric substances; also, forecasting changes in the weather.
A`AMPeuml;r*om"e*ter (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + -meter: cf. F. AMPeacute;romAMPegrave;tre.] An instrument for ascertaining the weight or density of air and gases.
A`AMPeuml;r*o*met"ric (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to aAMPeuml;rometry; as, aAMPeuml;rometric investigations.

A`AMPeuml;r*om"e*try (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + -metry: cf. F. AMPeacute;romAMPeacute;trie.] The science of measuring the air, including the doctrine of its pressure, elasticity, rarefaction, and condensation; pneumatics.
A"AMPeuml;r*o*naut (?; 277), n. [F. aAMPeacute;ronaute, fr. Gr. AMP?; air + AMP?; sailor. See Nautical.] An aAMPeuml;rial navigator; a balloonist.
{ A`AMPeuml;r*o*naut"ic (AMP?;), A`AMPeuml;r*o*naut"ic*al (AMP?;), } a. [Cf. F. aAMPeacute;ronauitique.] Pertaining to aAMPeuml;ronautics, or aAMPeuml;rial sailing.
A`AMPeuml;r*o*naut"ics (AMP?;), n. The science or art of ascending and sailing in the air, as by means of a balloon; aAMPeuml;rial navigation; ballooning.
{ ||A`AMPeuml;r*o*pho"bi*a (AMP?;), A`AMPeuml;r*oph"o*by (AMP?;), } n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + Gr. AMP?; fear: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rophobie.] (Med.) Dread of a current of air.

A"AMPeuml;r*o*phyte (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + Gr. AMP?; plant, AMP?; to grow: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rophyte.] (Bot.) A plant growing entirely in the air, and receiving its nourishment from it; an air plant or epiphyte.
A"AMPeuml;r*o*plane` (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + plane.] A flying machine, or a small plane for experiments on flying, which floats in the air only when propelled through it.
A"AMPeuml;r*o*scope (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + Gr. AMP?; to look out.] (Biol.) An apparatus designed for collecting spores, germs, bacteria, etc., suspended in the air.
A`AMPeuml;r*os"co*py (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + Gr. AMP?; a looking out; AMP?; to spy out.] The observation of the state and variations of the atmosphere.
AMPAElig;*rose" (AMP?;), a. [L. aerosus, fr. aes, aeris, brass, copper.] Of the nature of, or like, copper; brassy. [R.]
A`AMPeuml;r*o*sid"er*ite (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + siderite.] (Meteor.) A mass of meteoric iron.
A"AMPeuml;r*o*sphere (AMP?;), n. [AAMPeuml;ro- + sphere: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rosphAMPegrave;re.] The atmosphere. [R.]
A"AMPeuml;r*o*stat (AMP?;), n. [F. aAMPeacute;rostat, fr. Gr. AMP?; air + AMP?; placed. See Statics.] 1. A balloon.

p.def: A balloonist; an aAMPeuml;ronaut.

dictionary.p: {A`AMPeuml;r*o*stat"ic (AMP?;), A`AMPeuml;r*o*stat"ic*al (AMP?;),} a. [AAMPeuml;ro- + Gr. AMP?;: cf. F. aAMPeacute;rostatique. See Statical, Statics.] 1. Of or pertaining to aAMPeuml;rostatics; pneumatic.

p.def: AAMPeuml;ronautic; as, an aAMPeuml;rostatic voyage.

dictionary.p: A`AMPeuml;r*o*stat"ics (AMP?;), n. The science that treats of the equilibrium of elastic fluids, or that of bodies sustained in them. Hence it includes aAMPeuml;ronautics.
A`AMPeuml;r*os*ta"tion (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. aAMPeacute;rostation the art of using aAMPeuml;rostats.] 1. AAMPeuml;rial navigation; the art of raising and guiding balloons in the air.
2. The science of weighing air; aAMPeuml;rostatics. [Obs.]
AMPAElig;*ru"gi*nous (AMP?;), a. [L. aeruginosus, fr. aerugo rust of copper, fr. aes copper: cf. F. AMPeacute;rugineux.] Of the nature or color of verdigris, or the rust of copper.
Ae"ry (AMP?;), n. An aerie.
A"AMPeuml;r*y (AMP?;), a. [See Air.] AAMPeuml;rial; ethereal; incorporeal; visionary. [Poetic] M. Arnold.
AMPAElig;s`cu*la"pi*us (AMP?;), n. [L. Aesculapius, Gr. AMP?;.] (Myth.) The god of medicine. Hence, a physician.
AMPAElig;s"cu*lin (AMP?;), n. Same as Esculin.
AMPAElig;*so"pi*an, E*so"pi*an (AMP?;), a. [L. Aesopius, from Gr. AMP?;, fr. the famous Greek fabulist AMPAElig;sop (AMP?;).] Of or pertaining to AMPAElig;sop, or in his manner.
AMPAElig;*sop"ic, E*sop"ic (AMP?;), a. [L. Aesopicus, Gr. AMP?;.] Same as AMPAElig;sopian.

AMPAElig;s*the`si*om"e*ter, Es*the`si*om"e*ter (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; (see AMPAElig;sthesia) + -meter.] An instrument to measure the degree of sensation, by determining at how short a distance two impressions upon the skin can be distinguished, and thus to determine whether the condition of tactile sensibility is normal or altered.
||AMPAElig;s*the""sis (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?;.] Sensuous perception. [R.] Ruskin.
AMPAElig;s`the*sod"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; sensation + AMP?; a way; cf. F. esthAMPeacute;sodique.] (Physiol.) Conveying sensory or afferent impulses; AMPmdash; said of nerves.
AMPAElig;s"thete (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; one who perceives.] One who makes much or overmuch of AMPaelig;sthetics. [Recent]
{AMPAElig;s*thet"ic (AMP?;), AMPAElig;s*thet"ic*al (AMP?;),} a. Of or Pertaining to AMPaelig;sthetics; versed in AMPaelig;sthetics; as, AMPaelig;sthetic studies, emotions, ideas, persons, etc.
-- AMPAElig;s*thet"ic*al*ly, adv.
AMPAElig;s`the*ti"can (AMP?;), n. One versed in AMPaelig;sthetics.
AMPAElig;s*thet"i*cism (AMP?;), n. The doctrine of AMPaelig;sthetics; AMPaelig;sthetic principles; devotion to the beautiful in nature and art. Lowell.

AMPAElig;s*thet"ics, Es*thet"ics (AMP?;; 277), n. [Gr. AMP?; perceptive, esp. by feeling, fr. AMP?; to perceive, feel: cf. G. AMPauml;sthetik, F. esthAMPeacute;tique.] The theory or philosophy of taste; the science of the beautiful in nature and art; esp. that which treats of the expression and embodiment of beauty by art.
AMPAElig;s"ti*val (AMP?;), a. [L. aestivalis, aestivus, fr. aestas summer.] Of or belonging to the summer; as, AMPaelig;stival diseases. [Spelt also estival.]
AMPAElig;s"ti*vate (AMP?;), v. i. [L. aestivare, aestivatum.] 1. To spend the summer.

p.def: To pass the summer in a state of torpor.

dictionary.p: [Spelt also estivate.]
AMPAElig;s`ti*va"tion (AMP?;), n. 1. (ZoAMPouml;l.) The state of torpidity induced by the heat and dryness of summer, as in certain snails; -- opposed to hibernation.

p.def: The arrangement of the petals in a flower bud, as to folding, overlapping, etc.; prefloration.

dictionary.p: [Spelt also estivation.]
AMPAElig;s"tu*a*ry (?; 135), n. AMP a. See Estuary.
AMPAElig;s"tu*ous (AMP?;), a. [L. aestuosus, fr. aestus fire, glow.] Glowing; agitated, as with heat.
AMPAElig;"ther (AMP?;), n. See Ether.
AMPAElig;"thi*ops min"er*al (AMP?;). (Chem.) Same as Ethiops mineral. [Obs.]
AMPAElig;th"o*gen (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; fire, light + -gen.] (Chem.) A compound of nitrogen and boroAMP?;, which, when heated before the blowpipe, gives a brilliant phosphorescent; boric nitride.

AMPAElig;"thri*o*scope (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; clear + AMP?; to observe.] An instrument consisting in part of a differential thermometer. It is used for measuring changes of temperature produced by different conditions of the sky, as when clear or clouded.
AMPAElig;`ti*o*log"ic*al (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to AMPaelig;tiology; assigning a cause. -- AMPAElig;`ti*o*log"ic*al*ly, adv.

AMPAElig;`ti*ol"o*gy (AMP?;), n. [L. aetologia, Gr. AMP?;; AMP?; cause + AMP?; description: cf. F. AMPeacute;tiologie.] 1. The science, doctrine, or demonstration of causes; esp., the investigation of the causes of any disease; the science of the origin and development of things.

p.def: The assignment of a cause.

dictionary.p: ||A`AMPeuml;*ti"tes (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?; (sc. AMP?;) stone, fr. AMP?; eagle.] See Eaglestone.
A*far" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- (for on or of) + far.] At, to, or from a great distance; far away; -- often used with from preceding, or off following; as, he was seen from afar; I saw him afar off.

p.blockquote:
The steep where Fame's proud temple shines afar.
Beattie.

dictionary.p: A*feard" (AMPadot;*fAMPemacr;rd"), p. a. [OE. afered, AS. AMPamacr;fAMPaemacr;red, p. p. of AMPamacr;fAMPaemacr;ran to frighten; AMPamacr;- (cf. Goth. us- , Ger. er-, orig. meaning out) + fAMPaemacr;ran to frighten. See Fear.] Afraid. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Be not afeard; the isle is full of noises.
Shak.

dictionary.p: ||A"fer (AMP?;), n. [L.] The southwest wind. Milton.

Af`fa*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. [L. affabilitas: cf. F. affabilitAMPeacute;.] The quality of being affable; readiness to converse; courteousness in receiving others and in conversation; complaisant behavior.

p.blockquote:
Affability is of a wonderful efficacy or power in procuring love.
Elyot

dictionary.p: Af"fa*ble (AMP?;), a. [F. affable, L. affabilis, fr. affari to speak to; ad + fari to speak. See Fable.] 1. Easy to be spoken to or addressed; receiving others kindly and conversing with them in a free and friendly manner; courteous; sociable.

p.blockquote:
An affable and courteous gentleman.
Shak.

His manners polite and affable.
Macaulay.

p.def: Gracious; mild; benign.

p.blockquote:
A serene and affable countenance.
Tatler.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Courteous; civil; complaisant; accessible; mild; benign; condescending.
Af"fa*ble*ness, n. Affability.
Af"fa*bly, adv. In an affable manner; courteously.
Af"fa*brous (AMPabreve;f*fAMPadot;"brAMPubreve;s), a. [L. affaber workmanlike; ad + faber.] Executed in a workmanlike manner; ingeniously made. [R.] Bailey.

Af*fair" (AMPabreve;f*fAMPacirc;r"), n. [OE. afere, affere, OF. afaire, F. affaire, fr. a faire to do; L.. ad + facere to do. See Fact, and cf. Ado.] 1. That which is done or is to be done; matter; concern; as, a difficult affair to manage; business of any kind, commercial, professional, or public; -- often in the plural. "At the head of affairs." Junius. "A talent for affairs." Prescott.

p.def: Any proceeding or action which it is wished to refer to or characterize vaguely; as, an affair of honor, i. e., a duel; an affair of love, i. e., an intrigue.
An action or engagement not of sufficient magnitude to be called a battle.

dictionary.p: 4. Action; endeavor. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
And with his best affair
Obeyed the pleasure of the Sun.
Chapman.

p.def: A material object (vaguely designated).

p.blockquote:
A certain affair of fine red cloth much worn and faded.
Hawthorne.

dictionary.p: Af*fam"ish (AMPabreve;f*fAMPabreve;m"AMPibreve;sh), v. t. AMP i. [F. affamer, fr. L. ad + fames hunger. See Famish.] To afflict with, or perish from, hunger. [Obs.] Spenser.
Af*fam"ish*ment (-ment), n. Starvation. Bp. Hall.
Af*fat"u*ate (AMP?;), v. t. [L. ad + fatuus foolish.] To infatuate. [Obs.] Milton.
Af*fear" (AMP?;), v. t. [OE. aferen, AS. AMPamacr;fAMP?;ran. See Afeard.] To frighten. [Obs.] Spenser.

Af*fect" (AMPabreve;f*fAMPebreve;kt"), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Affected; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Affecting.] [L. affectus, p. p. of afficere to affect by active agency; ad + facere to make: cf. F. affectere, L. affectare, freq. of afficere. See Fact.] 1. To act upon; to produce an effect or change upon.

p.blockquote:
As might affect the earth with cold heat.
Milton.

The climate affected their health and spirits.
Macaulay.

p.def: To influence or move, as the feelings or passions; to touch.

p.blockquote: A consideration of the rationale of our passions seems to me very necessary for all who would affect them upon solid and pure principles.

dictionary.p: 3. To love; to regard with affection. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
As for Queen Katharine, he rather respected than affected, rather honored than loved, her.
Fuller.

p.def: To show a fondness for; to like to use or practice; to choose; hence, to frequent habitually.

p.blockquote:
For he does neither affect company, nor is he fit for it, indeed.
Shak.

Do not affect the society of your inferiors in rank, nor court that of the great.
Hazlitt.

p.def: To dispose or incline.

p.blockquote:
Men whom they thought best affected to religion and their country's liberty.
Milton.

dictionary.p: 6. To aim at; to aspire; to covet. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
This proud man affects imperial AMP?;way.
Dryden.

p.def: To tend to by affinity or disposition.

p.blockquote:
The drops of every fluid affect a round figure.
Newton.

p.def: To make a show of; to put on a pretense of; to feign; to assume; as, to affect ignorance.

p.blockquote:
Careless she is with artful care,
Affecting to seem unaffected.
Congreve.

Thou dost affect my manners.
Shak.

dictionary.p: 9. To assign; to appoint. [R.]

p.blockquote:
One of the domestics was affected to his special service.
Thackeray.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To influence; operate; act on; concern; move; melt; soften; subdue; overcome; pretend; assume.
Af*fect", n. [L. affectus.] Affection; inclination; passion; feeling; disposition. [Obs.] Shak.
Af`fec*ta"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. affectatio: cf. F. affectation.] 1. An attempt to assume or exhibit what is not natural or real; false display; artificial show. "An affectation of contempt." Macaulay.

p.blockquote:
Affectation is an awkward and forced imitation of what should be genuine and easy, wanting the beauty that accompanies what is natural what is natural.
Locke.

dictionary.p: 2. A striving after. [Obs.] Bp. Pearson.
3. Fondness; affection. [Obs.] Hooker.
Af`fec*ta"tion*ist, n. One who exhibits affectation. [R.] Fitzed. Hall.

p.blockquote:
His affected Hercules.
Chapman.

p.def: Inclined; disposed; attached.

p.blockquote:
How stand you affected to his wish?
Shak.

p.def: Given to false show; assuming or pretending to possess what is not natural or real.

p.blockquote:
He is . . . too spruce, too affected, too odd.
Shak.

p.def: Assumed artificially; not natural.

p.blockquote:
Affected coldness and indifference.
Addison.

p.def: Made up of terms involving different powers of the unknown quantity; adfected; as, an affected equation.

dictionary.p: Af*fect"ed*ly, adv. 1. In an affected manner; hypocritically; with more show than reality.
2. Lovingly; with tender care. [Obs.] Shak.
Af*fect"ed*ness, n. Affectation.
Af*fect"er (AMP?;), n. One who affects, assumes, pretends, or strives after. "Affecters of wit." Abp. Secker.
Af*fect`i*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. The quality or state of being affectible. [R.]
Af*fect"i*ble (AMP?;), a. That may be affected. [R.]

p.blockquote:
Lay aside the absolute, and, by union with the creaturely, become affectible.
Coleridge.

dictionary.p: Af*fect"ing, a. 1. Moving the emotions; fitted to excite the emotions; pathetic; touching; as, an affecting address; an affecting sight.

p.blockquote:
The most affecting music is generally the most simple.
Mitford.

dictionary.p: 2. Affected; given to false show. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
A drawling; affecting rouge.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Af*fect"ing*ly (AMP?;), adv. In an affecting manner; is a manner to excite emotions.
Af*fec"tion (AMP?;), n. [F. affection, L. affectio, fr. afficere. See Affect.] 1. The act of affecting or acting upon; the state of being affected.
2. An attribute; a quality or property; a condition; a bodily state; as, figure, weight, etc. , are affections of bodies. "The affections of quantity." Boyle.

p.blockquote:
And, truly, waking dreams were, more or less,
An old and strange affection of the house.
Tennyson.

p.def: Bent of mind; a feeling or natural impulse or natural impulse acting upon and swaying the mind; any emotion; as, the benevolent affections, esteem, gratitude, etc.; the malevolent affections, hatred, envy, etc.; inclination; disposition; propensity; tendency.

p.blockquote:
Affection is applicable to an unpleasant as well as a pleasant state of the mind, when impressed by any object or quality.
Cogan.

p.def: A settled good will; kind feeling; love; zealous or tender attachment; -- often in the pl. Formerly followed by to, but now more generally by for or towards; as, filial, social, or conjugal affections; to have an affection for or towards children.

p.blockquote:
All his affections are set on his own country.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: 5. Prejudice; bias. [Obs.] Bp. Aylmer.

p.def: Disease; morbid symptom; malady; as, a pulmonary affection.
The lively representation of any emotion.

dictionary.p: 8. Affectation. [Obs.] "Spruce affection." Shak.
9. Passion; violent emotion. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Most wretched man,
That to affections does the bridle lend.
Spenser.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Attachment; passion; tenderness; fondness; kindness; love; good will. See Attachment; Disease.
Af*fec"tion*al (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to the affections; as, affectional impulses; an affectional nature.
Af*fec"tion*ate (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. affectionnAMPeacute;.] 1. Having affection or warm regard; loving; fond; as, an affectionate brother.
2. Kindly inclined; zealous. [Obs.] Johson.

p.blockquote:
Man, in his love God, and desire to please him, can never be too affectionate.
Sprat.

dictionary.p: 4. Strongly inclined; -- with to. [Obs.] Bacon.
Syn. -- Tender; attached; loving; devoted; warm; fond; earnest; ardent.
Af*fec"tion*a`ted, a. Disposed; inclined. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Affectionated to the people.
Holinshed.

dictionary.p: Af*fec"tion*ate*ly, adv. With affection; lovingly; fondly; tenderly; kindly.
Af*fec"tion*ate*ness, n. The quality of being affectionate; fondness; affection.
Af*fec"tioned (AMP?;), a. 1. Disposed. [Archaic]

p.blockquote:
Be kindly affectioned one to another.
Rom. xii. 10.

dictionary.p: 2. Affected; conceited. [Obs.] Shak.

p.def: Pertaining to or exciting emotion; affectional; emotional.

dictionary.p: Af*fec"tive*ly, adv. In an affective manner; impressively; emotionally.
Af*fec"tu*ous (?; 135), a. [L. affectuous: cf. F. affectueux. See Affect.] Full of passion or emotion; earnest. [Obs.] -- Af*fec"tu*ous*ly, adv. [Obs.] Fabyan.

Af*feer" (AMP?;), v. t. [OF. aforer, afeurer, to tax, appraise, assess, fr. L. ad + forum market, court of justice, in LL. also meaning price.] 1. To confirm; to assure. [Obs.] "The title is affeered." Shak.

p.def: To assess or reduce, as an arbitrary penalty or amercement, to a certain and reasonable sum.

p.blockquote:
Amercements . . . were affeered by the judges.
Blackstone.

dictionary.p: Af*feer"ment (AMP?;), n. [Cf. OF. aforement.] (Old Law) The act of affeering. Blackstone.

Af"fer*ent (AMP?;), a. [L. afferens, p. pr. of afferre; ad + ferre to bear.] (Physiol.) Bearing or conducting inwards to a part or organ; -- opposed to efferent; as, afferent vessels; afferent nerves, which convey sensations from the external organs to the brain.
||Af*fet`tu*o"so (AMP?;), adv. [It.] (Mus.) With feeling.

Af*fi"ance (AMP?;), n. [OE. afiaunce trust, confidence, OF. afiance, fr. afier to trust, fr. LL. affidare to trust; ad + fidare to trust, fr. L. fides faith. See Faith, and cf. Affidavit, Affy, Confidence.] 1. Plighted faith; marriage contract or promise.

p.def: Trust; reliance; faith; confidence.

p.blockquote:
Such feelings promptly yielded to his habitual affiance in the divine love.
Sir J. Stephen.

Lancelot, my Lancelot, thou in whom I have
Most joy and most affiance.
Tennyson.

dictionary.p: Af*fi"ance, v. t. [imp. AMP?; p. p. Affianced (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP?; vb. n. Affiancing (AMP?;).] [Cf. OF. afiancier, fr. afiance.] 1. To betroth; to pledge one's faith to for marriage, or solemnly promise (one's self or another) in marriage.

p.blockquote:
To me, sad maid, he was affianced.
Spenser.

dictionary.p: 2. To assure by promise. [Obs.] Pope.
Af*fi"an*cer (AMP?;), n. One who makes a contract of marriage between two persons.
Af*fi"ant (AMP?;), n. [From p. pr. of OF. afier, LL. affidare. See Affidavit.] (Law) One who makes an affidavit. [U. S.] Burrill.
Syn. -- Deponent. See Deponent.

Af`fi*da"vit (AMP?;), n. [LL. affidavit he has made oath, perfect tense of affidare. See Affiance, Affy.] (Law) A sworn statement in writing; a declaration in writing, signed and made upon oath before an authorized magistrate. Bouvier. Burrill.
AMPfist; It is always made ex parte, and without cross-examination, and in this differs from a deposition. It is also applied to written statements made on affirmation.
Syn. -- Deposition. See Deposition.
Af*file" (AMP?;), v. t. [OF. afiler, F. affiler, to sharpen; a (L. ad) + fil thread, edge.] To polish. [Obs.]
Af*fil"i*a*ble (AMP?;), a. Capable of being affiliated to or on, or connected with in origin.

Af*fil"i*ate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Affiliated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Affiliating (AMP?;).] [LL. adfiliare, affiliare, to adopt as son; ad + filius son: cf. F. affilier.] 1. To adopt; to receive into a family as a son; hence, to bring or receive into close connection; to ally.

p.blockquote:
Is the soul affiliated to God, or is it estranged and in rebellion?
I. Taylor.

p.def: To fix the paternity of; -- said of an illegitimate child; as, to affiliate the child to (or on or upon) one man rather than another.
To connect in the way of descent; to trace origin to.

p.blockquote:
How do these facts tend to affiliate the faculty of hearing upon the aboriginal vegetative processes?
H. Spencer.

p.def: To attach (to) or unite (with); to receive into a society as a member, and initiate into its mysteries, plans, etc.; -- followed by to or with.

dictionary.p: Affiliated societies, societies connected with a central society, or with each other.
Af*fil"i*ate, v. i. To connect or associate one's self; -- followed by with; as, they affiliate with no party.
Af*fil`i*a"tion (AMP?;), n. [F. affiliation, LL. affiliatio.] 1. Adoption; association or reception as a member in or of the same family or society.

p.def: Connection in the way of descent.

dictionary.p: Af*fi"nal (AMP?;), a. [L. affinis.] Related by marriage; from the same source.
Af*fine" (AMP?;), v. t. [F. affiner to refine; AMP?; (L. ad) + fin fine. See Fine.] To refine. [Obs.] Holland.

Af*fined" (AMP?;), a. [OF. afinAMPeacute; related, p. p., fr. LL. affinare to join, fr. L. affinis neighboring, related to; ad + finis boundary, limit.] Joined in affinity or by any tie. [Obs.] "All affined and kin." Shak.
Af*fin"i*ta*tive (AMP?;), a. Of the nature of affinity. -- Af*fin"i*ta*tive*ly, adv.
Af*fin"i*tive, a. Closely connected, as by affinity.
Af*fin"i*ty (AMP?;), n.; pl. Affinities(AMP?;). [OF. afinitAMPeacute;, F. affinitAMPeacute;, L. affinites, fr. affinis. See Affined.]

p.def: Relationship by marriage (as between a husband and his wife's blood relations, or between a wife and her husband's blood relations); -- in contradistinction to consanguinity, or relationship by blood; -- followed by with, to, or between.

p.blockquote:
Solomon made affinity with Pharaoh.
1 Kings iii. 1.

There is a close affinity between imposture and credulity.
Sir G. C. Lewis.

dictionary.p: 2. Companionship; acquaintance. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
About forty years past, I began a happy affinity with William Cranmer.
Burton.

p.def: That attraction which takes place, at an insensible distance, between the heterogeneous particles of bodies, and unites them to form chemical compounds; chemism; chemical or elective affinity or attraction.
A relation between species or higheAMP?; groups dependent on resemblance in the whole plan of structure, and indicating community of origin.
A superior spiritual relationship or attraction held to exist sometimes between persons, esp. persons of the opposite sex; also, the man or woman who exerts such psychical or spiritual attraction.

dictionary.p: Af*firm" (AMPabreve;f*fAMPetilde;rm"), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Affirmed (-fAMPetilde;rmd"); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Affirming.] [OE. affermen, OF. afermer, F. affirmer, affermir, fr. L. affirmare; ad + firmare to make firm, firmus firm. See Firm.] 1. To make firm; to confirm, or ratify; esp. (Law), to assert or confirm, as a judgment, decree, or order, brought before an appellate court for review.

p.def: To assert positively; to tell with confidence; to aver; to maintain as true; -- opposed to deny.

p.blockquote:
Jesus, . . . whom Paul affirmed to be alive.
Acts xxv. 19.

p.def: To declare, as a fact, solemnly, under judicial sanction. See Affirmation, 4.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To assert; aver; declare; asseverate; assure; pronounce; protest; avouch; confirm; establish; ratify. -- To Affirm, Asseverate, Aver, Protest. We affirm when we declare a thing as a fact or a proposition. We asseverate it in a peculiarly earnest manner, or with increased positiveness as what can not be disputed. We aver it, or formally declare it to be true, when we have positive knowledge of it. We protest in a more public manner and with the energy of perfect sincerity. People asseverate in order to produce a conviction of their veracity; they aver when they are peculiarly desirous to be believed; they protest when they wish to free themselves from imputations, or to produce a conviction of their innocence.
Af*firm", v. i. 1. To declare or assert positively.

p.blockquote:
Not that I so affirm, though so it seem
To thee, who hast thy dwelling here on earth.
Milton.

p.def: To make a solemn declaration, before an authorized magistrate or tribunal, under the penalties of perjury; to testify by affirmation.

dictionary.p: Af*firm"a*ble (AMP?;), a. Capable of being affirmed, asserted, or declared; -- followed by of; as, an attribute affirmable of every just man.

p.blockquote:
This statute . . . in affirmance of the common law.
Bacon.

p.def: A strong declaration; affirmation.

dictionary.p: Af*firm"ant (AMPabreve;f*fAMPetilde;rm"ant), n. [L. affirmans, -antis, p. pr. See Affirm.] 1. One who affirms or asserts.

p.def: One who affirms, instead of taking an oath.

dictionary.p: Af`fir*ma"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. affirmatio: cf. F. affirmation.] 1. Confirmation of anything established; ratification; as, the affirmation of a law. Hooker.

p.def: The act of affirming or asserting as true; assertion; -- opposed to negation or denial.
That which is asserted; an assertion; a positive statement; an averment; as, an affirmation, by the vender, of title to property sold, or of its quality.
A solemn declaration made under the penalties of perjury, by persons who conscientiously decline taking an oath, which declaration is in law equivalent to an oath.

dictionary.p: Af*firm"a*tive (AMP?;), a. [L. affirmativus: cf. F. affirmatif.] 1. Confirmative; ratifying; as, an act affirmative of common law.

p.def: That affirms; asserting that the fact is so; declaratory of what exists; answering "yes" to a question; -- opposed to negative; as, an affirmative answer; an affirmative vote.

dictionary.p: 3. Positive; dogmatic. [Obs.] J. Taylor.

p.blockquote:
Lysicles was a little by the affirmative air of Crito.
Berkeley.

p.def: Expressing the agreement of the two terms of a proposition.
Positive; -- a term applied to quantities which are to be added, and opposed to negative, or such as are to be subtracted.

dictionary.p: Af*firm"a*tive, n. 1. That which affirms as opposed to that which denies; an affirmative proposition; that side of question which affirms or maintains the proposition stated; -- opposed to negative; as, there were forty votes in the affirmative, and ten in the negative.

p.blockquote:
Whether there are such beings or not, 't is sufficient for my purpose that many have believed the affirmative.
Dryden.

p.def: A word or phrase expressing affirmation or assent; as, yes, that is so, etc.

dictionary.p: Af*firm"a*tive*ly, adv. In an affirmative manner; on the affirmative side of a question; in the affirmative; -- opposed to negatively.
Af*firm"a*to*ry (AMP?;), a. Giving affirmation; assertive; affirmative. Massey.
Af*firm"er (AMP?;), n. One who affirms.

Af*fix" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Affixed (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Affixing.] [LL. affixare, L. affixus, p. p. of affigere to fasten to; ad + figere to fasten: cf. OE. affichen, F. afficher, ultimately fr. L. affigere. See Fix.] 1. To subjoin, annex, or add at the close or end; to append to; to fix to any part of; as, to affix a syllable to a word; to affix a seal to an instrument; to affix one's name to a writing.

p.def: To fix or fasten in any way; to attach physically.

p.blockquote:
Should they [caterpillars] affix them to the leaves of a plant improper for their food.
Ray.

p.def: To attach, unite, or connect with; as, names affixed to ideas, or ideas affixed to things; to affix a stigma to a person; to affix ridicule or blame to any one.

dictionary.p: 4. To fix or fasten figuratively; -- with on or upon; as, eyes affixed upon the ground. [Obs.] Spenser.
Syn. -- To attach; subjoin; connect; annex; unite.

Af"fix (AMP?;), n.; pl. Affixes (#). [L. affixus, p. p. of affigere: cf. F. affixe.] That which is affixed; an appendage; esp. one or more letters or syllables added at the end of a word; a suffix; a postfix.
Af*fix"ion (AMP?;), n. [L. affixio, fr. affigere.] Affixture. [Obs.] T. Adams.
Af*fix"ture (?; 135), n. The act of affixing, or the state of being affixed; attachment.
Af*fla"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. afflatus, p. p. of afflare to blow or breathe on; ad + flare to blow.] A blowing or breathing on; inspiration.
Af*fla"tus (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. afflare. See Afflation.] 1. A breath or blast of wind.

p.def: A divine impartation of knowledge; supernatural impulse; inspiration.

p.blockquote:
A poet writing against his genius will be like a prophet without his afflatus.
Spence.

dictionary.p: Af*flict" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Afflicted; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Afflicting.] [L. afflictus, p. p. of affigere to cast down, deject; ad + fligere to strike: cf. OF. aflit, afflict, p. p. Cf. Flagellate.] 1. To strike or cast down; to overthrow. [Obs.] "Reassembling our afflicted powers." Milton.

p.def: To inflict some great injury or hurt upon, causing continued pain or mental distress; to trouble grievously; to torment.

p.blockquote:
They did set over them taskmasters to afflict them with their burdens.
Exod. i. 11.

That which was the worst now least afflicts me.
Milton.

dictionary.p: 3. To make low or humble. [Obs.] Spenser.

p.blockquote:
Men are apt to prefer a prosperous error before an afflicted truth.
Jer. Taylor.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To trouble; grieve; pain; distress; harass; torment; wound; hurt.
Af*flict", p. p. AMP a. [L. afflictus, p. p.] Afflicted. [Obs.] Becon.
Af*flict"ed*ness, n. The state of being afflicted; affliction. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Af*flict"er (AMP?;), n. One who afflicts.
Af*flic"tion (AMP?;), n. [F. affliction, L. afflictio, fr. affligere.] 1. The cause of continued pain of body or mind, as sickness, losses, etc.; an instance of grievous distress; a pain or grief.

p.blockquote:
To repay that money will be a biting affliction.
Shak.

p.def: The state of being afflicted; a state of pain, distress, or grief.

p.blockquote:
Some virtues are seen only in affliction.
Addison.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Calamity; sorrow; distress; grief; pain; adversity; misery; wretchedness; misfortune; trouble; hardship. -- Affliction, Sorrow, Grief, Distress. Affliction and sorrow are terms of wide and general application; grief and distress have reference to particular cases. Affliction is the stronger term. The suffering lies deeper in the soul, and usually arises from some powerful cause, such as the loss of what is most dear -- friends, health, etc. We do not speak of mere sickness or pain as "an affliction," though one who suffers from either is said to be afflicted; but deprivations of every kind, such as deafness, blindness, loss of limbs, etc., are called afflictions, showing that term applies particularly to prolonged sources of suffering. Sorrow and grief are much alike in meaning, but grief is the stronger term of the two, usually denoting poignant mental suffering for some definite cause, as, grief for the death of a dear friend; sorrow is more reflective, and is tinged with regret, as, the misconduct of a child is looked upon with sorrow. Grief is often violent and demonstrative; sorrow deep and brooding. Distress implies extreme suffering, either bodily or mental. In its higher stages, it denotes pain of a restless, agitating kind, and almost always supposes some struggle of mind or body. Affliction is allayed, grief subsides, sorrow is soothed, distress is mitigated.
Af*flic"tion*less (AMP?;), a. Free from affliction.
Af*flic"tive (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. afflictif.] Giving pain; causing continued or repeated pain or grief; distressing. "Jove's afflictive hand." Pope.

p.blockquote:
Spreads slow disease, and darts afflictive pain.
Prior.

dictionary.p: Af*flic"tive*ly, adv. In an afflictive manner.
Af"flu*ence (AMP?;), n. [F. affluence, L. affluentia, fr. affluens, p. pr. of affluere to flow to; ad + fluere to flow. See Flux.] 1. A flowing to or towards; a concourse; an influx.

p.blockquote:
The affluence of young nobles from hence into Spain.
Wotton.

There is an unusual affluence of strangers this year.
Carlyle.

p.def: An abundant supply, as of thought, words, feelings, etc.; profusion; also, abundance of property; wealth.

p.blockquote:
And old age of elegance, affluence, and ease.
Coldsmith.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Abundance; riches; profusion; exuberance; plenty; wealth; opulence.
Af"flu*en*cy (AMP?;), n. Affluence. [Obs.] Addison.
Af"flu*ent (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. affluent, L. affluens, -entis, p. pr. See Affluence.] 1. Flowing to; flowing abundantly. "Affluent blood." Harvey.

p.def: Abundant; copious; plenteous; hence, wealthy; abounding in goods or riches.

p.blockquote:
Language . . . affluent in expression.
H. Reed.

Loaded and blest with all the affluent store,
Which human vows at smoking shrines implore.
Prior.

dictionary.p: Af"flu*ent, n. A stream or river flowing into a larger river or into a lake; a tributary stream.
Af"flu*ent*ly, adv. Abundantly; copiously.
Af*flu*ent*ness, n. Great plenty. [R.]
Af"flux` (AMP?;), n. [L. affluxum, p. p. of affluere: cf. F. afflux. See Affluence.] A flowing towards; that which flows to; as, an afflux of blood to the head.
Af*flux"ion (AMP?;), n. The act of flowing towards; afflux. Sir T. Browne.
Af"fo*dill (AMP?;), n. Asphodel. [Obs.]
Af*force" (AMP?;), v. t. [OF. afforcier, LL. affortiare; ad + fortiare, fr. L. fortis strong.] To reAMPeuml;nforce; to strengthen. Hallam.
Af*force"ment (AMP?;), n. [OF.] 1. A fortress; a fortification for defense. [Obs.] Bailey.

p.def: A reAMPeuml;nforcement; a strengthening.

dictionary.p: Af*for"ci*a*ment (AMP?;), n. See Afforcement. [Obs.]

Af*ford" (AMPabreve;f*fAMPomacr;rd"), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Afforded; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Affording.] [OE. aforthen, AS. geforAMPeth;ian, forAMPeth;ian, to further, accomplish, afford, fr. forAMPeth; forth, forward. The prefix ge- has no well defined sense. See Forth.] 1. To give forth; to supply, yield, or produce as the natural result, fruit, or issue; as, grapes afford wine; olives afford oil; the earth affords fruit; the sea affords an abundant supply of fish.

p.def: To give, grant, or confer, with a remoter reference to its being the natural result; to provide; to furnish; as, a good life affords consolation in old age.

p.blockquote:
His tuneful Muse affords the sweetest numbers.
Addison.

The quiet lanes . . . afford calmer retreats.
Gilpin.

p.def: To offer, provide, or supply, as in selling, granting, expending, with profit, or without loss or too great injury; as, A affords his goods cheaper than B; a man can afford a sum yearly in charity.
To incur, stand, or bear without serious detriment, as an act which might under other circumstances be injurious; -- with an auxiliary, as can, could, might, etc.; to be able or rich enough.

p.blockquote:
The merchant can afford to trade for smaller profits.
Hamilton.

He could afford to suffer
With those whom he saw suffer.
Wordsworth.

dictionary.p: Af*ford"a*ble (AMP?;), a. That may be afforded.
Af*ford"ment (AMP?;), n. Anything given as a help; bestowal. [Obs.]
Af*for"est (AMP?;), v. t. [LL. afforestare; ad + forestare. See Forest.] To convert into a forest; as, to afforest a tract of country.
Af*for`es*ta"tion (AMP?;), n. The act of converting into forest or woodland. Blackstone.
Af*form"a*tive (AMP?;), n. An affix.
Af*fran"chise (AMP?;), v. t. [F. affranchir; AMP?; (L. ad) + franc free. See Franchise and Frank.] To make free; to enfranchise. Johnson.
Af*frap" (AMP?;), v. t. AMP i. [Cf. It. affrappare, frappare, to cut, mince, F. frapper to strike. See Frap.] To strike, or strike down. [Obs.] Spenser.

Af*fray" (AMP?;), v. t. [p. p. Affrayed.] [OE. afraien, affraien, OF. effreer, esfreer, F. effrayer, orig. to disquiet, put out of peace, fr. L. ex + OHG. fridu peace (akin to E. free). Cf. Afraid, Fray, Frith inclosure.] [Archaic] 1. To startle from quiet; to alarm.

p.blockquote:
Smale foules a great heap
That had afrayed [affrayed] me out of my sleep.
Chaucer.

p.def: To frighten; to scare; to frighten away.

p.blockquote:
That voice doth us affray.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Af*fray" (AMP?;), n. [OE. afrai, affrai, OF. esfrei, F. effroi, fr. OF. esfreer. See Affray, v. t.] 1. The act of suddenly disturbing any one; an assault or attack. [Obs.]
2. Alarm; terror; fright. [Obs.] Spenser.
3. A tumultuous assault or quarrel; a brawl; a fray. "In the very midst of the affray." Motley.

p.def: The fighting of two or more persons, in a public place, to the terror of others.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; A fighting in private is not, in a legal sense, an affray.
Syn. -- Quarrel; brawl; scuffle; encounter; fight; contest; feud; tumult; disturbance.
Af*fray"er (AMP?;), n. One engaged in an affray.
Af*fray"ment (AMP?;), n. Affray. [Obs.] Spenser.
Af*freight" (AMP?;), v. t. [Pref. ad- + freight: cf. F. affrAMPeacute;ter. See Freight.] To hire, as a ship, for the transportation of goods or freight.
Af*freight"er (AMP?;), n. One who hires or charters a ship to convey goods.
Af*freight"ment (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. affrAMPeacute;tement.] The act of hiring, or the contract for the use of, a vessel, or some part of it, to convey cargo.
Af*fret" (AMP?;), n. [Cf. It. affrettare to hasten, fretta haste.] A furious onset or attack. [Obs.] Spenser.
Af*fric"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. affricare to rub on. See Friction.] The act of rubbing against. [Obs.]

Af*fright" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Affrighted; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Affrighting.] [Orig. p. p.; OE. afright, AS. AMPamacr;fyrhtan to terrify; AMPamacr;- (cf. Goth. us-, Ger. er-, orig. meaning out) + fyrhto fright. See Fright.] To impress with sudden fear; to frighten; to alarm.

p.blockquote:
Dreams affright our souls.
Shak.

A drear and dying sound
Affrights the flamens at their service quaint.
Milton.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To terrify; frighten; alarm; dismay; appall; scare; startle; daunt; intimidate.
Af*fright", p. a. Affrighted. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Af*fright", n. 1. Sudden and great fear; terror. It expresses a stronger impression than fear, or apprehension, perhaps less than terror.

p.blockquote:
He looks behind him with affright, and forward with despair.
Goldsmith.

p.def: The act of frightening; also, a cause of terror; an object of dread.

dictionary.p: Af*fright"ed*ly, adv. With fright. Drayton.
Af*fright"en (AMP?;), v. t. To frighten. [Archaic] "Fit tales . . . to affrighten babes." Southey.
Af*fright"er (AMP?;), n. One who frightens. [Archaic]

p.blockquote:
Bugbears or affrightful apparitions.
Cudworth.

dictionary.p: Af*fright"ment (AMP?;), n. Affright; the state of being frightened; sudden fear or alarm. [Archaic]

p.blockquote:
Passionate words or blows . . . fill the child's mind with terror and affrightment.
Locke.

dictionary.p: Af*front" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Affronted; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Affronting.] [OF. afronter, F. affronter, to confront, LL. affrontare to strike against, fr. L. ad + frons forehead, front. See Front.] 1. To front; to face in position; to meet or encounter face to face. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
All the sea-coasts do affront the Levant.
Holland.

That he, as 't were by accident, may here
Affront Ophelia.
Shak.

dictionary.p: 2. To face in defiance; to confront; as, to affront death; hence, to meet in hostile encounter. [Archaic]

p.blockquote:
How can any one imagine that the fathers would have dared to affront the wife of Aurelius?
Addison.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To insult; abuse; outrage; wound; illtreat; slight; defy; offend; provoke; pique; nettle.
Af*front", n. [Cf. F. affront, fr. affronter.] 1. An encounter either friendly or hostile. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
I walked about, admired of all, and dreaded
On hostile ground, none daring my affront.
Milton.

Offering an affront to our understanding.
Addison.

p.def: An offense to one's self-respect; shame.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Affront, Insult, Outrage. An affront is a designed mark of disrespect, usually in the presence of others. An insult is a personal attack either by words or actions, designed to humiliate or degrade. An outrage is an act of extreme and violent insult or abuse. An affront piques and mortifies; an insult irritates and provokes; an outrage wounds and injures.

p.blockquote:
Captious persons construe every innocent freedom into an affront. When people are in a state of animosity, they seek opportunities of offering each other insults. Intoxication or violent passion impels men to the commission of outrages.
Crabb.

dictionary.p: Af*fron*tAMPeacute;" (AMP?;), a. [F. affrontAMPeacute;, p. p.] (Her.) Face to face, or front to front; facing.
Af*front"ed*ly (AMP?;), adv. Shamelessly. [Obs.] Bacon.
Af*fron*tee", n. One who receives an affront. Lytton.
Af*front"er (AMP?;), n. One who affronts, or insults to the face.
Af*front"ing*ly, adv. In an affronting manner.
Af*front"ive (AMP?;), a. Tending to affront or offend; offensive; abusive.

p.blockquote:
How affrontive it is to despise mercy.
South.

dictionary.p: Af*front"ive*ness (AMPabreve;f*frAMPubreve;nt"AMPibreve;v*nAMPebreve;s), n. The quality that gives an affront or offense. [R.] Bailey.

Af*fuse" (AMPabreve;f*fAMPumacr;z"), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Affused (-fAMPumacr;zd"); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Affusing (AMP?;).] [L. affusus, p. p. of affundere to pour to; ad + fundere. See Fuse.] To pour out or upon. [R.]

p.blockquote:
I first affused water upon the compressed beans.
Boyle.

dictionary.p: Af*fu"sion (AMPabreve;f*fAMPumacr;"zhAMPubreve;n), n. [Cf. F. affusion.] The act of pouring upon, or sprinkling with a liquid, as water upon a child in baptism. Specifically: (Med) The act of pouring water or other fluid on the whole or a part of the body, as a remedy in disease. Dunglison.
Af*fy" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Affied (AMP?;); p. pr. Affying.] [OF. afier, LL. affidare. Cf. Affiance.] 1. To confide (one's self to, or in); to trust. [Obs.]
2. To betroth or espouse; to affiance. [Obs.] Shak.
3. To bind in faith. [Obs.] Bp. Montagu.
Af*fy", v. i. To trust or confide. [Obs.] Shak.
Af"ghan (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to Afghanistan.
Af"ghan, n. 1. A native of Afghanistan.

p.def: A kind of worsted blanket or wrap.

dictionary.p: A*field" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + field.] 1. To, in, or on the field. "We drove afield." Milton.

p.blockquote:
How jocund did they drive their team afield!
Gray.

p.def: Out of the way; astray.

p.blockquote:
Why should he wander afield at the age of fifty- five!
Trollope.

dictionary.p: A*fire" (AMPadot;*fAMPimacr;r"), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + fire.] On fire.
A*flame" (AMPadot;*flAMPamacr;m"), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + flame.] In flames; glowing with light or passion; ablaze. G. Eliot.
A*flat" (AMPadot;*flAMPabreve;t"), adv. [Pref. a- + flat.] Level with the ground; flat. [Obs.] Bacon.
A*flaunt" (AMPadot;*flAMPadd;nt"), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + flaunt.] In a flaunting state or position. Copley.
A*flick"er (AMPadot;*flAMPibreve;k"AMPetilde;r), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + flicker.] In a flickering state.
A*float" (AMPadot;*flAMPomacr;t"), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + float.] 1. Borne on the water; floating; on board ship.

p.blockquote:
On such a full sea are we now afloat.
Shak.

p.def: Moving; passing from place to place; in general circulation; as, a rumor is afloat.
Unfixed; moving without guide or control; adrift; as, our affairs are all afloat.

dictionary.p: A*flow" (AMPadot;*flAMPomacr;"), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + flow.] Flowing.

p.blockquote:
Their founts aflow with tears.
R. Browning.

dictionary.p: A*flush" (AMPadot;*flAMPubreve;sh"), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + flush, n.] In a flushed or blushing state.
A*flush", adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + flush, a.] On a level.

p.blockquote:
The bank is . . . aflush with the sea.
Swinburne.

dictionary.p: A*flut"ter (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + flutter.] In a flutter; agitated.
A*foam" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + foam.] In a foaming state; as, the sea is all afoam.
A*foot" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + foot.] 1. On foot.

p.blockquote:
We 'll walk afoot a while.
Shak.

p.def: Fig.: In motion; in action; astir; in progress.

p.blockquote:
The matter being afoot.
Shak.

dictionary.p: A*fore" (AMP?;), adv. [OE. afore, aforn, AS. onforan or AMPaelig;tforan; pref. a- + fore.] 1. Before. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
If he have never drunk wine afore.
Shak.

p.def: In the fore part of a vessel.

dictionary.p: A*fore", prep. 1. Before (in all its senses). [Archaic]

p.def: Before; in front of; farther forward than; as, afore the windlass.

dictionary.p: Afore the mast, among the common sailors; -- a phrase used to distinguish the ship's crew from the officers.
A*fore"cit`ed (AMP?;), a. Named or quoted before.
A*fore"go`ing (AMP?;), a. GoAMPimacr;ng before; foregoing.
A*fore"hand` (AMP?;) adv. Beforehand; in anticipation. [Archaic or Dial.]

p.blockquote:
She is come aforehand to anoint my body.
Mark xiv. 8.

dictionary.p: A*fore"hand`, a. Prepared; previously provided; -- opposed to behindhand. [Archaic or Dial.]

p.blockquote:
Aforehand in all matters of power.
Bacon.

dictionary.p: A*fore"men`tioned (AMP?;), a. Previously mentioned; before-mentioned. Addison.
A*fore"named` (AMP?;), a. Named before. Peacham.
A*fore"said` (AMP?;), a. Said before, or in a preceding part; already described or identified.
A*fore"thought`, n. Premeditation.
||A for`ti*o"ri (AMP?;). [L.] (Logic AMP Math.) With stronger reason.
A*foul" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + foul.] In collision; entangled. Totten.
To run afoul of, to run against or come into collision with, especially so as to become entangled or to cause injury.

A*fraid" (AMP?;), p. a. [OE. afrayed, affraide, p. p. of afraien to affray. See Affray, and cf. Afeard.] Impressed with fear or apprehension; in fear; apprehensive. [Afraid comes after the noun it limits.] "Back they recoiled, afraid." Milton.

AMPfist; This word expresses a less degree of fear than terrified or frightened. It is followed by of before the object of fear, or by the infinitive, or by a dependent clause; as, to be afraid of death. "I am afraid to die." "I am afraid he will chastise me." "Be not afraid that I your hand should take." Shak. I am afraid is sometimes used colloquially to soften a statement; as, I am afraid I can not help you in this matter.
Syn. -- Fearful; timid; timorous; alarmed; anxious.
Af"reet (AMP?;), n. Same as Afrit.
A*fresh" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + fresh.] Anew; again; once more; newly.

p.blockquote:
They crucify . . . the Son of God afresh.
Heb. vi. 6.

dictionary.p: Af"ric (AMP?;), a. African. -- n. Africa. [Poetic]
Af"ri*can (AMP?;), a. [L. Africus, Africanus, fr. Afer African.] Of or pertaining to Africa.

African hemp, a fiber prepared from the leaves of the Sanseviera Guineensis, a plant found in Africa and India. - - African marigold, a tropical American plant (Tagetes erecta). -- African oak or African teak, a timber furnished by Oldfieldia Africana, used in ship building.
Af"ri*can, n. A native of Africa; also one ethnologically belonging to an African race.
Af`ri*can"der (AMP?;), n. One born in Africa, the offspring of a white father and a "colored" mother. Also, and now commonly in Southern Africa, a native born of European settlers.
Af"ri*can*ism (AMP?;), n. A word, phrase, idiom, or custom peculiar to Africa or Africans. "The knotty Africanisms . . . of the fathers." Milton.
Af"ri*can*ize (AMP?;), v. t. To place under the domination of Africans or negroes. [Amer.] Bartlett.
Af"rit (AMP?;), Af"rite(AMP?;), Af"reet(AMP?;), n. [Arab. 'ifrAMPimacr;t.] (Moham. Myth.) A powerful evil jinnee, demon, or monstrous giant.
A*front" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + front.] In front; face to face. -- prep. In front of. Shak.
Aft (AMPadot;ft), adv. AMP a. [AS. AMPaelig;ftan behind; orig. superl. of of, off. See After.] (Naut.) Near or towards the stern of a vessel; astern; abaft.

Aft"er (AMPadot;ft"tAMPetilde;r), a. [AS. AMPaelig;fter after, behind; akin to Goth. aftaro, aftra, backwards, Icel. aptr, Sw. and Dan. efter, OHG. aftar behind, Dutch and LG. achter, Gr. 'apwte`rw further off. The ending -ter is an old comparative suffix, in E. generally -ther (as in other), and after is a compar. of of, off. AMPradic;194. See Of; cf. Aft.] 1. Next; later in time; subsequent; succeeding; as, an after period of life. Marshall.

AMPfist; In this sense the word is sometimes needlessly combined with the following noun, by means of a hyphen, as, after-ages, after- act, after-days, after-life. For the most part the words are properly kept separate when after has this meaning.

2. Hinder; nearer the rear. (Naut.) To ward the stern of the ship; -- applied to any object in the rear part of a vessel; as the after cabin, after hatchway. It is often combined with its noun; as, after-bowlines, after-braces, after-sails, after-yards, those on the mainmasts and mizzenmasts.
After body (Naut.), the part of a ship abaft the dead flat, or middle part.
Aft"er, prep. 1. Behind in place; as, men in line one after another. "Shut doors after you." Shak.

p.def: Below in rank; next to in order.

p.blockquote:
Codrus after PhAMP?;bus sings the best.
Dryden.

p.def: Later in time; subsequent; as, after supper, after three days. It often precedes a clause. Formerly that was interposed between it and the clause.

p.blockquote:
After I am risen again, I will go before you into Galilee.
Matt. xxvi. 32.

p.def: Subsequent to and in consequence of; as, after what you have said, I shall be careful.
Subsequent to and notwithstanding; as, after all our advice, you took that course.
Moving toward from behind; following, in search of; in pursuit of.

p.blockquote:
Ye shall not go after other gods.
Deut. vi. 14.

After whom is the king of Israel come out?
1 Sam. xxiv. 14.

p.def: Denoting the aim or object; concerning; in relation to; as, to look after workmen; to inquire after a friend; to thirst after righteousness.
In imitation of; in conformity with; after the manner of; as, to make a thing after a model; a picture after Rubens; the boy takes after his father.

dictionary.p: To name or call after, to name like and reference to.

p.blockquote:
Our eldest son was named George after his uncle.
Goldsmith.

p.def: According to; in accordance with; in conformity with the nature of; as, he acted after his kind.

p.blockquote:
He shall not judge after the sight of his eyes.
Isa. xi. 3.

They that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh.
Rom. viii. 5.

dictionary.p: 10. According to the direction and influence of; in proportion to; befitting. [Archaic]

p.blockquote:
He takes greatness of kingdoms according to bulk and currency, and not after their intrinsic value.
Bacon.

dictionary.p: After all, when everything has been considered; upon the whole. -- After (with the same noun preceding and following), as, wave after wave, day after day, several or many (waves, etc.) successively. -- One after another, successively. -- To be after, to be in pursuit of in order to reach or get; as, he is after money.
Aft"er, adv. Subsequently in time or place; behind; afterward; as, he follows after.

p.blockquote:
It was about the space of three hours after.
Acts. v. 7.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; After is prefixed to many words, forming compounds, but retaining its usual signification. The prefix may be adverbial, prepositional, or adjectival; as in after- described, after- dinner, after-part. The hyphen is sometimes needlessly used to connect the adjective after with its noun. See Note under After, a., 1.
Aft"er*birth` (AMP?;), n. (Med.) The placenta and membranes with which the fetus is connected, and which come away after delivery.
Aft"er*cast` (AMP?;), n. A throw of dice after the game in ended; hence, anything done too late. Gower.
Aft"er*clap` (AMP?;), n. An unexpected subsequent event; something disagreeable happening after an affair is supposed to be at an end. Spenser.
Aft"er*crop` (AMP?;), n. A second crop or harvest in the same year. Mortimer.
Aft"er damp` (AMP?;).An irrespirable gas, remaining after an explosion of fire damp in mines; choke damp. See Carbonic acid.
Aft"er-din`ner(AMP?;), n. The time just after dinner. "An after-dinner's sleep." Shak. [Obs.] -- a. Following dinner; post-prandial; as, an after-dinner nap.
Aft"er-eat`age(AMP?;), n. Aftergrass.
Aft"er*eye` (AMP?;), v. t. To look after. [Poetic] Shak.
Aft"er*game` (AMP?;), n. A second game; hence, a subsequent scheme or expedient. Wotton.
Aftergame at Irish, an ancient game very nearly resembling backgammon. Beau. AMP Fl.
Aft"er-glow(AMP?;), n. A glow of refulgence in the western sky after sunset.
Aft"er*grass` (AMP?;), n. The grass that grows after the first crop has been mown; aftermath.
Aft"er*growth` (AMP?;), n. A second growth or crop, or (metaphorically) development. J. S. Mill.
Aft"er*guard` (AMP?;), n. (Naut.) The seaman or seamen stationed on the poop or after part of the ship, to attend the after-sails. Totten.
Aft"er-im`age(AMP?;), n. The impression of a vivid sensation retained by the retina of the eye after the cause has been removed; also extended to impressions left of tones, smells, etc.
Aft"er*ings (AMP?;), n. pl. The last milk drawn in milking; strokings. [Obs.] Grose.
Aft"er*math (AMP?;), n. [After + math. See Math.] A second moving; the grass which grows after the first crop of hay in the same season; rowen. Holland.
Aft"er-men`tioned(AMP?;), a. Mentioned afterwards; as, persons after-mentioned (in a writing).

Aft"er*most (AMP?;), a. superl. [OE. eftemest, AS. AMPaelig;ftemest,akin to Gothic aftumist and aftuma, the last, orig. a superlative of of, with the superlative endings -te, -me, -st.] 1. Hindmost; -- opposed to foremost.

p.def: Nearest the stern; most aft.

dictionary.p: Aft"er*noon" (AMP?;), n. The part of the day which follows noon, between noon and evening.
Aft"er-note`(AMP?;), n. (Mus.) One of the small notes occur on the unaccented parts of the measure, taking their time from the preceding note.
Aft"er*pains` (AMP?;), n. pl. (Med.) The pains which succeed childbirth, as in expelling the afterbirth.
Aft"er*piece` (AMP?;), n. 1. A piece performed after a play, usually a farce or other small entertainment.

p.def: The heel of a rudder.

dictionary.p: Aft"er-sails`(AMP?;), n. pl. (Naut.) The sails on the mizzenmast, or on the stays between the mainmast and mizzenmast. Totten.
Aft"er*shaft` (AMP?;), n. (ZoAMPouml;l.) The hypoptilum.
Aft"er*taste` (AMP?;), n. A taste which remains in the mouth after eating or drinking.
Aft"er*thought` (AMP?;), n. Reflection after an act; later or subsequent thought or expedient.

{ Aft"er*wards (AMP?;), Aft"er*ward (AMP?;), } adv. [AS. AMPaelig;fteweard, a., behind. See Aft, and -ward (suffix). The final s in afterwards is adverbial, orig. a genitive ending.] At a later or succeeding time.
Aft"er*wise` (AMP?;), a. Wise after the event; wise or knowing, when it is too late.
Aft"er-wit` (#), n. Wisdom or perception that comes after it can be of use. "After-wit comes too late when the mischief is done." L'Estrange.
Aft"er-wit`ted (AMP?;), a. Characterized by after-wit; slow-witted. Tyndale.
Aft"most (AMP?;), a. (Naut.) Nearest the stern.
Aft"ward (AMP?;), adv. (Naut.) Toward the stern.
||A*ga" or ||A*gha" (#), n. [Turk. adhAMPamacr; a great lord, chief master.] In Turkey, a commander or chief officer. It is used also as a title of respect.

p.def: Another time; once more; anew.

p.blockquote:
If a man die, shall he live again?
Job xiv. 14.

p.def: Once repeated; -- of quantity; as, as large again, half as much again.

dictionary.p: 4. In any other place. [Archaic] Bacon.
5. On the other hand. "The one is my sovereign . . . the other again is my kinsman." Shak.

p.def: Moreover; besides; further.

p.blockquote:
Again, it is of great consequence to avoid, etc.
HerscheAMP?;.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; Again was formerly used in many verbal combinations, as, again-witness, to witness against; again-ride, to ride against; again-come, to come against, to encounter; again- bring, to bring back, etc.

p.blockquote:
Albeit that it is again his kind.
Chaucer.

dictionary.p: A*gain"buy` (AMP?;), v. t. To redeem. [Obs.] Wyclif.
A*gain"say` (AMP?;), v. t. To gainsay. [Obs.] Wyclif.

A*gainst" (?; 277), prep. [OE. agens, ageynes, AS. ongegn. The s is adverbial, orig. a genitive ending. See Again.] 1. Abreast; opposite to; facing; towards; as, against the mouth of a river; -- in this sense often preceded by over.

p.blockquote:
Jacob saw the angels of God come against him.
Tyndale.

p.def: From an opposite direction so as to strike or come in contact with; in contact with; upon; as, hail beats against the roof.

In opposition to, whether the opposition is of sentiment or of action; on the other side; counter to; in contrariety to; hence, adverse to; as, against reason; against law; to run a race against time.

p.blockquote:
The gate would have been shut against her.
Fielding.

An argument against the use of steam.
Tyndale.

dictionary.p: 4. By of before the time that; in preparation for; so as to be ready for the time when. [Archaic or Dial.]

p.blockquote:
Urijah the priest made it, against King Ahaz came from Damascus.
2 Kings xvi. 11.

dictionary.p: Against the sun, in a direction contrary to that in which the sun appears to move.
A*gain"stand` (AMP?;), v. t. To withstand. [Obs.]
A*gain"ward (AMP?;), adv. Back again. [Obs.]

{ ||Ag`a*lac"ti*a (AMPabreve;g`AMPadot;*lAMPabreve;k"tAMPibreve;*AMPadot;), Ag"a*lax`y (AMPabreve;g"AMPadot;*lAMPabreve;k`sAMPybreve;), } n. [Gr. 'agalakti`a; 'a priv. + ga`la, gala`ktos, milk.] (Med.) Failure of the due secretion of milk after childbirth.
Ag`a*lac"tous (AMP?;), a. Lacking milk to suckle with.
||A`gal-a"gal (AMP?;), n. Same as Agar- agar.

{ Ag"al*loch (AMP?;), ||A*gal"lo*chum (AMP?;), } n. [Gr. AMP?;, of Eastern origin: cf. Skr. aguru, Heb. pl. ahAMPamacr;lAMPimacr;m.] A soft, resinous wood (Aquilaria Agallocha) of highly aromatic smell, burnt by the orientals as a perfume. It is called also agalwood and aloes wood. The name is also given to some other species.

Ag`al*mat"o*lite (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?;, AMP?;, image, statue + -lite: cf. F. agalmatolithe.] (Min.) A soft, compact stone, of a grayish, greenish, or yellowish color, carved into images by the Chinese, and hence called figure stone, and pagodite. It is probably a variety of pinite.

||Ag"a*ma (AMP?;), n.; pl. Agamas (AMP?;). [From the Caribbean name of a species of lizard.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A genus of lizards, one of the few which feed upon vegetable substances; also, one of these lizards.

||Ag"a*mi (AMP?;), n.; pl. Agamis (AMP?;). [F. agex>, fr. the native name.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A South American bird (Psophia crepitans), allied to the cranes, and easily domesticated; -- called also the gold- breasted trumpeter. Its body is about the size of the pheasant. See Trumpeter.
A*gam"ic (AMP?;), a. [Agamous.] (a) (Biol.) Produced without sexual union; as, agamic or unfertilized eggs. (b) Not having visible organs of reproduction, as flowerless plants; agamous.
A*gam"ic*al*ly (AMP?;), adv. In an agamic manner.
Ag"a*mist (AMP?;), n. [See Agamous.] An unmarried person; also, one opposed to marriage. Foxe.
||Ag`a*mo*gen"e*sis (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; unmarried ('a priv. + AMP?; marriage) + AMP?; reproduction.] (Biol.) Reproduction without the union of parents of distinct sexes: asexual reproduction.
Ag`a*mo*ge*net"ic (AMP?;), n. (Biol.) Reproducing or produced without sexual union. -- Ag`a*mo*ge*net"ic*al*ly (AMP?;), adv.

p.blockquote:
All known agamogenetic processes end in a complete return to the primitive stock.
Huxley.

dictionary.p: Ag"a*mous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. 'a`gamos unmarried; 'a priv. + ga`mos marriage.] (Biol.) Having no visible sexual organs; asexual. In Bot., cryptogamous.
A*gan`gli*o"nic (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- not + ganglionic.] (Physiol.) Without ganglia.
A*gape" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + gape.] Gaping, as with wonder, expectation, or eager attention.

p.blockquote:
Dazzles the crowd and sets them all agape.
Milton.

dictionary.p: ||Ag"a*pe (AMP?;), n.; pl. AgapAMPaelig; (#). [Gr. 'aga`ph love, pl. 'aga`pai.] The love feast of the primitive Christians, being a meal partaken of in connection with the communion.
Ag"a*ric (?; 277), n. [L. agaricum, Gr. AMP?;, said to be fr. Agara, a town in Sarmatia.] 1. (Bot.) A fungus of the genus Agaricus, of many species, of which the common mushroom is an example.

p.def: An old name for several species of Polyporus, corky fungi growing on decaying wood.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; The "female agaric" (Polyporus officinalis) was renowned as a cathartic; the "male agaric" (Polyporus igniarius) is used for preparing touchwood, called punk or German tinder.
Agaric mineral, a light, chalky deposit of carbonate of lime, sometimes called rock milk, formed in caverns or fissures of limestone.
A*gasp" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [. a- + gasp.] In a state of gasping. Coleridge.
A*gast" or A*ghast" (AMP?;), v. t. To affright; to terrify. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.
A*gast" (AMP?;), p. p. AMP a. See Aghast.
A*gas"tric (AMP?;), a. [Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; stomach.] (Physiol.) Having to stomach, or distinct digestive canal, as the tapeworm.
A*gate" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- on + gate way.] On the way; agoing; as, to be agate; to set the bells agate. [Obs.] Cotgrave.

Ag"ate (AMP?;), n. [F. agate, It. agata, L. achates, fr. Gr. AMP?;.] 1. (Min.) A semipellucid, uncrystallized variety of quartz, presenting various tints in the same specimen. Its colors are delicately arranged in stripes or bands, or blended in clouds.
AMPfist; The fortification agate, or Scotch pebble, the moss agate, the clouded agate, etc., are familiar varieties.

p.def: A kind of type, larger than pearl and smaller than nonpareil; in England called ruby.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; This line is printed in the type called agate.
3. A diminutive person; so called in allusion to the small figures cut in agate for rings and seals. [Obs.] Shak.

p.def: A tool used by gold-wire drawers, bookbinders, etc.; -- so called from the agate fixed in it for burnishing.

dictionary.p: Ag`a*tif"er*ous (AMP?;), a. [Agate + -ferous.] Containing or producing agates. Craig.
Ag"a*tine (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to, or like, agate.
Ag"a*tize (AMP?;), v. t. [Usually p. p. Agatized(AMP?;).] To convert into agate; to make resemble agate. Dana.
Ag"a*ty (AMP?;), a. Of the nature of agate, or containing agate.

A*ga"ve (AMP?;), n. [L. Agave, prop. name, fr. Gr. AMP?;, fem. of AMP?; illustrious, noble.] (bot.) A genus of plants (order AmaryllidaceAMPaelig;) of which the chief species is the maguey or century plant (A. Americana), wrongly called Aloe. It is from ten to seventy years, according to climate, in attaining maturity, when it produces a gigantic flower stem, sometimes forty feet in height, and perishes. The fermented juice is the pulque of the Mexicans; distilled, it yields mescal. A strong thread and a tough paper are made from the leaves, and the wood has many uses.
A*gazed" (AMP?;), p. p. [Only in p. p.; another spelling for aghast.] Gazing with astonishment; amazed. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The whole army stood agazed on him.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Age (AMPamacr;j), n. [OF. aage, eage, F. AMPacirc;ge, fr. L. aetas through a supposed LL. aetaticum. L. aetas is contracted fr. aevitas, fr. aevum lifetime, age; akin to E. aye ever. Cf. Each.] 1. The whole duration of a being, whether animal, vegetable, or other kind; lifetime.

p.blockquote:
Mine age is as nothing before thee.
Ps. xxxix. 5.

p.def: That part of the duration of a being or a thing which is between its beginning and any given time; as, what is the present age of a man, or of the earth?
The latter part of life; an advanced period of life; seniority; state of being old.

p.blockquote:
Nor wrong mine age with this indignity.
Shak.

p.def: One of the stages of life; as, the age of infancy, of youth, etc.

dictionary.p: 5. Mature age; especially, the time of life at which one attains full personal rights and capacities; as, to come of age; he (or she) is of age. Abbott. In the United States, both males and females are of age when twenty-one years old.
7. A particular period of time in history, as distinguished from others; as, the golden age, the age of Pericles. "The spirit of the age." Prescott.

p.blockquote:
Truth, in some age or other, will find her witness.
Milton.

dictionary.p: Archeological ages are designated as three: The Stone age (the early and the later stone age, called paleolithic and neolithic), the Bronze age, and the Iron age. During the Age of Stone man is supposed to have employed stone for weapons and implements.
See Augustan, Brazen, Golden, Heroic, Middle.

p.def: A great period in the history of the Earth.
