dictionary.p: The geologic ages are as follows: 1. The ArchAMPaelig;an, including the time when was no life and the time of the earliest and simplest forms of life. 2. The age of Invertebrates, or the Silurian, when the life on the globe consisted distinctively of invertebrates. 3. The age of Fishes, or the Devonian, when fishes were the dominant race. 4. The age of Coal Plants, or Acrogens, or the Carboniferous age. 5. The Mesozoic or Secondary age, or age of Reptiles, when reptiles prevailed in great numbers and of vast size. 6. The Tertiary age, or age of Mammals, when the mammalia, or quadrupeds, abounded, and were the dominant race. 7. The Quaternary age, or age of Man, or the modern era. Dana.

p.def: A century; the period of one hundred years.

p.blockquote:
Fleury . . . apologizes for these five ages.
Hallam.

dictionary.p: 10. The people who live at a particular period; hence, a generation. "Ages yet unborn." Pope.

p.blockquote:
The way which the age follows.
J. H. Newman.

Lo! where the stage, the poor, degraded stage,
Holds its warped mirror to a gaping age.
C. Sprague.

dictionary.p: 11. A long time. [Colloq.] "He made minutes an age." Tennyson.

Age of a tide, the time from the origin of a tide in the South Pacific Ocean to its arrival at a given place. -- Moon's age, the time that has elapsed since the last preceding conjunction of the sun and moon.
AMPfist; Age is used to form the first part of many compounds; as, agelasting, age-adorning, age-worn, age- enfeebled, agelong.
Syn. -- Time; period; generation; date; era; epoch.
Age, v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Aged (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Aging (AMP?;).] To grow aged; to become old; to show marks of age; as, he grew fat as he aged.

p.blockquote:
They live one hundred and thirty years, and never age for all that.
Holland.

I am aging; that is, I have a whitish, or rather a light-colored, hair here and there.
Landor.

dictionary.p: Age, v. t. To cause to grow old; to impart the characteristics of age to; as, grief ages us.
A"ged (AMP?;), a. 1. Old; having lived long; having lived almost to or beyond the usual time allotted to that species of being; as, an aged man; an aged oak.
2. Belonging to old age. "Aged cramps." Shak.
3. (AMPamacr;"jAMPebreve;d or AMPamacr;jd) Having a certain age; at the age of; having lived; as, a man aged forty years.
A"ged*ly, adv. In the manner of an aged person.
A"ged*ness, n. The quality of being aged; oldness.

p.blockquote:
Custom without truth is but agedness of error.
Milton.

dictionary.p: Age"less (AMP?;), a. Without old age limits of duration; as, fountains of ageless youth.
A*gen" (AMP?;), adv. AMP prep. See Again. [Obs.]

A"gen*cy (AMP?;), n.; pl. Agencies (AMP?;). [agentia, fr. L. agens, agentis: cf. F. agence. See Agent.] 1. The faculty of acting or of exerting power; the state of being in action; action; instrumentality.

p.blockquote:
The superintendence and agency of Providence in the natural world.
Woodward.

p.def: The office of an agent, or factor; the relation between a principal and his agent; business of one intrusted with the concerns of another.
The place of business of am agent.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Action; operation; efficiency; management.
A"gend (AMP?;), n. See Agendum. [Obs.]
||A*gen"dum (AMP?;), n.; pl. Agenda (AMP?;). [L., neut. of the gerundive of agere to act.] 1. Something to be done; in the pl., a memorandum book.

p.def: A church service; a ritual or liturgy. [In this sense, usually Agenda.]

dictionary.p: Ag`e*nes"ic (AMP?;), a. [See Agensis.] (Physiol.) Characterized by sterility; infecund.
||A*gen"e*sis (AMP?;), n. [Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; birth.] (Physiol.) Any imperfect development of the body, or any anomaly of organization.

A"gent (AMP?;), a. [L. agens, agentis, p. pr. of agere to act; akin to Gr. AMP?; to lead, Icel. aka to drive, Skr. aj. AMPradic;2.] Acting; -- opposed to patient, or sustaining, action. [Archaic] "The body agent." Bacon.
A"gent, n. 1. One who exerts power, or has the power to act; an actor.

p.blockquote:
Heaven made us agents, free to good or ill.
Dryden.

p.def: One who acts for, or in the place of, another, by authority from him; one intrusted with the business of another; a substitute; a deputy; a factor.
An active power or cause; that which has the power to produce an effect; as, a physical, chemical, or medicinal agent; as, heat is a powerful agent.

dictionary.p: A*gen"tial (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to an agent or an agency. Fitzed. Hall.
A"gent*ship (AMP?;), n. Agency. Beau. AMP Fl.
||A*ger"a*tum (AMP?;), n. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; a sort of plant; 'a priv. + AMP?; old age.] (Bot.) A genus of plants, one species of which (A. Mexicanum) has lavender- blue flowers in dense clusters.
Ag*gen`er*a"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. aggenerare to beget in addition. See Generate.] The act of producing in addition. [Obs.] T. Stanley.
||Ag"ger (AMP?;), n. [L., a mound, fr. aggerere to bear to a place, heap up; ad + gerere to bear.] An earthwork; a mound; a raised work. [Obs.] Hearne.
Ag"ger*ate (AMP?;), v. t. [L. aggeratus, p. p. of aggerare. See Agger.] To heap up. [Obs.] Foxe.
Ag`ger*a"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. aggeratio.] A heaping up; accumulation; as, aggerations of sand. [R.]
Ag`ger*ose" (AMP?;), a. In heaps; full of heaps.
Ag*gest" (AMP?;), v. t. [L. aggestus, p. p. of aggerere. See Agger.] To heap up. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The violence of the waters aggested the earth.
Fuller.

dictionary.p: Ag*glom"er*ate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Agglomerated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Agglomerating (AMP?;).] [L. agglomeratus, p. p. of agglomerare; ad + glomerare to form into a ball. See Glomerate.] To wind or collect into a ball; hence, to gather into a mass or anything like a mass.

p.blockquote:
Where he builds the agglomerated pile.
Cowper.

dictionary.p: Ag*glom"er*ate, v. i. To collect in a mass.

p.def: Collected into a rounded head of flowers.

dictionary.p: Ag*glom"er*ate (AMP?;), n. 1. A collection or mass.

p.def: A mass of angular volcanic fragments united by heat; -- distinguished from conglomerate.

dictionary.p: Ag*glom`er*a"tion (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. agglomAMPeacute;ration.] 1. The act or process of collecting in a mass; a heaping together.

p.blockquote:
An excessive agglomeration of turrets.
Warton.

p.def: State of being collected in a mass; a mass; cluster.

dictionary.p: Ag*glom"er*a*tive (AMP?;), a. Having a tendency to gather together, or to make collections.

p.blockquote:
Taylor is eminently discursive, accumulative, and (to use one of his own words) agglomerative.
Coleridge.

dictionary.p: Ag*glu"ti*nant (AMP?;), a. [L. agglutinans, -antis, p. pr. of agglutinare.] Uniting, as glue; causing, or tending to cause, adhesion. -- n. Any viscous substance which causes bodies or parts to adhere.

Ag*glu"ti*nate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Agglutinated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Agglutinating.] [L. agglutinatus, p. p. of agglutinare to glue or cement to a thing; ad + glutinare to glue; gluten glue. See Glue.] To unite, or cause to adhere, as with glue or other viscous substance; to unite by causing an adhesion of substances.
Ag*glu"ti*nate (AMP?;), a. 1. United with glue or as with glue; cemented together.

p.def: Consisting of root words combined but not materially altered as to form or meaning; as, agglutinate forms, languages, etc. See Agglutination, 2.

dictionary.p: Ag*glu`ti*na"tion (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. agglutination.] 1. The act of uniting by glue or other tenacious substance; the state of being thus united; adhesion of parts.

p.def: Combination in which root words are united with little or no change of form or loss of meaning. See Agglutinative, 2.
Formed or characterized by agglutination, as a language or a compound.

p.blockquote:
In agglutinative languages the union of words may be compared to mechanical compounds, in inflective languages to chemical compounds.
R. Morris.

Cf. man-kind, heir-loom, war-like, which are agglutinative compounds. The Finnish, Hungarian, Turkish, the Tamul, etc., are agglutinative languages.
R. Morris.

Agglutinative languages preserve the consciousness of their roots.
Max MAMPuuml;ller.

dictionary.p: Ag*grace" (AMP?;), v. t. [Pref. a- + grace: cf. It. aggraziare, LL. aggratiare. See Grace.] To favor; to grace. [Obs.] "That knight so much aggraced." Spenser.
Ag*grace" (AMP?;), n. Grace; favor. [Obs.] Spenser.
Ag"gran*di"za*ble (AMP?;), a. Capable of being aggrandized.
Ag*gran`di*za"tion (AMP?;), n. Aggrandizement. [Obs.] Waterhouse.

Ag"gran*dize (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Aggrandized (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Aggrandizing (AMP?;).] [F. agrandir; AMPagrave; (L. ad) + grandir to increase, L. grandire, fr. grandis great. See Grand, and cf. Finish.] 1. To make great; to enlarge; to increase; as, to aggrandize our conceptions, authority, distress.

p.def: To make great or greater in power, rank, honor, or wealth; -- applied to persons, countries, etc.

p.blockquote:
His scheme for aggrandizing his son.
Prescott.

p.def: To make appear great or greater; to exalt.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To augment; exalt; promote; advance.
Ag"gran*dize, v. i. To increase or become great. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Follies, continued till old age, do aggrandize.
J. Hall.

dictionary.p: Ag*gran"dize*ment (?; 277), n. [Cf. F. agrandissement.] The act of aggrandizing, or the state of being aggrandized or exalted in power, rank, honor, or wealth; exaltation; enlargement; as, the emperor seeks only the aggrandizement of his own family.
Syn. -- Augmentation; exaltation; enlargement; advancement; promotion; preferment.
Ag"gran*di`zer (AMP?;), n. One who aggrandizes, or makes great.
Ag*grate" (AMP?;), v. t. [It. aggratare, fr. L. ad + gratus pleasing. See Grate, a.] To please. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Each one sought his lady to aggrate.
Spenser.

dictionary.p: Ag"gra*vate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Aggravated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Aggravating.] [L. aggravatus, p. p. of aggravare. See Aggrieve.] 1. To make heavy or heavier; to add to; to increase. [Obs.] "To aggravate thy store." Shak.
2. To make worse, or more severe; to render less tolerable or less excusable; to make more offensive; to enhance; to intensify. "To aggravate my woes." Pope.

p.blockquote:
To aggravate the horrors of the scene.
Prescott.

The defense made by the prisoner's counsel did rather aggravate than extenuate his crime.
Addison.

p.def: To give coloring to in description; to exaggerate; as, to aggravate circumstances.

dictionary.p: 4. To exasperate; to provoke; to irritate. [Colloq.]

p.blockquote:
If both were to aggravate her parents, as my brother and sister do mine.
Richardson (Clarissa).

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To heighten; intensify; increase; magnify; exaggerate; provoke; irritate; exasperate.
Ag"gra*va`ting (AMP?;), a. 1. Making worse or more heinous; as, aggravating circumstances.
2. Exasperating; provoking; irritating. [Colloq.]

p.blockquote:
A thing at once ridiculous and aggravating.
J. Ingelow.

dictionary.p: Ag"gra*va`ting*ly, adv. In an aggravating manner.

Ag`gra*va"tion (AMP?;), n. [LL. aggravatio: cf. F. aggravation.] 1. The act of aggravating, or making worse; -- used of evils, natural or moral; the act of increasing in severity or heinousness; something additional to a crime or wrong and enhancing its guilt or injurious consequences.

p.def: Exaggerated representation.

p.blockquote:
By a little aggravation of the features changed it into the Saracen's head.
Addison.

p.def: An extrinsic circumstance or accident which increases the guilt of a crime or the misery of a calamity.

dictionary.p: 4. Provocation; irritation. [Colloq.] Dickens.
Ag"gra*va*tive (AMP?;), a. Tending to aggravate. -- n. That which aggravates.

Ag"gre*gate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Aggregated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Aggregating.] [L. aggregatus, p. p. of aggregare to lead to a flock or herd; ad + gregare to collect into a flock, grex flock, herd. See Gregarious.] 1. To bring together; to collect into a mass or sum. "The aggregated soil." Milton.

p.def: To add or unite, as, a person, to an association.

p.blockquote:
It is many times hard to discern to which of the two sorts, the good or the bad, a man ought to be aggregated.
Wollaston.

dictionary.p: 3. To amount in the aggregate to; as, ten loads, aggregating five hundred bushels. [Colloq.]
Syn. -- To heap up; accumulate; pile; collect.
Ag"gre*gate (AMP?;), a. [L. aggregatus, p. p.] 1. Formed by a collection of particulars into a whole mass or sum; collective.

p.blockquote:
The aggregate testimony of many hundreds.
Sir T. Browne.

p.def: Formed into clusters or groups of lobules; as, aggregate glands.
Composed of several florets within a common involucre, as in the daisy; or of several carpels formed from one flower, as in the raspberry.
Having the several component parts adherent to each other only to such a degree as to be separable by mechanical means.
United into a common organized mass; -- said of certain compound animals.

dictionary.p: Corporation aggregate. (Law) See under Corporation.
Ag"gre*gate, n. 1. A mass, assemblage, or sum of particulars; as, a house is an aggregate of stone, brick, timber, etc.
AMPfist; In an aggregate the particulars are less intimately mixed than in a compound.

p.def: A mass formed by the union of homogeneous particles; -- in distinction from a compound, formed by the union of heterogeneous particles.

dictionary.p: In the aggregate, collectively; together.
Ag"gre*gate*ly, adv. Collectively; in mass.

Ag`gre*ga"tion (AMP?;), n. [Cf. LL. aggregatio, F. agrAMPeacute;gation.] The act of aggregating, or the state of being aggregated; collection into a mass or sum; a collection of particulars; an aggregate.

p.blockquote:
Each genus is made up by aggregation of species.
Carpenter.

A nation is not an idea only of local extent and individual momentary aggregation, but . . . of continuity, which extends in time as well as in numbers, and in space.
Burke.

dictionary.p: 2. Gregarious; social. [R.] Carlyle.
Ag"gre*ga`tor (AMP?;), n. One who aggregates.
Ag*grege" (AMP?;), v. t. [OF. agreger. See Aggravate.] To make heavy; to aggravate. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Ag*gress" (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Aggressed (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Aggressing.] [L. aggressus, p. p. of aggredi to go to, approach; ad + gradi to step, go, gradus step: cf. OF. aggresser. See Grade.] To commit the first act of hostility or offense; to begin a quarrel or controversy; to make an attack; -- with on.
Ag*gress", v. t. To set upon; to attack. [R.]
Ag*gress", n. [L. aggressus.] Aggression. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Their military aggresses on others.
Sir M. Hale.

dictionary.p: Ag*gres"sion (AMP?;), n. [L. aggressio, fr. aggredi: cf. F. agression.] The first attack, or act of hostility; the first act of injury, or first act leading to a war or a controversy; unprovoked attack; assault; as, a war of aggression. "Aggressions of power." Hallam
Syn. -- Attack; offense; intrusion; provocation.

Ag*gres"sive (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. agressif.] Tending or disposed to aggress; characterized by aggression; making assaults; unjustly attacking; as, an aggressive policy, war, person, nation. -- Ag*gres"sive*ly, adv. -- Ag*gres"sive*ness, n.

p.blockquote:
No aggressive movement was made.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: Ag*gres"sor (AMP?;), n. [L.: cf. F. agresseur.] The person who first attacks or makes an aggression; he who begins hostility or a quarrel; an assailant.

p.blockquote:
The insolence of the aggressor is usually proportioned to the tameness of the sufferer.
Ames.

dictionary.p: Ag*griev"ance (AMP?;), n. [OF. agrevance, fr. agrever. See Aggrieve.] Oppression; hardship; injury; grievance. [Archaic]

Ag*grieve" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Aggrieved (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Aggrieving (AMP?;).] [OE. agreven, OF. agrever; a (L. ad) + grever to burden, injure, L. gravare to weigh down, fr. gravis heavy. See Grieve, and cf. Aggravate.] To give pain or sorrow to; to afflict; hence, to oppress or injure in one's rights; to bear heavily upon; -- now commonly used in the passive TO be aggrieved.

p.blockquote:
Aggrieved by oppression and extortion.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: Ag*grieve", v. i. To grieve; to lament. [Obs.]

Ag*group" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Aggrouped (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Aggrouping.] [F. agrouper; AMPagrave; (L. ad) + groupe group. See Group..] To bring together in a group; to group. Dryden.
Ag*group"ment (AMP?;), n. Arrangement in a group or in groups; grouping.
||Ag"gry, ||Ag"gri (AMP?;), a. Applied to a kind of variegated glass beads of ancient manufacture; as, aggry beads are found in Ashantee and Fantee in Africa.
A*ghast" (AMP?;), v. t. See Agast, v. t. [Obs.]

A*ghast" (AMP?;), a. AMP p. p. [OE. agast, agasted, p. p. of agasten to terrify, fr. AS. pref. AMPamacr;- (cf. Goth. us-, G. er-, orig. meaning out) + gAMP?;stan to terrify, torment: cf. Goth. usgaisjan to terrify, primitively to fix, to root to the spot with terror; akin to L. haerere to stick fast, cling. See Gaze, Hesitate.] Terrified; struck with amazement; showing signs of terror or horror.

p.blockquote:
Aghast he waked; and, starting from his bed,
Cold sweat in clammy drops his limbs o'erspread.
Dryden.

The commissioners read and stood aghast.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: Ag"i*ble (AMP?;), a. [Cf. LL. agibilis, fr. L. agere to move, do.] Possible to be done; practicable. [Obs.] "Fit for agible things." Sir A. Sherley.
Ag"ile (AMP?;), a. [F. agile, L. agilis, fr. agere to move. See Agent.] Having the faculty of quick motion in the limbs; apt or ready to move; nimble; active; as, an agile boy; an agile tongue.

p.blockquote:
Shaking it with agile hand.
Cowper.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Active; alert; nimble; brisk; lively; quick.
Ag"ile*ly, adv. In an agile manner; nimbly.
Ag"ile*ness, n. Agility; nimbleness. [R.]

A*gil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. [F. agiliAMPeacute;, L. agilitas, fr. agilis.] 1. The quality of being agile; the power of moving the limbs quickly and easily; nimbleness; activity; quickness of motion; as, strength and agility of body.

p.blockquote:
They . . . trust to the agility of their wit.
Bacon.

Wheeling with the agility of a hawk.
Sir W. Scott.

dictionary.p: 2. Activity; powerful agency. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The agility of the sun's fiery heat.
Holland.

dictionary.p: Ag"i*o (AMP?;), n.; pl. Agios (AMP?;). [It. aggio exchange, discount, premium, the same word as agio ease. See Ease.] (Com.) The premium or percentage on a better sort of money when it is given in exchange for an inferior sort. The premium or discount on foreign bills of exchange is sometimes called agio.

Ag"i*o*tage (AMP?;), n. [F. agiotage, fr. agioter to practice stockjobbing, fr. agio.] Exchange business; also, stockjobbing; the maneuvers of speculators to raise or lower the price of stocks or public funds.

p.blockquote:
Vanity and agiotage are to a Parisian the oxygen and hydrogen of life.
Landor.

dictionary.p: A*gist" (AMP?;), v. t. [OF. agister; AMPagrave; (L. ad) + gister to assign a lodging, fr. giste lodging, abode, F. gAMPicirc;te, LL. gistum, gista, fr. L. jacitum, p. p. of jacAMP?;re to lie: cf. LL. agistare, adgistare. See Gist.] (Law) To take to graze or pasture, at a certain sum; -- used originally of the feeding of cattle in the king's forests, and collecting the money for the same. Blackstone.
Ag`is*ta"tor (AMP?;), n. [LL.] See Agister.

{ A*gist"er, A*gist"or } (AMP?;), n. [Anglo-Norman agistour.] (Law) (a) Formerly, an officer of the king's forest, who had the care of cattle agisted, and collected the money for the same; -- hence called gisttaker, which in England is corrupted into guest- taker. (b) Now, one who agists or takes in cattle to pasture at a certain rate; a pasturer. Mozley AMP W.

A*gist"ment (AMP?;), n. [OF. agistement. See Agist.] (Law) (a) Formerly, the taking and feeding of other men's cattle in the king's forests. (b) The taking in by any one of other men's cattle to graze at a certain rate. Mozley AMP W. (c) The price paid for such feeding. (d) A charge or rate against lands; as, an agistment of sea banks, i. e., charge for banks or dikes.
Ag"i*ta*ble (AMP?;), a. [L. agitabilis: cf. F. agitable.] Capable of being agitated, or easily moved. [R.]

Ag"i*tate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Agitated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Agitating (AMP?;).] [L. agitatus, p. p. of agitare to put in motion, fr. agere to move: cf. F. agiter. See Act, Agent.] 1. To move with a violent, irregular action; as, the wind agitates the sea; to agitate water in a vessel. "Winds . . . agitate the air." Cowper.
2. To move or actuate. [R.] Thomson.

p.def: To stir up; to disturb or excite; to perturb; as, he was greatly agitated.

p.blockquote:
The mind of man is agitated by various passions.
Johnson.

p.def: To discuss with great earnestness; to debate; as, a controversy hotly agitated.
To revolve in the mind, or view in all its aspects; to contrive busily; to devise; to plot; as, politicians agitate desperate designs.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To move; shake; excite; rouse; disturb; distract; revolve; discuss; debate; canvass.
Ag"i*ta`ted*ly, adv. In an agitated manner.

Ag`i*ta"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. agitatio: cf. F. agitation.] 1. The act of agitating, or the state of being agitated; the state of being moved with violence, or with irregular action; commotion; as, the sea after a storm is in agitation.

p.def: A stirring up or arousing; disturbance of tranquillity; disturbance of mind which shows itself by physical excitement; perturbation; as, to cause any one agitation.

dictionary.p: 3. Excitement of public feeling by discussion, appeals, etc.; as, the antislavery agitation; labor agitation. "Religious agitations." Prescott.

p.blockquote:
A logical agitation of the matter.
L'Estrange.

The project now in agitation.
Swift.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Emotion; commotion; excitement; trepidation; tremor; perturbation. See Emotion.
Ag"i*ta*tive (AMP?;), a. Tending to agitate.
||A`gi*ta"to (AMP?;), a. [It., agitated.] (Mus.) Sung or played in a restless, hurried, and spasmodic manner.
Ag"i*ta`tor (AMP?;), n. [L.] 1. One who agitates; one who stirs up or excites others; as, political reformers and agitators.

p.def: One of a body of men appointed by the army, in Cromwell's time, to look after their interests; - - called also adjutators.
An implement for shaking or mixing.

dictionary.p: A*gleam" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + gleam.] Gleaming; as, faces agleam. Lowell.

{ Ag"let (AMPabreve;g"lAMPebreve;t), Aig"let (AMPamacr;g"lAMPebreve;t), } n. [F. aiguillette point, tagged point, dim. of aiguilee needle, fr. LL. acucula for acicula, dim. of L. acus needle, pin; cf. OF. agleter to hook on. See Acute, and cf. Aiguillette.] 1. A tag of a lace or of the points, braids, or cords formerly used in dress. They were sometimes formed into small images. Hence, "aglet baby" (Shak.), an aglet image.

p.def: A round white staylace.

dictionary.p: A*gley" (AMP?;), adv. Aside; askew. [Scotch] Burns.
A*glim"mer (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + glimmer.] In a glimmering state. Hawthorne.
A*glit"ter (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + glitter.] Glittering; in a glitter.
A*glos"sal (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Without tongue; tongueless.
A*glow" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + glow.] In a glow; glowing; as, cheeks aglow; the landscape all aglow.
Ag`lu*ti"tion (AMP?;), n. [Pref. a- not + L. glutire to swallow.] (Med.) Inability to swallow.
{ Ag"mi*nate (AMP?;), Ag"mi*na`ted (AMP?;), } a. [L. agmen, agminis, a train, crowd.] (Physiol.) Grouped together; as, the agminated glands of Peyer in the small intestine.
Ag"nail (AMP?;), n. [AS. angnAMPaelig;gl; ange vexation, trouble + nAMPaelig;gel nail. Cf. Hangnail.] 1. A corn on the toe or foot. [Obs.]

p.def: An inflammation or sore under or around the nail; also, a hangnail.

dictionary.p: Ag"nate (AMP?;), a. [L. agnatus, p. p. of agnasci to be born in addition to; ad + nasci (for gnasci) to be born. Cf. Adnate.] 1. Related or akin by the father's side; also, sprung from the same male ancestor.
2. Allied; akin. "Agnate words." Pownall.

p.blockquote:
Assume more or less of a fictitious character, but congenial and agnate with the former.
Landor.

dictionary.p: Ag"nate, n. [Cf. F. agnat.] (Civil Law) A relative whose relationship can be traced exclusively through males.
Ag*nat"ic (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. agnatique.] Pertaining to descent by the male line of ancestors. "The agnatic succession." Blackstone.
Ag*na"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. agnatio: cf. F. agnation.] 1. (Civil Law) Consanguinity by a line of males only, as distinguished from cognation. Bouvier.
Ag*ni"tion (AMPabreve;g*nAMPibreve;sh"AMPubreve;n), n. [L. agnitio, fr. agnoscere. See Notion.] Acknowledgment. [Obs.] Grafton.

p.blockquote:
I do agnize a natural and prompt alacrity.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Ag`noi*ol"o*gy (AMPabreve;g`noi*AMPobreve;l"AMPosl;*jAMPybreve;), n. [Gr. 'a`gnoia ignorance + -logy.] (Metaph.) The doctrine concerning those things of which we are necessarily ignorant.

||Ag*no"men (AMPabreve;g*nAMPomacr;"mAMPebreve;n), n. [L.; ad + nomen name.] 1. An additional or fourth name given by the Romans, on account of some remarkable exploit or event; as, Publius Caius Scipio Africanus.

p.def: An additional name, or an epithet appended to a name; as, Aristides the Just.

dictionary.p: Ag*nom"i*nate (AMPabreve;g*nAMPobreve;m"AMPibreve;*nAMPamacr;t), v. t. To name. [Obs.]
Ag*nom`i*na"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. agnominatio. See Agnomen.] 1. A surname. [R.] Minsheu.

p.def: Paronomasia; also, alliteration; annomination.

dictionary.p: Ag*nos"tic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; knowing, AMP?; to know.] Professing ignorance; involving no dogmatic; pertaining to or involving agnosticism. -- Ag*nos"tic*al*ly (AMP?;), adv.

Ag*nos"tic, n. One who professes ignorance, or denies that we have any knowledge, save of phenomena; one who supports agnosticism, neither affirming nor denying the existence of a personal Deity, a future life, etc.

Ag*nos"ti*cism (AMP?;), n. That doctrine which, professing ignorance, neither asserts nor denies. Specifically: (Theol.) The doctrine that the existence of a personal Deity, an unseen world, etc., can be neither proved nor disproved, because of the necessary limits of the human mind (as sometimes charged upon Hamilton and Mansel), or because of the insufficiency of the evidence furnished by physical and physical data, to warrant a positive conclusion (as taught by the school of Herbert Spencer); -- opposed alike dogmatic skepticism and to dogmatic theism.
||Ag"nus (AMP?;), n.; pl. E. Agnuses (AMP?;); L. Agni (AMP?;). [L., a lamb.] Agnus Dei.
||Ag"nus cas"tus (AMP?;). [Gr. AMP?; a willowlike tree, used at a religious festival; confused with AMP?; holy, chaste.] (Bot.) A species of Vitex (V. agnus castus); the chaste tree. Loudon.

p.blockquote:
And wreaths of agnus castus others bore.
Dryden.

dictionary.p: ||Ag"nus De"i (AMP?;). [L., lamb of God.] (R. C. Ch.) (a) A figure of a lamb bearing a cross or flag. (b) A cake of wax stamped with such a figure. It is made from the remains of the paschal candles and blessed by the Pope. (c) A triple prayer in the sacrifice of the Mass, beginning with the words "Agnus Dei."

A*go" (AMP?;), a. AMP adv. [OE. ago, agon, p. p. of agon to go away, pass by, AS. AMPamacr;gAMPamacr;n to pass away; AMPamacr;- (cf. Goth. us- , Ger. er-, orig. meaning out) + gAMPamacr;n to go. See Go.] Past; gone by; since; as, ten years ago; gone long ago.

p.blockquote:
All agog to dash through thick and thin.
Cowper.

dictionary.p: A*go"ing (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + p. pr. of go.] In motion; in the act of going; as, to set a mill agoing.
||Ag"on (AMP?;), n.; pl. Agones (AMP?;). [Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to lead.] (Gr. Antiq.) A contest for a prize at the public games.
A*gone" (AMP?;), a. AMP adv. Ago. [Archaic> AMP Poet.]

p.blockquote:
Three days agone I fell sick.
1 Sam. xxx. 13.

dictionary.p: A"gone (AMP?;), n. [See Agonic.] Agonic line.
A*gon"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; without angles; 'a priv. + AMP?; an angle.] Not forming an angle.

Agonic line (Physics), an imaginary line on the earth's surface passing through those places where the magnetic needle points to the true north; the line of no magnetic variation. There is one such line in the Western hemisphere, and another in the Eastern hemisphere.
Ag"o*nism (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to contend for a prize, fr. AMP?;. See Agon.] Contention for a prize; a contest. [Obs.] Blount.
Ag"o*nist (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?;.] One who contends for the prize in public games. [R.]

{ Ag`o*nis"tic (AMP?;), Ag`o*nis"tic*al (AMP?;), } a. [Gr. AMP?;. See Agonism.] Pertaining to violent contests, bodily or mental; pertaining to athletic or polemic feats; athletic; combative; hence, strained; unnatural.

p.blockquote:
As a scholar, he [Dr. Parr] was brilliant, but he consumed his power in agonistic displays.
De Quincey.

dictionary.p: Ag`o*nis"tic*al*ly, adv. In an agonistic manner.
Ag`o*nis"tics (AMP?;), n. The science of athletic combats, or contests in public games.

Ag"o*nize (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Agonized (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Agonizing (AMP?;).] [F. agoniser, LL. agonizare, fr. Gr. AMP?;. See Agony.] 1. To writhe with agony; to suffer violent anguish.

p.blockquote:
To smart and agonize at every pore.
Pope.

p.def: To struggle; to wrestle; to strive desperately.

dictionary.p: Ag"o*nize, v. t. To cause to suffer agony; to subject to extreme pain; to torture.

p.blockquote:
He agonized his mother by his behavior.
Thackeray.

dictionary.p: Ag"o*ni`zing*ly (AMP?;), adv. With extreme anguish or desperate struggles.
Ag`o*no*thet"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;.] Pertaining to the office of an agonothete.
Ag"o*ny (AMP?;), n.; pl. Agonies (AMP?;). [L. agonia, Gr. AMP?;, orig. a contest, fr. AMP?;: cf. F. agonie. See Agon.] 1. Violent contest or striving.

p.blockquote:
The world is convulsed by the agonies of great nations.
Macaulay.

p.def: Pain so extreme as to cause writhing or contortions of the body, similar to those made in the athletic contests in Greece; and hence, extreme pain of mind or body; anguish; paroxysm of grief; specifically, the sufferings of Christ in the garden of Gethsemane.

p.blockquote:
Being in an agony he prayed more earnestly.
Luke xxii. 44.

p.def: Paroxysm of joy; keen emotion.

p.blockquote:
With cries and agonies of wild delight.
Pope.

p.def: The last struggle of life; death struggle.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Anguish; torment; throe; distress; pangs; suffering. -- Agony, Anguish, Pang. These words agree in expressing extreme pain of body or mind. Agony denotes acute and permanent pain, usually of the whole system., and often producing contortions. Anguish denotes severe pressure, and, considered as bodily suffering, is more commonly local (as anguish of a wound), thus differing from agony. A pang is a paroxysm of excruciating pain. It is severe and transient. The agonies or pangs of remorse; the anguish of a wounded conscience. "Oh, sharp convulsive pangs of agonizing pride!" Dryden.
A*good(AMPadot;*gAMPoocr;d"), adv. [Pref. a- + good.] In earnest; heartily. [Obs.] "I made her weep agood." Shak.
||Ag"o*ra (AMPabreve;g"AMPosl;*rAMPadot;), n. [Gr. 'agora`.] An assembly; hence, the place of assembly, especially the market place, in an ancient Greek city.
||A*gou"a*ra (AMP?;), n. [Native name.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) The crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus), found in the tropical parts of America.
||A*gou"ta (AMP?;), n. [Native name.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A small insectivorous mammal (Solenodon paradoxus), allied to the moles, found only in Hayti.

{ A*gou"ti, A*gou"ty } (AMPadot;*gAMPoomac;"tAMPibreve;), n. [F. agouti, acouti, Sp. aguti, fr. native name.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A rodent of the genus Dasyprocta, about the size of a rabbit, peculiar to South America and the West Indies. The most common species is the Dasyprocta agouti.
A*grace" (AMP?;), n. AMP v. See Aggrace. [Obs.]
A*graffe" (AMP?;), n. [F. agrafe, formerly agraffe, OF. agrappe. See Agrappes.] 1. A hook or clasp.

p.blockquote:
The feather of an ostrich, fastened in her turban by an agraffe set with brilliants.
Sir W. Scott.

p.def: A hook, eyelet, or other device by which a piano wire is so held as to limit the vibration.

dictionary.p: ||A*graph"i*a (AMP?;), n. [Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; to write.] The absence or loss of the power of expressing ideas by written signs. It is one form of aphasia.
A*graph"ic (AMP?;), a. Characterized by agraphia.
A*grappes" (AMP?;), n. pl. [OF. agrappe, F. agrafe; a + grappe (see Grape) fr. OHG. krAMPamacr;pfo hook.] Hooks and eyes for armor, etc. Fairholt.

A*gra"ri*an (AMP?;), a. [L. agrarius, fr. ager field.] 1. Pertaining to fields, or lands, or their tenure; esp., relating to an equal or equitable division of lands; as, the agrarian laws of Rome, which distributed the conquered and other public lands among citizens.

p.blockquote:
His Grace's landed possessions are irresistibly inviting to an agrarian experiment.
Burke.

p.def: Wild; -- said of plants growing in the fields.

dictionary.p: A*gra"ri*an, n. 1. One in favor of an equal division of landed property.
2. An agrarian law. [R.]

p.blockquote:
An equal agrarian is perpetual law.
Harrington.

dictionary.p: A*gra"ri*an*ism (AMP?;), n. An equal or equitable division of landed property; the principles or acts of those who favor a redistribution of land.
A*gra"ri*an*ize (AMP?;), v. t. To distribute according to, or to imbue with, the principles of agrarianism.

A*gree" (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Agreed (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Agreeing.] [F. agrAMPeacute;er to accept or receive kindly, fr. AMPagrave; grAMPeacute;; AMPagrave; (L. ad) + grAMPeacute; good will, consent, liking, fr. L. gratus pleasing, agreeable. See Grateful.] 1. To harmonize in opinion, statement, or action; to be in unison or concord; to be or become united or consistent; to concur; as, all parties agree in the expediency of the law.

p.blockquote:
If music and sweet poetry agree.
Shak.

Their witness agreed not together.
Mark xiv. 56.

The more you agree together, the less hurt can your enemies do you.
Sir T. Browne.

p.def: To yield assent; to accede; -- followed by to; as, to agree to an offer, or to opinion.
To make a stipulation by way of settling differences or determining a price; to exchange promises; to come to terms or to a common resolve; to promise.

p.blockquote:
Agree with thine adversary quickly.
Matt. v. 25.

Didst not thou agree with me for a penny ?
Matt. xx. 13.

p.def: To be conformable; to resemble; to coincide; to correspond; as, the picture does not agree with the original; the two scales agree exactly.
To suit or be adapted in its effects; to do well; as, the same food does not agree with every constitution.
To correspond in gender, number, case, or person.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; The auxiliary forms of to be are often employed with the participle agreed. "The jury were agreed." Macaulay. "Can two walk together, except they be agreed ?" Amos iii. 3. The principal intransitive uses were probably derived from the transitive verb used reflexively. "I agree me well to your desire." Ld. Berners.
A*gree" (AMP?;), v. t. 1. To make harmonious; to reconcile or make friends. [Obs.] Spenser.
2. To admit, or come to one mind concerning; to settle; to arrange; as, to agree the fact; to agree differences. [Obs.]
A*gree`a*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. [OF. agreablete.] 1. Easiness of disposition. [Obs.] Chaucer.

p.def: The quality of being, or making one's self, agreeable; agreeableness.

dictionary.p: A*gree"a*ble (AMP?;), a. [F. agrAMPeacute;able.] 1. Pleasing, either to the mind or senses; pleasant; grateful; as, agreeable manners or remarks; an agreeable person; fruit agreeable to the taste.

p.blockquote:
A train of agreeable reveries.
Goldsmith.

dictionary.p: 2. Willing; ready to agree or consent. [Colloq.]

p.blockquote:
These Frenchmen give unto the said captain of Calais a great sum of money, so that he will be but content and agreeable that they may enter into the said town.
Latimer.

That which is agreeable to the nature of one thing, is many times contrary to the nature of another.
L'Estrange.

p.def: In pursuance, conformity, or accordance; -- in this sense used adverbially for agreeably; as, agreeable to the order of the day, the House took up the report.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Pleasing; pleasant; welcome; charming; acceptable; amiable. See Pleasant.
A*gree"a*ble*ness, n. 1. The quality of being agreeable or pleasing; that quality which gives satisfaction or moderate pleasure to the mind or senses.

p.blockquote:
That author . . . has an agreeableness that charms us.
Pope.

p.def: The quality of being agreeable or suitable; suitableness or conformity; consistency.

p.blockquote:
The agreeableness of virtuous actions to human nature.
Pearce.

dictionary.p: 3. Resemblance; concordance; harmony; -- with to or between. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The agreeableness between man and the other parts of the universe.
Grew.

dictionary.p: A*gree"a*bly, adv. 1. In an agreeably manner; in a manner to give pleasure; pleasingly. "Agreeably entertained." Goldsmith.

p.blockquote:
The effect of which is, that marriages grow less frequent, agreeably to the maxim above laid down.
Paley.

dictionary.p: 3. Alike; similarly. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Both clad in shepherds' weeds agreeably.
Spenser.

dictionary.p: A*gree"ing*ly, adv. In an agreeing manner (to); correspondingly; agreeably. [Obs.]

A*gree"ment (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. agrAMPeacute;ment.] 1. State of agreeing; harmony of opinion, statement, action, or character; concurrence; concord; conformity; as, a good agreement subsists among the members of the council.

p.blockquote:
What agreement hath the temple of God with idols ?
2 Cor. vi. 16.

Expansion and duration have this further agreement.
Locke.

p.def: Concord or correspondence of one word with another in gender, number, case, or person.
A concurrence in an engagement that something shall be done or omitted; an exchange of promises; mutual understanding, arrangement, or stipulation; a contract.
The language, oral or written, embodying reciprocal promises.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Bargain; contract; compact; stipulation.
A*gre"er (AMP?;), n. One who agrees.
A*gres"tic (AMP?;), a. [L. agrestis, fr. ager field.] Pertaining to fields or the country, in opposition to the city; rural; rustic; unpolished; uncouth. "Agrestic behavior." Gregory.
A*gres"tic*al (AMP?;), a. Agrestic. [Obs.]
A*gric`o*la"tion (AMP?;), n. [L., agricolatio.] Agriculture. [Obs.] Bailey.
A*gric"o*list (AMP?;), n. A cultivator of the soil; an agriculturist. Dodsley.
Ag"ri*cul`tor (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. ager field + cultor cultivator.] An agriculturist; a farmer. [R.]
Ag`ri*cul"tur*al (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to agriculture; connected with, or engaged in, tillage; as, the agricultural class; agricultural implements, wages, etc. -- Ag`ri*cul"tur*al*ly, adv.

Agricultural ant (ZoAMPouml;l.), a species of ant which gathers and stores seeds of grasses, for food. The remarkable species (Myrmica barbata) found in Texas clears circular areas and carefully cultivates its favorite grain, known as ant rice.
Ag`ri*cul"tur*al*ist, n. An agriculturist (which is the preferred form.)

Ag"ri*cul`ture (?; 135), n. [L. agricultura; ager field + cultura cultivation: cf. F. agriculture. See Acre and Culture.] The art or science of cultivating the ground, including the harvesting of crops, and the rearing and management of live stock; tillage; husbandry; farming.
Ag`ri*cul"tur*ism (AMP?;), n. Agriculture. [R.]
Ag`ri*cul"tur*ist, n. One engaged or skilled in agriculture; a husbandman.

p.blockquote:
The farmer is always a practitioner, the agriculturist may be a mere theorist.
Crabb.

dictionary.p: A*grief" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + grief.] In grief; amiss. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Ag"ri*mo*ny (AMP?;), n. [OE. agremoyne, OF. aigremoine, L. agrimonia for argemonia, fr. Gr. AMP?;.] (Bot.) (a) A genus of plants of the Rose family. (b) The name is also given to various other plants; as, hemp agrimony (Eupatorium cannabinum); water agrimony (Bidens).
AMPfist; The Agrimonia eupatoria, or common agrimony, a perennial herb with a spike of yellow flowers, was once esteemed as a medical remedy, but is now seldom used.
A*grin" (AMPadot;*grAMPibreve;n"), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + grin.] In the act of grinning. "His visage all agrin." Tennyson.
Ag`ri*ol"o*gist (AMPabreve;g`rAMPibreve;*AMPobreve;l"AMPosl;*jAMPibreve;st), n. One versed or engaged in agriology.
Ag`ri*ol"o*gy (AMPabreve;g`rAMPibreve;*AMPobreve;l"AMPosl;*jAMPybreve;), n. [Gr. 'a`grios wild, savage + -logy.] Description or comparative study of the customs of savage or uncivilized tribes.

A*grise" (AMP?;), v. i. [AS. AMPamacr;grAMPimacr;san to dread; AMPamacr;- (cf. Goth. us-, Ger. er-, orig. meaning out) + grAMPimacr;san, for grAMP?;san (only in comp.), akin to OHG. grAMP?;isAMP?;n, G. grausen, to shudder. See Grisly.] To shudder with terror; to tremble with fear. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A*grise", v. t. 1. To shudder at; to abhor; to dread; to loathe. [Obs.] Wyclif.
2. To terrify; to affright. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
His manly face that did his foes agrise.
Spenser.

dictionary.p: ||A"grom (AMP?;), n. [Native name.] (Med.) A disease occurring in Bengal and other parts of the East Indies, in which the tongue chaps and cleaves.
{ Ag`ro*nom"ic (AMP?;), Ag`ro*nom"ic*al (AMP?;), } [Cf. F. agronomique.] Pertaining to agronomy, of the management of farms.
Ag`ro*nom"ics (AMP?;), n. The science of the distribution and management of land.
A*gron"o*mist (AMP?;), n. One versed in agronomy; a student of agronomy.

A*gron"o*my (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; rural; as a noun, an overseer of the public lands; AMP?; field + AMP?; usage, AMP?; to deal out, manage: cf. F. agronomie.] The management of land; rural economy; agriculture.
A*grope" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + grope.] In the act of groping. Mrs. Browning.
||A*gros"tis (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;.] A genus of grasses, including species called in common language bent grass. Some of them, as redtop (Agrostis vulgaris), are valuable pasture grasses.
{ A*gros`to*graph"ic (AMP?;), A*gros`to*graph"ic*al (AMP?;), } a. [Cf. F. agrostographique.] Pertaining to agrostography.
Ag`ros*tog"ra*phy (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; + - graphy.] A description of the grasses.
{ A*gros`to*log"ic (AMP?;), A*gros`to*log"ic*al (AMP?;), } a. Pertaining to agrostology.
Ag`ros*tol"o*gist (AMP?;), n. One skilled in agrostology.
Ag`ros*tol"ogy (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; + - logy.] That part of botany which treats of the grasses.
A*ground" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + ground.] On the ground; stranded; -- a nautical term applied to a ship when its bottom lodges on the ground. Totten.
A*group"ment (AMP?;), n. See Aggroupment.
Ag`ryp*not"ic (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; sleepless; AMP?; to chase, search for + AMP?; sleep: cf. F. agrypnotique.] Anything which prevents sleep, or produces wakefulness, as strong tea or coffee.
||A`guar*di*en"te (AMP?;), n. [Sp., contr. of agua ardiente burning water (L. aqua water + ardens burning).] 1. A inferior brandy of Spain and Portugal.
2. A strong alcoholic drink, especially pulque. [Mexico and Spanish America.]

A"gue (AMP?;), n. [OE. agu, ague, OF. agu, F. aigu, sharp, OF. fem. ague, LL. (febris) acuta, a sharp, acute fever, fr. L. acutus sharp. See Acute.] 1. An acute fever. [Obs.] "Brenning agues." P. Plowman.

p.def: An intermittent fever, attended by alternate cold and hot fits.
The cold fit or rigor of the intermittent fever; as, fever and ague.
A chill, or state of shaking, as with cold.

dictionary.p: Ague cake, an enlargement of the spleen produced by ague. -- Ague drop, a solution of the arsenite of potassa used for ague. -- Ague fit, a fit of the ague. Shak. -- Ague spell, a spell or charm against ague. Gay. -- Ague tree, the sassafras, -- sometimes so called from the use of its root formerly, in cases of ague. [Obs.]
A"gue, v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Agued (AMP?;).] To strike with an ague, or with a cold fit. Heywood.
A*guilt" (AMP?;), v. t. To be guilty of; to offend; to sin against; to wrong. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A*guise" (AMP?;), n. Dress. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
A*guise", v. t. [Pref a- + guise.] To dress; to attire; to adorn. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Above all knights ye goodly seem aguised.
Spenser.

Her aguish love now glows and burns.
Granville.

p.def: Productive of, or affected by, ague; as, the aguish districts of England.

dictionary.p: -- A"gu*ish*ness, n.
A*gush" (AMP?;), adv. AMP a. [Pref. a- + gush.] In a gushing state. Hawthorne.

Ah (AMP?;), interj. [OE. a: cf. OF. a, F. ah, L. ah, Gr. AMP?;, Sk. AMPamacr;, Icel. AMPaelig;, OHG. AMPamacr;, Lith. AMPaacute;, AMPaacute;AMPaacute;.] An exclamation, expressive of surprise, pity, complaint, entreaty, contempt, threatening, delight, triumph, etc., according to the manner of utterance.
A*ha" (AMP?;), interj. [Ah, interj. + ha.] An exclamation expressing, by different intonations, triumph, mixed with derision or irony, or simple surprise.
A*ha", n. A sunk fence. See Ha- ha. Mason.

p.blockquote:
The island bore but a little ahead of us.
Fielding.

dictionary.p: 2. Headlong; without restraint. [Obs.] L'Estrange.
To go ahead. (a) To go in advance. (b) To go on onward. (c) To push on in an enterprise. [Colloq] -- To get ahead of. (a) To get in advance of. (b) To surpass; to get the better of. [Colloq.]
A*heap" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + heap.] In a heap; huddled together. Hood.
A*height" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + height.] Aloft; on high. [Obs.] "Look up aheight." Shak.
A*hem" (AMP?;), interj. An exclamation to call one's attention; hem.
A*hey" (AMP?;), interj. Hey; ho.
A*high" (AMP?;), adv. On high. [Obs.] Shak.
A*hold" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + hold.] Near the wind; as, to lay a ship ahold. [Obs.] Shak.
A*horse"back (AMP?;), adv. On horseback.

p.blockquote:
Two suspicious fellows ahorseback.
Smollet.

dictionary.p: A*hoy" (AMP?;), interj. [OE. a, interj. + hoy.] (Naut.) A term used in hailing; as, "Ship ahoy."
||Ah"ri*man (AMP?;), n. [Per.] The Evil Principle or Being of the ancient Persians; the Prince of Darkness as opposer to Ormuzd, the King of Light.
||A"hu (AMP?;), n. [Native name.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) The Asiatic gazelle.
A*hull" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + hull.] (Naut.) With the sails furled, and the helm lashed alee; -- applied to ships in a storm. See Hull, n.
A*hun"gered (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- + hungered.] Pinched with hunger; very hungry. C. BrontAMPeacute;.
A"i (AMP?;), n.; pl. Ais (AMP?;). [Braz. aAMPiuml;, haAMPiuml;, from the animal's cry: cf. F. aAMPiuml;.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) The three-toed sloth (Bradypus tridactylus) of South America. See Sloth.
||Ai"blins, A"blins (AMP?;), adv. [See Able.] Perhaps; possibly. [Scotch] Burns.
Aich's met"al (AMP?;). A kind of gun metal, containing copper, zinc, and iron, but no tin.

Aid (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Aided (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Aiding.] [F. aider, OF. aidier, fr. L. adjutare to help, freq. of adjuvare to help; ad + juvare to help. Cf. Adjutant.] To support, either by furnishing strength or means in coAMPouml;peration to effect a purpose, or to prevent or to remove evil; to help; to assist.

p.blockquote:
You speedy helpers . . .
Appear and aid me in this enterprise.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To help; assist; support; sustain; succor; relieve; befriend; coAMPouml;perate; promote. See Help.
Aid, n. [F. aide, OF. aAMPiuml;de, aAMPiuml;e, fr. the verb. See Aid, v. t.] 1. Help; succor; assistance; relief.

p.blockquote:
An unconstitutional mode of obtaining aid.
Hallam.

p.def: The person or thing that promotes or helps in something done; a helper; an assistant.

p.blockquote:
It is not good that man should be alone; let us make unto him an aid like unto himself.
Tobit viii. 6.

p.def: A subsidy granted to the king by Parliament; also, an exchequer loan.
A pecuniary tribute paid by a vassal to his lord on special occasions.
An aid-de-camp, so called by abbreviation; as, a general's aid.

dictionary.p: Aid prayer (Law), a proceeding by which a defendant beseeches and claims assistance from some one who has a further or more permanent interest in the matter in suit. -- To pray in aid, to beseech and claim such assistance.
Aid"ance (AMP?;), n. [Cf. OF. aidance.] Aid. [R.]

p.blockquote:
Aidance 'gainst the enemy.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Aid"ant (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. aidant, p. pr. of aider to help.] Helping; helpful; supplying aid. Shak.

Aid"-de-camp` (AMP?;), n.; pl. Aids-de-camp. (AMP?;). [F. aide de camp (literally) camp assistant.] (Mil.) An officer selected by a general to carry orders, also to assist or represent him in correspondence and in directing movements.
Aid"er (AMP?;), n. One who, or that which, aids.
Aid"ful (AMP?;), a. Helpful. [Archaic.] Bp. Hall.
Aid"less, a. Helpless; without aid. Milton.
Aid"-ma`jor (AMP?;), n. The adjutant of a regiment.
Ai"el (AMP?;), n. See Ayle. [Obs.]
Aig"let (AMP?;), n. Same as Aglet.
Ai"gre (AMP?;), a. [F. See Eager.] Sour. [Obs.] Shak.
||Ai"gre*more (AMP?;), n. [F. origin unknown.] Charcoal prepared for making powder.

{ Ai"gret (AMP?;), Ai*grette (AMP?;), } n. [F., a sort of white heron, with a tuft of feathers on its head; a tuft of feathers; dim. of the same word as heron. See Heron, and cf. Egret, Egrette.] 1. (ZoAMPouml;l.) The small white European heron. See Egret.

p.def: A plume or tuft for the head composed of feathers, or of gems, etc.
A tuft like that of the egret.
A feathery crown of seed; egret; as, the aigrette or down of the dandelion or the thistle.

dictionary.p: ||Ai`guille" (AMP?;), n. [F., a needle. See Aglet.] 1. A needle-shaped peak.

p.def: An instrument for boring holes, used in blasting.

dictionary.p: Ai`guil*lette" (AMP?;), n. [F. See Aglet.] 1. A point or tag at the end of a fringe or lace; an aglet.

p.def: One of the ornamental tags, cords, or loops on some military and naval uniforms.

dictionary.p: Ai"gu*let (AMP?;), n. See Aglet. Spenser.

Ail (AMPamacr;l), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Ailed (AMPamacr;ld); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Ailing.] [OE. eilen, ailen, AS. eglan to trouble, pain; akin to Goth. us-agljan to distress, agls troublesome, irksome, aglo, aglitha, pain, and prob. to E. awe. AMPradic;3.] To affect with pain or uneasiness, either physical or mental; to trouble; to be the matter with; -- used to express some uneasiness or affection, whose cause is unknown; as, what ails the man? I know not what ails him.

p.blockquote:
What aileth thee, Hagar?
Gen. xxi. 17.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; It is never used to express a specific disease. We do not say, a fever ails him; but, something ails him.
Ail, v. i. To be affected with pain or uneasiness of any sort; to be ill or indisposed or in trouble.

p.blockquote:
When he ails ever so little . . . he is so peevish.
Richardson.

dictionary.p: Ail, n. Indisposition or morbid affection. Pope.
Ai*lan"thus (AMP?;), n. Same as Ailantus.

Ai*lan"tus (AMP?;), n. [From aylanto, i. e., tree of heaven, the name of the tree in the Moluccas.] (Bot.) A genus of beautiful trees, natives of the East Indies. The tree imperfectly diAMPoelig;cious, and the staminate or male plant is very offensive when blossom.
Ai*lette (AMP?;), n. [F. ailette, dim. of aile wing, L. ala.] A small square shield, formerly worn on the shoulders of knights, -- being the prototype of the modern epaulet. Fairholt.
Ail"ment (AMP?;), n. Indisposition; morbid affection of the body; -- not applied ordinarily to acute diseases. "Little ailments." Landsdowne.
||Ai`lu*roid"e*a (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; cat + -oid.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A group of the Carnivora, which includes the cats, civets, and hyenas.

Aim (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Aimed (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Aiming.] [OE. amen, aimen, eimen, to guess at, to estimate, to aim, OF. esmer, asmer, fr. L. aestimare to estimate; or perh. fr. OF. aesmer; AMP?; (L. ad) + esmer. See Estimate.] 1. To point or direct a missile weapon, or a weapon which propels as missile, towards an object or spot with the intent of hitting it; as, to aim at a fox, or at a target.

p.def: To direct the indention or purpose; to attempt the accomplishment of a purpose; to try to gain; to endeavor; -- followed by at, or by an infinitive; as, to aim at distinction; to aim to do well.

p.blockquote:
Aim'st thou at princes?
Pope.

dictionary.p: 3. To guess or conjecture. [Obs.] Shak.

Aim, v. t. To direct or point, as a weapon, at a particular object; to direct, as a missile, an act, or a proceeding, at, to, or against an object; as, to aim a musket or an arrow, the fist or a blow (at something); to aim a satire or a reflection (at some person or vice).

Aim, n. [Cf. OF. esme estimation, fr. esmer. See Aim, v. i.] 1. The pointing of a weapon, as a gun, a dart, or an arrow, in the line of direction with the object intended to be struck; the line of fire; the direction of anything, as a spear, a blow, a discourse, a remark, towards a particular point or object, with a view to strike or affect it.

p.blockquote:
Each at the head leveled his deadly aim.
Milton.

p.def: The point intended to be hit, or object intended to be attained or affected.

p.blockquote:
To be the aim of every dangerous shot.
Shak.

p.def: Intention; purpose; design; scheme.

p.blockquote:
How oft ambitious aims are crossed!
Pope.

dictionary.p: 4. Conjecture; guess. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
What you would work me to, I have some aim.
Shak.

dictionary.p: To cry aim (Archery), to encourage. [Obs.] Shak.
Syn. -- End; object; scope; drift; design; purpose; intention; scheme; tendency; aspiration.
Aim"er (AMP?;), n. One who aims, directs, or points.
Aim"less, a. Without aim or purpose; as, an aimless life. -- Aim"less*ly, adv. -- Aim"less*ness, n.

Ai"no (AMP?;), n. [Said to be the native name for man.] One of a peculiar race inhabiting Yesso, the Kooril Islands etc., in the northern part of the empire of Japan, by some supposed to have been the progenitors of the Japanese. The Ainos are stout and short, with hairy bodies.
Ain't (AMP?;). A contraction for are not and am not; also used for is not. [Colloq. or illiterate speech]. See An't.

Air (AMPacirc;r), n. [OE. air, eir, F. air, L. aAMPeuml;r, fr. Gr. 'ah`r, air, mist, for 'aAMPdigamma;hr, fr. root 'aAMPdigamma; to blow, breathe, probably akin to E. wind. In sense 10 the French has taking a meaning fr. It. aria atmosphere, air, fr. the same Latin word; and in senses 11, 12, 13 the French meaning is either fr. L. aria, or due to confusion with F. aire, in an older sense of origin, descent. Cf. AAMPeuml;ry, Debonair, Malaria, Wind.] 1. The fluid which we breathe, and which surrounds the earth; the atmosphere. It is invisible, inodorous, insipid, transparent, compressible, elastic, and ponderable.

AMPfist; By the ancient philosophers, air was regarded as an element; but modern science has shown that it is essentially a mixture of oxygen and nitrogen, with a small amount of carbon dioxide, the average proportions being, by volume: oxygen, 20.96 per cent.; nitrogen, 79.00 per cent.; carbon dioxide, 0.04 per cent. These proportions are subject to a very slight variability. Air also always contains some vapor of water.
2. Symbolically: Something unsubstantial, light, or volatile. "Charm ache with air." Shak.
He was still all air and fire. [Air and fire being the finer and quicker elements as opposed to earth and water.] Macaulay.

p.def: A particular state of the atmosphere, as respects heat, cold, moisture, etc., or as affecting the sensations; as, a smoky air, a damp air, the morning air, etc.

dictionary.p: 4. Any aAMPeuml;riform body; a gas; as, oxygen was formerly called vital air. [Obs.]

p.def: Air in motion; a light breeze; a gentle wind.

p.blockquote:
Let vernal airs through trembling osiers play.
Pope.

p.def: Odoriferous or contaminated air.
That which surrounds and influences.

p.blockquote:
The keen, the wholesome air of poverty.
Wordsworth.

p.def: Utterance abroad; publicity; vent.

p.blockquote:
You gave it air before me.
Dryden.

dictionary.p: 9. Intelligence; information. [Obs.] Bacon.

p.def: A musical idea, or motive, rhythmically developed in consecutive single tones, so as to form a symmetrical and balanced whole, which may be sung by a single voice to the stanzas of a hymn or song, or even to plain prose, or played upon an instrument; a melody; a tune; an aria.
In harmonized chorals, psalmody, part songs, etc., the part which bears the tune or melody -- in modern harmony usually the upper part -- is sometimes called the air.
Peculiar appearance; apparent character; semblance; manner; style.

p.blockquote:
It was communicated with the air of a secret.
Pope.

p.def: The representation or reproduction of the effect of the atmospheric medium through which every object in nature is viewed.
Carriage; attitude; action; movement; as, the head of that portrait has a good air.
The artificial motion or carriage of a horse.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; Air is much used adjectively or as the first part of a compound term. In most cases it might be written indifferently, as a separate limiting word, or as the first element of the compound term, with or without the hyphen; as, air bladder, air-bladder, or airbladder; air cell, air-cell, or aircell; air-pump, or airpump.

Air balloon. See Balloon. -- Air bath. (a) An apparatus for the application of air to the body. (b) An arrangement for drying substances in air of any desired temperature. -- Air castle. See Castle in the air, under Castle. -- Air compressor, a machine for compressing air to be used as a motive power. -- Air crossing, a passage for air in a mine. -- Air cushion, an air-tight cushion which can be inflated; also, a device for arresting motion without shock by confined air. -- Air fountain, a contrivance for producing a jet of water by the force of compressed air. -- Air furnace, a furnace which depends on a natural draft and not on blast. -- Air line, a straight line; a bee line. Hence Air-line, adj.; as, air-line road. -- Air lock (Hydr. Engin.), an intermediate chamber between the outer air and the compressed-air chamber of a pneumatic caisson. Knight. -- Air port (Nav.), a scuttle or porthole in a ship to admit air. -- Air spring, a spring in which the elasticity of air is utilized. -- Air thermometer, a form of thermometer in which the contraction and expansion of air is made to measure changes of temperature. -- Air threads, gossamer. -- Air trap, a contrivance for shutting off foul air or gas from drains, sewers, etc.; a stench trap. -- Air trunk, a pipe or shaft for conducting foul or heated air from a room. -- Air valve, a valve to regulate the admission or egress of air; esp. a valve which opens inwardly in a steam boiler and allows air to enter. -- Air way, a passage for a current of air; as the air way of an air pump; an air way in a mine. -- In the air. (a) Prevalent without traceable origin or authority, as rumors. (b) Not in a fixed or stable position; unsettled. (c) (Mil.) Unsupported and liable to be turned or taken in flank; as, the army had its wing in the air. -- To take air, to be divulged; to be made public. -- To take the air, to go abroad; to walk or ride out.

Air (AMPacirc;r), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Aired (AMPacirc;rd); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Airing.] [See Air, n., and cf. AAMPeuml;rate.] 1. To expose to the air for the purpose of cooling, refreshing, or purifying; to ventilate; as, to air a room.

p.blockquote:
It were good wisdom . . . that the jail were aired.
Bacon.

Were you but riding forth to air yourself.
Shak.

p.def: To expose for the sake of public notice; to display ostentatiously; as, to air one's opinion.

p.blockquote:
Airing a snowy hand and signet gem.
Tennyson.

p.def: To expose to heat, for the purpose of expelling dampness, or of warming; as, to air linen; to air liquors.

dictionary.p: Air" bed` (AMP?;). A sack or matters inflated with air, and used as a bed.

Air" blad`der (AMP?;). 1. (Anat.) An air sac, sometimes double or variously lobed, in the visceral cavity of many fishes. It originates in the same way as the lungs of air-breathing vertebrates, and in the adult may retain a tubular connection with the pharynx or esophagus.

p.def: A sac or bladder full of air in an animal or plant; also an air hole in a casting.

dictionary.p: Air" brake` (AMP?;). (Mach.) A railway brake operated by condensed air. Knight.
Air"-built` (AMP?;), a. Erected in the air; having no solid foundation; chimerical; as, an air-built castle.
Air" cell` (AMP?;). 1. (Bot.) A cavity in the cellular tissue of plants, containing air only.

p.def: A receptacle of air in various parts of the system; as, a cell or minute cavity in the walls of the air tubes of the lungs; the air sac of birds; a dilatation of the air vessels in insects.

dictionary.p: Air" cham`ber (AMP?;). 1. A chamber or cavity filled with air, in an animal or plant.

p.def: A cavity containing air to act as a spring for equalizing the flow of a liquid in a pump or other hydraulic machine.

dictionary.p: Air" cock` (AMP?;). A faucet to allow escape of air.
Air"-drawn" (AMP?;), a. Drawn in air; imaginary.

p.blockquote:
This is the air-drawn dagger.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Air" drill` (AMP?;). A drill driven by the elastic pressure of condensed air; a pneumatic drill. Knight.
Air" engine` (AMP?;). An engine driven by heated or by compressed air. Knight.
Air"er (AMP?;), n. 1. One who exposes to the air.

p.def: A frame on which clothes are aired or dried.

dictionary.p: Air" gas` (AMP?;). See under Gas.

Air" gun` (gAMPubreve;n`). A kind of gun in which the elastic force of condensed air is used to discharge the ball. The air is powerfully compressed into a reservoir attached to the gun, by a condensing pump, and is controlled by a valve actuated by the trigger.
Air" hole` (hAMPomacr;l`). 1. A hole to admit or discharge air; specifically, a spot in the ice not frozen over.

p.def: A fault in a casting, produced by a bubble of air; a blowhole.

dictionary.p: Air"i*ly (AMPacirc;r"AMPibreve;*lAMPybreve;), adv. In an airy manner; lightly; gaily; jauntily; flippantly.
Air"i*ness, n. 1. The state or quality of being airy; openness or exposure to the air; as, the airiness of a country seat.

p.def: Lightness of spirits; gayety; levity; as, the airiness of young persons.

dictionary.p: Air"ing (AMPacirc;r"AMPibreve;ng), n. 1. A walk or a ride in the open air; a short excursion for health's sake.

p.def: An exposure to air, or to a fire, for warming, drying, etc.; as, the airing of linen, or of a room.

dictionary.p: Air" jack`et (AMP?;). A jacket having air-tight cells, or cavities which can be filled with air, to render persons buoyant in swimming.
Air"less (AMP?;), a. Not open to a free current of air; wanting fresh air, or communication with the open air.
Air" lev`el (AMP?;). Spirit level. See Level.
Air"like` (AMP?;), a. Resembling air.
Air"ling (AMP?;), n. A thoughtless, gay person. [Obs.] "Slight airlings." B. Jonson.
Air*om"e*ter (AMP?;), n. [Air + - meter.] A hollow cylinder to contain air. It is closed above and open below, and has its open end plunged into water.
Air" pipe` (AMP?;). A pipe for the passage of air; esp. a ventilating pipe.
Air" plant` (AMP?;). (Bot.) A plant deriving its sustenance from the air alone; an aAMPeuml;rophyte.
AMPfist; The "Florida moss" (Tillandsia), many tropical orchids, and most mosses and lichens are air plants. Those which are lodged upon trees, but not parasitic on them, are epiphytes.
Air" poise` (AMP?;). [See Poise.] An instrument to measure the weight of air.
Air" pump` (AMP?;). 1. (Physics) A kind of pump for exhausting air from a vessel or closed space; also, a pump to condense air or force it into a closed space.

p.def: A pump used to exhaust from a condenser the condensed steam, the water used for condensing, and any commingled air.

dictionary.p: Air" sac` (AMP?;). (Anat.) One of the spaces in different parts of the bodies of birds, which are filled with air and connected with the air passages of the lungs; an air cell.
Air" shaft` (AMP?;). A passage, usually vertical, for admitting fresh air into a mine or a tunnel.
Air"-slacked` (AMP?;), a. Slacked, or pulverized, by exposure to the air; as, air-slacked lime.
Air" stove` (AMP?;). A stove for heating a current of air which is directed against its surface by means of pipes, and then distributed through a building.
Air"-tight` (AMP?;), a. So tight as to be impermeable to air; as, an air-tight cylinder.
Air"-tight`, n. A stove the draft of which can be almost entirely shut off. [Colloq. U. S.]

Air" ves`sel (AMP?;). A vessel, cell, duct, or tube containing or conducting air; as the air vessels of insects, birds, plants, etc.; the air vessel of a pump, engine, etc. For the latter, see Air chamber. The air vessels of insects are called tracheAMPaelig;, of plants spiral vessels.
Air"y (AMP?;), a. 1. Consisting of air; as, an airy substance; the airy parts of bodies.

p.def: Open to a free current of air; exposed to the air; breezy; as, an airy situation.

dictionary.p: 4. Resembling air; thin; unsubstantial; not material; airlike. "An airy spirit." Shak.

p.def: Relating to the spirit or soul; delicate; graceful; as, airy music.

dictionary.p: 6. Without reality; having no solid foundation; empty; trifling; visionary. "Airy fame." Shak.

p.blockquote:
Empty sound, and airy notions.
Roscommon.

dictionary.p: 7. Light of heart; vivacious; sprightly; flippant; superficial. "Merry and airy." Jer. Taylor.
8. Having an affected manner; being in the habit of putting on airs; affectedly grand. [Colloq.]

p.def: Having the light and aAMPeuml;rial tints true to nature.

dictionary.p: Aisle (AMP?;), n. [OF. ele, F. aile, wing, wing of a building, L. ala, contr. fr. axilla.] (Arch.) (a) A lateral division of a building, separated from the middle part, called the nave, by a row of columns or piers, which support the roof or an upper wall containing windows, called the clearstory wall. (b) Improperly used also for the have; -- as in the phrases, a church with three aisles, the middle aisle. (c) Also (perhaps from confusion with alley), a passage into which the pews of a church open.
Aisled (AMP?;), a. Furnished with an aisle or aisles.
Ais"less (AMP?;), a. Without an aisle.
Ait (AMP?;), n. [AS. AMP?;, AMP?;, perh. dim. of AMPimacr;eg, AMPimacr;g, island. See Eyot.] An islet, or little isle, in a river or lake; an eyot.

p.blockquote:
The ait where the osiers grew.
R. Hodges (1649).

Among green aits and meadows.
Dickens.

dictionary.p: Ait (AMP?;), n. Oat. [Scot.] Burns.
Aitch (AMP?;), n. The letter h or H.
Aitch"bone` (AMP?;), n. [For nachebone. For loss of n, cf. Adder. See Natch.] The bone of the rump; also, the cut of beef surrounding this bone. [Spelt also edgebone.]
Ai`ti*ol"o*gy (AMP?;), n. See AMPAElig;tiology.
A*jar" (AMP?;), adv. [OE. on char ajar, on the turn; AS. cerr, cyrr, turn, akin to G. kehren to turn, and to D. akerre. See Char.] Slightly turned or opened; as, the door was standing ajar.
A*jar" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + jar.] In a state of discord; out of harmony; as, he is ajar with the world.
A*jog" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + jog.] On the jog.

Aj"u*tage (AMP?;), n. [F. ajutage, for ajoutage, fr. ajouter to add, LL. adjuxtare, fr. L. ad + juxta near to, nigh. Cf. Adjutage, Adjustage, Adjust.] A tube through which water is discharged; an efflux tube; as, the ajutage of a fountain.
Ake (AMP?;), n. AMP v. See Ache.
A*kene" (AMP?;), n. (Bot.) Same as Achene.
Ak"e*ton (AMP?;), n. [Obs.] See Acton.
A*kim"bo (AMP?;), a. [Etymology unknown. Cf. Kimbo.] With a crook or bend; with the hand on the hip and elbow turned outward. "With one arm akimbo." Irving.
A*kin" (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- (for of) + kin.] 1. Of the same kin; related by blood; -- used of persons; as, the two families are near akin.
2. Allied by nature; partaking of the same properties; of the same kind. "A joy akin to rapture." Cowper.

p.blockquote:
The literary character of the work is akin to its moral character.
Jeffrey.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; This adjective is used only after the noun.
Ak`i*ne"sic (AMP?;), a. (Med.) Pertaining to akinesia.
A*knee" (AMP?;), adv. On the knee. [R.] Southey.
Ak*now" (AMP?;). Earlier form of Acknow. [Obs.]
To be aknow, to acknowledge; to confess. [Obs.]
Al (AMP?;), a. All. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Al-. A prefix. (a) [AS. eal.] All; wholly; completely; as, almighty, almost. (b) [L. ad.] To; at; on; -- in OF. shortened to a-. See Ad-. (c) The Arabic definite article answering to the English the; as, Alkoran, the Koran or the Book; alchemy, the chemistry.
Al. conj. Although; if. [Obs.] See All, conj.
||A"la (AMP?;), n.; pl. AlAMPaelig; (AMP?;). [L., a wing.] (Biol.) A winglike organ, or part.
Al`a*ba"ma pe"ri*od (AMP?;). (Geol.) A period in the American eocene, the lowest in the tertiary age except the lignitic.

Al"a*bas"ter (AMP?;), n. [L. alabaster, Gr. AMP?;, said to be derived fr. Alabastron, the name of a town in Egypt, near which it was common: cf. OF. alabastre, F. albAMPacirc;tre.] 1. (Min.) (a) A compact variety or sulphate of lime, or gypsum, of fine texture, and usually white and translucent, but sometimes yellow, red, or gray. It is carved into vases, mantel ornaments, etc. (b) A hard, compact variety of carbonate of lime, somewhat translucent, or of banded shades of color; stalagmite. The name is used in this sense by Pliny. It is sometimes distinguished as oriental alabaster.

p.def: A box or vessel for holding odoriferous ointments, etc.; -- so called from the stone of which it was originally made.

dictionary.p: Al`a*bas"tri*an (AMP?;), a. Alabastrine.
Al`a*bas"trine (AMP?;), a. Of, pertaining to, or like, alabaster; as alabastrine limbs.
||Al`a*bas"trum (AMP?;), n.; pl. Alabastra (AMP?;). [NL.] (Bot.) A flower bud. Gray.
A*lack" (AMP?;), interj. [Prob. from ah! lack! OE. lak loss, failure, misfortune. See Lack.] An exclamation expressive of sorrow. [Archaic. or Poet.] Shak.
A*lack"a*day` (AMP?;), interj. [For alack the day. Cf. Lackaday.] An exclamation expressing sorrow.
AMPfist; Shakespeare has "alack the day" and "alack the heavy day." Compare "woe worth the day."
A*lac"ri*fy (AMP?;), v. t. [L. alacer, alacris, lively + -fly.] To rouse to action; to inspirit.
A*lac"ri*ous (AMP?;), a. [L. alacer, alacris.] Brisk; joyously active; lively.

p.blockquote:
'T were well if we were a little more alacrious.
Hammond.

dictionary.p: A*lac"ri*ous*ly, adv. With alacrity; briskly.
A*lac"ri*ous*ness, n. Alacrity. [Obs.] Hammond.

A*lac"ri*ty (AMP?;), n. [L. alacritas, fr. alacer lively, eager, prob. akin to Gr. AMP?; to drive, Goth. aljan zeal.] A cheerful readiness, willingness, or promptitude; joyous activity; briskness; sprightliness; as, the soldiers advanced with alacrity to meet the enemy.

p.blockquote:
I have not that alacrity of spirit,
Nor cheer of mind that I was wont to have.
Shak.

dictionary.p: A*lad"in*ist (AMP?;), n. [From Aladin, for Ala Eddin, i. e., height of religion, a learned divine under Mohammed II. and Bajazet II.] One of a sect of freethinkers among the Mohammedans.
Al`a*lon"ga (AMP?;), or Al`i*lon"ghi (AMP?;), n. (ZoAMPouml;l.) The tunny. See Albicore.
||A`la*mi"re (AMP?;), n. [Compounded of a la mi re, names of notes in the musical scale.] The lowest note but one in Guido Aretino's scale of music.
Al"a*mode`, n. A thin, black silk for hoods, scarfs, etc.; -- often called simply mode. Buchanan.
A*lan" (AMPadot;*lAMPadot;n"), n. [OF. alan, alant; cf. Sp. alano.] A wolfhound. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A*land" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + land.] On land; to the land; ashore. "Cast aland." Sir P. Sidney.
Al"a*nine (AMP?;), n. [Aldehyde + the ending -ine. The -n- is a euphonic insertion.] (Chem.) A white crystalline base, C3H7NO2, derived from aldehyde ammonia.
A*lan"tin (AMP?;), n. [G. alant elecampane, the Inula helenium of LinnAMPaelig;us.] (Chem.) See Inulin.
A"lar (AMP?;), a. [L. alarius, fr. ala wing: cf. F. alaire.] 1. Pertaining to, or having, wings.

p.def: Axillary; in the fork or axil.

dictionary.p: A*larm" (AMPadot;*lAMPauml;rm"), n. [F. alarme, It. all' arme to arms ! fr. L. arma, pl., arms. See Arms, and cf. Alarum.] 1. A summons to arms, as on the approach of an enemy.

p.blockquote:
Arming to answer in a night alarm.
Shak.

p.def: Any sound or information intended to give notice of approaching danger; a warning sound to arouse attention; a warning of danger.

p.blockquote:
Sound an alarm in my holy mountain.
Joel ii. 1.

dictionary.p: 3. A sudden attack; disturbance; broil. [R.] "These home alarms." Shak.

p.blockquote:
Thy palace fill with insults and alarms.
Pope.

p.def: Sudden surprise with fear or terror excited by apprehension of danger; in the military use, commonly, sudden apprehension of being attacked by surprise.

p.blockquote:
Alarm and resentment spread throughout the camp.
Macaulay.

p.def: A mechanical contrivance for awaking persons from sleep, or rousing their attention; an alarum.

dictionary.p: Alarm bell, a bell that gives notice on danger. -- Alarm clock or watch, a clock or watch which can be so set as to ring or strike loudly at a prearranged hour, to wake from sleep, or excite attention. -- Alarm gauge, a contrivance attached to a steam boiler for showing when the pressure of steam is too high, or the water in the boiler too low. -- Alarm post, a place to which troops are to repair in case of an alarm.

Syn. -- Fright; affright; terror; trepidation; apprehension; consternation; dismay; agitation; disquiet; disquietude. -- Alarm, Fright, Terror, Consternation. These words express different degrees of fear at the approach of danger. Fright is fear suddenly excited, producing confusion of the senses, and hence it is unreflecting. Alarm is the hurried agitation of feeling which springs from a sense of immediate and extreme exposure. Terror is agitating and excessive fear, which usually benumbs the faculties. Consternation is overwhelming fear, and carries a notion of powerlessness and amazement. Alarm agitates the feelings; terror disorders the understanding and affects the will; fright seizes on and confuses the sense; consternation takes possession of the soul, and subdues its faculties. See Apprehension.

A*larm", v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Alarmed (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Alarming.] [Alarm, n. Cf. F. alarmer.] 1. To call to arms for defense; to give notice to (any one) of approaching danger; to rouse to vigilance and action; to put on the alert.

p.def: To keep in excitement; to disturb.
To surprise with apprehension of danger; to fill with anxiety in regard to threatening evil; to excite with sudden fear.

p.blockquote:
Alarmed by rumors of military preparation.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: A*larm"a*ble (AMP?;), a. Easily alarmed or disturbed.
A*larmed" (AMP?;), a. Aroused to vigilance; excited by fear of approaching danger; agitated; disturbed; as, an alarmed neighborhood; an alarmed modesty.

p.blockquote:
The white pavilions rose and fell
On the alarmed air.
Longfellow.

dictionary.p: A*larm"ed*ly (AMP?;), adv. In an alarmed manner.
A*larm"ing, a. Exciting, or calculated to excite, alarm; causing apprehension of danger; as, an alarming crisis or report. -- A*larm"ing*ly, adv.
A*larm"ist, n. [Cf. F. alarmiste.] One prone to sound or excite alarms, especially, needless alarms. Macaulay.
A*lar"um (?; 277), n. [OE. alarom, the same word as alarm, n.] See Alarm. [Now Poetic]
AMPfist; The variant form alarum is now commonly restricted to an alarm signal or the mechanism to sound an alarm (as in an alarm clock.)
Al"a*ry (AMP?;), a. [L. alarius, fr. ala wing.] Of or pertaining to wings; also, wing- shaped.

p.blockquote:
The alary system of insects.
Wollaston.

dictionary.p: A*las" (AMP?;), interj. [OE. alas, allas, OF. alas, F. hAMPeacute;las; a interj. (L. ah.) + las wretched (that I am), L. lassus weary, akin to E. late. See Late.] An exclamation expressive of sorrow, pity, or apprehension of evil; -- in old writers, sometimes followed by day or white; alas the day, like alack a day, or alas the white.
A*late" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + late.] Lately; of late. [Archaic]

p.blockquote:
There hath been alate such tales spread abroad.
Latimer.

dictionary.p: { A"late (AMP?;), A"la*ted (AMP?;), } a. [L. alatus, from ala wing.] Winged; having wings, or side appendages like wings.
{ Al"a*tern (AMP?;), ||Al`a*ter"nus (AMP?;), } n. [L. ala wing + terni three each.] (Bot.) An ornamental evergreen shrub (Rhamnus alaternus) belonging to the buckthorns.
A*la"tion (AMP?;), n. [F., fr. L. alatus winged.] The state of being winged.
A*launt" (AMP?;), n. See Alan. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Alb (AMP?;), n. [OE. albe, LL. alba, fr. L. albus white. Cf. Album and Aube.] A vestment of white linen, reaching to the feet, an enveloping the person; -- in the Roman Catholic church, worn by those in holy orders when officiating at mass. It was formerly worn, at least by clerics, in daily life.
Al"ba*core (AMP?;), n. (ZoAMPouml;l.) See Albicore.
Al"ban (AMP?;), n. [L. albus white.] (Chem.) A white crystalline resinous substance extracted from gutta-percha by the action of alcohol or ether.
Al*ba"ni*an (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to Albania, a province of Turkey. -- n. A native of Albania.

||Al*ba"ta (AMP?;), n. [L. albatus, p. p. of albare to make white, fr. albus white.] A white metallic alloy; which is made into spoons, forks, teapots, etc. British plate or German silver. See German silver, under German.

Al"ba*tross (AMP?;), n. [Corrupt. fr. Pg. alcatraz cormorant, albatross, or Sp. alcatraz a pelican: cf. Pg. alcatruz, Sp. arcaduz, a bucket, fr. Ar. al- qAMPamacr;dus the bucket, fr. Gr. ka`dos, a water vessel. So an Arabic term for pelican is water-carrier, as a bird carrying water in its pouch.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A web-footed bird, of the genus Diomedea, of which there are several species. They are the largest of sea birds, capable of long-continued flight, and are often seen at great distances from the land. They are found chiefly in the southern hemisphere.
{ Al`be", Al`bee" } (AMP?;), conj. [See Albeit.] Although; albeit. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Albe Clarissa were their chiefest founderess.
Spenser.

dictionary.p: ||Al*be"do (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. albus white.] Whiteness. Specifically: (Astron.) The ratio which the light reflected from an unpolished surface bears to the total light falling upon that surface.
Al`be"it (AMP?;), conj. [OE. al be although it be, where al is our all. Cf. Although.] Even though; although; notwithstanding. Chaucer.

p.blockquote:
Albeit so masked, Madam, I love the truth.
Tennyson.

dictionary.p: Al"bert*ite (AMP?;), n. (Min.) A bituminous mineral resembling asphaltum, found in the county of A. AMP?;bert, New Brunswick.
Al"ber*type (AMP?;), n. [From the name of the inventor, Albert, of Munich.] A picture printed from a kind of gelatine plate produced by means of a photographic negative.
Al*bes"cence (AMP?;), n. The act of becoming white; whitishness.
Al*bes"cent (AMP?;), a. [L. albescens, p. pr. of albescere to grow white, fr. albus white.] Becoming white or whitish; moderately white.
Al"bi*cant (AMP?;), a. [L. albicans, p. pr. of albicare, albicatum, to be white, fr. albus white.] Growing or becoming white.
Al`bi*ca"tion (AMP?;), n. The process of becoming white, or developing white patches, or streaks.

Al"bi*core (AMP?;), n. [F. albicore (cf. Sp. albacora, Pg. albacor, albacora, albecora), fr. Ar. bakr, bekr, a young camel, young cow, heifer, and the article al: cf. Pg. bacoro a little pig.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A name applied to several large fishes of the Mackerel family, esp. Orcynus alalonga. One species (Orcynus thynnus), common in the Mediterranean and Atlantic, is called in New England the horse mackerel; the tunny. [Written also albacore.]
Al`bi*fi*ca"tion (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. albification: L. albus white + ficare (only in comp.), facere, to make.] The act or process of making white. [Obs.]
