2. Hence: A double-dealer; one equally ready to act on either side in party disputes.

p.blockquote:
The rest are hypocrites, ambidexters, so many turning pictures -- a lion on one side, a lamb on the other.
Burton.

p.def: A juror who takes money from both parties for giving his verdict.

dictionary.p: Am"bi*dex*ter"i*ty (AMP?;), n. 1. The quality of being ambidextrous; the faculty of using both hands with equal facility. Hence: Versatility; general readiness; as, ambidexterity of argumentation. Sterne.

p.blockquote:
Ignorant I was of the human frame, and of its latent powers, as regarded speed, force, and ambidexterity.
De Quincey.

p.def: Double-dealing.
A juror's taking of money from the both parties for a verdict.

dictionary.p: Am`bi*dex"tral (AMP?;), a. Pertaining equally to the right-hand side and the left-hand side. Earle.
Am`bi*dex"trous (AMP?;), a. 1. Having the faculty of using both hands with equal ease. Sir T. Browne.

p.def: Practicing or siding with both parties.

p.blockquote:
All false, shuffling, and ambidextrous dealings.
L'Estrange.

dictionary.p: Am"bi*dex"trous*ly, adv. In an ambidextrous manner; cunningly.
Am`bi*dex"trous*ness (AMP?;), n. The quality of being ambidextrous; ambidexterity.
Am"bi*ent (AMP?;), a. [L. ambiens, p. pr. of ambire to go around; amb- + ire to go.] Encompassing on all sides; circumfused; investing. "Ambient air." Milton. "Ambient clouds." Pope.
Am"bi*ent, n. Something that surrounds or invests; as, air . . . being a perpetual ambient. Sir H. Wotton.

Am*big"e*nous (AMP?;), a. [L. ambo both + genus kind.] Of two kinds. (Bot.) Partaking of two natures, as the perianth of some endogenous plants, where the outer surface is calycine, and the inner petaloid.
Am"bi*gu (AMP?;), n. [F., fr. ambigu doubtful, L. ambiquus. See Ambiguous.] An entertainment at which a medley of dishes is set on at the same time.

Am`bi*gu"i*ty (AMP?;), n.; pl. Ambiguities (AMP?;). [L. ambiguitas, fr. ambiguus: cf. F. ambiguitAMPeacute;.] The quality or state of being ambiguous; doubtfulness or uncertainty, particularly as to the signification of language, arising from its admitting of more than one meaning; an equivocal word or expression.

p.blockquote:
No shadow of ambiguity can rest upon the course to be pursued.
I. Taylor.

The words are of single signification, without any ambiguity.
South.

dictionary.p: Am*big"u*ous (AMP?;), a. [L. ambiguus, fr. ambigere to wander about, waver; amb- + agere to drive.] Doubtful or uncertain, particularly in respect to signification; capable of being understood in either of two or more possible senses; equivocal; as, an ambiguous course; an ambiguous expression.

p.blockquote:
What have been thy answers? What but dark,
Ambiguous, and with double sense deluding?
Milton.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Doubtful; dubious; uncertain; unsettled; indistinct; indeterminate; indefinite. See Equivocal.
Am*big"u*ous*ly, adv. In an ambiguous manner; with doubtful meaning.
Am*big"u*ous*ness, n. Ambiguity.
Am`bi*le"vous (AMP?;), a. [L. ambo both + laevus left.] Left-handed on both sides; clumsy; -- opposed to ambidexter. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Am*bil"o*quy (AMP?;), n. Doubtful or ambiguous language. [Obs.] Bailey.
Am*bip"a*rous (AMP?;), a. [L. ambo both + parere to bring forth.] (Bot.) Characterized by containing the rudiments of both flowers and leaves; -- applied to a bud.
Am"bit (AMP?;), n. [L. ambitus circuit, fr. ambire to go around. See Ambient.] Circuit or compass.

p.blockquote:
His great parts did not live within a small ambit.
Milward.

dictionary.p: Am*bi"tion (AMP?;), n. [F. ambition, L. ambitio a going around, especially of candidates for office is Rome, to solicit votes (hence, desire for office or honorAMP?; fr. ambire to go around. See Ambient, Issue.] 1. The act of going about to solicit or obtain an office, or any other object of desire; canvassing. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
[I] used no ambition to commend my deeds.
Milton.

p.def: An eager, and sometimes an inordinate, desire for preferment, honor, superiority, power, or the attainment of something.

p.blockquote:
Cromwell, I charge thee, fling a way ambition:
By that sin fell the angels.
Shak.

The pitiful ambition of possessing five or six thousand more acres.
Burke.

dictionary.p: Am*bi"tion, v. t. [Cf. F. ambitionner.] To seek after ambitiously or eagerly; to covet. [R.]

p.blockquote:
Pausanias, ambitioning the sovereignty of Greece, bargains with Xerxes for his daughter in marriage.
Trumbull.

dictionary.p: Am*bi"tion*ist, n. One excessively ambitious. [R.]
Am*bi"tion*less, a. Devoid of ambition. Pollok.

Am*bi"tious (AMP?;), a. [L. ambitiosus: cf. F. ambitieux. See Ambition.] 1. Possessing, or controlled by, ambition; greatly or inordinately desirous of power, honor, office, superiority, or distinction.

p.blockquote:
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious,
And Brutus is an honorable man.
Shak.

p.def: Strongly desirous; -- followed by of or the infinitive; as, ambitious to be or to do something.

p.blockquote:
I was not ambitious of seeing this ceremony.
Evelyn.

Studious of song, and yet ambitious not to sing in vain.
Cowper.

p.def: Springing from, characterized by, or indicating, ambition; showy; aspiring; as, an ambitious style.

p.blockquote:
A giant statue . . .
Pushed by a wild and artless race,
From off wide, ambitious base.
Collins.

dictionary.p: Am*bi"tious*ly, adv. In an ambitious manner.
||Am"bi*tus (AMPabreve;m"bAMPibreve;*tAMPubreve;s), n. [L. See Ambit, Ambition.] 1. The exterior edge or border of a thing, as the border of a leaf, or the outline of a bivalve shell.

p.def: A canvassing for votes.

dictionary.p: Am"ble (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Ambled (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Ambling (AMP?;).] [F. ambler to amble, fr. L. ambulare to walk, in LL., to amble, perh. fr. amb-, ambi-, and a root meaning to go: cf. Gr. AMP?; to go, E. base. Cf. Ambulate.] 1. To go at the easy gait called an amble; -- applied to the horse or to its rider.

p.def: To move somewhat like an ambling horse; to go easily or without hard shocks.

p.blockquote:
The skipping king, he ambled up and down.
Shak.

Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Am"ble, n. 1. A peculiar gait of a horse, in which both legs on the same side are moved at the same time, alternating with the legs on the other side. "A fine easy amble." B. Jonson.

p.def: A movement like the amble of a horse.

dictionary.p: Am"bler (AMP?;), n. A horse or a person that ambles.
Am"bling*ly, adv. With an ambling gait.
Am*blot"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;, AMP?;, fr. AMP?; an abortion.] Tending to cause abortion.
Am*blyg"o*nal (AMP?;), a. Obtuse- angled. [Obs.] Hutton.

{ ||Am`bly*o"pi*a (AMP?;), Am"bly*o`py (AMP?;), } n. [Gr. AMP?;; AMP?; blunt, dim + AMP?; eye: cf. F. amblyopie.] (Med.) Weakness of sight, without and opacity of the cornea, or of the interior of the eye; the first degree of amaurosis.
Am"bly*op"ic (AMP?;), a. (Med.) Of or pertaining to amblyopy. Quain.
||Am*blyp"o*da (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; blunt + AMP?;, AMP?;, foot.] (Paleon.) A group of large, extinct, herbivorous mammals, common in the Tertiary formation of the United States.
||Am"bo (AMP?;), n.; pl. Ambos (AMP?;). [LL. ambo, Gr. AMP?;, any rising, a raised stage, pulpit: cf. F. ambon.] A large pulpit or reading desk, in the early Christian churches. Gwilt.
||Am"bon (AMP?;), n. Same as Ambo.
Am*boy"na wood (AMP?;). A beautiful mottled and curled wood, used in cabinetwork. It is obtained from the Pterocarpus Indicus of Amboyna, Borneo, etc.
Am"bre*ate (AMP?;), n. (Chem.) A salt formed by the combination of ambreic acid with a base or positive radical.
Am*bre"ic (AMP?;), a. (Chem.) Of or pertaining to ambrein; -- said of a certain acid produced by digesting ambrein in nitric acid.
Am"bre*in (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. ambrAMPeacute;ine. See Amber.] (Chem.) A fragrant substance which is the chief constituent of ambergris.
Am"brite (AMP?;), n. [From amber.] A fossil resin occurring in large masses in New Zealand.
Am"brose (AMP?;), n. A sweet-scented herb; ambrosia. See Ambrosia, 3. Turner.

Am*bro"sia (?; 277), n. [L. ambrosia, Gr. AMP?;, properly fem. of AMP?;, fr. AMP?; immortal, divine; 'a priv. + AMP?; mortal (because it was supposed to confer immortality on those who partook of it). AMP?; stands for AMP?;, akin to Skr. mrita, L. mortuus, dead, and to E. mortal.] 1. (Myth.) (a) The fabled food of the gods (as nectar was their drink), which conferred immortality upon those who partook of it. (b) An unguent of the gods.

p.blockquote:
His dewy locks distilled ambrosia.
Milton.

p.def: A perfumed unguent, salve, or draught; something very pleasing to the taste or smell.
Formerly, a kind of fragrant plant; now (Bot.), a genus of plants, including some coarse and worthless weeds, called ragweed, hogweed, etc.

dictionary.p: Am"bro"si*ac (AMP?;), a. [L. ambrosiacus: cf. F. ambrosiaque.] Having the qualities of ambrosia; delicious. [R.]"Ambrosiac odors." B. Jonson.

Am*bro"sial (AMP?;), a. [L. ambrosius, Gr. AMP?;.] 1. Consisting of, or partaking of the nature of, ambrosia; delighting the taste or smell; delicious. "Ambrosial food." "Ambrosial fragrance." Milton.
2. Divinely excellent or beautiful. "Shakes his ambrosial curls." Pope.
Am*bro"sial*ly, adv. After the manner of ambrosia; delightfully. "Smelt ambrosially." Tennyson.
Am*bro"sian (AMP?;), a. Ambrosial. [R.] . Jonson.
Am*bro"sian, a. Of or pertaining to St. Ambrose; as, the Ambrosian office, or ritual, a formula of worship in the church of Milan, instituted by St. Ambrose.
Ambrosian chant, the mode of signing or chanting introduced by St. Ambrose in the 4th century.
Am"bro*sin (AMP?;), n. [LL. Ambrosinus nummus.] An early coin struck by the dukes of Milan, and bearing the figure of St. Ambrose on horseback.

Am"bro*type (-tAMPimacr;p), n. [Gr. 'a`mbrotos immortal + -type.] (Photog.) A picture taken on a plate of prepared glass, in which the lights are represented in silver, and the shades are produced by a dark background visible through the unsilvered portions of the glass.

Am"bry (AMP?;), n.; pl. Ambries (AMP?;). [OE. aumbry, almery, OF. almarie, armarie, aumaire, F. armoire, LL. armarium chest, cupboard, orig. a repository for arms, fr. L. arama arms. The word has been confused with almonry. See Armory.] 1. In churches, a kind of closet, niche, cupboard, or locker for utensils, vestments, etc.

p.def: A store closet, as a pantry, cupboard, etc.

dictionary.p: 3. Almonry. [Improperly so used]
Am`bu*la"cral (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Of or pertaining to ambulacra; avenuelike; as, the ambulacral ossicles, plates, spines, and suckers of echinoderms.
Am`bu*la"cri*form (AMP?;), a. [Ambulacrum + -form] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Having the form of ambulacra.

||Am`bu*la"crum (AMP?;), n.; pl. Ambulacra (AMP?;). [L., an alley or covered way.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) (a) One of the radical zones of echinoderms, along which run the principal nerves, blood vessels, and water tubes. These zones usually bear rows of locomotive suckers or tentacles, which protrude from regular pores. In star fishes they occupy the grooves along the under side of the rays. (b) One of the suckers on the feet of mites.

Am"bu*lance (AMP?;), n. [F. ambulance, hAMPocirc;pital ambulant, fr. L. ambulare to walk. See Amble.] (Mil.) (a) A field hospital, so organized as to follow an army in its movements, and intended to succor the wounded as soon as possible. Often used adjectively; as, an ambulance wagon; ambulance stretcher; ambulance corps. (b) An ambulance wagon or cart for conveying the wounded from the field, or to a hospital.
Am"bu*late (AMP?;), v. i. [L. ambulare to walk. See Amble.] To walk; to move about. [R.] Southey.
Am`bu*la"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. ambulatio.] The act of walking. Sir T. Browne.
Am"bu*la*tive (AMP?;), a. Walking. [R.]
Am"bu*la`tor (AMP?;), n. 1. One who walks about; a walker.

p.def: A beetle of the genus Lamia.
A genus of birds, or one of this genus.
An instrument for measuring distances; -- called also perambulator.

dictionary.p: Am`bu*la*to"ri*al (AMP?;), a. Ambulatory; fitted for walking. Verrill.
Am"bu*la*to*ry (AMP?;), a. [L. ambulatorius.] 1. Of or pertaining to walking; having the faculty of walking; formed or fitted for walking; as, an ambulatory animal.

p.def: Accustomed to move from place to place; not stationary; movable; as, an ambulatory court, which exercises its jurisdiction in different places.

p.blockquote:
The priesthood . . . before was very ambulatory, and dispersed into all families.
Jer. Taylor.

dictionary.p: 3. Pertaining to a walk. [R.]

p.blockquote:
The princess of whom his majesty had an ambulatory view in his travels.
Sir H. Wotton.

p.def: Not yet fixed legally, or settled past alteration; alterable; as, the dispositions of a will are ambulatory until the death of the testator.

dictionary.p: Am"bu*la*to*ry, n.; pl. Ambulatories (AMP?;). [Cf. LL. ambulatorium.] (Arch.) A place to walk in, whether in the open air, as the gallery of a cloister, or within a building.
Am"bur*ry (AMP?;), n. Same as Anbury.

Am`bus*cade" (AMP?;), n. [F. embuscade, fr. It. imboscata, or Sp. emboscada, fr. emboscar to ambush, fr. LL. imboscare. See Ambush, v. t.] 1. A lying in a wood, concealed, for the purpose of attacking an enemy by surprise. Hence: A lying in wait, and concealed in any situation, for a like purpose; a snare laid for an enemy; an ambush.
2. A place in which troops lie hid, to attack an enemy unexpectedly. [R.] Dryden.

p.def: The body of troops lying in ambush.

dictionary.p: Am`bus*cade", v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Ambuscaded (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Ambuscading (AMP?;).] 1. To post or conceal in ambush; to ambush.

p.def: To lie in wait for, or to attack from a covert or lurking place; to waylay.

dictionary.p: Am`bus*cade", v. i. To lie in ambush.
Am`bus*ca"do (AMP?;), n. Ambuscade. [Obs.] Shak.
Am`bus*ca"doed (AMP?;), p. p. Posted in ambush; ambuscaded. [Obs.]

Am"bush (AMPabreve;m"bAMPoocr;sh), n. [F. embAMPucirc;che, fr. the verb. See Ambush, v. t.] 1. A disposition or arrangement of troops for attacking an enemy unexpectedly from a concealed station. Hence: Unseen peril; a device to entrap; a snare.

p.blockquote:
Heaven, whose high walls fear no assault or siege
Or ambush from the deep.
Milton.

p.def: A concealed station, where troops or enemies lie in wait to attack by surprise.

p.blockquote:
Bold in close ambush, base in open field.
Dryden.

dictionary.p: 3. The troops posted in a concealed place, for attacking by surprise; liers in wait. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The ambush arose quickly out of their place.
Josh. viii. 19.

dictionary.p: To lay an ambush, to post a force in ambush.

Am"bush (AMPabreve;m"bAMPoocr;sh), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Ambushed (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Ambushing.] [OE. enbussen, enbushen, OF. embushier, embuissier, F. embAMPucirc;cher, embusquer, fr. LL. imboscare; in + LL. boscus, buscus, a wood; akin to G. bush, E. bush. See Ambuscade, Bush.] 1. To station in ambush with a view to surprise an enemy.

p.blockquote:
By ambushed men behind their temple laid,
We have the king of Mexico betrayed.
Dryden.

p.def: To attack by ambush; to waylay.

dictionary.p: Am"bush, v. i. To lie in wait, for the purpose of attacking by surprise; to lurk.

p.blockquote:
Nor saw the snake that ambushed for his prey.
Trumbull.

dictionary.p: Am"bush*er (AMP?;), n. One lying in ambush.
Am"bush*ment (AMP?;), n. [OF. embuschement. See Ambush, v. t.] An ambush. [Obs.] 2 Chron. xiii. 13.
Am*bus"tion (?; 106), n. [L. ambustio.] (Med.) A burn or scald. Blount.
Am`e*be"an (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) See AmAMP?;bean.
A*meer", A*mir" (AMP?;), n. [See Emir.] 1. Emir. [Obs.]

p.def: One of the Mohammedan nobility of Afghanistan and Scinde.

dictionary.p: Am"el (AMP?;), n. [OE. amell, OF. esmail, F. AMPeacute;mail, of German origin; cf. OHG. smelzi, G. schmelz. See Smelt, v. t.] Enamel. [Obs.] Boyle.
Am"el, v. t. [OE. amellen, OF. esmailler, F. AMPeacute;mailler, OF. esmail, F. AMPeacute;mail.] To enamel. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Enlightened all with stars,
And richly ameled.
Chapman.

dictionary.p: Am"el*corn` (AMP?;), n. [Ger. amelkorn: cf. MHG. amel, amer, spelt, and L. amylum starch, Gr. AMP?;.] A variety of wheat from which starch is produced; -- called also French rice.
A*mel"io*ra*ble (AMP?;), a. Capable of being ameliorated.

A*mel"io*rate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Ameliorated (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Ameliorating.] [L. ad + meliorare to make better: cf. F. amAMPeacute;liorer. See Meliorate.] To make better; to improve; to meliorate.

p.blockquote:
In every human being there is a wish to ameliorate his own condition.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: A*mel"io*rate, v. i. To grow better; to meliorate; as, wine ameliorates by age.

A*mel`io*ra"tion (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. amAMPeacute;lioration.] The act of ameliorating, or the state of being ameliorated; making or becoming better; improvement; melioration. "Amelioration of human affairs." J. S. Mill.
A*mel"io*ra*tive (AMP?;), a. Tending to ameliorate; producing amelioration or improvement; as, ameliorative remedies, efforts.
A*mel"io*ra`tor (AMP?;), n. One who ameliorates.

A`men" (?; 277), interj., adv., AMP n. [L. amen, Gr. 'amh`n, Heb. AMPamacr;mAMPemacr;n certainly, truly.] An expression used at the end of prayers, and meaning, So be it. At the end of a creed, it is a solemn asseveration of belief. When it introduces a declaration, it is equivalent to truly, verily. It is used as a noun, to denote: (a) concurrence in belief, or in a statement; assent; (b) the final word or act; (c) Christ as being one who is true and faithful.

p.blockquote:
And let all the people say, Amen.
Ps. cvi. 48.

Amen, amen, I say to thee, except a man be born again, he can not see the kingdom of God.
John ii. 3. Rhemish Trans.

dictionary.p: To say amen to, to approve warmly; to concur in heartily or emphatically; to ratify; as, I say Amen to all.
A`men", v. t. To say Amen to; to sanction fully.
A*me`na*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. The quality of being amenable; amenableness. Coleridge.

A*me"na*ble (AMP?;), a. [F. amener to lead; AMP?; (L. ad) = mener to lead, fr. L. minare to drive animals (properly by threatening cries), in LL. to lead; L. minari, to threaten, minae threats. See Menace.] 1. (Old Law) Easy to be led; governable, as a woman by her husband. [Obs.] Jacob.

p.def: Liable to be brought to account or punishment; answerable; responsible; accountable; as, amenable to law.

p.blockquote:
Nor is man too diminutive . . . to be amenable to the divine government.
I. Taylor.

p.def: Liable to punishment, a charge, a claim, etc.
Willing to yield or submit; responsive; tractable.

p.blockquote:
Sterling . . . always was amenable enough to counsel.
Carlyle.

dictionary.p: A*me"na*bly, adv. In an amenable manner.
Am"e*nage (AMP?;), v. t. [OF. amesnagier. See Manage.] To manage. [Obs.] Spenser.
Am"e*nance (AMP?;), n. [OF. See Amenable.] Behavior; bearing. [Obs.] Spenser.

A*mend" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Amended; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Amending.] [F. amender, L. emendare; e (ex) + mendum, menda, fault, akin to Skr. minda personal defect. Cf. Emend, Mend.] To change or modify in any way for the better; as, (a) by simply removing what is erroneous, corrupt, superfluous, faulty, and the like; (b) by supplying deficiencies; (c) by substituting something else in the place of what is removed; to rectify.

p.blockquote:
Mar not the thing that can not be amended.
Shak.

An instant emergency, granting no possibility for revision, or opening for amended thought.
De Quincey.

We shall cheer her sorrows, and amend her blood, by wedding her to a Norman.
Sir W. Scott.

dictionary.p: To amend a bill, to make some change in the details or provisions of a bill or measure while on its passage, professedly for its improvement.

Syn. -- To Amend, Emend, Correct, Reform, Rectify. These words agree in the idea of bringing things into a more perfect state. We correct (literally, make straight) when we conform things to some standard or rule; as, to correct proof sheets. We amend by removing blemishes, faults, or errors, and thus rendering a thing more a nearly perfect; as, to amend our ways, to amend a text, the draft of a bill, etc. Emend is only another form of amend, and is applied chiefly to editions of books, etc. To reform is literally to form over again, or put into a new and better form; as, to reform one's life. To rectify is to make right; as, to rectify a mistake, to rectify abuses, inadvertencies, etc.
A*mend" (AMPadot;*mAMPebreve;nd"), v. i. To grow better by rectifying something wrong in manners or morals; to improve. "My fortune . . . amends." Sir P. Sidney.
A*mend"a*ble (AMP?;), a. Capable of being amended; as, an amendable writ or error. -- A*mend"a*ble*ness, n.
A*mend"a*to*ry (AMP?;), a. Supplying amendment; corrective; emendatory. Bancroft.
||A`mende" (AMP?;), n. [F. See Amend.] A pecuniary punishment or fine; a reparation or recantation.

Amende honorable (AMP?;). (Old French Law) A species of infamous punishment in which the offender, being led into court with a rope about his neck, and a lighted torch in his hand, begged pardon of his God, the court, etc. In popular language, the phrase now denotes a public apology or recantation, and reparation to an injured party, for improper language or treatment.
A*mend"er (AMP?;), n. One who amends.
A*mend"ful (AMP?;), a. Much improving. [Obs.]
A*mend"ment (AMP?;), n. [F. amendement, LL. amendamentum.] 1. An alteration or change for the better; correction of a fault or of faults; reformation of life by quitting vices.

p.def: In public bodies; Any alternation made or proposed to be made in a bill or motion by adding, changing, substituting, or omitting.
Correction of an error in a writ or process.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Improvement; reformation; emendation.
A*mends" (AMP?;), n. sing. AMP pl. [F. amendes, pl. of amende. Cf. Amende.] Compensation for a loss or injury; recompense; reparation. [Now const. with sing. verb.] "An honorable amends." Addison.

p.blockquote:
Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends.
Shak.

dictionary.p: A*men"i*ty (AMP?;), n.; pl. Amenities (AMP?;). [F. amAMPeacute;nitAMPeacute;, L. amoenitas, fr. amoenus pleasant.] The quality of being pleasant or agreeable, whether in respect to situation, climate, manners, or disposition; pleasantness; civility; suavity; gentleness.

p.blockquote:
A sweetness and amenity of temper.
Buckle.

This climate has not seduced by its amenities.
W. Howitt.

dictionary.p: ||A*men`or*rhAMPoelig;"a (AMP?;), n. [Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; month + AMP?; to flow: cf. F. amAMPeacute;norrhAMPeacute;e.] (Med.) Retention or suppression of the menstrual discharge.
A*men`or*rhAMPoelig;"al (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to amenorrhAMPoelig;a.
||A men"sa et tho"ro (AMP?;). [L., from board and bed.] (Law) A kind of divorce which does not dissolve the marriage bond, but merely authorizes a separate life of the husband and wife. Abbott.
Am"ent (AMP?;), n. [L. amentum thong or strap.] (Bot.) A species of inflorescence; a catkin.

p.blockquote:
The globular ament of a buttonwood.
Coues.

dictionary.p: Am`en*ta"ceous (AMP?;), a. [LL. amentaceus.] (Bot.) (a) Resembling, or consisting of, an ament or aments; as, the chestnut has an amentaceous inflorescence. (b) Bearing aments; having flowers arranged in aments; as, amentaceous plants.
||A*men"ti*a (AMP?;), n. [L.] (Med.) Imbecility; total want of understanding.
Am`en*tif"er*ous (AMP?;), a. [L. amentum + -ferous.] (Bot.) Bearing catkins. Balfour.
A*men"ti*form (AMP?;), a. [L. amentum + -form.] (Bot.) Shaped like a catkin.
||A*men"tum (AMP?;), n.; pl. Amenta (AMP?;). Same as Ament.
Am"e*nuse (AMP?;), v. t. [OF. amenuisier. See Minute.] To lessen. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A*merce" (AMPadot;*mAMPetilde;rs"), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Amerced (AMPadot;*mAMPetilde;rst"); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Amercing.] [OF. amercier, fr. a merci at the mercy of, liable to a punishment. See Mercy.] 1. To punish by a pecuniary penalty, the amount of which is not fixed by law, but left to the discretion of the court; as, the court amerced the criminal in the sum of one hundred dollars.
AMPfist; The penalty or fine may be expressed without a preposition, or it may be introduced by in, with, or of.

p.def: To punish, in general; to mulct.

p.blockquote:
Millions of spirits for his fault amerced
Of Heaven.
Milton.

Shall by him be amerced with penance due.
Spenser.

dictionary.p: A*merce"a*ble (AMP?;), a. Liable to be amerced.

A*merce"ment (AMP?;), n. [OF. amerciment.] The infliction of a penalty at the discretion of the court; also, a mulct or penalty thus imposed. It differs from a fine,in that the latter is, or was originally, a fixed and certain sum prescribed by statute for an offense; but an amercement is arbitrary. Hence, the act or practice of affeering. [See Affeer.] Blackstone.
AMPfist; This word, in old books, is written amerciament.
Amercement royal, a penalty imposed on an officer for a misdemeanor in his office. Jacobs.
A*mer"cer (AMP?;), n. One who amerces.
A*mer"cia*ment (AMP?;), n. [LL. amerciamentum.] Same as Amercement. Mozley AMP W.
A*mer"i*can (AMPadot;*mAMPetilde;r"AMPibreve;*kan), a. [Named from Americus Vespucius.] 1. Of or pertaining to America; as, the American continent: American Indians.
2. Of or pertaining to the United States. "A young officer of the American navy." Lyell.

American ivy. See Virginia creeper. -- American Party (U. S. Politics), a party, about 1854, which opposed the influence of foreign-born citizens, and those supposed to owe allegiance to a foreign power. -- Native american Party (U. S. Politics), a party of principles similar to those of the American party. It arose about 1843, but soon died out.

A*mer"i*can (AMPadot;*mAMPetilde;r"AMPibreve;*kan), n. A native of America; -- originally applied to the aboriginal inhabitants, but now applied to the descendants of Europeans born in America, and especially to the citizens of the United States.

p.blockquote:
The name American must always exalt the pride of patriotism.
Washington.

dictionary.p: A*mer"i*can*ism (AMP?;), n. 1. Attachment to the United States.

p.def: A custom peculiar to the United States or to America; an American characteristic or idea.
A word or phrase peculiar to the United States.

dictionary.p: A*mer`i*can*i*za"tion (AMPadot;*mAMPetilde;r`AMPibreve;*kan*AMPibreve;*zAMPamacr;"shAMPubreve;n), n. The process of Americanizing.

A*mer"i*can*ize (-AMPimacr;z), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Americanizer (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Americanizing.] To render American; to assimilate to the Americans in customs, ideas, etc.; to stamp with American characteristics.
Ames"-ace (AMP?;), n. Same as Ambs- ace.
Am"ess (AMP?;), n. (Eccl.) Amice, a hood or cape. See 2d Amice.
||Am`e*tab"o*la (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A group of insects which do not undergo any metamorphosis. [Written also Ametabolia.]
A*met`a*bo"li*an (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; unchangeable; 'a priv. + AMP?; changeable, AMP?; to change.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Of or pertaining to insects that do undergo any metamorphosis.
A*meth"o*dist (AMP?;), n. [Pref. a- not + methodist.] One without method; a quack. [Obs.]

Am"e*thyst (AMP?;), [F. ametiste, amatiste, F. amAMPeacute;thyste, L. amethystus, fr. Gr. AMP?; without drunkenness; as a noun, a remedy for drunkenness, the amethyst, supposed to have this power; 'a priv. + AMP?; to be drunken, AMP?; strong drink, wine. See Mead.]

p.def: A variety of crystallized quartz, of a purple or bluish violet color, of different shades. It is much used as a jeweler's stone.

dictionary.p: Oriental amethyst, the violet-blue variety of transparent crystallized corundum or sapphire.

p.def: A purple color in a nobleman's escutcheon, or coat of arms.

dictionary.p: Am`e*thys"tine (AMP?;), a. [L. amethystinus, Gr. AMP?;.] 1. Resembling amethyst, especially in color; bluish violet.

p.def: Composed of, or containing, amethyst.

dictionary.p: ||Am`e*tro"pi*a (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; irregular + AMP?;, AMP?;, eye.] (Med.) Any abnormal condition of the refracting powers of the eye. -- Am`e*trop"ic (AMP?;), a.

Am*har"ic (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to Amhara, a division of Abyssinia; as, the Amharic language is closely allied to the Ethiopic. -- n. The Amharic language (now the chief language of Abyssinia).

||Am"i*a (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?; a kind of tunny.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A genus of fresh-water ganoid fishes, exclusively confined to North America; called bowfin in Lake Champlain, dogfish in Lake Erie, and mudfish in South Carolina, etc. See Bowfin.
A`mi*a*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. The quality of being amiable; amiableness; sweetness of disposition.

p.blockquote:
Every excellency is a degree of amiability.
Jer. Taylor.

dictionary.p: A"mi*a*ble (AMP?;), a. [F. amiable, L. amicabilis friendly, fr. amicus friend, fr. amare to love. The meaning has been influenced by F. aimable, L. amabilis lovable, fr. amare to love. Cf. Amicable, Amorous, Amability.] 1. Lovable; lovely; pleasing. [Obs. or R.]

p.blockquote:
So amiable a prospect.
Sir T. Herbert.

p.def: Friendly; kindly; sweet; gracious; as, an amiable temper or mood; amiable ideas.

dictionary.p: 4. Done out of love. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Lay an amiable siege to the honesty of this Ford's wife.
Shak.

dictionary.p: A`mi*a*ble*ness, n. The quality of being amiable; amiability.
A"mi*a*bly, adv. In an amiable manner.
Am"i*anth (AMP?;), n. See Amianthus. [Poetic]
Am`i*an"thi*form (AMP?;), a. [Amianthus + -form.] Resembling amianthus in form.
Am`i*an"thoid (AMP?;), a. [Amianthus + -oid: cf. F. amiantoAMPiuml;de.] Resembling amianthus.

Am`i*an"thus (AMP?;), n. [L. amiantus, Gr. AMP?; AMP?; (lit., unsoiled stone) a greenish stone, like asbestus; 'a priv. + AMP?; to stain, to defile; so called from its incombustibility.] (Min.) Earth flax, or mountain flax; a soft silky variety of asbestus.
Am"ic (AMP?;), a. [L. ammonia + - ic.] (Chem.) Related to, or derived, ammonia; -- used chiefly as a suffix; as, amic acid; phosphamic acid.
Amic acid (Chem.), one of a class of nitrogenized acids somewhat resembling amides.
Am`i*ca*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. The quality of being amicable; friendliness; amicableness. Ash.

Am"i*ca*ble (AMP?;), a. [L. amicabilis, fr. amicus friend, fr. amare to love. See Amiable.] Friendly; proceeding from, or exhibiting, friendliness; after the manner of friends; peaceable; as, an amicable disposition, or arrangement.

p.blockquote:
That which was most remarkable in this contest was . . . the amicable manner in which it was managed.
Prideoux.

dictionary.p: Amicable action (Law.), an action commenced and prosecuted by amicable consent of the parties, for the purpose of obtaining a decision of the court on some matter of law involved in it. Bouvier. Burrill. -- Amicable numbers (Math.), two numbers, each of which is equal to the sum of all the aliquot parts of the other.

Syn. -- Friendly; peaceable; kind; harmonious. -- Amicable, Friendly. Neither of these words denotes any great warmth of affection, since friendly has by no means the same strength as its noun friendship. It does, however, imply something of real cordiality; while amicable supposes very little more than that the parties referred to are not disposed to quarrel. Hence, we speak of amicable relations between two countries, an amicable adjustment of difficulties. "Those who entertain friendly feelings toward each other can live amicably together."
Am"i*ca*ble*ness (AMP?;), n. The quality of being amicable; amicability.
Am"i*ca*bly, adv. In an amicable manner.

Am"ice (AMP?;), n. [OE. amyse, prob. for amyt, OF. amit, ameit, fr. L. amictus cloak, the word being confused with amice, almuce, a hood or cape. See next word.] A square of white linen worn at first on the head, but now about the neck and shoulders, by priests of the Roman Catholic Church while saying Mass.

Am"ice, n. [OE. amuce, amisse, OF. almuce, aumuce, F. aumusse, LL. almucium, almucia, aumucia: of unknown origin; cf. G. mAMPuuml;tze cap, prob. of the same origin. Cf. Mozetta.] (Eccl.) A hood, or cape with a hood, made of lined with gray fur, formerly worn by the clergy; -- written also amess, amyss, and almuce.
A*mid" (AMP?;), prep. See Amidst.

Am"ide (?; 277), n. [Ammonia + - ide.] (Chem.) A compound formed by the union of amidogen with an acid element or radical. It may also be regarded as ammonia in which one or more hydrogen atoms have been replaced by an acid atom or radical.
Acid amide, a neutral compound formed by the substitution of the amido group for hydroxyl in an acid.

Am"i*din (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. amidine, fr. amidoAMP?; starch, fr. L. amylum, Gr. AMP?; fine meal, neut. of AMP?; not ground at the mill, -- hence, of the finest meal; 'a priv. + AMP?;, AMP?;, mill. See Meal.] (Chem.) Start modified by heat so as to become a transparent mass, like horn. It is soluble in cold water.
A*mi"do (AMP?;), a. [From Amide.] (Chem.) Containing, or derived from, amidogen.
Amido acid, an acid in which a portion of the nonacid hydrogen has been replaced by the amido group. The amido acids are both basic and acid. -- Amido group, amidogen, NH2.

A*mid"o*gen (AMP?;), n. [Amide + - gen.] (Chem.) A compound radical, NH2, not yet obtained in a separate state, which may be regarded as ammonia from the molecule of which one of its hydrogen atoms has been removed; -- called also the amido group, and in composition represented by the form amido.
A*mid"ships (AMP?;), adv. (Naut.) In the middle of a ship, with regard to her length, and sometimes also her breadth. Totten.

{ A*midst" (AMP?;), A*mid" (AMP?;), } prep. [OE. amidde, amiddes, on midden, AS. on middan, in the middle, fr. midde the middle. The s is an adverbial ending, originally marking the genitive; the t is a later addition, as in whilst, amongst, alongst. See Mid.] In the midst or middle of; surrounded or encompassed by; among. "This fair tree amidst the garden." "Unseen amid the throng." "Amidst thick clouds." Milton. "Amidst acclamations." "Amidst the splendor and festivity of a court." Macaulay.

p.blockquote:
But rather famish them amid their plenty.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Amidst, Among. These words differ to some extent from each other, as will be seen from their etymology. Amidst denotes in the midst or middle of, and hence surrounded by; as, this work was written amidst many interruptions. Among denotes a mingling or intermixing with distinct or separable objects; as, "He fell among thieves." "Blessed art thou among women." Hence, we say, among the moderns, among the ancients, among the thickest of trees, among these considerations, among the reasons I have to offer. Amid and amidst are commonly used when the idea of separate or distinguishable objects is not prominent. Hence, we say, they kept on amidst the storm, amidst the gloom, he was sinking amidst the waves, he persevered amidst many difficulties; in none of which cases could among be used. In like manner, Milton speaks of Abdiel, --

The seraph Abdiel, faithful found;
Among the faithless faithful only he,
because he was then considered as one of the angels. But when the poet adds, --
From amidst them forth he passed,
we have rather the idea of the angels as a collective body.
Those squalid cabins and uncleared woods amidst which he was born.
Macaulay.
Am"ine (?; 277), n. [Ammonia + - ine.] (Chem.) One of a class of strongly basic substances derived from ammonia by replacement of one or more hydrogen atoms by a basic atom or radical.
Am"i*oid (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Like or pertaining to the Amioidei. -- n. One of the Amioidei.
||Am`i*oi"de*i (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Amia + -oid.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) An order of ganoid fishes of which Amia is the type. See Bowfin and Ganoidei.
||A*mir" (AMP?;), n. Same as Ameer.
A*miss" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + miss.] Astray; faultily; improperly; wrongly; ill.

p.blockquote:
What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?
Shak.

Ye ask and receive not, because ye ask amiss.
James iv. 3.

dictionary.p: To take (an act, thing) amiss, to impute a wrong motive to (an act or thing); to take offense at; to take unkindly; as, you must not take these questions amiss.

p.blockquote:
His wisdom and virtue can not always rectify that which is amiss in himself or his circumstances.
Wollaston.

dictionary.p: A*miss", n. A fault, wrong, or mistake. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Each toy seems prologue to some great amiss.
Shak.

dictionary.p: A*mis`si*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), [Cf. F. amissibilitAMPeacute;. See Amit.] The quality of being amissible; possibility of being lost. [R.]

p.blockquote:
Notions of popular rights and the amissibility of sovereign power for misconduct were alternately broached by the two great religious parties of Europe.
Hallam.

dictionary.p: A*mis"si*ble (AMP?;), a. [L. amissibilis: cf. F. amissible.] Liable to be lost. [R.]
A*mis"sion (AMP?;), n. [L. amissio: cf. F. amission.] Deprivation; loss. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A*mit" (AMP?;), v. t. [L. amittere, amissum, to lose; a (ab) + mittere to send. See Missile.] To lose. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
A lodestone fired doth presently amit its proper virtue.
Sir T. Browne.

dictionary.p: Am"i*ty (AMP?;), n.; pl. Amities (AMP?;). [F. amitiAMPeacute;, OF. amistiAMPeacute;, amistAMPeacute;, fr. an assumed LL. amisitas, fr. L. amicus friendly, from amare to love. See Amiable.] Friendship, in a general sense, between individuals, societies, or nations; friendly relations; good understanding; as, a treaty of amity and commerce; the amity of the Whigs and Tories.

p.blockquote:
To live on terms of amity with vice.
Cowper.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Harmony; friendliness; friendship; affection; good will; peace.
||Am"ma (AMP?;), n. [LL. amma, prob. of interjectional or imitative origin: cf. Sp. ama, G. amme, nurse, Basque ama mother, Heb. AMP?;m, Ar. immun, ummun.] An abbes or spiritual mother.
Am"me*ter (AMP?;), n. (Physics) A contraction of amperometer or ampAMPegrave;remeter.
Am"mi*ral (AMP?;), n. An obsolete form of admiral. "The mast of some great ammiral." Milton.
Am"mite (AMPabreve;m"mAMPimacr;t), n. [Gr. 'ammi`ths, 'ammi`tis, sandstone, fr. 'a`mmos or "a`mmos sand.] (Geol.) OAMPouml;lite or roestone; -- written also hammite. [Obs.]

Am"mo*dyte (AMP?;), n. [L. ammodytes, Gr. AMP?; sand burrower, a kind of serpent; 'a`mmos sand + AMP?; diver, AMP?; to dive.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) (a) One of a genus of fishes; the sand eel. (b) A kind of viper in southern Europe. [Obs.]

Am*mo"ni*a (AMP?;), n. [From sal ammoniac, which was first obtaining near the temple of Jupiter Ammon, by burning camel's dung. See Ammoniac.] (Chem.) A gaseous compound of hydrogen and nitrogen, NH3, with a pungent smell and taste: -- often called volatile alkali, and spirits of hartshorn.

Ammoniacal engine, an engine in which the vapor of ammonia is used as the motive force. -- Sal ammoniac [L. sal ammoniacus], the salt usually called chloride of ammonium, and formerly muriate of ammonia.

Am*mo"ni*ac (AMP?;) (or Gum` am*mo"ni*ac , n. [L. Ammoniacum, Gr. AMP?; a resinous gum, said to distill from a tree near the temple of Jupiter Ammon; cf. F. ammoniac. See Ammonite.] (Med.) The concrete juice (gum resin) of an umbelliferous plant, the Dorema ammoniacum. It is brought chiefly from Persia in the form of yellowish tears, which occur singly, or are aggregated into masses. It has a peculiar smell, and a nauseous, sweet taste, followed by a bitter one. It is inflammable, partially soluble in water and in spirit of wine, and is used in medicine as an expectorant and resolvent, and for the formation of certain plasters.
Am*mo"ni*a`ted (AMP?;), a. (Chem.) Combined or impregnated with ammonia.
Am*mo"nic (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to ammonia.

Am"mon*ite (AMP?;), n. [L. cornu Ammonis born of Ammon; L. Ammon, Gr. AMP?; an appellation of Jupiter, as represented with the horns of a ram. It was originally the name of an. Egyptian god, Amun.] (Paleon.) A fossil cephalopod shell related to the nautilus. There are many genera and species, and all are extinct, the typical forms having existed only in the Mesozoic age, when they were exceedingly numerous. They differ from the nautili in having the margins of the septa very much lobed or plaited, and the siphuncle dorsal. Also called serpent stone, snake stone, and cornu Ammonis.
Am`mon*i*tif"er*ous (AMP?;), a. [Ammonite + -ferous.] Containing fossil ammonites.
||Am*mon`i*toid"e*a (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Ammonite + -oid.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) An extensive group of fossil cephalopods often very abundant in Mesozoic rocks. See Ammonite.
Am*mo"ni*um (AMP?;), n. [See Ammonia.] (Chem.) A compound radical, NH4, having the chemical relations of a strongly basic element like the alkali metals.
Am`mu*ni"tion (AMP?;), n. [F. amunition, for munition, prob. caused by taking la munition as l'amunition. See Munition.] 1. Military stores, or provisions of all kinds for attack or defense. [Obs.]

p.def: Articles used in charging firearms and ordnance of all kinds; as powder, balls, shot, shells, percussion caps, rockets, etc.
Any stock of missiles, literal or figurative.

dictionary.p: Ammunition bread, shoes, etc., such as are contracted for by government, and supplied to the soldiers. [Eng.]
Am`mu*ni"tion (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Ammunitioned (AMP?;); p pr. AMP vb. n. Ammunitioning.] To provide with ammunition.
Am*ne"sic (AMP?;), a. (Med.) Of or pertaining to amnesia. "Amnesic or coAMPouml;rdinate defects." Quian.
Am*nes"tic (AMP?;), a. Causing loss of memory.

p.def: An act of the sovereign power granting oblivion, or a general pardon, for a past offense, as to subjects concerned in an insurrection.

dictionary.p: Am"nes*ty, v. t. [imp. p. p. Amnestied (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Amnestying.] To grant amnesty to.
Am*nic"o*list (AMP?;), n. [L. amnicola, amnis a river + colere to dwell.] One who lives near a river. [Obs.] Bailey.
Am"ni*on (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; the membrane round the fetus, dim. of AMP?; lamb.] (Anat.) A thin membrane surrounding the embryos of mammals, birds, and reptiles.
Am"ni*os (AMP?;), n. Same as Amnion.

||Am`ni*o"ta (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL. See Amnion.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) That group of vertebrates which develops in its embryonic life the envelope called the amnion. It comprises the reptiles, the birds, and the mammals.
Am`ni*ot"ic (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. amniotique.] (Anat.) Of or pertaining to the amnion; characterized by an amnion; as, the amniotic fluid; the amniotic sac.
Amniotic acid. (Chem.) [R.] See Allantoin.

A*mAMPoelig;"ba (AMP?;), n.; pl. L. AmAMPoelig;bAMPaelig; (AMP?;); E. AmAMPoelig;bas (AMP?;). [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; change.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A rhizopod. common in fresh water, capable of undergoing many changes of form at will. See Rhizopoda.

||Am`AMPoelig;*bAMPaelig;"um (AMP?;), n. [L. amAMPoelig;baeus, Gr. AMP?;, alternate; L. amoebaeum carmen, Gr. AMP?; AMP?;, a responsive song, fr. AMP?; change.] A poem in which persons are represented at speaking alternately; as the third and seventh eclogues of Virgil.
||Am`AMPoelig;*be"a (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) That division of the Rhizopoda which includes the amAMPoelig;ba and similar forms.
Am`AMPoelig;*be"an (AMP?;), a. Alternately answering.
A*mAMPoelig;"bi*an (AMP?;), n. (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of the AmAMPoelig;bea.
{ A*mAMPoelig;"bi*form (AMP?;), A*mAMPoelig;"boid (AMP?;), } a. [AmAMPoelig;ba + -form or -oid.] (Biol.) Resembling an amAMPoelig;ba; amAMPoelig;ba-shaped; changing in shape like an amAMPoelig;ba.
AmAMPoelig;boid movement, movement produced, as in the amAMPoelig;ba, by successive processes of prolongation and retraction.
A*mAMPoelig;"bous (AMP?;), a. Like an amAMPoelig;ba in structure.
Am`o*li"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. amolitio, fr. amoliri to remove; a (ab) + moliri to put in motion.] Removal; a putting away. [Obs.] Bp. Ward (1673).
||A*mo"mum (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?; an Indian spice plant.] (Bot.) A genus of aromatic plants. It includes species which bear cardamoms, and grains of paradise.
A*mon"este (AMP?;), v. t. To admonish. [Obs.]

{ A*mong" (AMP?;), A*mongst" (AMP?;), } prep. [OE. amongist, amonges, amonge, among, AS. onmang, ongemang, gemang, in a crowd or mixture. For the ending -st see Amidst. See Mingle.] 1. Mixed or mingled; surrounded by.

p.blockquote:
They heard,
And from his presence hid themselves among
The thickest trees.
Milton.

p.def: Conjoined, or associated with, or making part of the number of; in the number or class of.

p.blockquote:
Blessed art thou among women.
Luke i. 28.

p.def: Expressing a relation of dispersion, distribution, etc.; also, a relation of reciprocal action.

p.blockquote:
What news among the merchants?
Shak.

Human sacrifices were practiced among them.
Hume.

Divide that gold amongst you.
Marlowe.

Whether they quarreled among themselves, or with their neighbors.
Addison.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Amidst; between. See Amidst, Between.
||A*mon`til*la"do (AMP?;), n. [Sp.] A dry kind of cherry, of a light color. Simmonds.
Am"o*ret (AMP?;), n. [OF. amorette, F. amourette, dim. of amour.] 1. An amorous girl or woman; a wanton. [Obs.] J. Warton.
2. A love knot, love token, or love song. (pl.) Love glances or love tricks. [Obs.]
3. A petty love affair or amour. [Obs.]
Am"o*rette" (AMP?;), n. An amoret. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
Am"o*rist (AMP?;), n. [L. armor love. See Amorous.] A lover; a gallant. [R.] Milton.

p.blockquote:
It was the custom for an amorist to impress the name of his mistress in the dust, or upon the damp earth, with letters fixed upon his shoe.
Southey.

dictionary.p: A-morn"ings (AMP?;), adv. [See Amorwe. The -s is a genitival ending. See -wards.] In the morning; every morning. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
And have such pleasant walks into the woods
A-mornings.
J. Fletcher.

dictionary.p: ||Am`o*ro"sa (AMP?;), n. [It. amoroso, fem. amorosa.] A wanton woman; a courtesan. Sir T. Herbert.
Am`o*ros"i*ty (AMP?;), n. The quality of being amorous; lovingness. [R.] Galt.
||Am`o*ro"so (AMP?;), n. [It. amoroso, LL. amorosus.] A lover; a man enamored.
||Am`o*ro"so, adv. [It.] (Mus.) In a soft, tender, amatory style.

Am"o*rous (AMP?;), a. [OF. amoros, F. amoreux, LL. amorosus, fr. L. amor love, fr. amare to love.] 1. Inclined to love; having a propensity to love, or to sexual enjoyment; loving; fond; affectionate; as, an amorous disposition.

p.def: Affected with love; in love; enamored; -- usually with of; formerly with on.

p.blockquote:
Thy roses amorous of the moon.
Keats.

High nature amorous of the good.
Tennyson.

Sure my brother is amorous on Hero.
Shak.

dictionary.p: 3. Of or relating to, or produced by, love. "Amorous delight." Milton. "Amorous airs." Waller.
Syn. -- Loving; fond; tender; passionate; affectionate; devoted; ardent.
Am"o*rous*ly, adv. In an amorous manner; fondly.
Am"o*rous*ness, n. The quality of being amorous, or inclined to sexual love; lovingness.
A*mor"pha (AMP?;), n.; pl. Amorphas (AMP?;). [Gr. AMP?; shapeless.] (Bot.) A genus of leguminous shrubs, having long clusters of purple flowers; false or bastard indigo. Longfellow.

A*mor"phism (AMP?;), n. [See Amorphous.] A state of being amorphous; esp. a state of being without crystallization even in the minutest particles, as in glass, opal, etc. There are stony substances which, when fused, may cool as glass or as stone; the glass state is spoken of as a state of amorphism.
A*mor"phous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;; 'a priv. + AMP?; form.] 1. Having no determinate form; of irregular; shapeless. Kirwan.

p.def: Without crystallization in the ultimate texture of a solid substance; uncrystallized.
Of no particular kind or character; anomalous.

p.blockquote:
Scientific treatises . . . are not seldom rude and amorphous in style.
Hare.

dictionary.p: -- A*mor"phous*ly, adv. -- A*mor"phous*ness, n.
||A*mor`pho*zo"a (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; shapeless; 'a priv. + AMP?; form + AMP?; animal.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Animals without a mouth or regular internal organs, as the sponges.
A*mor`pho*zo"ic (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Of or pertaining to the Amorphozoa.
A*mor"phy (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?;: cf. F. amorphie. See Amorphous.] Shapelessness. [Obs.] Swift.
A*mort" (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- + F. mort death, dead; all amort is for alamort.] As if dead; lifeless; spiritless; dejected; depressed. Shak.
A*mor"tise (AMP?;), v., A*mor`ti*sa"tion (AMP?;), n., A*mor"tis*a*ble (AMP?;), a., A*mor"tise*ment (AMP?;), n. Same as Amortize, Amortization, etc.
A*mor"tiz*a*ble (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. amortissable.] Capable of being cleared off, as a debt.

A*mor`ti*za"tion (AMP?;), n. [LL. amortisatio, admortizatio. See Amortize, and cf. Admortization.] 1. (Law) The act or right of alienating lands to a corporation, which was considered formerly as transferring them to dead hands, or in mortmain.

p.def: The extinction of a debt, usually by means of a sinking fund; also, the money thus paid.

dictionary.p: A*mor"tize (AMP?;), v. t. [OE. amortisen, LL. amortisare, admortizare, F. amortir to sell in mortmain, to extinguish; L. ad + mors death. See Mortmain]. 1. To make as if dead; to destroy. [Obs.] Chaucer.

p.def: To alienate in mortmain, that is, to convey to a corporation. See Mortmain.
To clear off or extinguish, as a debt, usually by means of a sinking fund.

dictionary.p: A*mor"tize*ment (AMP?;), n. [F. amortissement.] Same as Amortization.
A*mor"we (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- on + OE. morwe. See Morrow.] 1. In the morning. [Obs.] Chaucer.
2. On the following morning. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A*mo"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. amotio. See Amove.] 1. Removal; ousting; especially, the removal of a corporate officer from his office.

p.def: Deprivation of possession.

dictionary.p: ||A*mo"tus (AMP?;), a. [L., withdrawn (from itAMP?;place).] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Elevated, -- as a toe, when raised so high that the tip does not touch the ground.

A*mount" (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Amounted; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Amounting.] [OF. amonter to increase, advance, ascend, fr. amont (equiv. to L. ad montem to the mountain) upward, F. amont up the river. See Mount, n.] 1. To go up; to ascend. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
So up he rose, and thence amounted straight.
Spenser.

p.def: To rise or reach by an accumulation of particular sums or quantities; to come (to) in the aggregate or whole; -- with to or unto.
To rise, reach, or extend in effect, substance, or influence; to be equivalent; to come practically (to); as, the testimony amounts to very little.

dictionary.p: A*mount", v. t. To signify; to amount to. [Obs.]

A*mount", n. 1. The sum total of two or more sums or quantities; the aggregate; the whole quantity; a totality; as, the amount of 7 and 9 is 16; the amount of a bill; the amount of this year's revenue.

p.def: The effect, substance, value, significance, or result; the sum; as, the amount of the testimony is this.

p.blockquote:
The whole amount of that enormous fame.
Pope.

dictionary.p: A*mour" (AMP?;), n. [F., fr. L. amor love.] 1. Love; affection. [Obs.]

p.def: Love making; a love affair; usually, an unlawful connection in love; a love intrigue; an illicit love affair.

dictionary.p: In amours with, in love with. [Obs.]
||A"mour` pro"pre (AMPadot;"mAMPoomac;r` prAMPosl;"pr'). [F.] Self-love; self-esteem.
A*mov`a*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. Liability to be removed or dismissed from office. [R.] T. Jefferson.
A*mov"a*ble (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. amovible.] Removable.
A*move" (AMP?;), v. t. [L. amovere; a- (ab) + movere to move: cf. OF. amover.] 1. To remove, as a person or thing, from a position. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.

p.def: To dismiss from an office or station.

dictionary.p: A*move", v. t. AMP i. [OE. amovir, L. admovere to move to, to excite; ad + movere.] To move or be moved; to excite. [Obs.] Spenser.

Am"pe*lite (AMPabreve;m"pAMPesl;*lAMPimacr;t), n. [L. ampelitis, Gr. 'ampeli^tis, fr. 'a`mpelos vine.] (Min.) An earth abounding in pyrites, used by the ancients to kill insects, etc., on vines; -- applied by Brongniart to a carbonaceous alum schist.

{ ||Am`pAMPegrave;re" (AMPauml;N`pAMPacirc;r"), Am*pere" (AMPabreve;m*pAMPamacr;r"), } n. [From the name of a French electrician.] (Elec.) The unit of electric current; -- defined by the International Electrical Congress in 1893 and by U. S. Statute as, one tenth of the unit of current of the C. G. S. system of electro-magnetic units, or the practical equivalent of the unvarying current which, when passed through a standard solution of nitrate of silver in water, deposits silver at the rate of 0.001118 grams per second. Called also the international ampAMPegrave;re.
{ ||Am`pAMPegrave;re"me`ter (AMP?;), Am`pe*rom"e*ter (AMP?;), } n. [AmpAMPegrave;re + meter.] (Physics) An instrument for measuring the strength of an electrical current in ampAMPegrave;res.
Am"per*sand (AMP?;), n. [A corruption of and, per se and, i. e., AMP by itself makes and.] A word used to describe the character AMP?;, AMP?;, or AMP. Halliwell.
Am*phi-. [Gr. 'amfi`.] A prefix in words of Greek origin, signifying both, of both kinds, on both sides, about, around.
Am`phi*ar*thro"di*al (AMP?;), a. [Pref. amphi- + arthrodial.] Characterized by amphiarthrosis.

Am`phi*ar*thro"sis (AMP?;), n. [NL., fr. Gr. 'amfi` + AMP?; a joining, AMP?; a joint.] (Anat.) A form of articulation in which the bones are connected by intervening substance admitting slight motion; symphysis.

Am"phi*as`ter (AMP?;), n. [NL., fr. Gr. 'amfi` + 'asth`r a star.] (Biol.) The achromatic figure, formed in mitotic cell-division, consisting of two asters connected by a spindle-shaped bundle of rodlike fibers diverging from each aster, and called the spindle.
||Am*phib"i*a (AMP?;), n. pl. [See Amphibium.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of the classes of vertebrates.

AMPfist; The Amphibia are distinguished by having usually no scales, by having eggs and embryos similar to those of fishes, and by undergoing a complete metamorphosis, the young having gills. There are three living orders: (1) The tailless, as the frogs (Anura); (2) The tailed (Urodela), as the salamanders, and the siren group (Sirenoidea), which retain the gills of the young state (hence called Perennibranchiata) through the adult state, among which are the siren, proteus, etc.; (3) The CAMPoelig;cilians, or serpentlike Amphibia (Ophiomorpha or Gymnophiona), with minute scales and without limbs. The extinct Labyrinthodonts also belonged to this class. The term is sometimes loosely applied to both reptiles and amphibians collectively.
Am*phib"i*al (-al), a. AMP n. Amphibian. [R.]
Am*phib"i*an (-an), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Of or pertaining to the Amphibia; as, amphibian reptiles.
Am*phib"i*an, n. (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of the Amphibia.
Am*phib`i*o*log"ic*al (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to amphibiology.
Am*phib`i*ol"o*gy (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; amphibious + -logy: cf. F. amphibiologie.] A treatise on amphibious animals; the department of natural history which treats of the Amphibia.
||Am*phib`i*ot"i*ca (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. 'amfi` + biwtiko`s pertaining to life.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A division of insects having aquatic larvAMPaelig;.

Am*phib"i*ous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. 'amfi`bios living a double life, i. e., both on land in water; 'amfi` + bi`os life.] 1. Having the ability to live both on land and in water, as frogs, crocodiles, beavers, and some plants.

p.def: Pertaining to, adapted for, or connected with, both land and water.

p.blockquote:
The amphibious character of the Greeks was already determined: they were to be lords of land and sea.
Hare.

p.def: Of a mixed nature; partaking of two natures.

p.blockquote:
Not in free and common socage, but in this amphibious subordinate class of villein socage.
Blackstone.

dictionary.p: Am*phib"i*ous*ly, adv. Like an amphibious being.
||Am*phib"i*um (AMP?;), n.; pl. L. Amphibia (AMP?;); E. Amphibiums (AMP?;). [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; (sc. AMP?; an animal). See Amphibious.] An amphibian.

Am`phi*blas"tic (AMPabreve;m`fAMPibreve;*blAMPabreve;s"tAMPibreve;k), a. [Gr. 'amfi` + blastiko`s tending to sprout.] (Biol.) Segmenting unequally; -- said of telolecithal ova with complete segmentation.

Am"phi*bole (AMPabreve;m"fAMPibreve;*bAMPomacr;l), n. [Gr. 'amfi`bolos doubtful, equivocal, fr. 'amfiba`llein to throw round, to doubt: cf. F. amphibole. HaAMPuuml;y so named the genus from the great variety of color and composition assumed by the mineral.] (Min.) A common mineral embracing many varieties varying in color and in composition. It occurs in monoclinic crystals; also massive, generally with fibrous or columnar structure. The color varies from white to gray, green, brown, and black. It is a silicate of magnesium and calcium, with usually aluminium and iron. Some common varieties are tremolite, actinolite, asbestus, edenite, hornblende (the last name being also used as a general term for the whole species). Amphibole is a constituent of many crystalline rocks, as syenite, diorite, most varieties of trachyte, etc. See Hornblende.

p.def: Of or resembling the mineral amphibole.

dictionary.p: Am*phib`o*log"ic*al (AMPabreve;m*fAMPibreve;b`AMPosl;*lAMPobreve;j"AMPibreve;*kal), a. Of doubtful meaning; ambiguous. "Amphibological expressions." Jer. Taylor.
-- Am*phib`o*log"ic*al*ly, adv.

Am`phi*bol"o*gy (AMPabreve;m`fAMPibreve;*bAMPosl;l"AMPosl;*jAMPybreve;), n.; pl. Amphibologies (- jAMPibreve;z). [L. amphibologia, for amphibolia, fr. Gr. 'amfiboli`a, with the ending -logia as if fr. Gr. 'amfi`bolos ambiguous + lo`gos speech: cf. F. amphibologie. See Amphiboly.] A phrase, discourse, or proposition, susceptible of two interpretations; and hence, of uncertain meaning. It differs from equivocation, which arises from the twofold sense of a single term.
Am*phib"o*lous (AMP?;), a. [L. amphibolus, Gr. AMP?; thrown about, doubtful. See Amphibole.]
1. Ambiguous; doubtful. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Never was there such an amphibolous quarrel -- both parties declaring themselves for the king.
Howell.

p.def: Capable of two meanings.

p.blockquote:
An amphibolous sentence is one that is capable of two meanings, not from the double sense of any of the words, but from its admitting of a double construction; e. g., "The duke yet lives that Henry shall depose."
Whately.

dictionary.p: Am*phib"o*ly (AMP?;), n.; pl. Amphibolies (AMP?;). [L. amphibolia, Gr. AMP?;: cf. OE. amphibolie. See Amphibolous.] Ambiguous discourse; amphibology.

p.blockquote:
If it oracle contrary to our interest or humor, we will create an amphiboly, a double meaning where there is none.
Whitlock.

dictionary.p: Am"phi*brach (AMPabreve;m"fAMPibreve;*brAMPabreve;k), n. [L. AMP?;, Gr. AMP?; short at both ends; 'amfi` + brachy`s short.] (Anc. Pros.) A foot of three syllables, the middle one long, the first and last short (AMPssmile; -- AMPssmile;); as, hAMPabreve;bAMPemacr;rAMPebreve;. In modern prosody the accented syllable takes the place of the long and the unaccented of the short; as, pro-phet\'b6ic.
{ Am`phi*car"pic (AMP?;), Am`phi*car"pous (AMP?;), } a. [Gr. 'amfi` + karpo`s fruit.] (Bot.) Producing fruit of two kinds, either as to form or time of ripening.
Am`phi*chro"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. 'amfi` + AMP?; color.] (Chem.) Exhibiting or producing two colors, as substances which in the color test may change red litmus to blue and blue litmus to red.

{ Am`phi*cAMPoelig;"li*an (AMP?;), Am`phi*cAMPoelig;"lous (AMP?;), } a. [Gr. AMP?; hollowed all round; 'amfi` + AMP?; hollow.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Having both ends concave; biconcave; -- said of vertebrAMPaelig;.
Am"phi*come (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; with hair all round; 'amfi` + AMP?; hair.] A kind of figured stone, rugged and beset with eminences, anciently used in divination. [Obs.] Encyc. Brit.
Am*phic`ty*on"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;.] Of or pertaining to the Amphictyons or their League or Council; as, an Amphictyonic town or state; the Amphictyonic body. W. Smith.

Am*phic"ty*ons (AMP?;), n. pl. [L. Amphictyones, Gr. AMP?;. Prob. the word was orig. AMP?; dwellers around, neighbors.] (Grecian Hist.) Deputies from the confederated states of ancient Greece to a congress or council. They considered both political and religious matters.

Am*phic"ty*o*ny (AMP?;), n.; pl. Amphictyonies (AMP?;). [Gr. AMP?;.] (Grecian Hist.) A league of states of ancient Greece; esp. the celebrated confederation known as the Amphictyonic Council. Its object was to maintain the common interests of Greece.

Am"phid (AMP?;), n. [Gr. 'a`mfw both: cf. F. amphide.] (Chem.) A salt of the class formed by the combination of an acid and a base, or by the union of two oxides, two sulphides, selenides, or tellurides, as distinguished from a haloid compound. [R.] Berzelius.
Am"phi*disc (AMP?;), n. [Gr. 'amfi` + di`skos a round plate.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A peculiar small siliceous spicule having a denticulated wheel at each end; -- found in freshwater sponges.

Am`phi*drom"ic*al (AMP?;), a. [Gr. 'amfi`dromos running about or around.] Pertaining to an Attic festival at the naming of a child; -- so called because the friends of the parents carried the child around the hearth and then named it.
Am*phig"a*mous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; + AMP?; marriage.] (Bot.) Having a structure entirely cellular, and no distinct sexual organs; -- a term applied by De Candolle to the lowest order of plants.
Am`phi*ge"an (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; + AMP?;, AMP?;, the earth.] Extending over all the zones, from the tropics to the polar zones inclusive.

Am"phi*gen (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; + -gen: cf. F. amphigAMPegrave;ne.] (Chem.) An element that in combination produces amphid salt; -- applied by Berzelius to oxygen, sulphur, selenium, and tellurium. [R.]
Am"phi*gene (AMP?;), n. (Min.) Leucite.
Am`phi*gen"e*sis (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; + AMP?; generation.] (Biol.) Sexual generation; amphigony.
Am*phig"e*nous (AMP?;), a. (Bot.) Increasing in size by growth on all sides, as the lichens.
Am`phi*gon"ic (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to amphigony; sexual; as, amphigonic propagation. [R.]
Am*phig"o*nous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; + AMP?; a begetting.] Relating to both parents. [R.]
Am*phig"o*ny (AMP?;), n. Sexual propagation. [R.]
Am`phi*gor"ic (AMP?;), a. [See Amphigory.] Nonsensical; absurd; pertaining to an amphigory.

Am"phi*go*ry (AMP?;), n. [F. amphigouri, of uncertain derivation; perh. fr. Gr. AMP?; + AMP?; a circle.] A nonsense verse; a rigmarole, with apparent meaning, which on further attention proves to be meaningless. [Written also amphigouri.]

Am*phim"a*cer (AMP?;), n. [L. amphimacruAMP?;, Gr. AMP?;; AMP?; on both sides + AMP?; long.] (Anc. Pros.) A foot of three syllables, the middle one short and the others long, as in cAMPamacr;stAMP?;tAMPamacr;s. Andrews.
||Am`phi*neu"ra (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. AMP?; + AMP?; sinew, nerve.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A division of Mollusca remarkable for the bilateral symmetry of the organs and the arrangement of the nerves.

||Am`phi*ox"us (AMP?;), n. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; + AMP?; sharp.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A fishlike creature (Amphioxus lanceolatus), two or three inches long, found in temperature seas; -- also called the lancelet. Its body is pointed at both ends. It is the lowest and most generalized of the vertebrates, having neither brain, skull, vertebrAMPaelig;, nor red blood. It forms the type of the group Acrania, Leptocardia, etc.

Am*phip"neust (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; + AMP?; one who breathes, AMP?; to breathe.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of a tribe of Amphibia, which have both lungs and gills at the same time, as the proteus and siren.
Am"phi*pod (AMP?;), n. (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of the Amphipoda.

||Am*phip"o*da (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., FR. Gr. AMP?; + AMP?;, AMP?; foot.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A numerous group of fourteen -- footed Crustacea, inhabiting both fresh and salt water. The body is usually compressed laterally, and the anterior pairs or legs are directed downward and forward, but the posterior legs are usually turned upward and backward. The beach flea is an example. See Tetradecapoda and Arthrostraca.
Am*phip"o*dous (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Of or pertaining to the Amphipoda.

Am*phip"ro*style (AMP?;), a. [L. amphiprostylos, Gr. AMP?; having a double prostyle: cf. F. amphiprostyle. See Prostyle.] (Arch.) Doubly prostyle; having columns at each end, but not at the sides. -- n. An amphiprostyle temple or edifice.
||Am`phi*rhi"na (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; + AMP?;, AMP?;, nose.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A name applied to the elasmobranch fishes, because the nasal sac is double.
||Am`phis*bAMPaelig;"na (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;; AMP?; on both ends + AMP?; to go.] 1. A fabled serpent with a head at each end, moving either way. Milton.

p.def: A genus of harmless lizards, serpentlike in form, without legs, and with both ends so much alike that they appear to have a head at each, and ability to move either way. See Illustration in Appendix.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; The Gordius aquaticus, or hairworm, has been called an amphisbAMPaelig;na; but it belongs among the worms.
||Am`phis*bAMPaelig;"noid (AMP?;), a. [NL., fr. L. amphisbaena + -oid.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Like or pertaining to the lizards of the genus AmphisbAMPaelig;na.
Am`phi*sty"lic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; + AMP?; pillar, support.] (Anat.) Having the mandibular arch articulated with the hyoid arch and the cranium, as in the cestraciont sharks; -- said of a skull.

{ Am`phi*the"a*ter, Am`phi*the"a*tre, } (AMP?;), n. [L. amphitheatrum, fr. Gr. AMP?;; AMP?; + AMP?; theater: cf. F. amphithAMPeacute;AMPacirc;tre. See Theater.] 1. An oval or circular building with rising tiers of seats about an open space called the arena.
AMPfist; The Romans first constructed amphitheaters for combats of gladiators and wild beasts.

p.def: Anything resembling an amphitheater in form; as, a level surrounded by rising slopes or hills, or a rising gallery in a theater.

dictionary.p: Am`phi*the"a*tral (AMP?;), a. [L. amphitheatralis: cf. F. amphithAMPeacute;AMPacirc;tral.] Amphitheatrical; resembling an amphitheater.
Am`phi*the*at"ric*al*ly, adv. In the form or manner of an amphitheater.

||Am*phit"ro*cha (AMPabreve;m*fAMPibreve;t"rAMPosl;kAMPadot;), n. [NL., fr. Gr. 'amfi` + trocho`s a wheel.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A kind of annelid larva having both a dorsal and a ventral circle of special cilia.

{ Am*phit"ro*pal (-pal), Am*phit"ro*pous (- pAMPubreve;s), } a. [Gr. 'amfi` + tre`pein to turn.] (Bot.) Having the ovule inverted, but with the attachment near the middle of one side; half anatropous.

||Am`phi*u"ma (AMPabreve;m`fAMPibreve;*AMPumacr;"mAMPadot;), n. (ZoAMPouml;l.) A genus of amphibians, inhabiting the Southern United States, having a serpentlike form, but with four minute limbs and two persistent gill openings; the Congo snake.
Am`pho*pep"tone (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; + E. peptone.] (Physiol.) A product of gastric digestion, a mixture of hemipeptone and antipeptone.

||Am"pho*ra (AMP?;), n.; pl. AmophorAMPaelig; (AMP?;). [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;, AMP?;, a jar with two handles; AMP?; + AMP?; bearer, AMP?; to bear. Cf. Ampul.] Among the ancients, a two-handled vessel, tapering at the bottom, used for holding wine, oil, etc.
Am"pho*ral (AMP?;), a. [L. amphoralis.] Pertaining to, or resembling, an amphora.

Am*phor"ic (AMP?;), a. (Med.) Produced by, or indicating, a cavity in the lungs, not filled, and giving a sound like that produced by blowing into an empty decanter; as, amphoric respiration or resonance.

Am"ple (AMP?;), a. [F. ample, L. amplus, prob. for ambiplus full on both sides, the last syllable akin to L. plenus full. See Full, and cf. Double.] Large; great in size, extent, capacity, or bulk; spacious; roomy; widely extended.

p.blockquote:
All the people in that ample house
Did to that image bow their humble knees.
Spenser.

p.def: Fully sufficient; abundant; liberal; copious; as, an ample fortune; ample justice.
Not contracted of brief; not concise; extended; diffusive; as, an ample narrative.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Full; spacious; extensive; wide; capacious; abundant; plentiful; plenteous; copious; bountiful; rich; liberal; munificent. -- Ample, Copious, Abundant, Plenteous. These words agree in representing a thing as large, but under different relations, according to the image which is used. Ample implies largeness, producing a sufficiency or fullness of supply for every want; as, ample stores or resources, ample provision. Copious carries with it the idea of flow, or of collection at a single point; as, a copious supply of materials. "Copious matter of my song." Milton. Abundant and plenteous refer to largeness of quantity; as, abundant stores; plenteous harvests.
Am*plec"tant (AMP?;), a. [L. amplecti to embrace.] (Bot.) Clasping a support; as, amplectant tendrils. Gray.
Am"ple*ness (AMP?;), n. The state or quality of being ample; largeness; fullness; completeness.
Am`plex*a"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. amplexari to embrace.] An embrace. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
An humble amplexation of those sacred feet.
Bp. Hall.

dictionary.p: Am*plex"i*caul (AMP?;), a. [L. amplexus, p. p. of amplecti to encircle, to embrace + caulis stem: cf. F. amplexicaule.] (Bot.) Clasping or embracing a stem, as the base of some leaves. Gray.
Am"pli*ate (AMP?;), v. t. [L. ampliatus, p. p. of ampliare to make wider, fr. amplus. See Ample.] To enlarge. [R.]

p.blockquote:
To maintain and ampliate the external possessions of your empire.
Udall.

dictionary.p: Am"pli*ate (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Having the outer edge prominent; said of the wings of insects.

p.def: A postponement of the decision of a cause, for further consideration or re-argument.

dictionary.p: Am"pli*a*tive (AMP?;), a. (Logic) Enlarging a conception by adding to that which is already known or received.

p.blockquote:
"All bodies possess power of attraction" is an ampliative judgment; because we can think of bodies without thinking of attraction as one of their immediate primary attributes.
Abp. W. Thomson.

dictionary.p: Am*plif"i*cate (AMP?;), v. t. [L. amplificatus, p. p. of amplificare.] To amplify. [Obs.] Bailey.
Am`pli*fi*ca"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. amplificatio.] 1. The act of amplifying or enlarging in dimensions; enlargement; extension.

p.def: The enlarging of a simple statement by particularity of description, the use of epithets, etc., for rhetorical effect; diffuse narrative or description, or a dilating upon all the particulars of a subject.

p.blockquote:
Exaggeration is a species of amplification.
Brande AMP C.

I shall summarily, without any amplification at all, show in what manner defects have been supplied.
Sir J. Davies.

p.def: The matter by which a statement is amplified; as, the subject was presented without amplifications.

dictionary.p: Am*plif"i*ca*tive (AMP?;), a. Amplificatory.
Am*plif"i*ca*to*ry (AMP?;), a. Serving to amplify or enlarge; amplificative. Morell.
Am"pli*fi`er (AMP?;), n. One who or that which amplifies.

Am"pli*fy (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Amplified (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Amplifying.] [F. amplifier, L. amplificare. See Ample, -fy.] 1. To render larger, more extended, or more intense, and the like; -- used especially of telescopes, microscopes, etc.

p.blockquote:
Troilus and Cressida was written by a Lombard author, but much amplified by our English translator.
Dryden.

dictionary.p: Am"pli*fy (AMP?;), v. i. 1. To become larger. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Strait was the way at first, withouten light,
But further in did further amplify.
Fairfax.

p.def: To speak largely or copiously; to be diffuse in argument or description; to dilate; to expatiate; -- often with on or upon.

p.blockquote:
He must often enlarge and amplify upon the subject he handles.
South.

dictionary.p: Am"pli*tude (AMP?;), n. [L. amplitudo, fr. amplus: cf. F. amplitude. See Ample.] 1. State of being ample; extent of surface or space; largeness of dimensions; size.

p.blockquote:
The cathedral of Lincoln . . . is a magnificent structure, proportionable to the amplitude of the diocese.
Fuller.

dictionary.p: 2. Largeness, in a figurative sense; breadth; abundance; fullness. (a) Of extent of capacity or intellectual powers. "Amplitude of mind." Milton. "Amplitude of comprehension." Macaulay. (b) Of extent of means or resources. "Amplitude of reward." Bacon.

p.def: The arc of the horizon between the true east or west point and the center of the sun, or a star, at its rising or setting. At the rising, the amplitude is eastern or ortive: at the setting, it is western, occiduous, or occasive. It is also northern or southern, when north or south of the equator.
The arc of the horizon between the true east or west point and the foot of the vertical circle passing through any star or object.
The horizontal line which measures the distance to which a projectile is thrown; the range.
The extent of a movement measured from the starting point or position of equilibrium; -- applied especially to vibratory movements.
An angle upon which the value of some function depends; -- a term used more especially in connection with elliptic functions.

dictionary.p: Magnetic amplitude, the angular distance of a heavenly body, when on the horizon, from the magnetic east or west point as indicated by the compass. The difference between the magnetic and the true or astronomical amplitude (see 3 above) is the "variation of the compass."
Am"ply (AMP?;), adv. In an ample manner.
Am"pul (AMP?;), n. [AS. ampella, ampolla, L. ampulla: cf. OF. ampolle, F. ampoule.] Same as Ampulla, 2.
||Am*pul"la, n.; pl. AmpullAMPaelig; (AMP?;). [L. ] 1. (Rom. Antiq.) A narrow-necked vessel having two handles and bellying out like a jug.

p.def: A cruet for the wine and water at Mass.
The vase in which the holy oil for chrism, unction, or coronation is kept.
Any membranous bag shaped like a leathern bottle, as the dilated end of a vessel or duct; especially the dilations of the semicircular canals of the ear.

dictionary.p: Am`pul*la"ceous (AMP?;), a. [L. ampullaceus, fr. ampulla.] Like a bottle or inflated bladder; bottle-shaped; swelling. Kirby.
Ampullaceous sac (ZoAMPouml;l.), one of the peculiar cavities in the tissues of sponges, containing the zooidal cells.
{ Am"pul*lar (AMP?;), Am`pul*la*ry (AMP?;), } a. Resembling an ampulla.
Am*pul"li*form (AMP?;), a. [Ampulla + -form.] Flask-shaped; dilated.

Am"pu*tate (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Amputated; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Amputating.] [L. amputatus, p. p. of amputare: amb- + putare to prune, putus clean, akin to E. pure. See Putative.] 1. To prune or lop off, as branches or tendrils.
2. (Surg.) To cut off (a limb or projecting part of the body). Wiseman.
Am`pu*ta"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. amputatio: cf. F. amputation.] The act of amputating; esp. the operation of cutting off a limb or projecting part of the body.
Am"pu*ta"tor (AMP?;), n. One who amputates.
||Am"pyx (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?;.] (Greek Antiq.) A woman's headband (sometimes of metal), for binding the front hair.
||Am*ri"ta (AMP?;), n. [Skr. amrita.] (Hind. Myth.) Immortality; also, the nectar conferring immortality. -- a. Ambrosial; immortal.
Am"sel, Am"zel (AMP?;), n. [Ger. See Ousel.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) The European ring ousel (Turdus torquatus).
A*muck" (AMPadot;*mAMPubreve;k"), a. AMP adv. [Malay amoq furious.] In a frenzied and reckless manner.
To run amuck, to rush out in a state of frenzy, as the Malays sometimes do under the influence of "bhang," and attack every one that comes in the way; to assail recklessly and indiscriminately.

p.blockquote:
Satire's my weapon, but I'm too discreet
To run amuck, and tilt at all I meet.
Pope.

dictionary.p: Am"u*let (AMP?;), n. [L. amuletum: cf. F. amulette.] An ornament, gem, or scroll, or a package containing a relic, etc., worn as a charm or preservative against evils or mischief, such as diseases and witchcraft, and generally inscribed with mystic forms or characters. [Also used figuratively.]
Am`u*let"ic (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to an amulet; operating as a charm.
A*mur"cous (AMP?;), a. [LL. amurcosus, L. amurca the dregs of olives, Gr. 'amo`rghs, fr. 'ame`rgein to pluck.] Full off dregs; foul. [R.] Knowles.
A*mus"a*ble (AMPadot;*mAMPumacr;z"AMPadot;*b'l), a. [Cf. F. amusable.] Capable of being amused.

A*muse" (AMPadot;*mAMPumacr;z"), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Amused (AMPadot;*mAMPumacr;zd"); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Amusing.] [F. amuser to make stay, to detain, to amuse, AMPagrave; (L. ad) + OF. muser. See Muse, v.] 1. To occupy or engage the attention of; to lose in deep thought; to absorb; also, to distract; to bewilder. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Camillus set upon the Gauls when they were amused in receiving their gold.
Holland.

Being amused with grief, fear, and fright, he could not find the house.
Fuller.

p.def: To entertain or occupy in a pleasant manner; to stir with pleasing or mirthful emotions; to divert.

p.blockquote:
A group of children amusing themselves with pushing stones from the top [of the cliff], and watching as they plunged into the lake.
Gilpin.

p.def: To keep in expectation; to beguile; to delude.

p.blockquote:
He amused his followers with idle promises.
Johnson.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To entertain; gratify; please; divert; beguile; deceive; occupy. -- To Amuse, Divert, Entertain. We are amused by that which occupies us lightly and pleasantly. We are entertained by that which brings our minds into agreeable contact with others, as conversation, or a book. We are diverted by that which turns off our thoughts to something of livelier interest, especially of a sportive nature, as a humorous story, or a laughable incident.

p.blockquote:
Whatever amuses serves to kill time, to lull the faculties, and to banish reflection. Whatever entertains usually awakens the understanding or gratifies the fancy. Whatever diverts is lively in its nature, and sometimes tumultuous in its effects.
Crabb.

dictionary.p: A*muse", v. i. To muse; to mediate. [Obs.]
A*mused" (AMP?;), a. 1. Diverted.

p.def: Expressing amusement; as, an amused look.

dictionary.p: A*muse"ment (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. amusement.] 1. Deep thought; muse. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Here I . . . fell into a strong and deep amusement, revolving in my mind, with great perplexity, the amazing change of our affairs.
Fleetwood.

p.def: The state of being amused; pleasurable excitement; that which amuses; diversion.

p.blockquote:
His favorite amusements were architecture and gardening.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Diversion; entertainment; recreation; relaxation; pastime; sport.
A*mus"er (-AMPetilde;r), n. One who amuses.
||Am`u*sette" (AMP?;), n. [F.] A light field cannon, or stocked gun mounted on a swivel.
A*mu"sive (?; 277), a. Having power to amuse or entertain the mind; fitted to excite mirth. [R.] -- A*mu"sive*ly, adv. -- A*mu"sive*ness, n.
A*my" (AMP?;), n. [F. ami, fr. L. amicus.] A friend. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A*my"e*lous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; without marrow.] (Med.) Wanting the spinal cord.
A*myg`da*la"ceous (AMP?;), a. (Bot.) Akin to, or derived from, the almond.
A*myg"da*late (AMP?;), a. [L. amygdala, amygdalum, almond, Gr. AMP?;, AMP?;. See Almond.] Pertaining to, resembling, or made of, almonds.
A*myg"da*late, n. 1. (Med.) An emulsion made of almonds; milk of almonds. Bailey. Coxe.

p.def: A salt amygdalic acid.

dictionary.p: Am`yg*dal"ic (AMP?;), a. (Chem.) Of or pertaining to almonds; derived from amygdalin; as, amygdalic acid.
A*myg`da*lif"er*ous (AMP?;), a. [L. amygdalum almond + -ferous.] Almond-bearing.
A*myg"da*lin (AMP?;), n. (Chem.) A glucoside extracted from bitter almonds as a white, crystalline substance.
A*myg"da*line (AMP?;), a. [L. amygdalinus.] Of, pertaining to, or resembling, almonds.

A*myg"da*loid (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; almond + -oid: cf. F. amygdaloAMPiuml;de.] (Min.) A variety of trap or basaltic rock, containing small cavities, occupied, wholly or in part, by nodules or geodes of different minerals, esp. agates, quartz, calcite, and the zeolites. When the imbedded minerals are detached or removed by decomposition, it is porous, like lava.
{ A*myg"da*loid (AMP?;), A*myg`da*loid"al (AMP?;), } a. 1. Almond-shaped.

p.def: Pertaining to, or having the nature of, the rock amygdaloid.

dictionary.p: Am"yl (AMP?;), n. [L. amylum starch + -yl. Cf. Amidin.] (Chem.) A hydrocarbon radical, C5H11, of the paraffine series found in amyl alcohol or fusel oil, etc.
