A*pe"ri*ent (AMP?;), a. [L. aperiens, p. pr. of aperire to uncover, open; ab + parire, parere, to bring forth, produce. Cf. Cover, Overt.] (Med.) Gently opening the bowels; laxative. -- n. An aperient medicine or food. Arbuthnot.
A*pert" (AMP?;), a. [OF. apert, L. apertus, p. p. of aperire. See Aperient, and cf. Pert, a.] Open; evident; undisguised. [Archaic] Fotherby.
A*pert", adv. Openly. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A*per"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. apertio.] The act of opening; an opening; an aperture. [Archaic] Wiseman.
A*pert"ly, adv. Openly; clearly. [Archaic]
A*pert"ness, n. Openness; frankness. [Archaic]
Ap"er*ture (?; 135), n. [L. apertura, fr. aperire. See Aperient.] 1. The act of opening. [Obs.]

p.def: An opening; an open space; a gap, cleft, or chasm; a passage perforated; a hole; as, an aperture in a wall.

p.blockquote:
An aperture between the mountains.
Gilpin.

The back aperture of the nostrils.
Owen.

p.def: The diameter of the exposed part of the object glass of a telescope or other optical instrument; as, a telescope of four-inch aperture.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; The aperture of microscopes is often expressed in degrees, called also the angular aperture, which signifies the angular breadth of the pencil of light which the instrument transmits from the object or point viewed; as, a microscope of 100AMPdeg; aperture.
Ap"er*y (AMP?;), n.; pl. Aperies. 1. A place where apes are kept. [R.] Kingsley.

p.def: The practice of aping; an apish action.

dictionary.p: A*pet"al*ous (AMPadot;*pAMPebreve;t"al*AMPubreve;s), a. [Pref. a- not + petal.] (Bot.) Having no petals, or flower leaves. [See Illust. under Anther].
A*pet"al*ous*ness, n. The state of being apetalous.
A"pex (AMP?;), n.; pl. E. Apexes (AMP?;); L. Apices (AMP?;). [L.] 1. The tip, top, point, or angular summit of anything; as, the apex of a mountain, spire, or cone; the apex, or tip, of a leaf.
2. (Mining) The end or edge of a vein nearest the surface. [U.S.]
Apex of the earth's motion (Astron.), that point of the heavens toward which the earth is moving in its orbit.
||A*phAMPaelig;r"e*sis (?; 277), n. [L.] Same as Apheresis.

||A*pha"ki*a (AMP?;), n. [NL.; Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; seed of a lentil.] (Med.) An anomalous state of refraction caused by the absence of the crystalline lens, as after operations for cataract. The remedy is the use of powerful convex lenses. Dunglison.
A*pha"ki*al (AMP?;), a. (Med.) Pertaining to aphakia; as, aphakial eyes.
||Aph`a*nip"te*ra (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; invisible ('a priv. + AMP?; to appear) + AMP?; a wing.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A group of wingless insects, of which the flea in the type. See Flea.
Aph`a*nip"ter*ous (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Of or pertaining to the Aphaniptera.

Aph"a*nite (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; invisible; 'a priv. + AMP?; to appear.] (Min.) A very compact, dark-colored AMP?;ock, consisting of hornblende, or pyroxene, and feldspar, but neither of them in perceptible grains.
Aph`a*nit"ic (AMP?;), a. (Min.) Resembling aphanite; having a very fine-grained structure.
A*pha"sic (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to, or affected by, aphasia; speechless.
A*phel"ion (?; 277), n.; pl. Aphelia (AMP?;). [Gr. AMP?; + AMP?; sun.] (Astron.) That point of a planet's or comet's orbit which is most distant from the sun, the opposite point being the perihelion.
A*phe`li*ot"ro*pism (AMP?;), n. The habit of bending from the sunlight; -- said of certain plants.
||A*phe"mi*a (AMP?;), n. [NL., fr. Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; voice.] (Med.) Loss of the power of speaking, while retaining the power of writing; -- a disorder of cerebral origin.

A*pher"e*sis (?; 277), n. [L. aphaeresis, Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to take away; AMP?; + AMP?; to take.] 1. (Gram.) The dropping of a letter or syllable from the beginning of a word; e. g., cute for acute.
2. (Surg.) An operation by which any part is separated from the rest. [Obs.] Dunglison.

||Aph"e*sis (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; a letting go; AMP?; + AMP?; to let go.] The loss of a short unaccented vowel at the beginning of a word; -- the result of a phonetic process; as, squire for esquire. New Eng. Dict.

A*phet"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; letting go, fr. AMP?; to let go.] Shortened by dropping a letter or a syllable from the beginning of a word; as, an aphetic word or form. -- A*phet"ic*al*ly, adv. New Eng. Dict.
Aph"e*tism (AMP?;), n. An aphetized form of a word. New Eng. Dict.
Aph"e*tize (AMP?;), v. t. To shorten by aphesis.

p.blockquote:
These words . . . have been aphetized.
New Eng. Dict.

dictionary.p: A"phid (AMP?;), n. (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of the genus Aphis; an aphidian.
Aph"i*des (AMP?;), n. pl. (ZoAMPouml;l.) See Aphis.
A*phid"i*an (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Of or pertaining to the family AphidAMPaelig;. -- n. One of the aphides; an aphid.
Aph`i*doph"a*gous (AMP?;), a. [Aphis + Gr. AMP?; to eat.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Feeding upon aphides, or plant lice, as do beetles of the family CoccinellidAMPaelig;.
Aph`i*lan"thro*py (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; not loving man; 'a priv. + AMP?; to love + AMP?; man.] Want of love to mankind; -- the opposite of philanthropy. Coxe.

||A"phis (AMP?;), n.; pl. Aphides (AMP?;). [NL.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A genus of insects belonging to the order Hemiptera and family AphidAMPaelig;, including numerous species known as plant lice and green flies.

AMPfist; Besides the true males and females, there is a race of wingless asexual individuals which have the power of producing living young in rapid succession, and these in turn may produce others of the same kind for several generations, before sexual individuals appear. They suck the sap of plants by means of a tubular proboscis, and owing to the wonderful rapidity of their reproduction become very destructive to vegetation. Many of the AphidAMPaelig; excrete honeydew from two tubes near the end of the body.
A"phis li"on (AMP?;). (ZoAMPouml;l.) The larva of the lacewinged flies (Chrysopa), which feeds voraciously upon aphids. The name is also applied to the larvAMPaelig; of the ladybugs (Coccinella).

Aph`lo*gis"tic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; not inflammable; 'a priv. + AMP?; set on fire. See Phlogiston.] Flameless; as, an aphlogistic lamp, in which a coil of wire is kept in a state of continued ignition by alcohol, without flame.
{ A*phon"ic (AMP?;), Aph"o*nous (AMP?;), } a. Without voice; voiceless; nonvocal.

Aph"o*rism (AMP?;), n. [F. aphorisme, fr. Gr. AMP?; definition, a short, pithy sentence, fr. AMP?; to mark off by boundaries, to define; AMP?; from + AMP?; to separate, part. See Horizon.] A comprehensive maxim or principle expressed in a few words; a sharply defined sentence relating to abstract truth rather than to practical matters.

p.blockquote:
The first aphorism of Hippocrates is, "Life is short, and the art is long."
Fleming.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Axiom; maxim; adage; proverb; apothegm; saying; saw; truism; dictum. See Axiom.
Aph`o*ris"mer (AMP?;) n. A dealer in aphorisms. [Used in derogation or contempt.] Milton.
Aph"o*rist, n. A writer or utterer of aphorisms.
{ Aph`o*ris"tic (AMP?;), Aph`o*ris"tic*al (AMP?;), } a. [Gr. AMP?;.] In the form of, or of the nature of, an aphorism; in the form of short, unconnected sentences; as, an aphoristic style.

p.blockquote:
The method of the book is aphoristic.
De Quincey.

dictionary.p: Aph`o*ris"tic*al*ly, adv. In the form or manner of aphorisms; pithily.
Aph"o*rize (AMP?;), v. i. To make aphorisms.
Aph"rite (AMP?;), n. (Min.) See under Calcite.
{ Aph`ro*dis"i*ac (AMP?;), Aph`ro*di*si"a*cal (AMP?;), } a. [Gr. AMP?; pertaining to sensual love, fr. AMP?;. See Aphrodite.] Exciting venereal desire; provocative to venery.
Aph`ro*dis"i*ac, n. That which (as a drug, or some kinds of food) excites to venery.
Aph`ro*dis"i*an (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;.] Pertaining to Aphrodite or Venus. "Aphrodisian dames" [that is, courtesans]. C. Reade.
||Aph`ro*di"te (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?;.] 1. (Classic Myth.) The Greek goddess of love, corresponding to the Venus of the Romans.

p.def: A large marine annelid, covered with long, lustrous, golden, hairlike setAMPaelig;; the sea mouse.
A beautiful butterfly (Argunnis Aphrodite) of the United States.

dictionary.p: Aph`ro*dit"ic (AMP?;), a. Venereal. [R.] Dunglison.
||Aph"tha (AMP?;), n. [Sing. of AphthAMPaelig;.] (Med.) (a) One of the whitish specks called aphthAMPaelig;. (b) The disease, also called thrush.

||Aph"thAMPaelig; (AMP?;), n. pl. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?; (mostly in pl. AMP?;, Hipp.) an eruption, thrush, fr. AMP?; to set on fire, inflame.] (Med.) Roundish pearl-colored specks or flakes in the mouth, on the lips, etc., terminating in white sloughs. They are commonly characteristic of thrush.
Aph"thoid, a. [Aphtha + -oid.] Of the nature of aphthAMPaelig;; resembling thrush.

Aph"thong (?; 277), n. [Gr. AMP?; silent; 'a priv. + AMP?; voice, sound, fr. AMP?; to sound.] A letter, or a combination of letters, employed in spelling a word, but in the pronunciation having no sound. -- Aph*thon"gal (AMP?;), a.
Aph"thous (AMP?;) a. [Cf. F. aphtheux.] Pertaining to, or caused by, aphthAMPaelig;; characterized by aphtAMPaelig;; as, aphthous ulcers; aphthous fever.
Aph"yl*lous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;; 'a priv. + AMP?; leaf.] (Bot.) Destitute of leaves, as the broom rape, certain euphorbiaceous plants, etc.
A`pi*a"ceous (AMP?;), a. (Bot.) Umbelliferous.
A"pi*an (AMP?;), a. Belonging to bees.
A`pi*a"ri*an (AMP?;), a. Of or relating to bees.
A"pi*a*rist (AMP?;), n. One who keeps an apiary.
A"pi*a*ry (AMP?;), n. [L. apiarium, fr. apis bee.] A place where bees are kept; a stand or shed for bees; a beehouse.
Ap"ic*al (AMP?;), a. [L. apex, apicis, tip or summit.] At or belonging to an apex, tip, or summit. Gray.
||Ap"i*ces (AMP?;), n. pl. See Apex.
A*pi"cian (AMP?;), a. [L. Apicianus.] Belonging to Apicius, a notorious Roman epicure; hence applied to whatever is peculiarly refined or dainty and expensive in cookery. H. Rogers.
Ap"i*cul`ture (?; 135), n. [L. apis bee + E. culture.] Rearing of bees for their honey and wax.
A*piece" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + piece.] Each by itself; by the single one; to each; as the share of each; as, these melons cost a shilling apiece. "Fined . . . a thousand pounds apiece." Hume.
A*pie"ces (AMP?;), adv. In pieces or to pieces. [Obs.] "Being torn apieces." Shak.
A*pik"ed (AMP?;), a. Trimmed. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Full fresh and new here gear apiked was.
Chaucer.

dictionary.p: A"pi*ol (AMP?;), n. [L. apium parsley + -ol.] (Med.) An oily liquid derived from parsley.
A`pi*ol"o*gist (AMP?;), n. [L. apis bee + -logist (see -logy).] A student of bees. [R.] Emerson.
||A"pis (AMP?;), n. [L., bee.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A genus of insects of the order Hymenoptera, including the common honeybee (Apis mellifica) and other related species. See Honeybee.
Ap"ish (AMP?;), a. Having the qualities of an ape; prone to imitate in a servile manner. Hence: Apelike; fantastically silly; foppish; affected; trifling.

p.blockquote:
The apish gallantry of a fantastic boy.
Sir W. Scott.

dictionary.p: Ap"ish*ly, adv. In an apish manner; with servile imitation; foppishly.
Ap"ish*ness, n. The quality of being apish; mimicry; foppery.
A*pit"pat, adv. [Pref. a- + pitpat.] With quick beating or palpitation; pitapat. Congreve.
Ap`la*cen"tal, a. [Pref. a- + placental.] Belonging to the Aplacentata; without placenta.
||Ap`la*cen*ta"ta, n. pl. [Pref. a- not + placenta.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) Mammals which have no placenta.

||Ap`la*coph"o*ra (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; a flat cake + AMP?; to bear.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A division of Amphineura in which the body is naked or covered with slender spines or setAMPaelig;, but is without shelly plates.

Ap`la*nat"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?; disposed to wander, wandering, AMP?; to wander.] (Opt.) Having two or more parts of different curvatures, so combined as to remove spherical aberration; -- said of a lens.

Aplanatic focus of a lens (Opt.), the point or focus from which rays diverging pass the lens without spherical aberration. In certain forms of lenses there are two such foci; and it is by taking advantage of this fact that the best aplanatic object glasses of microscopes are constructed.
A*plan"a*tism (AMP?;), n. Freedom from spherical aberration.
A*plas"tic (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- not + plastic.] Not plastic or easily molded.
||A`plomb" (AMP?;), n. [F., lit. perpendicularity; AMP?; to + plomb lead. See Plumb.] Assurance of manner or of action; self-possession.
A*plot"o*my (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; simple + AMP?; a cutting.] (Surg.) Simple incision. Dunglison.
||A*plus"tre (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;.] (Rom. Antiq.) An ornamental appendage of wood at the ship's stern, usually spreading like a fan and curved like a bird's feather. Audsley.

||A*plys"i*a (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; a dirty sponge, fr. AMP?; unwashed; 'a priv. + AMP?; to wash.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A genus of marine mollusks of the order Tectibranchiata; the sea hare. Some of the species when disturbed throw out a deep purple liquor, which colors the water to some distance. See Illust. in Appendix.

||Ap*neu"mo*na (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?;, AMP?;, a lung.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) An order of holothurians in which the internal respiratory organs are wanting; -- called also Apoda or Apodes.
||Ap*nAMPoelig;"a (AMP?;), n. [NL., fr. Gr. 'a priv. + AMP?;, AMP?;, breath, AMP?; to breathe, blow.] (Med.) Partial privation or suspension of breath; suffocation.

Ap"o (AMP?;). [Gr. AMP?;. See Ab-.] A prefix from a Greek preposition. It usually signifies from, away from, off, or asunder, separate; as, in apocope (a cutting off), apostate, apostle (one sent away), apocarpous.

A*poc"a*lypse (AMP?;), n. [L. apocalypsis, Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to uncover, to disclose; AMP?; from + AMP?; to cover, conceal: cf. F. apocalypse.] 1. The revelation delivered to St. John, in the isle of Patmos, near the close of the first century, forming the last book of the New Testament.

p.def: Anything viewed as a revelation; a disclosure.

p.blockquote:
The new apocalypse of Nature.
Carlyle.

dictionary.p: { A*poc`a*lyp"tic (AMP?;), A*poc`a*lyp"tic*al (AMP?;), } a. [Gr. AMP?;.] Of or pertaining to a revelation, or, specifically, to the Revelation of St. John; containing, or of the nature of, a prophetic revelation.
Apocalyptic number, the number 666, mentioned in Rev. xiii. 18. It has been variously interpreted.
A*poc`a*lyp"tic (AMPadot;*pAMPobreve;k`AMPadot;*lAMPibreve;p"tAMPibreve;k), A*poc`a*lyp"tist, n. The writer of the Apocalypse.
A*poc`a*lyp"tic*al*ly (AMP?;), adv. By revelation; in an apocalyptic manner.
Ap`o*car"pous, a. [Pref. apo- + Gr. karpo`s fruit.] (Bot.) Either entirely or partially separate, as the carpels of a compound pistil; -- opposed to syncarpous. Lindley.

A*poc"o*pate (AMP?;), v. t. [LL. apocopatus, p. p. of apocopare to cut off, fr. L. apocore. See Apocope.] (Gram.) To cut off or drop; as, to apocopate a word, or the last letter, syllable, or part of a word.
A*poc`o*pa"tion (AMP?;), n. Shortening by apocope; the state of being apocopated.
||A*poc"o*pe, n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?; a cutting off, fr. AMP?; to cut off; AMP?; from + AMP?; to cut.] 1. The cutting off, or omission, of the last letter, syllable, or part of a word.

p.def: A cutting off; abscission.

dictionary.p: { Ap`o*cris"i*a*ry (AMP?;), ||Ap`o*cris`i*a"ri*us (AMP?;), } n. [L. apocrisiarius, apocrisarius, fr. Gr. AMP?; answer, fr. AMP?; to answer; AMP?; from + AMP?; to separate.] (Eccl.) A delegate or deputy; especially, the pope's nuncio or legate at Constantinople.
Ap`o*crus"tic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; able to drive off, fr. AMP?; to drive off.] (Med.) Astringent and repellent. -- n. An apocrustic medicine.

A*poc"ry*pha (AMP?;), n. pl., but often used as sing. with pl. Apocryphas (AMP?;). [L. apocryphus apocryphal, Gr. AMP?; hidden, spurious, fr. AMP?; to hide; AMP?; from + AMP?; to hide.] 1. Something, as a writing, that is of doubtful authorship or authority; -- formerly used also adjectively. [Obs.] Locke.

p.def: Specif.: Certain writings which are received by some Christians as an authentic part of the Holy Scriptures, but are rejected by others.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; Fourteen such writings, or books, formed part of the Septuagint, but not of the Hebrew canon recognized by the Jews of Palestine. The Council of Trent included all but three of these in the canon of inspired books having equal authority. The German and English Reformers grouped them in their Bibles under the title Apocrypha, as not having dogmatic authority, but being profitable for instruction. The Apocrypha is now commonly AMP?;mitted from the King James's Bible.
A*poc"ry*phal (AMP?;), a. 1. Pertaining to the Apocrypha.

p.def: Not canonical. Hence: Of doubtful authority; equivocal; mythic; fictitious; spurious; false.

p.blockquote:
The passages . . . are, however, in part from apocryphal or fictitious works.
Sir G. C. Lewis.

dictionary.p: A*poc"ry*phal*ist, n. One who believes in, or defends, the Apocrypha. [R.]
A*poc"ry*phal*ly, adv. In an apocryphal manner; mythically; not indisputably.
A*poc"ry*phal*ness, n. The quality or state of being apocryphal; doubtfulness of credit or genuineness.
A*poc`y*na"ceous (AMP?;), Ap`o*cyn"e*ous (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; dogbane; AMP?; from + AMP?; dog.] (Bot.) Belonging to, or resembling, a family of plants, of which the dogbane (Apocynum) is the type.
A*poc"y*nin (AMP?;), n. [From Apocynum, the generic name of dogbane.] (Chem.) A bitter principle obtained from the dogbane (Apocynum cannabinum).
{ Ap"od (AMP?;), Ap"o*dal (AMP?;), } a. [See Apod, n.] 1. Without feet; footless.

p.def: Destitute of the ventral fin, as the eels.

dictionary.p: { Ap"od (AMP?;), Ap"ode (AMP?;), } n.; pl. Apods (AMP?;) or Apodes (AMP?;). [Gr. AMP?;, AMP?;, footless; 'a priv. + AMP?;, AMP?;, foot.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of certain animals that have no feet or footlike organs; esp. one of certain fabulous birds which were said to have no feet.
AMPfist; The bird of paradise formerly had the name Paradisea apoda, being supposed to have no feet, as these were wanting in the specimens first obtained from the East Indies.

||Ap"o*da (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?;, AMP?;. See Apod, n.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) (a) A group of cirripeds, destitute of footlike organs. (b) An order of Amphibia without feet. See Ophiomorpha. (c) A group of worms without appendages, as the leech.
Ap"o*dan (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Apodal.
Ap`o*deic"tic*al*ly, Ap`o*dic"tic*al*ly, adv. So as to be evident beyond contradiction.
Ap"o*deme (AMP?;), n. [Pref. apo- + Gr. AMP?; body.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) One of the processes of the shell which project inwards and unite with one another, in the thorax of many Crustacea.
||Ap"o*des (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., masc. pl. See Apoda.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) (a) An order of fishes without ventral fins, including the eels. (b) A group of holothurians destitute of suckers. See Apneumona.
Ap`o*dic"tic (AMP?;), a. Same as Apodeictic.
||Ap`o*dix"is (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?;.] Full demonstration.

||A*pod"o*sis (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to give back; AMP?; from, back again + AMP?; to give.] (Gram.) The consequent clause or conclusion in a conditional sentence, expressing the result, and thus distinguished from the protasis or clause which expresses a condition. Thus, in the sentence, "Though he slay me, yet will I trust in him," the former clause is the protasis, and the latter the apodosis.
AMPfist; Some grammarians extend the terms protasis and apodosis to the introductory clause and the concluding clause, even when the sentence is not conditional.
Ap"o*dous (AMP?;)(#), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Apodal; apod.
||A*pod`y*te"ri*um (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to strip one's self.] (Anc. Arch.) The apartment at the entrance of the baths, or in the palestra, where one stripped; a dressing room.
Ap`o*ga"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?; far from the earth.] Apogean.
Ap`o*gam"ic (AMP?;), a. Relating to apogamy.
A*pog"a*my (AMP?;), n. [Pref. apo- + Gr. AMP?; marriage.] (Bot.) The formation of a bud in place of a fertilized ovule or oAMPouml;spore. De Bary.
Ap`o*ge"al (AMP?;), a. (Astron.) Apogean.
Ap`o*ge"an (AMP?;), a. Connected with the apogee; as, apogean (neap) tides, which occur when the moon has passed her apogee.

Ap"o*gee (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; from the earth; AMP?; from + AMP?;, AMP?;, earth: cf. F. apogAMPeacute;e.] 1. (Astron.) That point in the orbit of the moon which is at the greatest distance from the earth.

AMPfist; Formerly, on the hypothesis that the earth is in the center of the system, this name was given to that point in the orbit of the sun, or of a planet, which was supposed to be at the greatest distance from the earth.

p.def: Fig.: The farthest or highest point; culmination.

dictionary.p: Ap`o*ge`o*trop"ic (AMP?;), a. [Pref. apo- + Gr. AMP?; earth + AMP?; turning.] (Bot.) Bending away from the ground; -- said of leaves, etc. Darwin.
Ap"o*ge*ot"ro*pism (AMP?;), n. The apogeotropic tendency of some leaves, and other parts.
Ap`o*hy"al (AMP?;), a. [Pref. apo- + the Gr. letter Y.] (Anat.) Of or pertaining to a portion of the horn of the hyoid bone.
A*poise" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + poise.] Balanced.
A*po"lar (AMP?;), a. [Pref. a- + polar.] (Biol.) Having no radiating processes; -- applied particularly to certain nerve cells.
Ap`o*laus"tic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to enjoy.] Devoted to enjoyment.
A*pol`li*na"ri*an (AMP?;), a. [L. Apollinaris, fr. Apollo.] (Rom. Antiq.) In honor of Apollo; as, the Apollinarian games.
A*pol`li*na"ri*an, n. (Eccl. Hist.) A follower of Apollinaris, Bishop of Laodicea in the fourth century, who denied the proper humanity of Christ.
A*pol`li*na"ris wa"ter (AMP?;). An effervescing alkaline mineral water used as a table beverage. It is obtained from a spring in Apollinarisburg, near Bonn.

A*pol"lo (AMP?;), n. [L. Apollo, - linis, Gr. AMP?;.] (Classic Myth.) A deity among the Greeks and Romans. He was the god of light and day (the "sun god"), of archery, prophecy, medicine, poetry, and music, etc., and was represented as the model of manly grace and beauty; -- called also PhAMPeacute;bus.
The Apollo Belvedere, a celebrated statue of Apollo in the Belvedere gallery of the Vatican palace at Rome, esteemed of the noblest representations of the human frame.
Ap`ol*lo"ni*an (AMP?;), Ap`ol*lon"ic (AMP?;), a. Of, pertaining to, or resembling, Apollo.

A*pol"ly*on (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; destroying, fr. AMP?;, AMP?;, to destroy utterly; AMP?; from, entirely + AMP?; to destroy.] The Destroyer; -- a name used (Rev. ix. 11) for the angel of the bottomless pit, answering to the Hebrew Abaddon.
A*pol"o*ger (AMP?;), n. A teller of apologues. [Obs.]
A*pol`o*get"ic*al*ly, adv. By way of apology.
A*pol`o*get"ics (AMP?;), n. That branch of theology which defends the Holy Scriptures, and sets forth the evidence of their divine authority.

A*pol"o*gist (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. apologiste.] One who makes an apology; one who speaks or writes in defense of a faith, a cause, or an institution; especially, one who argues in defense of Christianity.
A*pol"o*gize (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Apologized (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Apologizing.] [Cf. F. apologiser.] 1. To make an apology or defense. Dr. H. More.

p.def: To make an apology or excuse; to make acknowledgment of some fault or offense, with expression of regret for it, by way of amends; -- with for; as, my correspondent apologized for not answering my letter.

p.blockquote:
To apologize for his insolent language.
Froude.

dictionary.p: A*pol"o*gize, v. t. To defend. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The Christians . . . were apologized by Plinie.
Dr. G. Benson.

dictionary.p: A*pol"o*gi`zer (AMP?;), n. One who makes an apology; an apologist.

Ap"o*logue (AMP?;), n. [L. apologous, Gr. AMP?;; AMP?; from + AMP?; speech, AMP?; to speak: cf. F. apologue.] A story or relation of fictitious events, intended to convey some moral truth; a moral fable.

AMPfist; An apologue differs from a parable in this;: the parable is drawn from events which take place among mankind, and therefore requires probability in the narrative; the apologue is founded on supposed actions of brutes or inanimate things, and therefore is not limited by strict rules of probability. AMPAElig;sop's fables are good examples of apologues.

A*pol"o*gy (AMP?;), n.; pl. Apologies. [L. apologia, Gr. AMP?;; AMP?; from + AMP?;: cf. F. apologie. See Apologetic.] 1. Something said or written in defense or justification of what appears to others wrong, or of what may be liable to disapprobation; justification; as, Tertullian's Apology for Christianity.

p.blockquote:
It is not my intention to make an apology for my poem; some will think it needs no excuse, and others will receive none.
Dryden.

p.def: An acknowledgment intended as an atonement for some improper or injurious remark or act; an admission to another of a wrong or discourtesy done him, accompanied by an expression of regret.
Anything provided as a substitute; a makeshift.

p.blockquote:
He goes to work devising apologies for window curtains.
Dickens.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Excuse. An apology, in the original sense of the word, was a pleading off from some charge or imputation, by explaining and defending one's principles or conduct. It therefore amounted to a vindication. One who offers an apology, admits himself to have been, at least apparently, in the wrong, but brings forward some palliating circumstance, or tenders a frank acknowledgment, by way of reparation. We make an apology for some breach of propriety or decorum (like rude expressions, unbecoming conduct, etc.), or some deficiency in what might be reasonably expected. We offer an excuse when we have been guilty of some breach or neglect of duty; and we do it by way of extenuating our fault, and with a view to be forgiven. When an excuse has been accepted, an apology may still, in some cases, be necessary or appropriate. "An excuse is not grounded on the claim of innocence, but is rather an appeal for favor resting on some collateral circumstance. An apology mostly respects the conduct of individuals toward each other as equals; it is a voluntary act produced by feelings of decorum, or a desire for the good opinion of others." Crabb.
A*pol"o*gy (AMP?;), v. i. To offer an apology. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
For which he can not well apology.
J. Webster.

dictionary.p: Ap`o*me*com"e*ter, n. An instrument for measuring the height of objects. Knight.
Ap`o*me*com"e*try, n. [Pref. apo- + Gr. AMP?; length + -metry.] The art of measuring the distance of objects afar off. [Obs. or R.]
{ ||Ap`o*mor"phi*a (AMP?;), Ap`o*mor"phine (AMP?;), } n. [Pref. apo- + morphia, morphine.] (Chem.) A crystalline alkaloid obtained from morphia. It is a powerful emetic.

||Ap`o*neu*ro"sis (AMP?;), n.; pl. Aponeuroses (AMP?;). [Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to pass into a tendon; AMP?; from + AMP?; to strain the sinews, AMP?; sinew, tendon, nerve.] (Anat.) Any one of the thicker and denser of the deep fasciAMPaelig; which cover, invest, and the terminations and attachments of, many muscles. They often differ from tendons only in being flat and thin. See Fascia.
Ap`o*neu*rot"ic (AMP?;), a. (Anat.) Of or pertaining to an aponeurosis.
Ap`o*neu*rot"o*my (AMP?;), n. [Aponeurosis + Gr. AMP?; a cutting.] Dissection of aponeuroses.

Ap`o*pemp"tic (-pAMPebreve;mp"tAMPibreve;k), a. [Gr. 'apopemptiko`s, fr. 'apope`mpein to send off or away; 'apo` from + pe`mpein to send.] Sung or addressed to one departing; valedictory; as, apopemptic songs or hymns.
[1913 Webster]

||A*poph"a*sis (AMPadot;*pAMPobreve;f"AMPadot;*sAMPibreve;s), n. [Gr. 'apo`fasis denial, fr. 'apofa`nai to speak out, to deny.] (Rhet.) A figure by which a speaker formally declines to take notice of a favorable point, but in such a manner as to produce the effect desired. [For example, see Mark Antony's oration. Shak., Julius CAMPaelig;sar, iii. 2.]
Ap`o*phleg"ma*tism, n. [Gr. AMP?;, Galen.] 1. (Med.) The action of apophlegmatics.
2. An apophlegmatic. [Obs.] Bacon.
Ap`o*phleg*mat"i*zant (AMP?;), n. (Med.) An apophlegmatic. [Obs.]
Ap`oph*thegm (AMP?;), n. See Apothegm.
Ap`oph*theg*mat"ic (AMP?;), Ap`oph*theg*mat"ic*al (AMP?;), a. Same as Apothegmatic.

||A*poph"y*ge (AMP?;), n. [Gr. 'apofygh` escape, in arch. the curve with which the shaft escapes into its base or capital, fr. 'apofey`gein to flee away; 'apo` from + fey`gein to flee: cf. F. apophyge.] (Arch.) The small hollow curvature given to the top or bottom of the shaft of a column where it expands to meet the edge of the fillet; -- called also the scape. Parker.

A*poph"yl*lite (AMP?;), n. [Pref. apo- + Gr. AMP?; leaf; so called from its foliated structure or easy cleavage.] (Min.) A mineral relating to the zeolites, usually occurring in square prisms or octahedrons with pearly luster on the cleavage surface. It is a hydrous silicate of calcium and potassium.

||A*poph"y*sis (AMP?;), n.; pl. -ses. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?; offshoot, process of a bone, fr. AMP?; to grow from; AMP?; from + AMP?;, AMP?;, to grow.] 1. (Anat.) A marked prominence or process on any part of a bone.

p.def: An enlargement at the top of a pedicel or stem, as seen in certain mosses.

dictionary.p: Ap`o*plec"tic, n. One liable to, or affected with, apoplexy.
Ap`o*plec"ti*form (AMP?;), Ap`o*plec"toid (AMP?;), a. [Apoplectic + -form, -oid.] Resembling apoplexy.
Ap"o*plex (AMP?;), n. Apoplexy. [Obs.] Dryden.
Ap`o*plexed (-plAMPebreve;kst), a. Affected with apoplexy. [Obs.] Shak.

Ap"o*plex`y (AMPabreve;p"AMPosl;*plAMPebreve;ks`AMPybreve;), n. [OE. poplexye, LL. poplexia, apoplexia, fr. Gr. 'apoplhxi`a, fr. 'apoplh`ssein to cripple by a stroke; 'apo` from + plh`ssein to strike: cf. F. apoplexie. See Plague.] (Med.) Sudden diminution or loss of consciousness, sensation, and voluntary motion, usually caused by pressure on the brain.

AMPfist; The term is now usually limited to cerebral apoplexy, or loss of consciousness due to effusion of blood or other lesion within the substance of the brain; but it is sometimes extended to denote an effusion of blood into the substance of any organ; as, apoplexy of the lung.
Ap`o*ret"ic*al (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;. See Aporia.] Doubting; skeptical. [Obs.] Cudworth.

||A*po"ri*a (AMP?;), n.; pl. Aporias (AMP?;). [L., doubt, Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; without passage, at a loss; 'a priv. + AMP?; passage.] (Rhet.) A figure in which the speaker professes to be at a loss what course to pursue, where to begin to end, what to say, etc.
||Ap`o*ro"sa (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL., fr. Gr. AMP?;. See Aporia.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A group of corals in which the coral is not porous; -- opposed to Perforata.
Ap`o*rose" (AMP?;), a. (ZoAMPouml;l.) Without pores.
A*port" (AMP?;), adv. [Pref. a- + port.] (Naut.) On or towards the port or left side; -- said of the helm.

||Ap`o*si`o*pe"sis (?; 277), n. [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;, from AMP?; to be quite silent.] (Rhet.) A figure of speech in which the speaker breaks off suddenly, as if unwilling or unable to state what was in his mind; as, "I declare to you that his conduct -- but I can not speak of that, here."

A*pos"ta*sy (AMP?;), n.; pl. Apostasies (AMP?;). [OE. apostasie, F. apostasie, L. apostasia, fr. Gr. AMP?; a standing off from, a defection, fr. AMP?; to stand off, revolt; AMP?; from + AMP?; to stand. See Off and Stand.] An abandonment of what one has voluntarily professed; a total desertion of departure from one's faith, principles, or party; esp., the renunciation of a religious faith; as, Julian's apostasy from Christianity.

A*pos"tate (AMP?;), n. [L. apostata, Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?;. See Apostasy.] 1. One who has forsaken the faith, principles, or party, to which he before adhered; esp., one who has forsaken his religion for another; a pervert; a renegade.

p.def: One who, after having received sacred orders, renounces his clerical profession.

p.blockquote:
So spake the apostate angel.
Milton.

A wretched and apostate state.
Steele.

dictionary.p: A*pos"tate, v. i. [L. apostatare.] To apostatize. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
We are not of them which apostate from Christ.
Bp. Hall.

dictionary.p: Ap`o*stat"ic (AMP?;), a. [L. apostaticus, Gr. AMP?;.] Apostatical. [R.]
Ap`o*stat"ic*al (AMP?;), a. Apostate.

p.blockquote:
An heretical and apostatical church.
Bp. Hall.

dictionary.p: A*pos"ta*tize (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Apostatized (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Apostatizing.] [LL. apostatizare.] To renounce totally a religious belief once professed; to forsake one's church, the faith or principles once held, or the party to which one has previously adhered.

p.blockquote:
He apostatized from his old faith in facts, took to believing in AMP?;emblances.
Carlyle.

dictionary.p: A*pos"te*mate (AMP?;), v. i. [See Aposteme.] To form an abscess; to swell and fill with pus. Wiseman.
A*pos`te*ma"tion (AMP?;), n. [LL. apostematio: cf. F. apostAMPeacute;mation.] (Med.) The formation of an aposteme; the process of suppuration. [Written corruptly imposthumation.] Wiseman.
Ap`os*tem"a*tous (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to, or partaking of the nature of, an aposteme.

Ap"os*teme (AMP?;), n. [L. apostema, Gr. AMP?; the separation of corrupt matter into an ulcer, fr. AMP?; to stand off: cf. F. apostAMPegrave;me. See Apostasy.] (Med.) An abscess; a swelling filled with purulent matter. [Written corruptly imposthume.]

||A` pos*te`ri*o"ri (AMP?;). [L. a (ab) + posterior latter.] 1. (Logic) Characterizing that kind of reasoning which derives propositions from the observation of facts, or by generalizations from facts arrives at principles and definitions, or infers causes from effects. This is the reverse of a priori reasoning.

p.def: Applied to knowledge which is based upon or derived from facts through induction or experiment; inductive or empirical.

dictionary.p: { A*pos"til (AMP?;), A*pos"tille (AMP?;), } n. [F. apostille. See Postil.] A marginal note on a letter or other paper; an annotation. Motley.

A*pos"tle (AMP?;), n. [OE. apostle, apostel, postle, AS. apostol, L. apostolus, fr. Gr. AMP?; messenger, one sent forth or away, fr. AMP?; to send off or away; AMP?; from + AMP?; to send; akin to G. stellen to set, E. stall: cf. F. apAMPocirc;tre, Of. apostre, apostle, apostele, apostole.] 1. Literally: One sent forth; a messenger. Specifically: One of the twelve disciples of Christ, specially chosen as his companions and witnesses, and sent forth to preach the gospel.

p.blockquote:
He called unto him his disciples, and of them he chose twelve, whom also he named apostles.
Luke vi. 13.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; The title of apostle is also applied to others, who, though not of the number of the Twelve, yet were equal with them in office and dignity; as, "Paul, called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ." 1 Cor. i. 1. In Heb. iii. 1, the name is given to Christ himself, as having been sent from heaven to publish the gospel. In the primitive church, other ministers were called apostles (Rom. xvi. 7).

p.def: The missionary who first plants the Christian faith in any part of the world; also, one who initiates any great moral reform, or first advocates any important belief; one who has extraordinary success as a missionary or reformer; as, Dionysius of Corinth is called the apostle of France, John Eliot the apostle to the Indians, Theobald Mathew the apostle of temperance.
A brief letter dimissory sent by a court appealed from to the superior court, stating the case, etc.; a paper sent up on appeals in the admiralty courts.

dictionary.p: Apostles' creed, a creed of unknown origin, which was formerly ascribed to the apostles. It certainly dates back to the beginning of the sixth century, and some assert that it can be found in the writings of Ambrose in the fourth century. -- Apostle spoon (Antiq.), a spoon of silver, with the handle terminating in the figure of an apostle. One or more were offered by sponsors at baptism as a present to the godchild. B. Jonson.
A*pos"tle*ship (AMP?;), n. The office or dignity of an apostle.
A*pos"to*late (AMP?;), n. [L. apostolatus, fr. apostolus. See Apostle.] 1. The dignity, office, or mission, of an apostle; apostleship.

p.blockquote:
Judas had miscarried and lost his apostolate.
Jer. Taylor.

p.def: The dignity or office of the pope, as the holder of the apostolic see.

dictionary.p: { Ap`os*tol"ic (AMP?;), Ap`os*tol"ic*al (AMP?;), } a. [L. apostolicus, Gr. AMP?;: cf. F. apostolique.] 1. Pertaining to an apostle, or to the apostles, their times, or their peculiar spirit; as, an apostolical mission; the apostolic age.

p.def: Of or pertaining to the pope or the papacy; papal.

dictionary.p: Apostolical brief. See under Brief. -- Apostolic canons, a collection of rules and precepts relating to the duty of Christians, and particularly to the ceremonies and discipline of the church in the second and third centuries. -- Apostolic church, the Christian church; -- so called on account of its apostolic foundation, doctrine, and order. The churches of Rome, Alexandria, Antioch, and Jerusalem were called apostolic churches. -- Apostolic constitutions, directions of a nature similar to the apostolic canons, and perhaps compiled by the same authors or author. -- Apostolic fathers, early Christian writers, who were born in the first century, and thus touched on the age of the apostles. They were Polycarp, Clement, Ignatius, and Hermas; to these Barnabas has sometimes been added. -- Apostolic king (or majesty), a title granted by the pope to the kings of Hungary on account of the extensive propagation of Christianity by St. Stephen, the founder of the royal line. It is now a title of the emperor of Austria in right of the throne of Hungary. -- Apostolic see, a see founded and governed by an apostle; specifically, the Church of Rome; -- so called because, in the Roman Catholic belief, the pope is the successor of St. Peter, the prince of the apostles, and the only apostle who has successors in the apostolic office. -- Apostolical succession, the regular and uninterrupted transmission of ministerial authority by a succession of bishops from the apostles to any subsequent period. Hook.
Ap`os*tol"ic, n. [L. apostolicus.] (Eccl. Hist.) A member of one of certain ascetic sects which at various times professed to imitate the practice of the apostles.
Ap`os*tol"ic*al*ly, adv. In an apostolic manner.
Ap`os*tol"ic*al*ness, n. Apostolicity. Dr. H. More.

A*pos"tro*phe (AMP?;), n. [(1) L., fr. Gr. AMP?; a turning away, fr. AMP?; to turn away; AMP?; from + AMP?; to turn. (2) F., fr. L. apostrophus apostrophe, the turning away or omitting of a letter, Gr. AMP?;.] 1. (Rhet.) A figure of speech by which the orator or writer suddenly breaks off from the previous method of his discourse, and addresses, in the second person, some person or thing, absent or present; as, Milton's apostrophe to Light at the beginning of the third book of "Paradise Lost."

p.def: The contraction of a word by the omission of a letter or letters, which omission is marked by the character ['] placed where the letter or letters would have been; as, call'd for called.

The mark ['] used to denote that a word is contracted (as in ne'er for never, can't for can not), and as a sign of the possessive, singular and plural; as, a boy's hat, boys' hats. In the latter use it originally marked the omission of the letter e.

dictionary.p: The apostrophe is used to mark the plural of figures and letters; as, two 10's and three a's. It is also employed to mark the close of a quotation.
Ap`os*troph"ic (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to an apostrophe, grammatical or rhetorical.
A*pos"tro*phize (AMP?;), v. t., [imp. AMP p. p. Apostrophized (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Apostrophizing.] 1. To address by apostrophe.

p.def: To contract by omitting a letter or letters; also, to mark with an apostrophe (') or apostrophes.

dictionary.p: A*pos"tro*phize, v. i. To use the rhetorical figure called apostrophe.
Ap"os*tume (AMP?;), n. See Aposteme. [Obs.]

Ap`o*tac"tite (AMP?;), n. [LL. pl. apotactitae, Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; set apart; AMP?; from + AMP?; to arrange, ordain.] (Eccl. Hist.) One of a sect of ancient Christians, who, in supposed imitation of the first believers, renounced all their possessions.
A*pot"e*lesm (AMP?;), n. [See Apotelesmatic.] 1. The result or issue. [Obs.]
2. (Astrol.) The calculation and explanation of a nativity. [Obs.] Bailey.

Ap`o*tel`es*mat"ic (AMP?;), a. [Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; effect of the stars on human destiny, fr. AMP?; to complete; AMP?; from + AMP?; to end, AMP?; end.] 1. Relating to the casting of horoscopes. [Archaic] Whewell.

p.def: Relating to an issue of fulfillment.

p.blockquote:
In this way a passage in the Old Testament may have, or rather comprise, an apotelesmatic sense, i. e., one of after or final accomplishment.
M. Stuart.

dictionary.p: A*poth"e*ca*ry (AMP?;), n.; pl. Apothecaries. [OE. apotecarie, fr. LL. apothecarius, fr. L. apotheca storehouse, Gr. apo, fr. AMP?; to put away; AMP?; from + AMP?; to put: cf. F. apothicaire, OF. apotecaire. See Thesis.] One who prepares and sells drugs or compounds for medicinal purposes.

AMPfist; In England an apothecary is one of a privileged class of practitioners -- a kind of sub-physician. The surgeon apothecary is the ordinary family medical attendant. One who sells drugs and makes up prescriptions is now commonly called in England a druggist or a pharmaceutical chemist.

Apothecaries' weight, the system of weights by which medical prescriptions were formerly compounded. The pound and ounce are the same as in Troy weight; they differ only in the manner of subdivision. The ounce is divided into 8 drams, 24 scruples, 480 grains. See Troy weight.
||Apo`*the"ci*um, n.; pl. Apothecia (AMP?;). [NL.] (Bot.) The ascigerous fructification of lichens, forming masses of various shapes.

{ Ap"o*thegm, Ap"oph*thegm } (AMP?;), n. [Gr. 'apo`fqegma thing uttered, apothegm, from 'apofqe`ggesqai to speak out; 'apo` from + fqe`ggesqai to speak.] A short, pithy, and instructive saying; a terse remark, conveying some important truth; a sententious precept or maxim. [Apothegm is now the prevalent spelling in the United States.]
Ap`o*theg"ma*tist (AMP?;), n. A collector or maker of apothegms. Pope.
Ap`o*theg"ma*tize (AMP?;), v. i. To utter apothegms, or short and sententious sayings.
Ap"o*them (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; + AMP?; that which is placed, AMP?; to place.] 1. (Math.) The perpendicular from the center to one of the sides of a regular polygon.

p.def: A deposit formed in a liquid extract of a vegetable substance by exposure to the air.

dictionary.p: Ap`o*the"o*sis (?; 277), n. pl. Apotheoses (AMP?;). [L., fr. Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to deify; AMP?; from + AMP?; to deify, AMP?; a god.] 1. The act of elevating a mortal to the rank of, and placing him among, "the gods;" deification.
2. Glorification; exaltation. "The apotheosis of chivalry." Prescott. "The noisy apotheosis of liberty and machinery." F. Harrison.
Ap`o*the"o*size (AMP?;), v. t. To exalt to the dignity of a deity; to declare to be a god; to deify; to glorify.

||A*poth"e*sis (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; a putting back or away, fr. AMP?;. See Apothecary.] (Arch.) (a) A place on the south side of the chancel in the primitive churches, furnished with shelves, for books, vestments, etc. Weale. (b) A dressing room connected with a public bath.

||A*pot"o*me (AMP?;), n. [Gr. AMP?; a cutting off, fr. AMP?; to cut off; AMP?; from + AMP?; to cut.] 1. (Math.) The difference between two quantities commensurable only in power, as between AMPradic;2 and 1, or between the diagonal and side of a square.
2. (Mus) The remaining part of a whole tone after a smaller semitone has been deducted from it; a major semitone. [Obs.]
Ap"o*zem (AMP?;), n. [L. apozema, Gr. AMP?;, fr. AMP?; to extract by boiling; AMP?; from + AMP?; boil.] (Med.) A decoction or infusion. [Obs.] Wiseman.
Ap`o*zem"ic*al (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to, or resembling, a decoction. [Obs.] J. Whitaker.
Ap*pair" (AMP?;), v. t. AMP i. [OF. empeirier, F. empire. See Impair.] To impair; to grow worse. [Obs.]
Ap`pa*la"chi*an (AMP?;), a. Of or pertaining to a chain of mountains in the United States, commonly called the Allegheny mountains.
AMPfist; The name Appalachian was given to the mountains by the Spaniards under De Soto, who derived it from the neighboring Indians. Am. Cyc.

Ap*pall" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Appalled (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Appalling.] [OF. appalir to grow pale, make pale; a (L. ad) + pAMPacirc;lir to grow pale, to make pale, pAMPacirc;le pale. See Pale, a., and cf. Pall.] 1. To make pale; to blanch. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The answer that ye made to me, my dear, . . .
Hath so appalled my countenance.
Wyatt.

dictionary.p: 2. To weaken; to enfeeble; to reduce; as, an old appalled wight. [Obs.] Chaucer.

p.blockquote:
Wine, of its own nature, will not congeal and freeze, only it will lose the strength, and become appalled in extremity of cold.
Holland.

p.def: To depress or discourage with fear; to impress with fear in such a manner that the mind shrinks, or loses its firmness; to overcome with sudden terror or horror; to dismay; as, the sight appalled the stoutest heart.

p.blockquote:
The house of peers was somewhat appalled at this alarum.
Clarendon.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To dismay; terrify; daunt; frighten; affright; scare; depress. See Dismay.
Ap*pall", v. i. 1. To grow faint; to become weak; to become dismayed or discouraged. [Obs.] Gower.
2. To lose flavor or become stale. [Obs.]
Ap*pall", n. Terror; dismay. [Poet.] Cowper.
Ap*pall"ing, a. Such as to appall; as, an appalling accident. -- Ap*pall"ing*ly, adv.
Ap*pall"ment (AMP?;), n. Depression occasioned by terror; dismay. [Obs.] Bacon.

Ap"pa*nage (AMP?;), n. [F. apanage, fr. OF. apaner to nourish, support, fr. LL. apanare to furnish with bread, to provision; L. ad + pains bread.] 1. The portion of land assigned by a sovereign prince for the subsistence of his younger sons.

p.def: A dependency; a dependent territory.

dictionary.p: 3. That which belongs to one by custom or right; a natural adjunct or accompaniment. "Wealth . . . the appanage of wit." Swift.
Ap*pan"a*gist (AMPabreve;p*pAMPabreve;n"AMPadot;*jAMPibreve;st), n. [F. apanagiste.] A prince to whom an appanage has been granted.
Ap*par"ail*lyng (AMP?;), n. [See Apparel, n. AMP v.] Preparation. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Ap"pa*ratus (AMP?;), n.; pl. Apparatus, also rarely Apparatuses (AMP?;). [L., from apparare, apparatum, to prepare; ad + prepare to make ready.] 1. Things provided as means to some end.

p.def: Hence: A full collection or set of implements, or utensils, for a given duty, experimental or operative; any complex instrument or appliance, mechanical or chemical, for a specific action or operation; machinery; mechanism.
A collection of organs all of which unite in a common function; as, the respiratory apparatus.

dictionary.p: Ap*par"el (AMP?;), n. [OE. apparel, apareil, OF. apareil, appareil, preparation, provision, furniture, OF. apareiller to match, prepare, F. appareiller; OF. a (L. ad) + pareil like, similar, fr. LL. pariculus, dim. of L. par equal. See Pair.] 1. External clothing; vesture; garments; dress; garb; external habiliments or array.

p.blockquote:
Fresh in his new apparel, proud and young.
Denham.

At public devotion his resigned carriage made religion appear in the natural apparel of simplicity.
Tatler.

p.def: A small ornamental piece of embroidery worn on albs and some other ecclesiastical vestments.
The furniture of a ship, as masts, sails, rigging, anchors, guns, etc.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Dress; clothing; vesture; garments; raiment; garb; costume; attire; habiliments.
Ap*par"el, v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Appareled, or Apparelled (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Appareling, or Apparelling.] [OF. apareiller.] 1. To make or get (something) ready; to prepare. [Obs.] Chaucer.

p.def: To furnish with apparatus; to equip; to fit out.

p.blockquote:
Ships . . . appareled to fight.
Hayward.

p.def: To dress or clothe; to attire.

p.blockquote:
They which are gorgeously appareled, and live delicately, are in kings' courts.
Luke vii. 25.

p.def: To dress with external ornaments; to cover with something ornamental; to deck; to embellish; as, trees appareled with flowers, or a garden with verdure.

p.blockquote:
Appareled in celestial light.
Wordsworth.

dictionary.p: Ap*par"ence (AMP?;), n. [OF. aparence.] Appearance. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Ap*par"en*cy (AMP?;), n. 1. Appearance. [Obs.]

p.def: Apparentness; state of being apparent.
The position of being heir apparent.

dictionary.p: Ap*par"ent (AMP?;), a. [F. apparent, L. apparens, -entis, p. pr. of apparere. See Appear.] 1. Capable of being seen, or easily seen; open to view; visible to the eye; within sight or view.

p.blockquote:
The moon . . . apparent queen.
Milton.

p.def: Clear or manifest to the understanding; plain; evident; obvious; known; palpable; indubitable.

p.blockquote:
It is apparent foul play.
Shak.

To live on terms of civility, and even of apparent friendship.
Macaulay.

What Berkeley calls visible magnitude was by astronomers called apparent magnitude.
Reid.

dictionary.p: Apparent horizon, the circle which in a level plain bounds our view, and is formed by the apparent meeting of the earth and heavens, as distinguished from the rational horizon. -- Apparent time. See Time. -- Heir apparent (Law), one whose to an estate is indefeasible if he survives the ancestor; -- in distinction from presumptive heir. See Presumptive.
Syn. -- Visible; distinct; plain; obvious; clear; certain; evident; manifest; indubitable; notorious.
Ap*par"ent, n. An heir apparent. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
I'll draw it [the sword] as apparent to the crown.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Ap*par"ent*ly, adv. 1. Visibly. [Obs.] Hobbes.

p.def: Plainly; clearly; manifestly; evidently.

p.blockquote:
If he should scorn me so apparently.
Shak.

p.def: Seemingly; in appearance; as, a man may be apparently friendly, yet malicious in heart.

dictionary.p: Ap*par"ent*ness, n. Plainness to the eye or the mind; visibleness; obviousness. [R.] Sherwood.
Ap`pa*ri"tion (AMP?;), n. [F. apparition, L. apparitio, fr. apparere. See Appear.] 1. The act of becoming visible; appearance; visibility. Milton.

p.blockquote:
The sudden apparition of the Spaniards.
Prescott.

The apparition of Lawyer Clippurse occasioned much speculation in that portion of the world.
Sir W. Scott.

p.def: The thing appearing; a visible object; a form.

p.blockquote:
Which apparition, it seems, was you.
Tatler.

dictionary.p: 3. An unexpected, wonderful, or preternatural appearance; a ghost; a specter; a phantom. "The heavenly bands . . . a glorious apparition." Milton.

p.blockquote:
I think it is the weakness of mine eyes
That shapes this monstrous apparition.
Shak.

p.def: The first appearance of a star or other luminary after having been invisible or obscured; -- opposed to occultation.

dictionary.p: Circle of perpetual apparition. See under Circle.
Ap`pa*ri"tion*al (AMP?;), a. Pertaining to an apparition or to apparitions; spectral. "An apparitional soul." Tylor.
Ap*par"i*tor (AMP?;), n. [L., fr. apparere. See Appear.] 1. Formerly, an officer who attended magistrates and judges to execute their orders.

p.blockquote:
Before any of his apparitors could execute the sentence, he was himself summoned away by a sterner apparitor to the other world.
De Quincey.

p.def: A messenger or officer who serves the process of an ecclesiastical court.

dictionary.p: ||Ap`pau`mAMPeacute;" (AMP?;), n. [F. appaumAMPeacute;; AMP?; (l. ad) + paume the palm, fr. L. palma.] (Her.) A hand open and extended so as to show the palm.
Ap*pay" (AMP?;), v. t. [OF. appayer, apaier, LL. appacare, appagare, fr. L. ad + pacare to pacify, pax, pacis, peace. See Pay, Appease.] To pay; to satisfy or appease. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
Ap*peach" (AMP?;), v. t. [OE. apechen, for empechen, OF. empeechier, F. empAMPecirc;cher, to hinder. See Impeach.] To impeach; to accuse; to asperse; to inform against; to reproach. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
And oft of error did himself appeach.
Spenser.

dictionary.p: Ap*peach"er, n. An accuser. [Obs.] Raleigh.
Ap*peach"ment (AMP?;), n. Accusation. [Obs.]

Ap*peal" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Appealed (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Appealing.] [OE. appelen, apelen, to appeal, accuse, OF. appeler, fr. L. appellare to approach, address, invoke, summon, call, name; akin to appellere to drive to; ad + pellere to drive. See Pulse, and cf. Peal.] 1. (Law) (a) To make application for the removal of (a cause) from an inferior to a superior judge or court for a rehearing or review on account of alleged injustice or illegality in the trial below. We say, the cause was appealed from an inferior court. (b) To charge with a crime; to accuse; to institute a private criminal prosecution against for some heinous crime; as, to appeal a person of felony.
2. To summon; to challenge. [Archaic]

p.blockquote:
Man to man will I appeal the Norman to the lists.
Sir W. Scott.

dictionary.p: 3. To invoke. [Obs.] Milton.
Ap*peal", v. t. 1. (Law) To apply for the removal of a cause from an inferior to a superior judge or court for the purpose of reAMPeuml;xamination of for decision. Tomlins.

p.blockquote:
I appeal unto CAMPaelig;sar.
Acts xxv. 11.

p.def: To call upon another to decide a question controverted, to corroborate a statement, to vindicate one's rights, etc.; as, I appeal to all mankind for the truth of what is alleged. Hence: To call on one for aid; to make earnest request.

p.blockquote:
I appeal to the Scriptures in the original.
Horsley.

They appealed to the sword.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: Ap*peal", n. [OE. appel, apel, OF. apel, F. appel, fr. appeler. See Appeal, v. t.] 1. (Law) (a) An application for the removal of a cause or suit from an inferior to a superior judge or court for reAMPeuml;xamination or review. (b) The mode of proceeding by which such removal is effected. (c) The right of appeal. (d) An accusation; a process which formerly might be instituted by one private person against another for some heinous crime demanding punishment for the particular injury suffered, rather than for the offense against the public. (e) An accusation of a felon at common law by one of his accomplices, which accomplice was then called an approver. See Approvement. Tomlins. Bouvier.

p.def: A summons to answer to a charge.
A call upon a person or an authority for proof or decision, in one's favor; reference to another as witness; a call for help or a favor; entreaty.

p.blockquote:
A kind of appeal to the Deity, the author of wonders.
Bacon.

p.def: Resort to physical means; recourse.

p.blockquote:
Every milder method is to be tried, before a nation makes an appeal to arms.
Kent.

dictionary.p: Ap*peal"a*ble (AMP?;), a. 1. Capable of being appealed against; that may be removed to a higher tribunal for decision; as, the cause is appealable.
2. That may be accused or called to answer by appeal; as, a criminal is appealable for manslaughter. [Obs.]
Ap*peal"ant (AMP?;), n. An appellant. [Obs.] Shak.
Ap*peal"er (AMP?;), n. One who makes an appeal.

Ap*pear" (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Appeared (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Appearing.] [OE. apperen, aperen, OF. aparoir, F. apparoir, fr. L. apparAMP?;re to appear + parAMP?;reto come forth, to be visible; prob. from the same root as parAMP?;re to produce. Cf. Apparent, Parent, Peer, v. i.] 1. To come or be in sight; to be in view; to become visible.

p.blockquote:
And God . . . said, Let . . . the dry land appear.
Gen. i. 9.

p.def: To come before the public; as, a great writer appeared at that time.

To stand in presence of some authority, tribunal, or superior person, to answer a charge, plead a cause, or the like; to present one's self as a party or advocate before a court, or as a person to be tried.

p.blockquote:
We must all appear before the judgment seat.
AMPfist; Cor. v. 10.

One ruffian escaped because no prosecutor dared to appear.
Macaulay.

p.def: To become visible to the apprehension of the mind; to be known as a subject of observation or comprehension, or as a thing proved; to be obvious or manifest.

p.blockquote:
It doth not yet appear what we shall be.
1 John iii. 2.

Of their vain contest appeared no end.
Milton.

p.def: To seem; to have a certain semblance; to look.

p.blockquote:
They disfigure their faces, that they may appear unto men to fast.
Matt. vi. 16.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To seem; look. See Seem.
Ap*pear", n. Appearance. [Obs.] J. Fletcher.

Ap*pear"ance (AMP?;), n. [F. apparence, L. apparentia, fr. apparere. See Appear.] 1. The act of appearing or coming into sight; the act of becoming visible to the eye; as, his sudden appearance surprised me.

p.def: A thing seed; a phenomenon; a phase; an apparition; as, an appearance in the sky.
Personal presence; exhibition of the person; look; aspect; mien.

p.blockquote:
And now am come to see . . .
It thy appearance answer loud report.
Milton.

p.def: Semblance, or apparent likeness; external show. pl. Outward signs, or circumstances, fitted to make a particular impression or to determine the judgment as to the character of a person or a thing, an act or a state; as, appearances are against him.

p.blockquote:
There was upon the tabernacle, as it were, the appearance of fire.
Num. ix. 15.

For man looketh on the outward appearance.
1 Sam. xvi. 7.

Judge not according to the appearance.
John. vii. 24.

p.def: The act of appearing in a particular place, or in society, a company, or any proceedings; a coming before the public in a particular character; as, a person makes his appearance as an historian, an artist, or an orator.

p.blockquote:
Will he now retire,
After appearance, and again prolong
Our expectation?
Milton.

dictionary.p: 6. Probability; likelihood. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
There is that which hath no appearance.
Bacon.

p.def: The coming into court of either of the parties; the being present in court; the coming into court of a party summoned in an action, either by himself or by his attorney, expressed by a formal entry by the proper officer to that effect; the act or proceeding by which a party proceeded against places himself before the court, and submits to its jurisdiction.

dictionary.p: To put in an appearance, to be present; to appear in person. -- To save appearances, to preserve a fair outward show.
Syn. -- Coming; arrival; presence; semblance; pretense; air; look; manner; mien; figure; aspect.
Ap*pear"er (AMP?;), n. One who appears. Sir T. Browne.
Ap*pear"ing*ly, adv. Apparently. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Ap*peas"a*ble (AMP?;), a. Capable of being appeased or pacified; placable. -- Ap*peas"a*ble*ness, n.

Ap*pease" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Appealed (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Appeasing.] [OE. apesen, apaisen, OF. apaisier, apaissier, F. apaiser, fr. a (L. ad) + OF. pais peace, F. paix, fr. L. pax, pacis. See Peace.] To make quiet; to calm; to reduce to a state of peace; to still; to pacify; to dispel (anger or hatred); as, to appease the tumult of the ocean, or of the passions; to appease hunger or thirst.
Syn. -- To pacify; quiet; conciliate; propitiate; assuage; compose; calm; allay; hush; soothe; tranquilize.
Ap*pease"ment (AMP?;), n. The act of appeasing, or the state of being appeased; pacification. Hayward.
Ap*peas"er (AMP?;), n. One who appeases; a pacifier.
Ap*pea"sive (AMP?;), a. Tending to appease.
Ap*pel"la*ble (AMP?;), a. Appealable.
Ap*pel"lan*cy (AMP?;), n. Capability of appeal.
Ap*pel"lant (AMP?;), a. [L. appellans, p. pr. of appellare; cf. F. appelant. See Appeal.] Relating to an appeal; appellate. "An appellant jurisdiction." Hallam.
Party appellant (Law), the party who appeals; appellant; -- opposed to respondent, or appellee. Tomlins.
Ap*pel"lant, n. 1. (Law) (a) One who accuses another of felony or treason. [Obs.] (b) One who appeals, or asks for a rehearing or review of a cause by a higher tribunal.
2. A challenger. [Obs.] Milton.

p.def: One who appealed to a general council against the bull Unigenitus.
One who appeals or entreats.

dictionary.p: Ap*pel"late (AMP?;), a. [L. appelatus, p. p. of appellare.] Pertaining to, or taking cognizance of, appeals. "Appellate jurisdiction." Blackstone. "Appellate judges." Burke.
Appelate court, a court having cognizance of appeals.
Ap*pel"late, n. A person or prosecuted for a crime. [Obs.] See Appellee.
Ap`pel*la"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. appellatio, fr. appellare: cf. F. appellation. See Appeal.] 1. The act of appealing; appeal. [Obs.] Spenser.

p.def: The act of calling by a name.
The word by which a particular person or thing is called and known; name; title; designation.

p.blockquote:
They must institute some persons under the appellation of magistrates.
Hume.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- See Name.
Ap*pel"la*tive (AMP?;), a. [L. appellativus, fr. appellare: cf. F. appelatif. See Appeal.] 1. Pertaining to a common name; serving as a distinctive denomination; denominative; naming. Cudworth.

p.def: Common, as opposed to proper; denominative of a class.

dictionary.p: Ap*pel"la*tive, n. [L. appelativum, sc. nomen.] 1. A common name, in distinction from a proper name. A common name, or appellative, stands for a whole class, genus, or species of beings, or for universal ideas. Thus, tree is the name of all plants of a particular class; plant and vegetable are names of things that grow out of the earth. A proper name, on the other hand, stands for a single thing; as, Rome, Washington, Lake Erie.

p.def: An appellation or title; a descriptive name.

p.blockquote:
God chosen it for one of his appellatives to be the Defender of them.
Jer. Taylor.

dictionary.p: Ap*pel"la*tive*ly, adv. After the manner of nouns appellative; in a manner to express whole classes or species; as, Hercules is sometimes used appellatively, that is, as a common name, to signify a strong man.
Ap*pel"la*tive*ness, n. The quality of being appellative. Fuller.
Ap*pel"la*tory (AMP?;), a. [L. appellatorius, fr. appellare.] Containing an appeal.

p.blockquote:
An appellatory libel ought to contain the name of the party appellant.
Ayliffe.

dictionary.p: Ap`pel*lee", n. [F. appelAMPeacute;, p. p. of appeler, fr. L. appellare.] (Law) (a) The defendant in an appeal; -- opposed to appellant. (b) The person who is appealed against, or accused of crime; -- opposed to appellor. Blackstone.

Ap`pel*lor" (AMPabreve;p`pAMPebreve;l*lAMPocirc;r"), n. [OF. apeleur, fr. L. appellator, fr. appellare.] (Law) (a) The person who institutes an appeal, or prosecutes another for a crime. Blackstone. (b) One who confesses a felony committed and accuses his accomplices. Blount. Burrill.
AMPfist; This word is rarely or never used for the plaintiff in appeal from a lower court, who is called the appellant. Appellee is opposed both to appellant and appellor.
Ap"pen*age, n. See Appanage.

Ap*pend" (AMPabreve;p*pAMPebreve;nd"), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Appended; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Appending.] [L. appendere or F. appendre: cf. OE. appenden, apenden, to belong, OF. apendre, F. appendre, fr. L. appendAMPemacr;re, v. i., to hang to, appendAMPebreve;re, v. t., to hang to; ad + pendAMPemacr;re, v. i., to hang, pendAMPebreve;re, v. t., to hang. See Pendant.] 1. To hang or attach to, as by a string, so that the thing is suspended; as, a seal appended to a record; the inscription was appended to the column.

p.def: To add, as an accessory to the principal thing; to annex; as, notes appended to this chapter.

p.blockquote:
A further purpose appended to the primary one.
I. Taylor.

dictionary.p: Ap*pend"age, n. 1. Something appended to, or accompanying, a principal or greater thing, though not necessary to it, as a portico to a house.

p.blockquote:
Modesty is the appendage of sobriety.
Jer. Taylor.

p.def: A subordinate or subsidiary part or organ; an external organ or limb, esp. of the articulates.

p.blockquote:
AntennAMPaelig; and other appendages used for feeling.
Carpenter.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Addition; adjunct; concomitant.
Ap*pend"aged, a. Furnished with, or supplemented by, an appendage.
Ap*pend"ance, n. [F.] Something appendant.
Ap*pend"ant, a. [F. appendant, p. pr. of appendre. See Append, v. t.] 1. Hanging; annexed; adjunct; concomitant; as, a seal appendant to a paper.

p.blockquote:
As they have transmitted the benefit to us, it is but reasonable we should suffer the appendant calamity.
Jer. Taylor.

p.def: Appended by prescription, that is, a personal usage for a considerable time; -- said of a thing of inheritance belonging to another inheritance which is superior or more worthy; as, an advowson, common, etc. , which may be appendant to a manor, common of fishing to a freehold, a seat in church to a house.

dictionary.p: Ap*pend"ant, n. 1. Anything attached to another as incidental or subordinate to it.

p.def: A inheritance annexed by prescription to a superior inheritance.

dictionary.p: Ap*pend"i*cal (AMP?;), a. Of or like an appendix.
Ap*pend"i*cate (AMP?;), v. t. To append. [Obs.]
Ap*pend`i*ca"tion (AMP?;), n. An appendage. [Obs.]
Ap*pend`i*ci"tis (AMP?;), n. (Med.) Inflammation of the vermiform appendix.
Ap*pend"i*cle (AMP?;), n. [L. appendicula, dim. of. appendix.] A small appendage.
Ap`pen*dic"u*lar (AMP?;), a. Relating to an appendicle; appendiculate. [R.]

||Ap`pen*dic`u*la"ri*a (AMP?;), n. [NL.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) A genus of small free-swimming Tunicata, shaped somewhat like a tadpole, and remarkable for resemblances to the larvAMPaelig; of other Tunicata. It is the type of the order Copelata or Larvalia. See Illustration in Appendix.
||Ap`pen*dic`u*la"ta (AMP?;), n. pl. [NL.] (ZoAMPouml;l.) An order of annelids; the PolychAMPaelig;ta.
Ap`pen*dic"u*late (AMP?;), a. [See Appendicle.] Having small appendages; forming an appendage.
Appendiculate leaf, a small appended leaf. Withering.
Ap*pen"dix (AMP?;), n.; pl. E. Appendixes (AMP?;), L. Appendices (AMP?;). [L. appendix, -dicis, fr. appendere. See Append.] 1. Something appended or added; an appendage, adjunct, or concomitant.

p.blockquote:
Normandy became an appendix to England.
Sir M. Hale.

p.def: Any literary matter added to a book, but not necessarily essential to its completeness, and thus distinguished from supplement, which is intended to supply deficiencies and correct inaccuracies.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- See Supplement.
Ap*pen"sion (AMP?;), n. The act of appending. [Obs.]
Ap`per*ceive" (AMP?;), v. t. [F. apercevoir, fr. L. ad + percipere, perceptum, to perceive. See Perceive.] To perceive; to comprehend. Chaucer.

Ap`per*cep"tion (AMP?;), n. [Pref. ad- + perception: cf. F. apperception.] (Metaph.) The mind's perception of itself as the subject or actor in its own states; perception that reflects upon itself; sometimes, intensified or energetic perception. Leibnitz. Reid.

p.blockquote:
This feeling has been called by philosophers the apperception or consciousness of our own existence.
Sir W. Hamilton.

dictionary.p: Ap*per"il (AMP?;), n. Peril. [Obs.] Shak.

Ap`per*tain" (AMP?;), v. i. [imp. AMP p. p. Appertained (AMP?;); p. pr. AMP vb. n. Appertaining.] [OE. apperteinen, apertenen, OF. apartenir, F. appartenir, fr. L. appertinere; ad + pertinere to reach to, belong. See Pertain.] To belong or pertain, whether by right, nature, appointment, or custom; to relate.

p.blockquote:
Things appertaining to this life.
Hooker.

Give it unto him to whom it appertaineth.
Lev. vi. 5.

dictionary.p: Ap`per*tain"ment, n. That which appertains to a person; an appurtenance. [Obs. or R.] Shak.
{ Ap*per"ti*nance (AMP?;), Ap*per"ti*nence (AMP?;), } n. See Appurtenance.
Ap*per"ti*nent, n. That which belongs to something else; an appurtenant. [Obs.] Shak.
Ap*pete" (AMP?;), v. t. [L. appetere: cf. F. appAMPeacute;ter. See Appetite.] To seek for; to desire. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Ap"pe*ten*cy (AMP?;), n.; pl. Appetencies (AMP?;). [L. appetentia, fr. appetere to strive after, long for. See Appetite.] 1. Fixed and strong desire; esp. natural desire; a craving; an eager appetite.

p.blockquote:
They had a strong appetency for reading.
Merivale.

p.def: Specifically: An instinctive inclination or propensity in animals to perform certain actions, as in the young to suck, in aquatic fowls to enter into water and to swim; the tendency of an organized body to seek what satisfies the wants of its organism.

p.blockquote:
These lacteals have mouths, and by animal selection or appetency the absorb such part of the fluid as is agreeable to their palate.
E. Darwin.

p.def: Natural tendency; affinity; attraction; -- used of inanimate objects.

dictionary.p: Ap"pe*tent (AMP?;), a. [L. appetens, p. pr. of appetere.] Desiring; eagerly desirous. [R.]

p.blockquote:
Appetent after glory and renown.
Sir G. Buck.

dictionary.p: Ap`pe*ti*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. [Cf. F. appAMPeacute;tibilitAMPeacute;.] The quality of being desirable. Bramhall.
Ap"pe*ti*ble (AMP?;), a. [L. appetibilis, fr. appetere: cf. F. appAMPeacute;tible.] Desirable; capable or worthy of being the object of desire. Bramhall.

Ap"pe*tite (AMP?;), n. [OE. appetit, F. appAMPeacute;tit, fr. L. appetitus, fr. appetere to strive after, long for; ad + petere to seek. See Petition, and cf. Appetence.] 1. The desire for some personal gratification, either of the body or of the mind.

p.blockquote:
The object of appetite it whatsoever sensible good may be wished for; the object of will is that good which reason does lead us to seek.
Hooker.

p.def: Desire for, or relish of, food or drink; hunger.

p.blockquote:
Men must have appetite before they will eat.
Buckle.

p.def: Any strong desire; an eagerness or longing.

p.blockquote:
It God had given to eagles an appetite to swim.
Jer. Taylor.

To gratify the vulgar appetite for the marvelous.
Macaulay.

dictionary.p: 4. Tendency; appetency. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
In all bodies there as an appetite of union.
Bacon.

dictionary.p: 5. The thing desired. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
Power being the natural appetite of princes.
Swift.

dictionary.p: AMPfist; In old authors, appetite is followed by to or of, but regularly it should be followed by for before the object; as, an appetite for pleasure.
Syn. -- Craving; longing; desire; appetency; passion.
Ap`pe*ti"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. appetitio: cf. F. appAMPeacute;tition.] Desire; a longing for, or seeking after, something. Holland.
Ap"pe*ti"tive (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. appAMPeacute;titif.] Having the quality of desiring gratification; as, appetitive power or faculty. Sir M. Hale.
Ap"pe*tize (AMP?;), v. t. To make hungry; to whet the appetite of. Sir W. Scott.
Ap"pe*ti`zer (AMP?;), n. Something which creates or whets an appetite.
Ap"pe*ti`zing (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. appAMPeacute;tissant.] Exciting appetite; as, appetizing food.

p.blockquote:
The appearance of the wild ducks is very appetizing.
Sir W. Scott.

dictionary.p: Ap"pe*ti`zing, adv. So as to excite appetite.
Ap"pi*an (AMP?;), a. [L. Appius, Appianus.] Of or pertaining to Appius.
Appian Way, the great paved highway from ancient Rome trough Capua to Brundisium, now Brindisi, constructed partly by Appius Claudius, about 312 b. c.

Ap*plaud" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Applauded; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Applauding.] [L. applaudere; ad + plaudere to clash, to clap the hands: cf. F. applaudir. Cf. Explode.] 1. To show approval of by clapping the hands, acclamation, or other significant sign.

p.blockquote:
I would applaud thee to the very echo,
That should applaud again.
Shak.

p.def: To praise by words; to express approbation of; to commend; to approve.

p.blockquote:
By the gods, I do applaud his courage.
Shak.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- To praise; extol; commend; cry up; magnify; approve. See Praise.
Ap*plaud", v. i. To express approbation loudly or significantly.
Ap*plaud"er (AMP?;), n. One who applauds.
Ap*plaus"a*ble (AMP?;), a. Worthy of applause; praiseworthy. [Obs.]

Ap*plause" (AMP?;), n. [L. applaudere, applausum. See Applaud.] The act of applauding; approbation and praise publicly expressed by clapping the hands, stamping or tapping with the feet, acclamation, huzzas, or other means; marked commendation.

p.blockquote:
The brave man seeks not popular applause.
Dryden.

dictionary.p: Syn. -- Acclaim; acclamation; plaudit; commendation; approval.
Ap*plau"sive (AMP?;), a. [LL. applausivus.] Expressing applause; approbative. -- Ap*plau"sive*ly, adv.

Ap"ple (AMPabreve;p"p'l), n. [OE. appel, eppel, AS. AMPaelig;ppel, AMPaelig;pl; akin to Fries. AMP D. appel, OHG, aphul, aphol, G. apfel, Icel. epli, Sw. AMPauml;ple, Dan. AMPaelig;ble, Gael. ubhall, W. afal, Arm. aval, Lith. obAMPuring;lys, Russ. iabloko; of unknown origin.] 1. The fleshy pome or fruit of a rosaceous tree (Pyrus malus) cultivated in numberless varieties in the temperate zones.
AMPfist; The European crab apple is supposed to be the original kind, from which all others have sprung.

p.def: Any tree genus Pyrus which has the stalk sunken into the base of the fruit; an apple tree.
Any fruit or other vegetable production resembling, or supposed to resemble, the apple; as, apple of love, or love apple (a tomato), balsam apple, egg apple, oak apple.
Anything round like an apple; as, an apple of gold.

dictionary.p: Apple is used either adjectively or in combination; as, apple paper or apple-paper, apple-shaped, apple blossom, apple dumpling, apple pudding.

Apple blight, an aphid which injures apple trees. See Blight, n. -- Apple borer (ZoAMPouml;l.), a coleopterous insect (Saperda candida or bivittata), the larva of which bores into the trunk of the apple tree and pear tree. -- Apple brandy, brandy made from apples. -- Apple butter, a sauce made of apples stewed down in cider. Bartlett. -- Apple corer, an instrument for removing the cores from apples. -- Apple fly (ZoAMPouml;l.), any dipterous insect, the larva of which burrows in apples. Apple flies belong to the genera Drosophila and Trypeta. -- Apple midge (ZoAMPouml;l.) a small dipterous insect (Sciara mali), the larva of which bores in apples. -- Apple of the eye, the pupil. -- Apple of discord, a subject of contention and envy, so called from the mythological golden apple, inscribed "For the fairest," which was thrown into an assembly of the gods by Eris, the goddess of discord. It was contended for by Juno, Minerva, and Venus, and was adjudged to the latter. -- Apple of love, or Love apple, the tomato (Lycopersicum esculentum). -- Apple of Peru, a large coarse herb (Nicandra physaloides) bearing pale blue flowers, and a bladderlike fruit inclosing a dry berry. -- Apples of Sodom, a fruit described by ancient writers as externally of fair appearance but dissolving into smoke and ashes when plucked; Dead Sea apples. The name is often given to the fruit of Solanum SodomAMPaelig;um, a prickly shrub with fruit not unlike a small yellow tomato. -- Apple sauce, stewed apples. [U. S.] -- Apple snail or Apple shell (ZoAMPouml;l.), a fresh-water, operculated, spiral shell of the genus Ampullaria. -- Apple tart, a tart containing apples. -- Apple tree, a tree which naturally bears apples. See Apple, 2. -- Apple wine, cider. -- Apple worm (ZoAMPouml;l.), the larva of a small moth (Carpocapsa pomonella) which burrows in the interior of apples. See Codling moth. -- Dead Sea Apple. (a) pl. Apples of Sodom. Also Fig. "To seek the Dead Sea apples of politics." S. B. Griffin. (b) A kind of gallnut coming from Arabia. See Gallnut.
Ap"ple (AMPabreve;p"p'l), v. i. To grow like an apple; to bear apples. Holland.
Ap"ple-faced` (AMP?;), a. Having a round, broad face, like an apple. "Apple-faced children." Dickens.
Ap"ple-jack` (AMP?;), n. Apple brandy. [U.S.]
Ap"ple-john`, n.. A kind of apple which by keeping becomes much withered; -- called also Johnapple. Shak.
Ap"ple pie` (AMP?;). A pie made of apples (usually sliced or stewed) with spice and sugar.

Apple-pie bed, a bed in which, as a joke, the sheets are so doubled (like the cover of an apple turnover) as to prevent any one from getting at his length between them. Halliwell Conybeare. -- Apple-pie order, perfect order or arrangement. [Colloq.] Halliwell.
Ap"ple-squire` (AMP?;), n. A pimp; a kept gallant. [Obs.] Beau. AMP Fl.
Ap*pli"a*ble (AMP?;), a. [See Apply.] Applicable; also, compliant. [Obs.] Howell.
Ap*pli"ance (AMP?;), n. 1. The act of applying; application; [Obs.] subservience. Shak.
Ap`pli*ca*bil"i*ty (AMP?;), n. The quality of being applicable or fit to be applied.

Ap"pli*ca*ble (AMP?;), a. [Cf. F. aplicable, fr. L. applicare. See Apply.] Capable of being applied; fit or suitable to be applied; having relevance; as, this observation is applicable to the case under consideration. -- Ap"pli*ca*ble*ness, n. -- Ap"pli*ca*bly, adv.
Ap"pli*can*cy (AMP?;), n. The quality or state of being applicable. [R.]
Ap"pli*cant (AMP?;), n. [L. applicans, p. pr. of applicare. See Apply.] One who apples for something; one who makes request; a petitioner.

p.blockquote:
The applicant for a cup of water.
Plumtre.

The court require the applicant to appear in person.
Z. Swift.

dictionary.p: Ap"pli*cate (AMP?;), a. [L. applicatus, p. p. of applicare. See Apply.] Applied or put to some use.

p.blockquote:
Those applicate sciences which extend the power of man over the elements.
I. Taylor.

dictionary.p: Applicate number (Math.), one which applied to some concrete case. -- Applicate ordinate, right line applied at right angles to the axis of any conic section, and bounded by the curve.
Ap"pli*cate (AMP?;), v. i. To apply. [Obs.]

p.blockquote:
The act of faith is applicated to the object.
Bp. Pearson.

dictionary.p: Ap`pli*ca"tion (AMP?;), n. [L. applicatio, fr. applicare: cf. F. application. See Apply.] 1. The act of applying or laying on, in a literal sense; as, the application of emollients to a diseased limb.

p.def: The thing applied.

p.blockquote:
He invented a new application by which blood might be stanched.
Johnson.

p.def: The act of applying as a means; the employment of means to accomplish an end; specific use.

p.blockquote:
If a right course . . . be taken with children, there will not be much need of the application of the common rewards and punishments.
Locke.

p.def: The act of directing or referring something to a particular case, to discover or illustrate agreement or disagreement, fitness, or correspondence; as, I make the remark, and leave you to make the application; the application of a theory.

Hence, in specific uses: (a) That part of a sermon or discourse in which the principles before laid down and illustrated are applied to practical uses; the "moral" of a fable. (b) The use of the principles of one science for the purpose of enlarging or perfecting another; as, the application of algebra to geometry.
The capacity of being practically applied or used; relevancy; as, a rule of general application.
The act of fixing the mind or closely applying one's self; assiduous effort; close attention; as, to injure the health by application to study.

p.blockquote:
Had his application been equal to his talents, his progress might have been greater.
J. Jay.

p.def: The act of making request of soliciting; as, an application for an office; he made application to a court of chancery.
A request; a document containing a request; as, his application was placed on file.

dictionary.p: Ap"pli*ca*tive (AMPabreve;p"plAMPibreve;*kAMPasl;*tAMPibreve;v), a. [Cf. F. applicatif, fr. L. applicare. See Apply.] Capable of being applied or used; applying; applicatory; practical. Bramhall. -- Ap"pli*ca*tive*ly, adv.
Ap"pli*ca*to*ri*ly (AMP?;), adv. By way of application.
Ap"pli*ca*to*ry, a. Having the property of applying; applicative; practical. -- n. That which applies.
Ap*pli"ed*ly (AMP?;), adv. By application. [R.]
Ap*pli"er (AMP?;), n. He who, or that which, applies.
Ap*pli"ment (AMP?;), n. Application. [Obs.] Marston

||Ap`pli`quAMPeacute;" (?; 277), a. [F., fr. appliquer to put on.] Ornamented with a pattern (which has been cut out of another color or stuff) applied or transferred to a foundation; as, appliquAMPeacute; lace; appliquAMPeacute; work.
Ap*plot" (AMP?;), v. t. [imp. AMP p. p. Applotted; p. pr. AMP vb. n. Applotting.] [Pref. ad- + plot.] To divide into plots or parts; to apportion. Milton.
